headline: Politics and a Ruptured Tendon Don’t Faze Lead Iran Negotiator
abstract: The focus of Wendy Sherman over the past two years helped prepare the ground for talks with Iran that gained momentum, both in public and through a secret channel.

She packed it in ice, went to a secure room, and continued her briefing on uranium enrichment levels and current intelligence about the intentions of America’s longtime adversary. Only then did she head to the emergency room.

headline: Inflationistas at Bayes
abstract: Wrong predictions matter.
lead_paragraph: I’m putting together a syllabus for one of the courses I’ll be teaching this spring – Econ 348, The Great Recession – and in the course of searching for various views about inflation, ended up looking at a dispute from a while back involving some of the usual suspects. Brad DeLong poked fun at John Cochrane for having declared, back in 2009, that “the danger now is inflation.” Cochrane angrily denied that this was of any significance – he only said that it was a danger, he didn’t necessarily predict that it would happen within any particular time frame. (He thereby provided a demonstration of another key fact about our economic debate: nobody ever admits that they were wrong about anything, and nobody changes views in the light of evidence.) Noah Smith, characteristically, tried to find some extenuating circumstances. Etc., etc.

headline: The High Times, and the Hard Ones, of a Gritty Musical Outlaw
abstract: Robert Hilburn’s new biography of the Man in Black, Johnny Cash, dissects his troubles and his broad popularity.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Cash’s life was a country song full of love and loss, passion and heartbreak — grief, loneliness, guilt, faith, melodrama and striving for redemption. His rough childhood and youth, and turbulent struggles with addiction and family tumult, gave him empathy for sinners in search of salvation and all those who had done hard time or known hard times. His plain-spoken writing and gritty, soul-deep singing transcended musical genres and gave voice to ordinary Americans’ experience of adversity. He was that rare outlaw beloved by soldiers and student protesters alike, by rock ’n’ rollers, convicts and devotees of Billy Graham’s crusades.

headline: In Three Symphonies, the Demands of Mozart

headline: Rest in Peace, Elwood, ‘World’s Ugliest Dog’
abstract: A mixed breed dog named Elwood, who was named the “World’s Ugliest Dog” in 2007 and inspired his owner to write a children’s book about self-acceptance, has died, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: A mixed breed dog named Elwood (below), who was named the “World’s Ugliest Dog” in 2007 and inspired his owner to write a children’s book about self-acceptance, has died, The Associated Press reported. He was 8 years old. Karen Quigley, 52, of Sewell, N.J., adopted Elwood, a dark-colored, nearly hairless Chinese crested and Chihuahua mix, after a breeder decided that he was too ugly to sell and would euthanize him. His odd appearance, which included heavy eyelids, a protruded tongue that hung out the side of his mouth and a white tuft of hair on his head, was a hit at the Sonoma-Marin County Fair in California, where the ugly dog contest is held. The experience motivated Ms. Quigley to write and self-publish a children’s book that promoted acceptance called “Everybody Loves Elwood.” The dog later developed an online following, being referred to as Yoda or E.T. by his fans. Elwood appeared at more than 200 events to help raise money for animal rescue groups and nonprofit animal organizations.

headline: Born of Grief, ‘Three Strikes’ Laws Are Being Rethought

Intended to lock up the most violent repeat offenders for 25 years to life, the law was almost immediately embroiled in controversy. keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: New co-presidents at the Association of Independent Creative Editors and a spate of promotions at the Meredith Corporation.
lead_paragraph: Zack Ashley joined Factory 360, New York, in a new post, chief marketing officer. He had been head of marketing and communications at Addiction Worldwide, New York.

headline: Q. and A. with Stuart Elliott
abstract: Dangerous advertising stunts and Jake the State Farm agent.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Michael Tilson Thomas to Fill In for Philadelphia Orchestra Conductor
abstract: A severe sinus condition has sidelined the conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Philadelphia Orchestra announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A severe sinus condition has sidelined the conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Philadelphia Orchestra announced on Monday, but created an opportunity for New Yorkers to hear an unusual pairing of conductor and orchestra. Michael Tilson Thomas, the music director of the San Francisco Symphony, will fill in for Mr. Nézet-Séguin, in Philadelphia on Dec. 5, 7 and 8 and at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 6. Mr. Thomas made his subscription debut in Philadelphia only in 2008 (though he led the orchestra in summer concerts as far back as 1971), and returned in 2011. But he has never been heard with the Philadelphians in New York.

headline: The Read Around: Carla Kaplan
abstract: Carla Kaplan says being a white woman in the field of black studies helped her sympathize with the women in her new book, “Miss Anne in Harlem.”
lead_paragraph: Carla Kaplan says being a white woman in the field of black studies helped her sympathize with the women in her new book, “Miss Anne in Harlem.”

headline: The G.O.P.’s Racism Tweet
abstract: The Republican National Committee got in trouble for suggesting that Rosa Parks had “ended” racism.
lead_paragraph: It took three-and-a-half hours for the Republican National Committee to amend a tweet.

headline: The Modern-Day Melting Pot of Tangier
abstract: With a proliferation of new cafes, four-star hotels and boutiques, not to mention a worldly set of residents, the diverse Moroccan city is poised to become a major resort destination.

headline: Yanks Trade a Catcher to the Pirates
abstract: Chris Stewart, who became expendable once the Yankees signed Brian McCann to a five-year deal, will presumably back up the former Yankee Russell Martin in Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: Chris Stewart had a unique feeling in April. It was the first time he had begun a second consecutive season with the same team, working with the same pitching staff and following the instructions from the same manager and coaches. It was a good feeling, he said, but it turned out to be fleeting.

headline: Canadian Opera Commissions New Work From Rufus Wainwright
abstract: The Canadian Opera Company in Toronto has commissioned Mr. Wainwright’s second opera, “Hadrian.”
lead_paragraph: Rufus Wainwright’s experience in the opera world may have seemed bruising to an observer. His first opera, “Prima Donna,” was commissioned by the Metropolitan Opera and Lincoln Center, but the Met withdrew when Mr. Wainwright insisted on writing in French instead of English; and though it was performed around the world, and by the New York City Opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was beat upon by critics for the thinness of its plot.

headline: Words That Wound
abstract: More than one-third of older adults reported some form of verbal abuse from family members and paid helpers in a recent study.
lead_paragraph: People may feel ashamed or afraid to talk about abuse, including the verbal kind, so the researchers from Northeastern University asked their older subjects to respond to questions by touching a computer screen. It gave them more privacy.

headline: The Read Around: Carla Kaplan
abstract: Ms. Kaplan says being a white woman in the field of black studies helped her sympathize with the women in her new book, “Miss Anne in Harlem.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, Carla Kaplan, the author of “Miss Anne in Harlem: The White Women of the Black Renaissance,” talks about her research habits, why this project took longer to write than she expected, and how being a white woman in the field of black studies helped her sympathize with the people in her book.

headline: Economists Are Different From You and Me
abstract: The general public may think preventing inflation should be a priority, but many economists disagree, and a new paper is the latest evidence.
lead_paragraph: The newly minted Nobel laureate Robert Shiller reported in a 1997 paper, based on polling data, that economists worry much less about inflation than does the general public. The poll asked, for example, whether “preventing high inflation is an important national priority, as important as preventing drug abuse or preventing deterioration in the quality of our schools.” Eighty-four percent of Americans agreed but, among economists, only 46 percent agreed.

headline: Image Mysteries and Flatiron Glow Sticks
keywords: ['Art', 'Theater', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Physics', 'Flatiron Building (NYC)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A Penn and Teller film documents a quest to find out whether the Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer had help from an optical device. And a Manhattan event involves the Flatiron Building, hundreds of volunteers and glow sticks.
lead_paragraph: December events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Sugary Drinks Tied to Endometrial Cancer Risk
abstract: A new study has found that drinking sugar-sweetened beverages is associated with an increased risk for endometrial cancer.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that drinking sugar-sweetened beverages is associated with an increased risk for endometrial cancer in postmenopausal women.

headline: Where Last Season’s Winners Are Still Being Celebrated
abstract: The Casting Society of America doesn’t hand out its annual awards till months after the Oscars. That’s how “Argo” and “Silver Linings Playbook” came to pick up more honors last month.
lead_paragraph: Campaigns for the 2014 Oscars may have officially kicked off this week, but not everyone is finished discussing the merits of “Argo,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and other contenders from the last awards season.

headline: Biden Faces a Delicate Two-Step in Asia
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. must reassure Japan of American support while confronting China on its imposition of an air defense zone over disputed islands.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — With Japan locked in a tense standoff with China over disputed airspace, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived here late Monday for a weeklong visit to Asia intended to reassure a close ally and demand answers from a potential adversary.

headline: Sam Champion Leaves ‘Good Morning America’ for Weather Channel
abstract: Sam Champion, the weather anchor on TV’s top-rated morning show, will be the host of an upgraded morning program on the all-weather, all-the-time Weather Channel.
lead_paragraph: The leading morning team in television is losing an important contributor with the announcement on Monday that Sam Champion would leave his post as the weather anchor for ABC’s “Good Morning America” to join the Weather Channel.

headline: Parliament in Somalia Votes to Remove Prime Minister
abstract: A “constitutional dispute” between President Hassan Sheik Mohamud and Prime Minister Abdi Farah Shirdon resulted in a no-confidence vote.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somalia’s Parliament voted the prime minister out of office on Monday in a no-confidence motion, with 184 of 249 lawmakers in favor, after what was termed a “constitutional dispute” between the president and the prime minister, Somali officials said.

headline: Amazon’s Blue-Sky Thinking
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Drone deliveries seem as overly optimistic as investors’ expectations of Amazon overall, the author notes. The company’s market value has ballooned to $180 billion, despite big profits always hovering in the future.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is promising yet more jam tomorrow – this time from drone deliveries.

headline: After Renting Out a Terrace, He Received an Eviction Notice
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Cooperatives', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The case of David Shea, who is facing eviction from his affordable housing development, is another battle in the fight over whether New Yorkers should be permitted to rent out their spare space.
lead_paragraph: David Shea, a retired typographer, thought that he was renting out his large enclosed terrace to a visitor from Miami who was looking for a cheap place to stay for a few days in Manhattan. The man had contacted him through Roomorama.com, one of several websites that connect travelers with private hosts.

headline: Nets and Knicks Share Woes and, This Week, a Floor
abstract: Thursday’s Knicks-Nets matchup, part of a TNT doubleheader, was supposed to be a preview of the playoffs, not a rebuff of the strategy of trying to win with aging, overpriced players.
lead_paragraph: Thursday is the one day of the week when the N.B.A.’s frantic nationwide schedule slows and all eyes turn to a doubleheader showcase on TNT. When the league scheduled this week’s matchup between the Nets and the Knicks, the first of their four meetings this season, it probably expected a game of far more consequence than a meeting of two of the three worst teams in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Healing Soldiers’ Most Exposed Wounds
keywords: ['Surgery and Surgeons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Face']
abstract: Col. Robert G. Hale, commander of the Army’s dental and trauma research detachment, has helped develop new ways to heal the facial wounds of troops returning from combat overseas.
lead_paragraph: Col. Robert G. Hale fixes faces.

headline: What to Expect at the Gothams
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Gotham Independent Film Awards']
abstract: The New York awards kick off awards season, and Oscar observers will be watching to see how “12 Years a Slave,” “Before Midnight” and ” Inside Llewyn Davis” fare.
lead_paragraph: The traditional starter’s pistol for the glitzy season in New York is the Gotham Independent Film Awards, taking place tonight at Cipriani Wall Street, with the the comedian Nick Kroll (of “Kroll Show” on Comedy Central), an old Bagger pal, serving as host. Like its West Coast cousin, the Film Independent Spirit Awards, the Gothams are more of a D.I.Y. affair, full of jokes about tight budgets, short shooting schedules and other difficulties of indie filmmaking, an apparently thankless task that nonetheless inspires devotion in the room.

headline: The Great Los Angeles Auto Show Fire of 1929
abstract: The show, which wrapped up on Sunday, has once again gone off without a problem. Things were different in 1929.
lead_paragraph: Sunday brought about the end of another chapter in the history of the Los Angeles Auto Show, an event that, aside from 1940 to 1951, has showed off new cars since 1907. This year in the hallway between the two cavernous rooms glinting with new automobiles, there was a long display about the history of the show, bringing to light a bit of trivia.

headline: French Court Orders Criminal Trial for EADS Shareholders
abstract: Daimler and Lagardère, along with a group of EADS executives, are accused of having known of manufacturing problems with the Airbus A380 jet when they sold shares in 2006.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Monday ordered the German carmaker Daimler and the French media conglomerate Lagardère to face a criminal trial on allegations of insider trading in the 2006 sale of shares in the European aerospace and defense group EADS.

headline: T HOLIDAY
abstract: For the Italian fabric designer Idarica Gazzoni, every surface is a blank canvas until she embellishes it with her whimsical patterns.
lead_paragraph: For the Italian fabric designer Idarica Gazzoni, every surface is a blank canvas until she embellishes it with her whimsical patterns.

headline: Rights Group Is Seeking Status of ‘Legal Person’ for Captive Chimpanzee
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Nonhuman Rights Project is using the novel strategy in seeking to have the chimp removed from his owners and placed in a sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Chimpanzees are not people, no matter how they are dressed up for commercials, but perhaps they are close enough that they deserve some of the same rights humans have.

headline: Reality Checks on Tumorous Rats and Methane Bombs
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Cancer', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A look back at tumorous rats and the GMO fight, radioactive tuna and Arctic methane.
lead_paragraph: This is a quick roundup of developments and resources illustrating how the most dramatic “front-page thought” or activist talking point is always worth examining from the root up. Or, as Carl Sagan liked to say, “Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.”

headline: In Thailand, a Drone’s Eye View of Protests
abstract: For the first time, widespread use of the tiny devices give an aerial perspective on Thailand’s deep civil unrest.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s news media outlets have been increasingly using small, unmanned flying gadgets that give them a bird’s-eye view of the protests in the streets of their capital. As my colleague Thomas Fuller writes, the miniature drones have circulated videos of the battles, including one between riot police outside the prime minister’s office and protesters attacking the barricades.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Visual Editions’ ‘Where You Are’
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a book of maps designed to get you delightfully lost.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: The Gun Report: Thanksgiving Weekend Edition
abstract: A holiday weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Alexander, the Florida woman who unsuccessfully argued last year that the state’s Stand Your Ground law made her immune from prosecution after she fired a bullet into a wall in her home to scare off her abusive husband, has been released from prison as she awaits a new trial. Though no one was hurt, she received a 20-year prison sentence. Alexander had argued that she fired a warning shot from a legally licensed gun to defend herself from a beating at the hands of her estranged husband, a man who had testified to abusing her in the past.

headline: Immaculate Stability (Wonkish)
abstract: Remember, it’s about people.
lead_paragraph: David Andolfatto, understandably, rises to Steve Williamson’s defense against the barbarians. But I’m sorry to say that he still doesn’t get the point.

headline: In Surprise Win, Laure Prouvost Takes Turner Prize
abstract: The artist Laure Prouvost, who was born in France but has lived in London since she was 18, won the award given to a British artist under 50.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The artist Laure Prouvost, whose works combine whimsical objects and drawings in evocative settings with an Instagram-like stream of film images, has won this year’s Turner Prize, the prestigious and often contentious annual award for a British artist under 50.

headline: Brussels to Investigate Deal for British Nuclear Plant
abstract: A full inquiry into a deal to build Britain’s first nuclear power station since 1995 threatens delays that could undermine investment plans for the project.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European regulators said on Monday that they expected to conduct a full inquiry into a deal to build Britain’s first nuclear power station since 1995, threatening delays that could undermine investment plans for the 16 billion pound project.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 26-Dec. 2, 2013
abstract: Answer these 10 questions to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: New Strides in Spaying and Neutering
abstract: Nonsurgical sterilization treatments for dogs and cats are emerging that could reduce or even eliminate the need for traditional neutering.
lead_paragraph: Todd Bruce, a herd manager on a farm in Oregon City, Ore., had long resisted neutering his 5-year-old Australian cattle dog, Cody, for fear of losing the extra set (or two) of legs in the field.

headline: A First Report Card Fails to ‘Exceed Expectations’
abstract: My son’s kindergarten report card brought out the worst in me.
lead_paragraph: Don’t compare yourself to others. Let go of striving and accept the world as it is, not as you’d like it to be. Practice humility and gratitude. Forty-three years, and this is the Buddhist wisdom I’ve learned to embrace, the foundation on which my inner peace rests. Until I got my son’s first report card.

headline: Rare Biblical Texts From Bodleian and Vatican Libraries Digitized
abstract: The site with rare Biblical texts went live on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A Gutenberg Bible, a dazzlingly illuminated 15th-century Hebrew Bible from Spain and a copy of Maimonides’s 12th-century commentary on the Mishnah written in the philosopher’s own hand are among the rare bibles and biblical commentaries from the Vatican Library and the Bodleian Libraries at Oxford that have been digitized and posted online, as part of a collaboration between the institutions that went live on Tuesday.

headline: As Lundqvist Sits Again, a Hot Hand Turns Cool
abstract: Cam Talbot, who started over a healthy Henrik Lundqvist, allowed four goals in 29 shots against Winnipeg and saw his record fall to 6-2.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers’ goaltender controversy ended almost as quickly as it began. On Monday morning, Coach Alain Vigneault surprisingly named the first-year sensation Cam Talbot to start against the Winnipeg Jets on Monday night at Madison Square Garden. The decision meant a healthy Henrik Lundqvist would sit out a second straight game — which had not happened since February 2011.

headline: Liberal Catholics in the Age of Francis
abstract: What should the church’s liberal wing hope for from the new pontificate?
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column discussed what Catholics on the political right should make of Pope Francis’s latest exhortation, and how they should respond to a papacy that has been emphasizing the church’s social teaching in language that Catholics with free-market views might not necessarily be eager to embrace. The other, equally-interesting question, of course is how Catholics of a more liberal persuasion (politically and theologically) should respond to Francis — or, perhaps more aptly, what they should be looking for, hoping for, and working toward in a pontificate whose tone they mostly find congenial, but whose substance has included reaffirmations of Catholic teaching on some of the culture-war issues dividing left and right.

headline: Justice Department Approves Microsoft Deal
abstract: Microsoft said it was pleased to receive the approval and it looked “forward to the date when our partners at Nokia will become members of the Microsoft family.”
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft got closer on Monday to completing the most significant deal in the company’s history, its $7.2 billion acquisition of Nokia’s mobile handset and services business.

headline: Robots and Property Values
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Delivery Services', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Driverless cars and delivery drones are likely to increase property values in big cities as such innovations are aimed at urban areas and make living there more efficient, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Searching for Answers After a Fatal Train Accident
abstract: The derailment was the deadliest in New York City in more than two decades, killing four and leaving dozens injured.
lead_paragraph: The derailment was the deadliest in New York City in more than two decades, killing four and leaving dozens injured.

headline: Video of Police Brutality in Kiev Fuels Rage
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Protesters and local journalists in Kiev documented a tumultuous weekend in the Ukrainian capital in online video.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Tuesday, 7:22 p.m. | As my colleague David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, thousands of opposition protesters demanding the resignation of the Ukrainian government continued to occupy Independence Square in the capital on Monday, two days after images of the police battering demonstrators there backfired on the authorities, swelling the street protests.

headline: Justices Pass on Tax Case From Online Merchants
abstract: The United States Supreme Court will let stand a decision that the companies must collect sales taxes despite the lack of a physical presence in the state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Supreme Court on Monday let stand a ruling from New York’s highest court requiring Internet retailers to collect sales taxes even if they have no physical presence in the state.

headline: A Head for Hunting
abstract: They may be slow, but seahorses can snatch fast prey because of the unusual shape of their heads.
lead_paragraph: They may be slow, but seahorses can snatch fast prey because of the unusual shape of their heads. Using a microscope outfitted with a laser and high-speed digital camera, researchers from the University of Texas at Austin observed that the area around a dwarf seahorse’s nostrils created a “no-wake zone” in front of its mouth, allowing the animal to sneak up on tiny crustaceans.

headline: Amazon Prime Air
abstract: Amazon released a video touting its Prime Air delivery service, which makes the use of drones.
lead_paragraph: Amazon released a video touting its Prime Air delivery service, which makes the use of drones.

headline: Emotion Has Its Place in Financial Planning
abstract: Spreadsheets can’t account for the intangibles that often need to have a place in our decision-making.
lead_paragraph: How many spreadsheets do you have on your computer? I bet a lot of you have at least one or two. There’s probably a budget spreadsheet showing how much you’ve spent, or one where you’ve worked out how much you’ll need in the future. Maybe you even use some budgeting software. Who knew it was so much fun lining up a bunch of numbers?

headline: Learning to Defuse the Aorta
keywords: ['Marfan Syndrome', 'Blood Pressure', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Children and Childhood', 'Series', 'Heart']
abstract: The long search for a gene mutation has led to a chance of stopping Marfan syndrome and reducing the risk of a fatal burst before it happens.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Hal Dietz arrived at Johns Hopkins University in the 1980s, he became obsessed with helping children with Marfan syndrome, a rare and often fatal disorder that can cause the aorta, the large blood vessel that carries blood from the heart, to grow and grow until it bursts.

headline: Accountant for Princeton Troupe Accused of Embezzling
abstract: Thomas J. Muza, the former accountant for Princeton’s Triangle Club, surrendered to authorities last week on charges of second-degree theft.
lead_paragraph: The longtime accountant for Princeton University’s legendary touring musical-comedy troupe, the Triangle Club, has been charged with embezzling more than $100,000 from the club.

headline: Oxytocin Found to Stimulate Social Brain Regions in Children With Autism
abstract: The results of a small study of children with mild autism given oxytocin suggests that their brains’ social regions are not irrevocably damaged.
lead_paragraph: The hormone oxytocin has been generating excitement — and caution — among people who care about autism.

headline: Bolshoi Music Director Resigns
abstract: Vassily Sinaisky, the musical director and top conductor for Moscow’s Bolshoi Theater, unexpectedly resigned on Monday.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The music director and top conductor for the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow unexpectedly resigned on Monday, threatening a premiere of Verdi’s “Don Carlos” later this month and undermining efforts the Bolshoi’s leadership to return a stable image to the iconic theater after a year marred by scandal.

headline: In Communal Living, Intimacy’s Logistics
abstract: History has shown that privacy for intimate encounters required a liberal view of what that meant or a little creativity.
lead_paragraph: Q. How did primitive peoples, like Native Americans who lived in long houses with 20 families, get enough privacy for intimacy and intercourse?

headline: American Brass Quintet Makes Sure It Doesn’t Shrink to a Trio
abstract: A new trumpeter and horn player are replacing two members.
lead_paragraph: Among North American brass ensembles none is more venerable than the American Brass Quintet, which was founded in 1960 and has been a resident ensemble at the Aspen Music Festival since 1970, and at the Juilliard School since 1987. But rosters change, and the retirement of the trumpeter Raymond Mase and the hornist David Wakefield has created two openings in the quintet in quick succession.

headline: Men at Work for Women in Labor
abstract: Doulas are trained to help new mothers cope with the rigors of childbirth, but very, very few of them are men.
lead_paragraph: Doulas are trained to help new mothers cope with the rigors of childbirth. The very origins of the word — in Greek, “doula” means “a woman who serves” — seem to settle the question of gender. Doulas are women.

headline: In Performance: Peter Bradbury
abstract: Peter Bradbury in a scene from Patrick Barlow’s adaptation of Charles Dickens’s “Christmas Carol,” at the Theater at St. Clement’s.
lead_paragraph: Peter Bradbury in a scene from Patrick Barlow’s adaptation of Charles Dickens’s “Christmas Carol,” at the Theater at St. Clement’s.

headline: Walkabout: Mishaps in Pet Travel; Cyber Monday Travel Deals
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:58 a.m. | Not every pet travel story ends happily. One woman reports that her dog was diagnosed with heat stroke, a urinary tract infection and liver problems, following a United flight from Houston to Boston. (NBC Washington)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Thailand, Ukraine, Syria and Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Thailand, Ukraine, Syria and Gaza.

headline: Uncertainty Comes Fast for Redskins’ Sure Thing
abstract: Less than a year after quarterback Robert Griffin III ended his stellar rookie season with a severe knee injury and a playoff loss, he is at a crossroads in his career.
lead_paragraph: LANDOVER, Md. — Antonio Smith Jr. works a merchandise stand at FedEx Field during Washington Redskins games, so he does not get to watch Robert Griffin III play every week. But he has a pretty good feel for how Griffin’s season is going.

headline: Chinese Leader’s Rise Came With New Attention to Dispute With Japan
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China appears to have approved the new air defense zone devised to weaken Japan’s grip on disputed islands in the East China Sea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The new air defense zone declared by China appears to have been approved by President Xi Jinping, the culmination of more than a year of pressure by Beijing to weaken Japan’s grip on disputed islands in the East China Sea, and by extension to expand China’s long-term access to the Western Pacific.

headline: Top U.N. Rights Official Links Assad to Crimes in Syria
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The assertion by Navi Pillay, the high commissioner for human rights, about President Bashar al-Assad was based on what she called information amassed by her panel of investigators.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The top United Nations human rights official linked President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to war crimes and crimes against humanity for the first time on Monday, citing evidence collected by her panel of investigators over the course of the 33-month-old conflict in that country.

headline: Building a Cheaper Catalyst
abstract: For years, scientists have tried to coax important chemical reactions out of nonprecious metals. Three different teams of researchers have pulled it off.
lead_paragraph: The chemical reactions that help produce margarine, medications, cleaner car exhaust and countless other useful things rely on valuable metals like platinum, rhodium and ruthenium as catalysts. But such metals are rare, expensive and occasionally toxic. For years, scientists have tried to develop methods of catalysis using cheap, common, nonpolluting metals like iron and cobalt.

headline: Gunmen Attack Offices of Pakistani Media Group in Karachi
abstract: Nobody has claimed responsibility for the attack, the second in recent months, on the Express Media Group, but suspicion fell on the Pakistani Taliban.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Unidentified gunmen opened fire on the office of a leading news media group in Karachi on Monday evening, wounding a security guard and underscoring the threats journalists face in the country.

headline: Five Wine Books Worth Noting
abstract: These books stand out amid a flood of interesting writing on wine.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a boon literary year for wine lovers. The flow of noteworthy books has been so steady that some seminal works can get lost in the current, like a 25th anniversary edition of “Adventures on the Wine Route,” Kermit Lynch’s prophetic look back at the wisdom and traditions discarded by the mid-20th-century wine industry, presaging a welcome rediscovery and new embrace.

headline: Salesforce Picks Second Winner for Criticized Hackathon
abstract: Salesforce.com said its $1 million prize for a recent contest for outside developers was a record, but following an outcry about how the contest was run, it has decided to give the top two companies $1 million each. Salesforce didn’t really acknowledge fault, but says it could have done a better job.
lead_paragraph: After its public relations coup turned into a significant embarrassment, Salesforce.com has investigated itself, and changed the results of its recent contest for software developers.

headline: Finding Japan’s Aircraft-Carrier Sub
abstract: The I-400, an enormous World War II submarine, was sunk by the United States — in 1946, after the war, to keep it out of the hands of the Soviet Union. The submersible Pisces V found it.
lead_paragraph: It could just as easily have been a rock.

headline: Circumcisions to Help Prevent AIDS Are on the Rise
abstract: A United Nations agency estimated that 3.2 million African men had been voluntarily circumcised since 2007. Studies show that the procedure reduces the risk of infection by about 60 percent.
lead_paragraph: Circumcision for AIDS prevention is increasing rapidly in eastern and southern Africa, according to newly released figures.

headline: An Older Buddha, and Disease Numbers Good and Bad
abstract: The World Health Organization increased its estimate of 2009 swine flu deaths, while researchers in Pittsburgh may have put a number on the cases of contagious disease prevented by vaccines.
lead_paragraph: As Americans paused to count their blessings last week, scientists made some reassessments of their own. The World Health Organization sharply increased its estimate of 2009 swine flu deaths and architects in Nepal found evidence that Buddha lived centuries earlier than previously thought. Still need something to be thankful for? Researchers in Pittsburgh may have put a number on the cases of contagious disease prevented by vaccines.

headline: In New Orleans, the More Restaurants the Merrier
abstract: Food-obsessed New Orleans has fewer people now than before Hurricane Katrina, but it has, by one local expert’s count, 70 percent more restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Food-obsessed New Orleans has fewer people now than before Hurricane Katrina, but it has, by one local expert’s count, 70 percent more restaurants.

headline: New Orleans Restaurant Scene Rises, Reflecting a Richer City
abstract: Eight years after Hurricane Katrina, the restaurant industry has become the backbone of the city, and the boom is a barometer of a more affluent and more educated New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — By one count there were already 65 restaurants on the three miles of Magazine Street, a major artery through this city’s upscale districts. But on a recent Monday, diners were eager for No. 66. The minute the lights went on at Ivy, an autumnal little lounge with an as-seen-on-TV chef, the curious were at the door.

headline: Families, in Many Shapes and Sizes (5 Comments)
abstract: Letters and comments to the Editor.

headline: Men Can Be Such Worms (and Vice Versa)
abstract: Male roundworms shorten the life spans of females, according to a new study, and the researchers believe their findings are linked to sex.
lead_paragraph: Studies have repeatedly shown that married people live longer. But not if you’re a roundworm: Having a man around can kill you.

headline: A Record Holiday Week for Broadway
abstract: Ticket sales for the 32 musicals and plays running last week hit $31.5 million, a record for Thanksgiving week.
lead_paragraph: Broadway had its best Thanksgiving week ever at the box office, setting a record of $31.5 million in ticket sales for the 32 musicals and plays running last week, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The previous Broadway record for the holiday week, set in 2011, was $28.1 million (about $29.2 million after adjusting for inflation).

lead_paragraph: The visionary poet William Blake tumbled into the universe through his infinite grain of sand. For the French painter Bernard Durin, the portal was a beetle.

headline: Reeling in the Years With Sour Reflection
abstract: In “Eminent Hipsters,” Donald Fagen begins with tales about his early years in Steely Dan, but halfway through, his book becomes a cranky account of being on the road for a recent summer concert tour.
lead_paragraph: If you like Steely Dan’s greatest hits too much, Donald Fagen of that band probably hates you already. You may be one of the “TV babies” who illegally download those songs, show up at his concerts expecting to hear familiar hits, have no patience for anything soulful or adventurous or obscure, yet rather humiliatingly are paying part of his rent these days. The phrase “TV babies” comes from the film “Drugstore Cowboy,” which used it to the same contemptuous effect.

headline: Jazz-Funk Persuasion Rules the Night
abstract: Dave Holland, who has a new album, “Prism,” reunited with colleagues from his 1990 CD, “Extensions” at Birdland.
lead_paragraph: The album of the year in 1989, according to Down Beat magazine’s annual critics’ poll, was “Extensions,” an imposingly strong debut by the Dave Holland Quartet. Featuring Mr. Holland on bass, Steve Coleman on alto saxophone, Kevin Eubanks on guitar and Marvin Smitty Smith on drums, it was a lesson in post-bop transition, poised between polarities: tight and loose, inside and out, acoustic and electric, hot and cool.

headline: On an Expansive Stage, a Company Spreads Its Wings
abstract: The Mark Morris Dance Group presented several recent works in two programs at Sadler’s Wells Theater in London, a much larger space than its center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The mind of the choreographer Mark Morris, as we read it in his dances, is bewilderingly diverse. I first saw his work 29 years ago, in its first London season, and he is as mysterious to me now as he was then — but more marvelously so. Last week, the week after the Mark Morris Dance Group’s 25th-anniversary performances of “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” at Lincoln Center, Mr. Morris presented seven recent works in two programs at Sadler’s Wells Theater here. They ranged from the tender celebration of eccentricity in “A Wooden Tree” to the controlled philosophical imagery of “Socrates,” from the male-female intimate duet of “Jenn and Spencer” to the intermeshing group patterns of “Crosswalk.”

headline: Adding a New Note to a Musical Menagerie
abstract: Isaac Mizrahi is transforming “Peter & the Wolf” at the Guggenheim Museum from concert and art installation to full theatrical production.
lead_paragraph: “Peter & the Wolf” quickly became a holiday tradition at the Guggenheim Museum after it was first presented in 2007. Each year, a different artist creates installations to visually interpret the tale, punctuated by the narration of Isaac Mizrahi, the fashion and design impresario. This year, for the first time, Mr. Mizrahi is transforming a concert with art and storytelling into a full theatrical production under his command: He is directing the actors and designed the set and the costumes.

headline: Mexico: U.S. Indicts a Former Governor
abstract: The United States has indicted Tomás Yarrington Ruvalcaba, a former governor of a Mexican state and a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, on racketeering and money laundering charges.
lead_paragraph: The United States has indicted a former governor of a Mexican state that borders Texas in a case that has come to illustrate concerns over political corruption and has embarrassed the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Federal prosecutors on Monday unsealed the indictment charging the former official, Tomás Yarrington Ruvalcaba, who served as governor of Tamaulipas State from 1999 to 2005, with racketeering and money laundering. Mr. Yarrington, who is being sought, funneled payments from drug traffickers into Texas banks, real estate and false businesses, prosecutors said. Mr. Yarrington, a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, ran for president in 2005. But he was ejected from the party in 2012 as the inquiry came to light during the presidential campaign of Enrique Peña Nieto, who promised a new PRI, free of corruption.

headline: Washington Mayor Will Seek Re-election
abstract: Mayor Vincent C. Gray of Washington said Monday that he would run for re-election.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Vincent C. Gray of Washington said Monday that he would run for re-election. A spokesman for the mayor’s office, Robert Marus, said Mr. Gray had picked up petitions to begin gathering the 2,000 signatures required to participate in the Democratic primary on April 1. Mr. Gray was elected in 2010, and his tenure has been shadowed by investigations into that campaign, which was financed in part by $650,000 that was not reported to the election authorities. Mr. Gray has denied any knowledge of wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime, but the investigation is still open and three of the mayor’s associates have been found guilty. Mr. Gray’s decision ended months of speculation and was likely to reshape the crowded Democratic field, which includes four members of the District of Columbia Council.

headline: Britain: Envoy Aims to Mend Iran Ties
abstract: Britain’s new envoy to Tehran will travel to Iran on Tuesday, the first diplomatic visit by a British official since Britain’s embassy in Tehran was stormed more than two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s new envoy to Tehran will travel to Iran on Tuesday, the first diplomatic visit by a British official since Britain’s embassy in Tehran was stormed more than two years ago. The visit of the envoy, Ajay Sharma, who has the rank of a nonresident chargé d’affaires, was announced by his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Habibollah-Zadeh, to the official news agency IRNA. Foreign Secretary William Hague confirmed the report in a Twitter message, adding, “We’ll improve U.K.-Iran ties on a step-by-step, reciprocal basis.” Mr. Habibollah-Zadeh said that Mr. Sharma’s visit would include a look at British diplomatic buildings and talks with Iranian Foreign Ministry officials, and that he would then make a similar visit to London.

headline: U.S. Pledges New Funds to Fight AIDS
abstract: The United States will commit up to $5 billion to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, President Obama said Monday at the White House.
lead_paragraph: The United States will commit up to $5 billion to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, President Obama said Monday at the White House. The pledge was made as the Geneva-based fund’s “replenishment conference” opened in Washington; the fund’s leaders hope to have $15 billion pledged by Tuesday. Under the terms of the pledge, the United States will pay the full amount only if other countries pledge $10 billion. “Don’t leave our money on the table,” Mr. Obama said. He also said that state waiting lists for AIDS drugs, which grew to more than 9,000 patients in 2010, were finally cleared last week with federal aid under the Ryan White Program. And he said another $100 million in the federal budget would be redirected to AIDS research.

headline: Should a Student Conceal Her Lesbian Identity in College Application Essays?
abstract: Parents, fearing homophobic prejudice in college admissions, want to know how to persuade their daughter from revealing her sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: Our daughter is a senior in high school and quite comfortable with her lesbian identity. We support her 100 percent, but we know the world is not always so tolerant. As she’s writing her college application essays this fall, she’s “coming out” in them — and we think that’s a bad idea. You just never know who’s reading these essays, so why risk revealing your orientation to someone who might be biased against you? We’ve strongly suggested she think over the ramifications of what she’s doing, but she doesn’t seem to have any doubt about it. Deadlines are approaching and we are at an impasse. How can we persuade her to keep some things private if they might hurt her chances of admission?” — Anonymous

headline: The Battle of Fort Sanders

And around the world, it is often at pop’s center, with Americans looking on in curiosity.

headline: When Is It Safe to Drive After Breaking a Bone?
abstract: Most studies say that braking function returns to normal four weeks after right knee arthroscopy, nine weeks after surgery for an ankle fracture, and six weeks after the patient can walk unencumbered after a fracture of a major lower-body bone.
lead_paragraph: Hands on the steering wheel, one foot toggling between brake and pedal, head twisting to check mirrors. Consider the many bones and joints you must engage before you even turn on a car’s ignition, among them the fingers, wrist, forearm, elbow, shoulder, neck, heel, ankle and leg.

headline: For Art Basel, Miami’s Swankiest Garage Becomes a Gallery Yet Again
abstract: The Herzog & de Meuron-designed car park at 1111 Lincoln Road plays host this week to an exhibition of jalopies that have been intriguingly tweaked by artists.
lead_paragraph: Right now, the art world and its glamorous interlopers are revving their engines for this year’s Art Basel Miami Beach, which opens to the public on Thursday. Meanwhile, at the city’s premier automotive temple, grease monkeys are putting the final touches on an exhibition of cars as art. The Swiss-minimal garage at 1111 Lincoln Road, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, has become the apogee of Art Basel lavishness and excess since opening in 2010, with pop-ups galore (like this year’s Colette-sponsored Art Drive Thru, which opened yesterday), and events like 2011’s Ferrari fete, during which hot rods paraded up and down the structure’s seven levels of open-air ramps all night long.

headline: A Love Letter to a Smelly Fruit
abstract: Durian stinks so badly that it’s banned from airplanes, hotels and mass transit in most Southeast Asian cities. So why does the author adore it?
lead_paragraph: When my friend Bob Halliday thinks about durians, the tropical fruit that some say smells like garbage, he not only salivates with delighted anticipation, but he also “foams like a geyser.” Those were the words he used on the eve of our visit to an orchard north of Bangkok that was filled with these green spiky fruits dangling dangerously from towering trees.

headline: Cultivating a Wine Region in India
abstract: Nashik, a picturesque area about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Mumbai, is turning into a popular wine destination.
lead_paragraph: In India, where whiskey is the alcoholic drink of choice and teetotalers exist by the legions, a wine culture has been almost nonexistent. Nashik (also Nasik), a picturesque area with deep green rolling hills about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Mumbai, is finally changing that perception. More than a half-dozen wineries with attractive tasting rooms and, in some cases, restaurants and accommodations, have opened here in the last several years and are turning this fertile valley into a popular oenophile destination for trendsetting Indians.

headline: Versace Valuation May Be as Over the Top as Its Clothes
abstract: The Italian fashion house reckons it is worth more than 1 billion euros, or $1.36 billion, and could triple in value in three years. That’s a big price tag for a skimpy minority stake next to a powerful family, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Versace’s valuation looks as aggressive as its outfits. The Italian fashion house, which is sizing up buyout firms and sovereign wealth funds to finance a capital increase, believes it is worth more than 1 billion euros, or $1.36 billion, and could triple in value in three years. There is real potential, because Versace has fallen behind industry trends. But a big price tag for a skimpy minority stake next to a powerful family? That’s hard to pull off.

headline: The Gun Report: December 3, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In September, Gary Roberts, 57, was shot to death by his wife after he threatened to kill the police officers who were on their way to the couple’s Greenfield, Ind., home to question him about the arsenal of explosives and some 1,400 weapons he had stored in the basement. Elizabeth Roberts, 56, his wife of 31 years, told police that her husband began loading ammunition into a gun magazine and pledged to kill any officers who came to the home. When she said she would shoot him to prevent the impending bloodshed, he handed her a gun loaded with hollow-point bullets and told her to do what she had to do. She fired one shot into his chest, killing him.

headline: Out of the Doldrums, Automakers Post Strong U.S. Sales
abstract: The sales increase, after a slowing in September and October, was being closely watched as an indication of the recovery’s staying power.
lead_paragraph: Sales over the Thanksgiving weekend may have been a disappointment for the nation’s retailers, but they were a boon for automakers, lifting their sales in the United States for November to the best rate since before the recession.

headline: Thomas Keneally to Write Book and Lyrics for New Musical
abstract: “Transport,” about the deportation of Irish women to Australia, will feature music by Larry Kirwan of the band Black 47.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Keneally, best known for writing “Schindler’s List” but also the author of historical works about the founding of his native Australia, will turn to that subject in “Transport,” a new musical for which he’s written the book and lyrics.

headline: 1930 Model A Ford Makes Cross-Country Voyage on Second Try
abstract: Rod Wade and Michael Flanders had to cut their trip short the last time they attempted the journey, but this time the car cooperated.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it’s best to cut one’s losses and move on. For Rod Wade, the Australian automotive adventurer whose cross-country run last month in a 1930 Model A Ford was abbreviated by a broken crankshaft, cutting his losses wasn’t in the cards. It was time to move on; all the way across the United States.

headline: Little Things Stand Out About Baseball’s Best
abstract: A quick recollection of each of the 36 players on the 2014 ballot for the Baseball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: The Hall of Fame is baseball’s finish line, the ultimate validation for careers that awed and inspired us when we were much younger. We view it with nostalgia because we want to remember the good.

headline: Extra FaceTime IDs, and Reordering Email
abstract: Tips on creating additional FaceTime addresses under one Apple ID, and how to turn off message threading.
lead_paragraph: Multiple IDs

headline: Pope Francis and the Ghost of Sargent Shriver
abstract: How the new pope is implicitly challenging Catholic liberals to prove that their worldview has a future.
lead_paragraph: After my post yesterday contrasting the challenges the Francis era may offer to American Catholics who feel at home on the political right of center with the opportunities it may open up to their more liberal co-religionists, it’s only fair to also point out the implicit challenge that the new pope is offering to liberal Catholics as well — or at least to liberal Catholics who see their relationship to the church in terms of fidelity as well as criticism and dissent.

headline: Sleep and the City
abstract: WestHouse, a hotel scheduled to open in New York in late December, is designed to help guests get a good night’s rest.
lead_paragraph: Travelers looking for a good night’s rest in a city that never sleeps can customize their experience at WestHouse, a luxury boutique hotel scheduled to open in late December.

headline: Windsor Terrace: Less Way Station, More Destination
abstract: A once-parenthetical neighborhood in central Brooklyn that has become a top choice, with parks, restaurants and more affordable rowhouses.
lead_paragraph: For decades the curved, somewhat comma-like shape of Windsor Terrace, in central Brooklyn, seemed almost to symbolize its role: a kind of geographic pause between larger flanking neighborhoods. Squeezed between Park Slope and the various parts of the Flatbush area, and linking them in the process, Windsor Terrace never really achieved the stature of its bigger-name peers.

headline: Fried Chicken’s Northern Exposure
abstract: When frying inside, you have to worry about spattering grease and lingering odors. Taking it outside eliminates those concerns.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a culinary etiquette question: Does a bottle of bourbon qualify as a “dish,” as in “bring your favorite Southern dish”?

headline: Why Tracey Emin Is in a Miami State of Mind
abstract: The audacious British artist, who has a solo show opening tomorrow at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami, has adopted South Florida as a home away from home. Here, she shares a few favorite destinations.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Emin has always been associated with London. It’s where she studied painting before achieving early notoriety as one of the “Young British Artists.” It’s the place she unveiled her infamous camping tent, embroidered with the names of all the people she’d ever slept with. It’s the city in which she continues to live, work and teach.

headline: Taconic Capital Co-Founder to Retire
abstract: Kenneth D. Brody, who turned 70 this year, will remain a principal and an adviser at the firm, as well as a “significant investor,” he said in a letter.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth D. Brody, a co-founder of the hedge fund Taconic Capital Advisors, plans to retire from his full-time role by the end of the year, he told his investors on Tuesday.

headline: Editor Describes Pressure After Leaks by Snowden
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'News and News Media', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Testimony to Parliament from the top editor of The Guardian illustrated the aggressive investigative and spying tactics increasingly faced by news organizations.
lead_paragraph: The top editor of the British newspaper The Guardian told Parliament on Tuesday that since it obtained documents on government surveillance from a former National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden, it has met with government agencies in Britain and the United States more than 100 times and has been subjected to measures “designed to intimidate.”

headline: Preview: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
abstract: Oscar Isaac and Adam Driver in a clip from the Coen brothers’ new movie.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Isaac and Adam Driver in a clip from the Coen brothers’ new movie.

headline: New York, Circa the ’60s, Reborn in New York, Circa Today
abstract: How the Coen brothers’ new film starring Oscar Isaac and Carey Mulligan recreates a lost bohemian downtown.
lead_paragraph: How the Coen brothers’ new film starring Oscar Isaac and Carey Mulligan recreates a lost bohemian downtown.

headline: Positively Fourth Street, All Over Again
abstract: Recreating the Greenwich Village of the 1960s, using the East Village, Brooklyn and Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: One primary pleasure of the Coen brothers’ new movie, “Inside Llewyn Davis” — a film that is abundant in its pleasures — is revisiting a New York that most New Yorkers thought was gone for good: Greenwich Village of the early 1960s, when downtown was teeming with bohemians and dreamers and not with lost tourists holding upside-down maps. “Davis” follows a Bob Dylanesque folk singer named Llewyn Davis and unfolds mostly (with a few detours to far-flung uptown and Chicago) in that fabled realm of a lost New York, complete with cold-water flats and smoke-filled subterranean clubs.

headline: Syria Crisis Is Worsening, U.N. Relief Official Says
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Despite modest progress by the Syrian government, Valerie Amos said, aid delivery remained far below what is needed.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The top emergency relief official at the United Nations expressed new alarm on Tuesday at the humanitarian crisis caused by Syria’s civil war, telling the Security Council that despite some modest progress, both the government and insurgent sides were still impeding urgent deliveries of food and medicine to millions of desperate civilians.

headline: Text to Text | ‘I Have a Dream’ and ‘The Lasting Power of Dr. King’s Dream Speech’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair Dr. King’s “I Have a Dream” speech with a reflection by the Times literary critic Michiko Kakutani, who explores why this speech has such lasting power.
lead_paragraph: Last summer was the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. painted his dream of racial equality and justice for the nation that still resonates with us. “I have a dream,” he proclaimed, “my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.” In this Text to Text, we pair Dr. King’s pivotal “I Have a Dream” speech with a reflection by the Times literary critic Michiko Kakutani, who explores why this singular speech has such lasting power.

headline: Beyond Brisket and Burritos in Austin, Tex.
abstract: Diverse options await diners in the capital city. Here are four places where you can sample textures from Austin’s palate.
lead_paragraph: People who say that Austin isn’t at all like the rest of Texas should look a little harder. The capital city may swaddle its Lone Star bravado in slacker irony, swap out big hair for cycling musculature and express its rugged individualism with six-strings rather than six-shooters ... but really, we’re talking about the same prideful, gabby, strangely infectious psychodynamic. Even for Austin’s most rabid Gov. Rick Perry haters, defecting from the state is not an option: they adore being Texans, one and all, and appreciate that the term sets them apart somehow.

headline: How a Growing Business Set Itself Apart
abstract: Recruiting is mostly about sales, one owner said, which is why the success of an office depends on the sales abilities of its recruiters.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners were joined by a guest, Rebecca Cenni, founder of Atrium Staffing. This post continues the conversation with Ms. Cenni, who explained how her $140 million staffing and payroll firm differentiates itself.

headline: Court Is Accused of Unfairly Targeting a Continent’s Leaders
abstract: The African Union, invoking old demons of racism and imperialism, claims that the International Criminal Court should back off.
lead_paragraph: Little noticed outside Africa, a movement against the International Criminal Court has been brewing on the continent this fall, challenging a unique but often polarizing international mechanism to prosecute grave human rights abuses.

headline: International Criminal Court Wrestles With Applying Law, or Bending
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The nations that adhere to the International Criminal Court have agreed to special rules for national leaders, but human rights groups warned that a category of privileged defendant had been created.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — As the International Criminal Court takes up its highest-profile trials to date — the case of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto — it is wrestling with a question that so often looms over international justice: Should the law prevail, or bend to the demands of diplomacy and political stability?

headline: Surprising New Face in Arabic Music
abstract: Jennifer Grout, a young American who sings classical Arabic music, is a finalist on “Arabs Got Talent,” an Arabic version of the reality show.
lead_paragraph: The Arab world has an unlikely new star: an American who sings — but barely speaks — Arabic. Not only that, her genre is traditional Arab music.

headline: TimesTalks: Kim Cattrall
abstract: The actress talks about acting for theater as opposed to television, and moving out from under the shadow of Samantha, her character on “Sex and the City.”
lead_paragraph: The actress talks about acting for theater as opposed to television, and moving out from under the shadow of Samantha, her character on “Sex and the City.”

lead_paragraph: Inside the SoHo restaurant that gets packed early on and stays that way for hours.

headline: A Relaxed Air, but Attention Must Be Paid
abstract: Charlie Bird leans heavily on cheese, salt and crunch (and warm smiles).
lead_paragraph: THE HARDEST-WORKING WOMAN in the food business one recent night was the host of Charlie Bird, in SoHo. Armed with nothing but good cheer and a smile that could stop a war, she had the unenviable job of preventing an uprising in a waiting area by the door that might comfortably hold three people if they were very skinny and could survive for minutes at a time without breathing. There were around 10 of us.

headline: ‘American Hustle’ Makes a Showing With Critics Circle
abstract: The New York Film Critics Circle gave three awards to the David O. Russell film, though “12 Years a Slave” won for best direction.
lead_paragraph: The late-arriving “American Hustle,” which reunites David O. Russell with much of his casts from “The Fighter” and “Silver Linings Playbook,” was the surprise winner with the New York Film Critics Circle, which announced its year-end picks on Tuesday. The film, set loosely around the 1970s Abscam scandal, took best feature, best screenplay (for Mr. Russell and Eric Singer) and best supporting actress, for Jennifer Lawrence. It is among the final entries in the very tight Oscar race this season and beat out expected competitors like “12 Years a Slave,” “Nebraska” and “Inside Llewyn Davis.”

headline: The Art of Plating
abstract: Amanda Cohen, the chef and owner of Dirt Candy, showcases the different qualities of spinach in this beautiful construction.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Cohen, the chef and owner of Dirt Candy, showcases the different qualities of spinach in this beautiful construction.

headline: Beautiful Plates
abstract: Food meets plate in a process far more elaborate and elemental than many may realize.
lead_paragraph: Food meets plate in a process far more elaborate and elemental than many may realize.

headline: The Ceramic Canvas
abstract: Plating is now as much a reflection of a chef’s craftsmanship as is the cooking itself.
lead_paragraph: Wait. We know you’re hungry. We know you’re ready to use that shiny fork as a battering ram. But before you dismantle and devour that dish of beautiful food placed in front of you, take a moment to look at it. Really look.

headline: Americanized Labor Policy Is Spreading in Europe
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Politics and Government', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Desperate to restore competitiveness, European nations are dismantling workplace protections that once supported labor and helped minimize income inequality.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, 1.9 million Portuguese workers in the private sector were covered by collective bargaining agreements. Last year, the number was down to 300,000.

headline: Supreme Court Considers Frequent Flier Contracts
abstract: The court heard arguments Tuesday in a rabbi’s case against Northwest Airlines, which revoked his membership in its frequent flier program. A federal law limits the kind of suits travelers may file.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rabbi S. Binyomin Ginsberg used to fly often enough on Northwest Airlines that he achieved Platinum Elite status, the highest level. But the airline revoked his membership in its frequent flier program in June 2008, saying that he had abused it by making too many complaints and by booking himself on full flights in the hope of being bumped.

headline: House Votes to Extend Gun Law Without New Provisions for 3-D Printed Firearms
keywords: ['Gun Control', '3-D Printers', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The House voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to extend a law banning firearms that can pass undetected through X-ray machines, but did not include provisions regulating guns made with 3-D printers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Tuesday to extend a law banning firearms that can pass undetected through airport X-ray machines, but left out provisions that law enforcement officials say are necessary to combat the growing threat of guns made with 3-D printers.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Black Action Tees
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: superhero shirts packed with a heavy dose of nostalgia.

headline: The Real Health Care Distraction?
abstract: President Obama said glitches were clouding the fact that the old insurance system wasn’t working, and that Republicans have no alternative.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks it’s been trendy, in Republican circles, to claim that anything Democrats do or say unrelated to the Affordable Care Act is a ploy to “distract” attention away from the problematic HealthCare.gov rollout. (Really, anything: filibuster reform or a diplomatic breakthrough with Iran.)

headline: She Makes That Much on Broadway?
abstract: TV Land has added “Kirstie,” featuring Kirstie Alley as a narcissistic Broadway actress, to its lineup.
lead_paragraph: On TV Land, you don’t sweat the details. Three Hollywood harpies accidentally land in Ohio, move in with Betty White and date young cornfed hunks (“Hot in Cleveland”)? Of course. Three men share an apartment owned by their wacky divorce lawyer (“The Exes”)? Why not.

headline: When Life Resembles Art … or at Least Monty Python
abstract: If there is one thing that Python has taught me, it’s that life isn’t just full of absurdity and non sequiturs; life IS absurdity and nonsequitors.
lead_paragraph: As a dude of a certain age whose so-called formative years were lived in the mid-’80s, I have spent a good portion of my life trying to perfect my Cockney accent in falsetto and forcing Monty Python expressions into everyday conversation. Sometimes it’s not easy. Then there are times like last week.

headline: Obama Urges Focus on Health Care Law’s Benefits
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: President Obama asked Americans to refocus on the positive changes the Affordable Care Act could bring, not the mechanics of enrollment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday urged Americans to “refocus on” the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, pointing to people who had already avoided costly health care expenses because of the law’s provisions.

headline: The City of Angels and Crime and Seriously Stylish Hats
abstract: “Mob City” is TNT’s new series about the police and the mob, set in 1947 Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Warning: In the Land of Noir, things move more slowly than they do in our usual television cop show universe. Men — and, yes, it’s mostly men in the Land of Noir — walk with an odd combination of shuffle and swagger that is not designed for speed. Conversation is sparse. Deliberate. Nobody’s in a hurry to get his words out.

headline: T.R. Fehrenbach, Historian, Dies at 88; Chronicler of Larger-Than-Life Texas
abstract: A member of the Sons of Texas, Mr. Fehrenbach said he had never claimed to be a historian; he once characterized his writing as “political science fiction.”
lead_paragraph: T. R. Fehrenbach, a historian and journalist whose sweeping treatment of Texas history portrayed the state as an almost mythic land, powerfully pleasing many Texans while mightily rankling others, died Sunday in San Antonio. He was 88.

headline: Expansive and Teasing, and Still a Superstar
abstract: In promoting his new boxed set, Garth Brooks could be setting the stage for a comeback.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, Garth Brooks, ubiquitous high-energy country megastar of the 1990s, has been more or less in hiding, spending time with his family and only peeking his head out from under his shell for occasional one-man shows — focusing on the music that influenced him — at the Wynn Las Vegas casino, where he had a residency beginning in 2009.

headline: Kozlowski Is Granted Parole
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, will be out on parole soon as Jan. 17.
lead_paragraph: Come January, L. Dennis Kozlowski’s long tenure in New York State’s penitentiary system will near its end.

headline: Bach as a Mensch and an Imperfect Human Being
abstract: John Eliot Gardiner’s book is not intended as a straight biography so much as a thematic examination of Bach the composer as man and musician.
lead_paragraph: Not to proclaim that an author’s first book will necessarily stand as his magnum opus, but it is hard to imagine what the English maestro John Eliot Gardiner, 70, might do to surpass “Bach: Music in the Castle of Heaven” in its commitment, scope and comprehensiveness. True, as Mr. Gardiner writes and has amply shown over the decades, he is “equally (though differently) drawn to the three B’s — Beethoven, Berlioz and Brahms — and could have mustered equivalent fervor for writing about Monteverdi, Schütz or Rameau.”

headline: On Piano, and Staying Attuned to the Audience
abstract: At the Laurie Beechman Theater in Manhattan, Eric Yves Garcia proved himself to be a comedian and storyteller as well as a musician.
lead_paragraph: Eric Yves Garcia, a Manhattan piano bar entertainer who toiled in semi-oblivion at Chez Josephine until his recent appearances at the New York Cabaret Convention, belongs to the school of jazz-leaning connoisseurs of the American Songbook epitomized by the irreplaceable Bobby Short. If Mr. Garcia’s sprightly appearance at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Monday evening says anything about the frustrations of turning out semi-anonymous background music in a restaurant, it might be that inside many a piano bar musician beats the heart of an aspiring concert entertainer, waiting for his moment.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The World’s Most Expensive Phone, and Why We Like Listicles
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the web include a photo feature that shows how Vertu phones are created. Plus, a list of reasons that our brains are hard-wired to like lists.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Instruments May Look Standard, but the Sounds They Create Are Not
abstract: The Mannes Percussion Ensemble performed Marcos Balter’s “Dark Rooms” and Hiroya Miura’s “Puncture Me.”
lead_paragraph: At the start of the Mannes Percussion Ensemble’s concert on Monday evening James Baker, the ensemble’s director, announced a change in the program. Two planned works had been dropped, he said, because the group had decided it would rather prepare fewer pieces at a higher level of polish than bite off more than it could comfortably chew.

headline: Fraternal Ties, of Gut and Sinew
abstract: “Out of the Furnace” looks at the visceral bond between two troubled brothers.
lead_paragraph: In movies, the working class often serves as a sacrificial emblem of the failure of the American dream, one that these days is often embellished with lovingly photographed decay and an elegiac air. Set in a corroded stretch of the Rust Belt, “Out of the Furnace” ups the ante with a story of two blue-collar brothers — a steel mill welder and a former soldier — who are as totemic as the figures immortalized in a Works Progress Administration mural. It’s a heavy, solemn tale of blood ties that turns into a melodramatic gusher filled with abstractions about masculinity, America and violence, but brought to specific, exciting life by Christian Bale, Casey Affleck and Woody Harrelson.

headline: Proving That Ailey Never Stands Still
abstract: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater continues to expand its horizons with Wayne McGregor’s “Chroma.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, 10 dancers from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater caught their breath after a run-through of “Chroma,” an exceptionally fast-paced, convoluted work by the British choreographer Wayne McGregor. The windows of the fifth-floor studio offered sweeping views of Midtown Manhattan, but the city looked almost sleepy next to the dancing that had just happened.

headline: A Home School Where the Lessons Are Subtle
abstract: In “Breakfast With Curtis,” a home-schooled teenager comes out of his shell in a neighborhood with many bohemians.
lead_paragraph: Desultory, dauntingly DIY but secretly efficient, “Breakfast With Curtis” is something like a leafy summer afternoon in movie form. This is the third feature from the writer and director Laura Colella, who has shot it in and around her own well-loved, multifamily Victorian and the house next door. Her neighbors play the film’s overlapping, underdressed group of friends and family. This micro-indie movie is partly about a taciturn, home-schooled teenager, Curtis (subtly played by Jonah Parker), coming out of his shell, but it’s mostly about hanging out.

lead_paragraph: Shortly after opening a new restaurant in Astoria, Queens, this year, the owner received an unwelcome visitor, he said, who explained that it would cost him money to operate “in our neighborhood.”

headline: Illinois Legislature Approves Retiree Benefit Cuts in Troubled Pension System
abstract: The hard-fought deal, which includes higher state contributions to the system, could be a template for agreements elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — The Illinois legislature on Tuesday ended a day of emotional debate and fierce back-room arm-twisting by passing a deal to shore up the state’s debt-engulfed pension system by trimming retiree benefits and increasing state contributions.

headline: Bryant and Messi Try to Repeat a Hit Airline Ad
abstract: Turkish Airlines hopes again to fascinate the global public by pairing two sports heroes, Kobe Bryant and Lionel Messi.
lead_paragraph: A commercial for Turkish Airlines that unexpectedly became a worldwide hit in social media, drawing more than 105 million views on YouTube in the last 12 months, is getting a sequel.

headline: A Rare Glimpse at Some of the Finest Jewelry and Objects Ever Made
abstract: At the Grand Palais in Paris, a sprawling exhibit culled from the collections of princesses and heiresses documents the rich design legacy of the French jeweler Cartier.
lead_paragraph: When Kate Middleton married Prince William in Westminster Abbey in April 2011, she wore a delicate Cartier diamond tiara known as the “Halo Scroll.” In 1936, the Duke of York purchased it from the French jeweler for his wife, three weeks before they ascended to the throne and became King George VI and Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother. She later gave it to her daughter, Princess Elizabeth — now Queen Elizabeth II — as an 18th birthday present.

headline: Busy in Gray Areas of the Law in a Bid to Control a Rival
abstract: In his effort to acquire LightSquared in bankruptcy court, Charles Ergen has taken advantage of every gray area in the law, the Deal Professor writes.
lead_paragraph: In Charles W. Ergen’s war for LightSquared, the fiercest fight involves a legal loophole.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ to Raise Money for Liz Cheney’s Senate Bid

abstract: The candidate’s father, former Vice President Dick Cheney, will be the keynote speaker at a $10,000-per-couple dinner in Washington this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Supporters of Liz Cheney, whose campaign for a Senate seat in Wyoming got off to a rocky start, have created a “super PAC” to bolster her “name awareness and approval rating.” The group is hosting a high-dollar fund-raiser this week in Washington featuring her father, former Vice President Dick Cheney, at a Georgetown restaurant, according to an emailed invitation.

headline: A Traditional Audio Company Enters the Wireless Realm
abstract: The Gig, a wireless speaker from Klipsch, shows that high-end audio companies know how to fit a lot of sound into tiny enclosures.
lead_paragraph: The growth of the market for wireless speakers has slowly been enticing more traditional audio companies to cut their wires, too. And a recent offering from Klipsch shows that high-end audio companies know how to fit a lot of sound into tiny wireless speakers.

lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Dinh Thien Thien’s barbecue business bloomed just as Vietnam’s property market wilted. It was not a coincidence.
