lead_paragraph: As consumers shift more of their attention from console games to mobile apps, gaming accessory makers are following suit. The latest offering comes from Turtle Beach, which has released a headset designed specifically for mobile media.

The fishery for northern shrimp, also called pink shrimp, was worth an estimated $1.2 million in its limited 2013 season; in 2011, according to regulators, it was worth more than $10 million.

headline: Parliament Versus the Press

lead_paragraph: Ever since Edward Snowden leaked documents on the National Security Agency’s data-mining programs, governments of countries such as the United States and Great Britain have tried to dismiss the concern that mass, secret surveillance is incompatible with an open, democratic society. So it was chilling and more than a little ironic to see members of the British Parliament grill a newspaper editor on Tuesday for daring to publish information on government spying.

headline: We’re Heading to London! (But How to Take the Dog?)
abstract: Inside the research, drama and, at times, staggering economics of trying to take the family pet on an overseas move.
lead_paragraph: When this newspaper decided to transfer me from upstate New York to London, the first question from my house was what would happen to our 2-year-old golden retriever.

headline: ‘Story First, Maps Second’
abstract: Caterina Fake, founder of a new location-based website, talks about the value of documenting the stories behind places.
lead_paragraph: Every tech start-up has its creation myth.

headline: Beats Music Streaming Service Says It Will Begin in January
abstract: The service, which intends to compete with Spotify, hopes to build on the popularity of Beats headphones.
lead_paragraph: The music world has spent more than a year guessing when Beats Music, the new service from the makers of Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, would arrive. Now there’s an official date, or at least a month: January.

headline: Ebb in Uranium Enrichment in U.S. Raises Questions About Nuclear Policy
abstract: Some experts fear that the United States’ reliance on imported enriched uranium may affect its global nonproliferation efforts and potentially cause supply problems in the future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Energy Department officials will shake hands and exchange congratulations with Russian representatives at a Port of Baltimore dockside ceremony on Tuesday as a freighter from St. Petersburg is to arrive with the final shipment of enriched uranium that was once intended for Soviet warheads. The uranium will be turned into fuel for American power reactors, completing a 20-year program, called Megatons to Megawatts, that has eliminated enough highly enriched uranium to fuel about 19,000 warheads.

headline: Classical Playlist: Anna Caterina Antonacci, Mivos Quartet, Matthew Brown and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: Poetry, and Motion
abstract: Fiona Shaw stars in a new staged reading of Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s “Rime of the Ancient Mariner.”
lead_paragraph: Since we are now entering the time of year when theater producers turn to Rockettes and blessings from Tiny Tim, consider “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,” a new staged reading of the harrowing 1798 poem by Samuel Taylor Coleridge, counterprogramming. The epic poem, performed by the illustrious Irish actress Fiona Shaw, features a sailor stopping a man on a way to a wedding to tell of a trip at sea that becomes cursed after he shot an albatross. His crew mates force him to wear the dead bird, which gives us the expression “albatross around your neck.”

headline: Libor Bank Fines Reflect Rewards of Cooperating
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: The lenient treatment of Barclays and UBS, the first banks to settle with financial agencies in the Libor case, highlights the risks in delaying settlements.
lead_paragraph: The rewards of early settlement in the scandal involving manipulation of the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, are becoming more obvious.

headline: Three Rockwell Classics Bring Nearly $57.8 Million
abstract: Norman Rockwell’s “Saying Grace,” one of the artist’s most popular covers for The Saturday Evening Post, sold for more than double its estimated price.
lead_paragraph: Three paintings by Norman Rockwell celebrating homey, small-town America, among the most popular of his 322 covers for The Saturday Evening Post, sold at Sotheby’s on Wednesday morning for a total of nearly $57.8 million, about twice their high estimate.

headline: Below the Line: Making ‘Gravity’
abstract: Tim Webber, the visual effects supervisor for “Gravity,” discusses how some of its effects were achieved.
lead_paragraph: With its immersive feel, large-scale visuals and adventurous pacing, Alfonso Cuarón’s sci-fi drama “Gravity” has won over critics and audiences alike — a good sign its Oscar possibilities. And with its long-take action sequences set in zero gravity, it has become one of the most “how did they do that?” movies of the year. Here’s a little on how they did it.

headline: Serbian-Born Composer Wins $100,000 Prize
abstract: Djuro Zivkovic is the winner of the 2014 Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition.
lead_paragraph: Djuro Zivkovic, a 38-year-old composer who was born in Serbia and lives in Stockholm, has won the 2014 Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition for his work “On the Guarding of the Heart.” The prize, awarded annually by the University of Louisville, is among the most prestigious international prizes for classical composition and carries a cash award of $100,000.

headline: Lundqvist’s Deal With Rangers Is ‘From the Heart’
abstract: Goalie Henrik Lundqvist, 31, who could have been a free agent at the end of the N.H.L. season, agreed to a deal worth $59.5 million.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist said he wanted to be a Ranger for life, and now he will have that chance. The Rangers announced Wednesday that Lundqvist had signed a seven-year contract extension, ending speculation that he might depart when his contract expired at the end of the N.H.L. season.

headline: The Magic of West Point
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Terry Babcock-Lumish, an economics professor at the United States Military Academy, on teaching at West Point.
lead_paragraph: My students jest that I earned my degree from Hogwarts. I dare not correct the record.

headline: A New Plan for Norton Museum of Art From Norman Foster
abstract: The Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., unveils a new master plan that will nearly double its gallery space.
lead_paragraph: The Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday unveiled a new master plan designed by the British architect Norman Foster that will nearly double its gallery space and add an education center, auditorium and restaurant.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Redfeather Snowshoes
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: practical gear that doubles as wintry home décor.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Student Debt Load Found to Vary by College and State
abstract: The picture is far from uniform, with students at some colleges borrowing ten times as much as their counterparts elsewhere, a new report says.
lead_paragraph: Rising student debt has become a national concern, but the picture is far from uniform, with students at some colleges borrowing 10 times as much as their counterparts at other colleges, a report released Wednesday says.

headline: Super Bowl Advertising Is Already Sold Out, Fox Executives Say
abstract: Concluding ad sales nearly two months before kickoff is unusually early and is a sign of an improving economy and interest in a New York-area game.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “going, going, gone” is associated with baseball rather than football, but Fox Broadcasting is telling advertisers that commercial time during Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2, 2014 is, finally, gone.

headline: Student Debt and the Class of 2012
abstract: The Institute for College Access and Success reports not only enormous variation in student debt from school to school, but also wide differences by region.
lead_paragraph: The Institute for College Access and Success reports not only enormous variation in student debt from school to school, but also wide differences by region.

headline: Video: Classically Structured in Bucharest
abstract: Wearing a tailored green blazer, a pinstriped shirt, a yellow tie and cuffed jeans, Victor Placinta, an architect, described his style as classic.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Victor Placinta was strolling in the old center of Bucharest, Romania, an area known for its historic architecture, and, in more modern times, as a cultural hub where coffee-guzzling intellectuals gather. Wearing a tailored green blazer, a pinstriped shirt, a yellow tie and cuffed jeans, he described his style to an interviewer as classic.

headline: Russia’s First Smartphone Goes on Sale
abstract: The quirky device has two screens, one color and the other black-and-white, to save battery life.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s first smartphone – a quirky, dual-screen device with a traditional LCD-color display on one side and an electronic-paper display similar to the Amazon Kindle on the other – began selling in Russia and several other European countries on Wednesday.

headline: Poll Finds Young People Souring on Health Law and Obama
abstract: A majority of 18- to 29-year-olds disapprove of the Affordable Care Act, and fewer than a third of those who are uninsured are likely to sign up for coverage, according to a new poll by Harvard University’s Institute of Politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of 18- to 29-year-olds – a constituency crucial to the success of President Obama’s health overhaul — disapprove of the law, and fewer than a third of those who are uninsured are likely to sign up for coverage, according to a new poll by Harvard University’s Institute of Politics.

headline: Image of the Day: December 4
abstract: The day is observed to commemorate the role of Indian Navy during the India-Pakistan war of 1971.

headline: Majority of Silent Films Are Lost, Study Finds
abstract: A survey by the Library of Congress reports that 70 percent of the features made from 1912 to 1929 cannot be found.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress announced on Wednesday the results of a survey that found that 70 percent of the feature-length films made in the United States during the silent era have been lost. The reasons range from the natural deterioration over time of highly flammable nitrate film stock to outright neglect.

headline: The Gun Report: December 4, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has banned an ad by a gun components distributor from airing during the Super Bowl, despite the fact that it was specifically designed to fit the rules that would allow it to be broadcast.

headline: Baffling 400,000-Year-Old Clue to Human Origins
abstract: DNA from a fossil in Spain most closely matches another extinct human lineage, Denisovans, whose remains have been found thousands of miles away in Siberia.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have found the oldest DNA evidence yet of humans’ biological history. But instead of neatly clarifying human evolution, the finding is adding new mysteries.

headline: Two Brothers to Lead Bowdoin Music Festival
abstract: The cellist David Ying and his brother, the violist Phillip Ying, have been named artistic directors of the Bowdoin International Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: The cellist David Ying and his brother, the violist Phillip Ying, have been named artistic directors of the Bowdoin International Music Festival, a summer festival and music school with a strong current of contemporary music running through its chamber and orchestral programs. The festival, held at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, was founded in 1964 by the violinist Lewis Kaplan, who will hand over the reins to the Yings at the end of the 2014 season.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Out of the Furnace’

headline: Daughter Says Mandela on ‘Deathbed’
abstract: A brief statement about the health of the South African leader spurred stories around the world.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Mandela waged a long struggle against apartheid. And he is still fighting, this time for his life from what his oldest daughter is describing as his “deathbed.”

headline: ‘Her’ Wins Big at  National Board of Review Awards
abstract: By choosing “Her” as best picture, the National Board of Review added yet another option to an already jumbled race.
lead_paragraph: The National Board of Review did little to provide clarity to a jumbled race with its best-of picks, announced Wednesday. The organization chose Spike Jonze’s near-future romance, “Her,” as best film, with Mr. Jonze as best director.

headline: A Supernova of Bad Sex? Manil Suri Wins Uncoveted Award
abstract: Physicists weigh in on a passage in Mr. Suri’s novel “The City of Devi,” which won Literary Review’s annual Bad Sex in Fiction Award.
lead_paragraph: The novelist and mathematician Manil Suri has been long-listed for the Booker Prize and short-listed for the PEN/Faulkner Award. But on Tuesday he finally came in first, when his novel “The City of Devi” took home the Literary Review’s annual Bad Sex in Fiction Prize.

headline: Memorial Image of Hezbollah Official Links Him to Sectarian Battle for Syria

lead_paragraph: As our colleagues Anne Barnard and Ben Hubbard report from Beirut, after the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah announced the death of a senior military official on Wednesday, a photo montage of the dead man began circulating online that connected him to the sectarian battle for control of neighboring Syria.

headline: Muscle Aches From Statins? Drug Interactions May Play a Role
abstract: Many people who take statin drugs complain of muscle pain and soreness. A new study suggests that these side effects may sometimes be a result of combining statins with other medications.
lead_paragraph: People who use statin drugs to lower their cholesterol sometimes complain of muscle pain and soreness. But a new study suggests that in some cases these side effects may be a result of combining statins with other medications.

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission fears that what has become known as “native advertising,” “paid links” or “sponsored content” can confuse consumers.

abstract: Analysts will for the first time post messages on English-language websites that jihadists use to recruit, raise money and promote their cause.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Concerned by the attempts of Al Qaeda and its global affiliates to attract more Americans and other Westerners, the State Department is stepping up its online efforts to combat violent extremists’ recruiting of English speakers.

lead_paragraph: News Corporation announced on Wednesday that Jim Kennedy, a veteran political operative who has worked closely with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton in a range of roles in the White House and elsewhere, will join the company as its chief communications officer.

headline: Kiev Protesters See Potent Ally Under a Spire
abstract: The Kyivan Patriarchate, part of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church, strongly favors European integration and is offering support, even refuge, to protesters.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — After riot police officers stormed Independence Square here early Saturday, spraying tear gas, throwing stun grenades and swinging truncheons, dozens of young protesters ran, terrified, scattering up the streets. It was after 4:30 a.m., the air cold, the sky black. As they got their bearings, the half-lit bell tower of St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery beckoned.

headline: Lawmakers in France Move to Discourage Sex Trade
abstract: The legislation approved by the lower house of Parliament would fine customers of prostitutes, an issue that has caused heated debate.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After months of heated debate, the French Parliament’s lower house on Wednesday took the first step in criminalizing the purchase of sex, approving a package of legislation to discourage prostitution.

headline: Text to Text | ‘How Photography Helps Astronomy’ and ‘Comet Nears Sun’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair an article from the Times archives about the then-cutting edge technology that allowed astronomers to photograph Halley’s comet in 1910 with a recent Times article highlighting what astronomers hope to learn about the origins of the solar system from space-based observations of Comet ISON.
lead_paragraph: What are comets, and why should we care about them? How have scientists studied them in the past, and how do they study them now? In this Text to Text, we pair an article from the Times archives about the then-cutting edge technology that allowed astronomers to photograph Halley’s comet in 1910 with a recent Times article highlighting what astronomers hope to learn about the origins of the solar system from space-based observations of Comet ISON.

headline: This Week’s Can’t-Miss Events Around Miami
abstract: If you happen to be in Miami for Art Basel or Design Miami, there are quite a few other art- and design-related attractions you should make time for.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 edition of Design Miami throws open its doors today, and Art Basel Miami Beach  follows suit tomorrow, but the city has been packed with fairgoers since Monday who have been flocking to the countless ancillary happenings. Below, a few destinations not to be missed. T will bring continuing coverage of what’s happening around Miami throughout the week, with some additional wrap reports early next week, so stay tuned, and be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram at @tmagazine for more.

headline: More Than Words Can Say
abstract: Fellow journalists took to Twitter to mourn the loss of Peter Kaplan and celebrate his life.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, Peter Kaplan, one of the greatest editors of his generation, and a name to rank among those like Gingrich, Felker and Shawn, died of cancer at the age of 59. Within hours, fellow journalists had taken to Twitter to mourn his loss and celebrate his life.

headline: Heady Days for Hair in the N.F.L.
abstract: Helmets just get in the way of style in today’s N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: It was a scene worthy of the Roman Colosseum. After stuffing a run by Arizona’s Andre Ellington in a game Nov. 17, Jacksonville defensive end Jason Babin emerged from the pile of bodies clutching a mysterious black tangle of what looked like snakes; he thrust it into the air like a victorious gladiator.

headline: Would a South Korean Lars Peter Hansen Have Won the Nobel Prize?
abstract: Do PISA scores reflect what’s good about education in the United States, or only what’s not?
lead_paragraph: Nobody (in the United States) likes the results of the PISA tests (the Program for International Student Assessment). As Motoko Rich writes elsewhere in The Times, 15-year-olds in the United States scored in the middle of the developed world in reading and science, while lagging in math, setting off “a familiar round” of hand-wringing (in the United States), blaming (ditto) and credit-taking (that would be in other, more successful countries, like South Korea, Japan and Singapore).

headline: Connecticut High School Cancels Student Production of ‘Rent’

lead_paragraph: The principal of Trumbull High School in Trumbull, Conn., has become the latest administrator to cancel a drama club production of the musical “Rent,” which deals frankly with sexuality, drug use, HIV and love in the lives of straight and gay characters.

headline: The Image Chaser
abstract: Known for his work with digital images, Pascal Dangin is stepping out onto a wider stage: fashion branding.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, when Pascal Dangin was one of the few people who knew how to retouch digital images — fixing the folds of a dress, adding more sunshine — he was something of a genie in a bottle. A former hairdresser, he had taught himself to perform a new kind of magic in a world of artifice. It brought him wealth and the top fashion photographers and art directors.

headline: Not Just for Breakfast Anymore
abstract: With a few additions, the tiny pancake is one of the easiest — and most satisfying — dishes there is.
lead_paragraph: It started simply enough: Some months ago, I needed to make myself something to eat, and I had a few ounces of leftover scallops from dinner the night before. I remembered something I learned in Madrid called a tortillita, which inspired me to produce a kind of eggy pancake — or, if you like, a floury omelet — laced with shrimp, parsley and onion. I beat together an egg and a little flour until smooth, wanting to thicken the mixture just enough so that it wouldn’t run in the pan. I chopped the scallops and added them to the batter, along with a bit of onion, some parsley, salt and chopped fresh chile, shallow-frying all this by the spoonful in abundant oil. Predictably, the little guys — eight in total — took a couple of minutes per side to become gorgeously golden. I sprinkled them with salt, squeezed a few drops of lemon over each and ate the entire batch by myself, in about the same amount of time they took to cook.

headline: Apps to Smooth Your Journey
abstract: From discovering Wi-Fi hot spots to booking last-minute hotels to finding restaurants at the next highway exit, these apps can help make travel a little easier.
lead_paragraph: Many travel apps, while great in principle, are too complicated, wonky or simply not helpful enough to earn a spot on your smartphone home screen. Some, however, can make travel easier. And who doesn’t want that during the frantic holiday season? Besides, now that smartphones can be used during takeoff and landing, there’s no time like the present to turn yours into a personal travel assistant. So whether this season’s travels take you up in the air or on the road, here are a few of my favorite apps to make the journey smoother.

headline: In Miami, a House Comes to Visit
abstract: An entire Jean Prouvé house was packed into crates and shipped to Design Miami for display.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Seguin is known for his Paris gallery, his friendship with Jean Nouvel, who designed it, and his treasure trove of 17 restored houses by Jean Prouvé. He has exhibited a house here and there, in Paris and Turin, but he has never before had his workers pack a whole Prouvé house into 10 crates and ship it to America. The 8X8 house (8 meters by 8 meters, or about 26 feet by 26 feet) is one of two 1945 Prouvé houses Mr. Seguin found in Bezaumont, France. (The other is a historical monument.) Made in a factory and easily assembled and taken apart, they were an elegant, thrifty solution to the postwar housing crisis in France. The 8X8 house is on display at Design Miami in Miami Beach through Sunday, furnished with pieces by Prouvé and Pierre Jeanneret. In Miami, it would make a high-status pool house. “No need to be a billionaire to go for one of these houses,” he said, but the price is $2.5 million. Information: patrickseguin.com.

headline: Patterns With Stories to Tell
abstract: Bisazza introduces new motifs by the Milanese designer Paola Navone.
lead_paragraph: Bisazza, a leading Italian producer of tile, is introducing two glass mosaic patterns by the Milanese designer Paola Navone, whose globally inflected style is becoming familiar to American audiences, thanks to her collaborations with Anthropologie and Crate & Barrel. For one pattern, Affresco, she translated a traditional floral design into something colorful, grainy and surrealistic, aiming to make the images look as if plaster had been peeled away to unveil frescoes beneath the surface. Halo-Halo, her black-and-white take on Pop Art and graffiti, which she describes as “perhaps pictograms by some distant civilization or a board game from an imaginary place,” is available in nine motifs that can be used in a multitude of configurations. Bisazza also introduced its first ceramic tiles, designed by Antonio Citterio, collaborating with Patricia Viel, and Marcel Wanders. Affresco is $44 to $68 a square foot; Halo-Halo is $324 a square foot. Information: 212-334-7130 or bisazza.com.

headline: Pretty, but Where’s the Kandinsky?
abstract: Madeline Weinrib remains true to the spirit, if not the letter, of the Russian artist.
lead_paragraph: Readers will be forgiven for not immediately seeing the connection between Vasily Kandinsky’s paintings and Madeline Weinrib’s new napkins for the Neue Galerie, where an exhibit of the Russian artist’s work is on view. “The idea was to collaborate, not copy Kandinsky,” Ms. Weinrib said via email from India. “I decided to reimagine one of my favorite patterns, using colors from Kandinsky’s ‘Fugue’ painting. I thought the combination of colors would complement a variety of dishes, with a modern unexpected punch.” That pattern, called Daphne, is usually hand-woven in silk Ikat. Ms. Weinrib used hand-printed cotton instead, which made possible the intricate design, as well as machine washing. A set of four napkins, one each in blue, celery, iris and navy, is $100 at the Neue Galerie Design Shop. Information: 212-628-6200, extension 496, or shop.neuegalerie.org.

headline: Classics From Midcentury Given a Second Chance
abstract: Vintage pieces repaired and resold by Stanley Furniture in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: While developing a line of midcentury-inspired products, employees of Stanley Furniture in North Carolina collected 40 of the company’s original pieces from the 1950s and ’60s by scouring sources like eBay and Craigslist. Each item was stripped down and restored to its original condition with updated paints, finishes and upholstery. Twenty-nine of the pieces — part of a group now known as the Heritage Collection — will be sold online starting Thursday at One Kings Lane. The pieces are “true to what midcentury furniture was all about: a great attention to detail, a precise design, honest materials and construction that can withstand the test of time,” said Adam Tilley, Stanley Furniture’s vice president for product. “It’s nice to see that all those things we held dear are still alive today.” The Mix’N Match Armchair is $1,199. Information: onekingslane.com.

headline: Reassessing an Uproar in Architecture
abstract: An exhibition called “Adolf Loos: Our Contemporary” examines the enigmatic architect’s enduring influence.
lead_paragraph: Adolf Loos, the enigmatic Moravian-born architect, is better known for his writings than his buildings. A century after the publication of his polemical essay “Ornament and Crime,” a Columbia University exhibition called “Adolf Loos: Our Contemporary” examines his enduring relevance. Loos provoked a furor in 1910 with the severe facade of a men’s tailoring shop and apartment block facing the imperial palace in Vienna. It became known as “the house without eyebrows” for its lack of decoration, and Emperor Franz Josef was said to have drawn his carriage curtains when he rode past. By contrast, Le Corbusier acknowledged the Modern movement’s debt to Loos, saying he “scrubbed under our feet; it was a Homeric cleansing — precise, philosophical and logical.” Yehuda E. Safran, who organized the show, had more to say about him. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: Alan Wanzenberg: A New View on Life
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Seventeen years after losing his partner in a plane crash, an architect starts over.
lead_paragraph: One was self-taught, his hungry, intuitive eye shaped by his years at Andy Warhol’s Factory, and by curating the artist’s multifarious acquisitions, creating order and beauty at Warhol’s townhouse. The other was more formally (if not quite traditionally) educated, at Berkeley, Harvard and by a fresh-out-of-grad-school job as a young architect at I. M. Pei. Together, Jed Johnson and Alan Wanzenberg formed one of the most influential design partnerships of the 1980s and early 1990s, making sensuous, modern environments for celebrity and art world heavies like Richard Gere, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall, Peter and Sandy Brant, and Beth Rudin De Woody.

headline: Mobile Payments Gain Traction Among India’s Poor
keywords: ['Mobile Commerce', 'Remittances', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']

headline: Raising Coca and Hopes in Bolivia
abstract: Marcelo Pérez del Carpio returned to the Bolivian countryside to find migrants and peasants abandoning traditional crops for the promise of quick cash with coca.
lead_paragraph: The landscape Marcelo Pérez del Carpio remembered from childhood days at his grandparents’ farm about four hours northeast of La Paz has changed over the last 20 years. Back then, the town of Challa was home to a few people who devoted themselves to agriculture. But when he returned this year, he found a boomtown that had turned its back on traditional fruit and vegetable crops, luring to its lush acres migrants intent on cultivating coca.

headline: There’s a Reason They Call Them ‘Crazy Ants’
abstract: What if you discovered an invasive species that seems drawn to electricity — in your outlets, appliances, laptops and TVs — and no one would listen?
lead_paragraph: The first time Mike the Hog-a-Nator noticed the ants, they were piled outside his cardiologist’s office. This was two summers ago, in Pearland, a suburb of Houston. There was a forbidding, fibrous heap of dead ants on either side of the building’s double doors, each a couple of feet long. And there were also legions of living ants shuffling over the dead ones — though Mike the Hog-a-Nator had to bend down to see these. Otherwise, so many individual ants were moving so chaotically, and so fast, that the entire reddish-brown tangle at his feet looked as if it were shimmering. Mike the Hog-a-Nator remembers thinking: What the world? Then he went inside for his weekly appointment.

headline: Shaking the Bitcoin Believers
abstract: China’s regulatory assault undermines the narrative that bitcoin is in the vanguard of a global shift toward new, computer-generated forms of money, writes Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews
lead_paragraph: So much for China’s willingness to tolerate financial innovation. Regulators have barred the country’s banks from trading Bitcoin, while denying the pseudo-money legal status and cracking down on anonymous users. Though China has stopped short of an outright ban, the move dashes hopes the country might allow start-up currencies to exist alongside the official renminbi.

headline: The Nashville Experiment
abstract: How the Tennessee city legalized prostitution during the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Emaline Cameron was among the thousands of refugees who poured into occupied Nashville, Tenn., in 1863. While the strains of war may have contributed to her flight from her native Smithville, about 50 miles to the east, Emaline crossed Union lines to distance herself from an imploded marriage. James Hayes, known as Toy, had divorced her on the grounds that he was not the father of their eldest child. She admitted as much in court: while growing up Emaline had worked as a chambermaid at the Smithville Hotel, which was run by her parents. After a boarder left the 15-year-old pregnant, they quickly married her off to the naïve Toy.

headline: Crossing Over to an Area We’ll Call. ...
abstract: Artists with a penchant for the surreal or nostalgic discuss the enduring appeal of “The Twilight Zone.”
lead_paragraph: When a strange little show called “The Twilight Zone” was first broadcast in 1959, the executives at CBS probably had no idea they had a game changer on their hands. The anthology of dark morality tales — with an occasional detour into brainy comedy — did well in the ratings but was canceled after five seasons. It wasn’t until the series started running in syndication at night and on weekends that its popularity soared. Shows like “The Walking Dead” and “American Horror Story” owe their popularity to its sharply written blend of horror, science fiction and thriller.

headline: Fake Artifact by an Unknown? Sold!
abstract: Bruce High Quality, an art collective that skewers art-world celebrity and astronomical prices, has gained a following among the collectors and institutions it critiques.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tick or two into an early November morning, and at a basement club in NoHo, members of the city’s most famous — and yet technically anonymous — art collective, the Bruce High Quality Foundation, are celebrating their latest lark.

headline: How Crime Declined in New York City and the U.S.
abstract: The city’s next police commissioner, William J. Bratton, managed during his first term to garner considerable acclaim for the drop in crime, even as crime was falling in many other big cities as well.
lead_paragraph: The city’s next police commissioner, William J. Bratton, managed during his first term to garner considerable acclaim for the drop in crime, even as crime was falling in many other big cities as well.

headline: 36 Hours in Kauai, Hawaii
abstract: You could fill a weekend simply staring slack-jawed at this island’s natural beauty. But Kauai’s appeal stretches far beyond those arresting views.
lead_paragraph: These days, Kauai sits firmly on the tourist radar, an indisputable rival of its famous neighbors, Oahu and Maui. But upon first glance at its unspoiled natural splendor, you’d never know it. A closer look at one of the oldest (geologically speaking) and arguably most beautiful of the major Hawaiian Islands reveals a blossoming culinary scene, a rooted arts community and a smattering of resorts. But thanks to careful regulation (by law, building heights max out at 55 feet) and a certain amount of pushback from residents (in 2007 protesters quickly quashed high-speed ferry service between Oahu and Kauai), most of the island still feels like the world’s most stunning backwater.

abstract: Rajat Gupta had accused a former longtime friend of trying to stop him from having a say over a private equity fund they started together.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a lawsuit brought by Rajat Gupta, the former managing director of the consulting giant McKinsey & Company, who had accused a former longtime friend of trying to stop him from having a say over a private equity fund they started together.

headline: A Vintage Vision for ‘Her’ (No Jeans Please)
abstract: The production designer for “Her” describes the film’s near-future setting as anti-Steve Jobs.
lead_paragraph: In the future, will we all be wearing high-waisted pants and shirts over shirts? Yes, if we live by Spike Jonze’s rules. That’s the look in his movie “Her,” a romance set in the near future that is gaining steam on the awards circuit.

headline: Reports From the Central African Republic’s ‘Darkest Days’
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: As the United Nations authorized African and French military forces to deploy to protect civilians, reporters and aid workers reported from a country descending into deeper tides of blood.
lead_paragraph: The civilian toll of the violence raging in the Central African Republic was highlighted on Thursday with multiple reports of hospitals overwhelmed by the wounded and people trying to flee to safety. The latest bout of fighting flared just before the United Nations Security Council voted to authorize African Union and French military forces to deploy to protect civilians.

headline: On the Right, It Will Always Be October
abstract: They can’t let go of Obamacare doom.
lead_paragraph: For almost two months, the debacle of healthcare.gov allowed conservatives to live the life they always wanted. Health reform was a dismal failure; Obama would go down in history as a laughingstock; government can’t do anything; viva Ayn Rand!

headline: Pope Setting Up Commission on the Sexual Abuse of Children by Priests
abstract: The announcement was a forthright acknowledgment by the Vatican of an enduring problem, and fit with Pope Francis’ pattern of willingness to set a new tone in the governance of the church.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In his first concrete step to address the clerical sexual-abuse problem in the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis will establish a commission to advise him on protecting children from pedophile priests and on how to counsel victims, the Vatican said Thursday.

headline: Private Equity and Monetary Thinking
abstract: Not going to end well.
lead_paragraph: There has been a kind of fun exchange between the think tank Third Way — which says it offers “fresh thinking”, although it looks pretty stale to me — and Elizabeth Warren. Third Way published a remarkably clumsy attack on economic populism, singling out the senator and Bill DeBlasio for special ire; Warren then raised the question of who, exactly, supports Third Way. The answer, big surprise, is Wall Street.

lead_paragraph: When I started this series on health insurance, I thought I might devote three or four posts to the subject. Instead, as I turned up surprising information, I realized that there was much more to say. This is an important and expensive purchase for a business owner, and there are great benefits to making the effort to understand how it works.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The video was undeniably silly: a 20-minute mockumentary about a fictional martial arts school in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, where grandmaster Saloom Snake trains combatants to throw sandals, strike with the thin ropes of an Arab headdress and summon help on Twitter for fights that never actually occur.

headline: The Gun Report: December 5, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the one-year anniversary of the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary, USA Today has published an interactive about mass killing in America called “Behind the Bloodshed.” Examining F.B.I. data, which defines a mass killing as four or more victims, a team of reporters found that since 2006, there have been more than 200 mass killings in the U.S. They also found that such massacres occur far more often than the government reports.

Mulally, Ford’s chief executive, spoke at the New York opening, noting that it was here, at the 1964 World’s Fair, that the Mustang was first introduced to an enthusiastic public.

headline: Marin Mazzie to Star in ‘Bullets Over Broadway’
abstract: Ms. Mazzie will play the role of the diva Helen Sinclair in the stage adaptation of Woody Allen’s 1994 film.
lead_paragraph: “Go, gentle Scorpio, go — your Pisces wishes you every happy return,” cooed Helen Sinclair, the self-dramatizing diva who had all the best lines in Woody Allen’s 1994 period comedy “Bullets Over Broadway.” Dianne Wiest won a supporting actress Academy Award as the aging Helen, and the character is once again generating buzz as a musical adaptation of “Bullets” prepares to start performances on Broadway this spring. The front-runner for the role has been an open secret for months — “don’t speak!” as Helen would say — but the producers finally confirmed on Thursday that, indeed, three-time Tony Award nominee Marin Mazzie would star as Helen.

headline: An Actress in a Different Take-Charge Role
abstract: Phylicia Rashad, who played Clair Huxtable in “The Cosby Show,” said she liked being a director because she can “hold a vision and galvanize all of the creative energies involved.”
lead_paragraph: If you ask most actors or directors why they love a particular writer’s work, they will give you blandly polite answers, cryptic answers or, if you’re really lucky, somewhat thoughtful answers. Ask Phylicia Rashad about August Wilson, whose Pulitzer Prize winner “Fences” she is directing at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven this month, and she pours forth like the daughter of a poet (Vivian Ayers) that she is.

headline: Your Questions Answered (and Your Actress Nods Wanted)

lead_paragraph: Loyal readers and commenters here in Baggerland have been wondering about the late-breaking additions to the awards melee, like “American Hustle” and “Wolf of Wall Street,” films that have yet to be released. Do the critics groups, voters and other all-important prognosticators get a chance to see them on the big screen before they make their pronouncements about what they liked best this year?

headline: Living With Cancer: Nude Mice
abstract: To know or not to know? Each person in my support group realizes that we remain defenseless against the information we seek or avoid, writes Susan Gubar in her Living with Cancer column.
lead_paragraph: A tense moment at a meeting of my support group convinced me that cancer patients have wildly divergent needs for information about their condition. This is especially true when the disease is considered chronic, rather than curable.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey,’ the Long Island Version
abstract: An exhibition about mansions and millionaires and the servants they employed on the East End of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Among the most noticeable residents of Southampton in the early 1900s was Samuel Longstreth Parrish, a local benefactor who donated the land for Southampton’s hospital, helped establish its library and founded its art museum. His former home, headquarters of the Southampton Historical Museum, is now the setting for “Downton Abbey Style in Southampton: 1900 to 1920,” an exhibition about mansions and millionaires and their many servants.

headline: Aficionados on Walkabout at Art Basel Miami Beach
abstract: For 13 years, Dennis and Debra Scholl have invited a guest curator to select works from their collection for display in their home.
lead_paragraph: And then on the second day, they had brunch. After the frenzied opening hours of the Art Basel art fair in Miami, ambitious shoppers and browsers ambled into Thursday a bit more leisurely, taking in coffee and bagels with their art at the homes of some of Miami’s top collectors. Dennis Scholl, a vice-president at the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, and his wife, Debra, have donated 300 works to the newly christened Pérez Art Museum Miami. But they still had plenty left to show off at their terraced apartment, which sits a stone’s throw from the convention center, home base for the fair.

headline: Two Remaining Rebel States
abstract: Georgia and Mississippi refuse to accept the post-DOMA reality.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a day (sometimes) makes.  On Tuesday, I reported here that three states — Mississippi, Georgia and Louisiana — were still refusing to comply with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s order issued in August that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given spousal and family benefits. That was down from eight states as of mid-November that were refusing to process applications for benefits at Guard facilities, or issue identification cards required to claim benefits, including medical services on the Guard member’s home base.

headline: Old Enough at Heart
abstract: Addressing matters of being young at the theater, charitable donations as gifts, meeting online friends in person and when jokes stop the laughter.
lead_paragraph: I am a seventh grader in New York City, and I love going to the theater, especially with my friends. Now that I can no longer buy under-12 tickets, mine cost just as much as everyone else’s in the theater, but I am still treated like a child who can’t behave. How should I respond when anxious ushers tell me not to kick the seats in front of me before I’m even seated? Or when adults warn me that taking pictures is not allowed, which everyone knows? I don’t want to whine (like a child), but I don’t want to be patronized, either. Any suggestions?

headline: Rough Trade NYC Puts Live Music On Hold
abstract: The record store, which opened two weeks ago, has canceled or moved its scheduled live performances to improve its soundproofing.
lead_paragraph: Rough Trade NYC, the record store and live music club that opened last week in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has canceled shows in its performance space, apparently to improve its soundproofing after noise complaints, the store announced Thursday.

headline: Kozlowski’s New Job: Software Company Clerk
abstract: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the onetime chief executive of Tyco International, has a clerical job as part of a work-release program.
lead_paragraph: L. Dennis Kozlowski was once a high-flying chief executive, perched atop Tyco International.

headline: On Other Side of Country, a Lesson in Chemistry
abstract: A team that won only 33 games last season is now a test tube in proving that putting the right combination of players on the court leads to success.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — While everyone in the East is trying to figure out what is going so sideways with the Knicks and the Nets, the West is puzzling over how the Portland Trail Blazers, who won 33 games last season, are off to a 16-3 start, the best in the conference. If there was any question that their start was a fluke, the Blazers answered by dealing the Indiana Pacers their second loss of the season on Monday and outgunning the Oklahoma City Thunder, 111-104, on Wednesday.

headline: Tapas, and More, by Brothers From Spain
abstract: Sangria 71’s popularity is understandable because of its delicious food, speedy service (if a bit ragged on the weekend) and reasonable prices. But first diners need to find a table.
lead_paragraph: When Sangria 71 opened in early September, it took Williston Park by storm, and the deluge of patrons continues. On a recent Tuesday night (an off night at most restaurants), Sangria 71 was packed. A man at a table near the center of the room complained, “I feel like I’m in the middle of the New York City Marathon.” He was talking about the swarm of waiters whizzing by, trying to keep up with the crowd of customers.

headline: Take Your Best Voice to the Singalong at BAMcafé
abstract: The actor and comedian Harry Shearer and his wife, the singer-songwriter Judith Owen, bring their “Holiday Sing-Along” tour to BAMcafé.
lead_paragraph: Millions know the actor and comedian Harry Shearer as the voice of multiple characters on “The Simpsons”; still others recognize his work on “Saturday Night Live” or “Le Show” on NPR. For the Miser, however, none of those achievements compares with his tour de force performance as Derek Smalls, the hapless bass player for the heavy-metal outfit in “This Is Spinal Tap,” Rob Reiner’s wildly influential 1984 mockumentary.

headline: New Zealand Vampires and Nazi Zombies at Sundance
abstract: Sundance announces the lineups in other sections, including the midnight and children’s categories.
lead_paragraph: “A feral swarm of mass savages.”

lead_paragraph: The New York art world’s attitude toward New Jersey has not changed much since the art critic Ted Castle wrote in 1978, “New Jersey is practically not a place.”

lead_paragraph: Inside the Hell’s Kitchen Thai restaurant where the focus is on the food.

headline: Awaiting Worst Storm Surge in 60 Years, Britain Closes Thames Barrier
abstract: Meteorologists warn Britain and northern Europe to prepare for the worst storm in years.
lead_paragraph: As Britain braced for the worst tidal surge in more than half a century, the massive steel barriers that protect London were being shut to save the capital from the possibility of deadly and damaging floods.

headline: 3 Concert Halls Complement and Compete
abstract: The Capitol Theater, the Paramount Hudson Valley and the Tarrytown Music Hall differ in draws for acts and audiences.
lead_paragraph: Still riding a wave of popularity after 50 years of touring, the Beach Boys are very likely to sell out both shows they have booked at the Tarrytown Music Hall on Dec. 14, according to Bjorn Olsson, the hall’s executive director.

headline: Afghan Policewoman Is Killed, Fourth in Last Six Months
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The officer was shot by gunmen on a motorcycle as she was dropping off relatives at school. Three others were wounded, including her daughter.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two gunmen on a motorcycle shot and killed a policewoman in western Afghanistan on Thursday, wounding her daughter and two other family members who were with her. It was the fourth killing of an Afghan policewoman in the last six months.

headline: And You Thought You Knew Thai
abstract: Larb Ubol presents the plain-spoken food of the Isan region of Thailand, which is underrepresented in New York.
lead_paragraph: To a passer-by, there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad Thai joints that are its neighbors in Hell’s Kitchen.

headline: Gym or Dance Floor? Either Works
abstract: A K-pop dance class proves to be both a workout and an introduction to a Korean cultural craze.
lead_paragraph: EVER since I got a C+ in a modern-dance class in college — despite my sincerest effort — I have been keenly aware that I am no dancer. Attempts over the years to learn other forms, including hip-hop and salsa, confirmed this. Yet I stubbornly persist. So when I learned about a K-pop dance class, I decided to give it a whirl.

headline: Casing the Greenwich Village Exteriors of ‘Inside Llewyn Davis’
abstract: To recreate New York of the 1960s, only certain places, shot at certain angles, can still serve.
lead_paragraph: In order to recreate the look of Greenwich Village in the early 1960s for their new movie, “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers filmed on real streets in present-day New York, installing props and adjusting the camera’s lens in ways that made the environment seem true to the time period. As the magazine’s culture editor Adam Sternbergh writes in this weekend’s magazine, finding the right location for each shot was crucial (the filmmakers avoided using special effects).

headline: A Warhol Is Said to Be Bought by a Walton
abstract: Alice Walton is said to have purchased a Warhol during the fall auctions; a MoMA exhibition focuses on studio photography.
lead_paragraph: As the dust settles after last month’s enormous fall auction season, it remains a mystery who bought Francis Bacon’s “Three Studies of Lucian Freud,” for $142.4 million, and Andy Warhol’s “Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster)” for $104.5 million.

headline: Too Late to Book a Holiday Getaway? Not Necessarily
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: If you want to make a last-minute escape to a warm-weather destination, you can still find deals — you just may need to work for them.
lead_paragraph: We’re into December, when last-minute planners from New York and other scarf-wearing regions start dreaming of spending Christmas break on a Caribbean beach somewhere, anywhere. Or, to put it more accurately, dream of having had the foresight to plan such a trip in August, when prices — both flights and hotel rooms — were still reasonable. Conventional wisdom has it that booking now for a late December getaway is a fool’s errand, and a rich fool at that.

headline: Old World Butchers, Preserving Traditions at the Holidays
abstract: At Christmas, meat shops find turkey takes a back seat to ham, prime rib and kielbasa for holiday dinners.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of Italian-Americans, David Perrotti enjoys the Feast of the Seven Fishes on Christmas Eve. But for Mr. Perrotti, 66, of Martinsville, the annual seafood extravaganza is not just a way to preserve tradition. It is also a night off from worrying about the centerpiece of a holiday dinner. Scores of dinners, actually.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Cassina x Louis Vuitton Chaise Longue
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a luxury lounger for the fashionable set.

headline: High Body Mass Linked to Hearing Loss in Women
abstract: Controlling for multiple factors in a 20-year study, researchers found that high body mass and a large waist were both associated with self-reported hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: A high body mass and a large waist are both associated with self-reported hearing loss, a new study has found.

headline: Antiques Stores Fall to Online Offerings
abstract: Vanishing antiques shops, reappearing Frank Lloyd Wright stained-glass windows, and newly digitized in-house publications from the archives of decorative arts institutions.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan antiques shops founded decades ago are vanishing at an alarming rate, unable to compete with online offerings. No trace remains of Elliott Galleries’ presence on East 79th Street; its white marble storefront has been razed. Yale R. Burge Antiques, on East 62nd Street, is closing and will auction inventory at Doyle New York in January. The former home of Cove Landing, on Lexington Avenue, has sat empty while the proprietor, Angus Wilkie, tucks inventory into his apartment storage spaces and organizes short-term displays at the W. M. Brady gallery on East 80th Street.

headline: Where Babysitting Is Truly an Art
abstract: They are called “artsitters” — ballerinas and Shakespearean actors, sculptors and opera singers — who look after other people’s children very creatively.
lead_paragraph: LET grown-ups have their personal chefs, personal shoppers and personal pilots. For waist-high tykes like Andrew Wang, 5 and fizzy, New York now offers something better: the personal artist, rentable by the hour as babysitter.

headline: Deal Lawyer Joins Willkie
abstract: Kirk A. Radke, known for his work on private equity deals, is moving to Willkie Farr & Gallagher after a long tenure at Kirkland & Ellis.
lead_paragraph: For decades, attorney Kirk A. Radke has worked behind the scenes helping to arrange private equity deals. Now the noted corporate lawyer is pulling off a deal for himself with a move to law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher after a long tenure at Kirkland & Ellis, another large law firm.

headline: David Salle: ‘Ghost Paintings’
abstract: It’s hard to envision paintings more perfect for our performance-mad time than the ones in “David Salle: Ghost Paintings.”
lead_paragraph: Skarstedt

headline: Jan Tichy: ‘Politics of Light’
abstract: Mr. Tichy’s works may be “political,” but it is a politics couched in aestheticizing the travails of others.

headline: A Poet Who Pushed (and Recycled) the Envelope

lead_paragraph: Like many a Connecticut Valley puritan, Emily Dickinson was practical, inventive and private. Dismissing the commercial marketing of poetry as an “auction of the mind,” she pioneered a very personal version of desktop publishing, creating 40 handwritten, stitch-bound volumes of her own poetry, each in an edition of one.

headline: Funny Lady
abstract: This collection of Nora Ephron’s writings includes the novel “Heartburn,” scripts for “When Harry Met Sally . . . ” and “Lucky Guy,” and more.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when Nora Ephron was frequently compared to Dorothy Parker, even by Nora Ephron. (“All I wanted in this world was to come to New York and be Dorothy Parker. The funny lady. The only lady at the table. The woman who made her living by her wit.”) I believe we have all gotten over that. As Ephron herself figured out long ago, the idea of Dorothy Parker was far superior to the living version, who was good with a one-liner but not much fun to be around. The real Nora Ephron was the person every­body wanted to hang out with, in part because she was funny and charming but more critically because she made the people she was with feel funny and charming. (I certainly wanted to hang around her, and we were friends for years.) She was never the life of the party in the classic center-of-the-crowd sense. She was the one who listened and then finally tossed in the one fabulous line that brought every­thing together. Her best writing was exactly the same.

As a director, though — notably of “Don’t Move” (2005) and now “Twice Born,” both starring Penélope Cruz — he seems to go out of his way to discourage precisely that quality. A throbbing melodrama set partly during the Balkan wars of the early 1990s (and based on a novel by Margaret Mazzantini, Mr. Castellitto’s wife), “Twice Born” generously allows each member of its talented, cosmopolitan cast an opportunity to howl and scream and tremble and generally overdo it.

headline: Statesman, Dandy, Flirt
abstract: Memories of Nelson Mandela by Suzanne Daley, who was Johannesburg bureau chief from 1995 to 1999.
lead_paragraph: As president, Nelson Mandela had so many requests for interviews that he frequently met with journalists in groups of three or four — often at 7 a.m. too, because he got up early. He never allotted much time for questions, sometimes just half an hour, and his temper flared easily, so watch out. In many ways, he was more a chief statesman than the head of a government. He didn’t like defending — or talking about — policy. And he had no patience for critics.

headline: (Almost) Meeting Mandela

At the end, everyone got in line to shake his hand as he exited. Normally, I don’t buddy up to important people — I think it’s compromising. But this time I was telling myself off: “Oh, for Christ’s sake, Donald, stop being such a prig. It’s Madiba, he’s a living saint, and he’s 80 years old. He’s not going to be around much longer. Get in line and shake his hand.”

headline: The Making Of | A Wardrobe Fitting for Joseph Altuzarra’s Fictional Leading Lady
abstract: The designer opened up his New York studio on the eve of his prefall presentation to share his personal inspirations and how it all came together.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Joseph Altuzarra was hard at work in his New York studio, putting the finishing touches on the prefall 2014 looks he began designing in September, right after his spring/summer 2014 runway. For this fifth anniversary collection, which hits stores in May 2014, the newly engaged designer is looking back to move forward. “In the past couple of years we were really developing the brand around this kind of woman,” says Altuzarra about his imaginary muse, who balances French sensuality with effortless American style. “I think it is a powerful thing to look at a show and have it superdesirable and have it superwearable.” To achieve that balance this time around, his nearly 80 designs are fraught with layers of contrast. Body-hugging sheath dresses are understatedly sexy thanks to preppy madras fabric. Innocent, collegiate-striped skirts have dangerously high slits, an Altuzarra signature. The resurfacing of his other popular standbys — cropped peacoats, oxford shirt dresses, simple knits and soft, draped cocktail dresses — round out the collection so that it essentially becomes a complete wardrobe for the Altuzarra woman. Here, a look at just who that is, along with a behind-the-scenes look at how it all come together.

The film’s protagonist, Gili (Sivan Levy), is a wide-eyed, flirtatious high school student whose family recently moved to an upscale neighborhood in Tel Aviv, which could stand for any affluent city where bored, sexed-up youths communicate via smartphone. headline: Good Samaritan Ensnared in a Web With No Exit

lead_paragraph: “Swerve,” a would-be thriller set in the Australian outback, throws a handful of familiar genre bits at the screen, including a very bad man, a menacing husband, a wily wife, a rootless stranger and a chunk of change. Certainly there’s promise in the setting, which with its swaths of desert and roads to nowhere evokes the violent sun-scorched world of “Red Rock West,” John Dahl’s 1993 cowboy noir about a chunk of change, a rootless stranger, a wily wife, a menacing husband and a very bad man. Yet to say that the films have similar parts is about as meaningful as pointing out that a 1970 Pontiac G.T.O. and a 1971 Ford Pinto both have internal combustion engines, when only one is worth the ride.

headline: In Pursuit of New Flights, and Reaching Beyond Soft Landings
abstract: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater paired its landmark “Revelations” with the British choreographer Wayne McGregor’s stark, explosive “Chroma” at City Center on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which has sometimes been criticized for having a showbiz sensibility and living in the past, continued its slow, steady rebirth under the artistic direction of Robert Battle on Wednesday. While the Ailey company knows how to cater to audiences, a more gratifying truth has emerged: The dancers are also generous with choreographers. Life outside of “Revelations” is within their grasp.

headline: East River Views, Boat Parking, Bar on Premises
abstract: The Campanile, like the more famous River House, came complete with yacht club.
lead_paragraph: River House, the majestic 1931 co-op tower at the north corner of the East River and 52nd Street, is taking the unusual step of offering the River Club complex on its lower floors as a $130 million apartment, which would close one of the most luxurious clubs in New York.

headline: Continental Flair, With an Aggressive Edge
abstract: Mike Levy, who records under the name Gesaffelstein, brought musical worlds together on Tuesday at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: The shtick is simple, as obvious as they come: handsome guy in a well-cut suit with pompadour held aloft by ample hair product, standing on an elevated platform behind D.J. gear and shaking vigorously to the music he’s playing. A little visual dissonance goes a long way.

headline: An Architecture Grounded in Opposing Forces
abstract: The bassist Ben Allison played songs from his latest album, “The Stars Look Very Different Today,” with his quartet at Joe’s Pub.
lead_paragraph: When people say that the frame of jazz is flexible enough to admit pretty much anything, they might be thinking of bandleaders like the bassist Ben Allison. But if they’re thinking specifically about him, they’re not defining flexibility only as real-time freedom and permissiveness; they’re thinking of structure and design.

headline: Ecological Shifts Spell Challenges for the Pecos River
abstract: The Pecos River has few public access points and has avoided problems from development, but it has not been spared from gradual ecological changes.
lead_paragraph: In the final 100 miles of the Pecos River, as it journeys south through far West Texas to empty into the Rio Grande, there is one public access point.

headline: Parting the Waters of the Exodus Story
abstract: In his latest work, “Moses(es),” Reggie Wilson draws from Zora Neale Hurston’s “Moses, Man of the Mountains” and his own travels to Israel, Egypt and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Reggie Wilson often finds the ideas for his dances while on a journey. Like an anthropologist, he conducts field research, traveling to places that interest him. Ideas lead to other ideas and accumulate in clusters before he translates them into sensual, structurally complex performances. So it’s a nice joke that near the start of “Moses(es),” a thrilling work that had its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater on Wednesday, Mr. Wilson comes upon a huge pile of tinsel that he methodically stuffs into a red wheelie suitcase. He gets it all in.

headline: The Singer’s Bohemia, and His New Legal Practice
abstract: In “Live at the Foxes Den,” Jackson Rathbone of the “Twilight” movies plays a lawyer who quits his job to sing in a run-down club.
lead_paragraph: Jackson Rathbone, Jasper from the “Twilight” movies, has a pretty good singing voice, and he shows it off in “Live at the Foxes Den,” a slight movie that could have been significantly better with a little story doctoring.

headline: Coal in Your Stocking? How About a Murderer in Your B&B?
abstract: “Merry Christmas” has actors improvising a murder mystery tale set in a bed-and-breakfast.
lead_paragraph: One of those who’s-the-murderer parlor games is a plot pillar of “Merry Christmas,” an experiment in filmmaking by Anna Condo that itself feels like a parlor game, and not a particularly entertaining one.

headline: The Insider | Thea Westreich on What Not to Miss at Art Basel in Miami Beach
abstract: The art adviser shares her tips on essential booths to visit at the fair this weekend, which are well worth paying attention to even if you’re not in Miami Beach right now.
lead_paragraph: If anyone should have a polished game plan for how to tackle the opening of an art fair, it’s an art adviser, whose entire professional livelihood is constructed around building collections for private clients. The wife-and-husband duo of Thea Westreich and Ethan Wagner have spent more than 30 years working, as Thea Westreich Art Advisory Services, on behalf of some of the world’s most intrepid collectors, often establishing markets of new and challenging genres, like living-room-unfriendly video art. They are also big collectors themselves, not only of art but also of books: the library in their SoHo loft has more than 13,000 volumes by and about artists.

headline: Remembering Composers Lost to AIDS
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: An annual tribute is the subject of the documentary “All the Way Through Evening.”
lead_paragraph: Seeking a bittersweet rhyme between vocal performances and talking-head recollections, “All the Way Through Evening” is a very modest memorial to New York City musicians cut down by AIDS in the 1980s and early 1990s.

headline: The N.B.A. Prospect, After the Chance Is Gone
abstract: The documentary “Lenny Cooke” traces the title figure, a basketball star whose supposed destiny never came to pass.
lead_paragraph: If history is often written by the victors, “Lenny Cooke” suggests that there might be a certain mercy to fading from view. With the benefit of hindsight, and with a bonanza of documentary footage shot by someone else, the brothers Josh and Benny Safdie relate the cautionary tale of Lenny Cooke, basketball phenomenon turned ordinary person. Like ghostly chroniclers hovering near, they show Mr. Cooke during his rise as a high school prodigy in the early 2000s up through his spectacular snub at the 2002 N.B.A. draft and beyond.

abstract: State Attorney William N. Meggs of Florida announced that prosecutors would no longer pursue charges against Jameis Winston, the starting quarterback at Florida State.
lead_paragraph: State Attorney William N. Meggs of Florida announced that prosecutors would no longer pursue charges against Jameis Winston, the starting quarterback at Florida State.

headline: The Puzzle of a Past
abstract: A young man’s trauma is the mystery of “Implanted,” a first feature from Thomas Verrette.
lead_paragraph: “Implanted” is an ambitious first feature from Thomas Verrette about Ethan, a young man trying to recover lost memories while being treated by his father, a doctor. It’s part medical science fiction and part puzzle film. Ethan’s fragmented self-narrative is linked to its traumatic cause, so solving the mystery at the center of the film is satisfying. This is not the case in some puzzle films (“Memento,” “Upstream Color”), in which an elaborate construction distracts from a standard crime or romance plot at the core.

headline: Treating Allergies With Pills or Drops Instead of Shots
abstract: Two companies are asking the Food and Drug Administration for approval to market tablets or liquids to treat allergies, drugs which are already available in Europe.
lead_paragraph: For much of her adult life, Shirley Hickey received two injections a week in an effort to tame severe allergies that caused frequent sore throats and sinus infections. Now she uses a less painful method.

headline: The Ecological Davy Jones’s Locker
abstract: Ocean acidification is but one of the daunting problems facing the oceans, scientists warn in the documentary “Revolution.”
lead_paragraph: The remorseless march of extinction — including our own — is captured with chilling clarity in “Revolution,” Rob Stewart’s unapologetically partisan argument against fossil fuels and fossilized thinking.

headline: After Great Loss, a Sexual Feeling Comes
abstract: As Christmas approaches, a woman manages mourning through experimentation.
lead_paragraph: Holiday movies don’t come much stranger than Zach Clark’s “White Reindeer,” a cool, kinky tale of sudden bereavement, sexual adventure and hard-won hope.

lead_paragraph: The Fox News Channel has long been described as insular and buttoned up, a reputation that has been reaffirmed in recent days over the question of whether it has reached a settlement with Brian Lewis, the former longtime chief spokesman for and close adviser to Roger Ailes.

lead_paragraph: Korea’s bifurcated identity takes center stage in “Commitment,” a combination action thriller and love story that places a conflicted teenage spy between the demands of the state and the dictates of his heart.

headline: A Zebra of a Different Color, or Another Pattern
abstract: The animated “Khumba” tells a tale of outcasts, including a South African zebra who’s striped on only half of his body.
lead_paragraph: “Khumba,” the second feature from the South African animation studio Triggerfish, is a wondrous and slightly deranged story about oddballs embracing their differences. The titular young hero is a South African zebra who is born half-white in a gated community of chicly striped peers. The superstitious zebras conclude that Khumba is the cause of the drought that follows his birth. For them, no stripes mean no rain.

lead_paragraph: Outbreaks of bacterial meningitis have struck two college campuses, though health officials say the episodes — one on the East Coast, the other on the West Coast — are apparently unrelated.

abstract: The Chinese guitarist Xuefei Yang performed works by Chen Yi and John Dowland at SubCulture on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The growth of Western classical music in China has been remarkable, with a number of notable instrumentalists emerging in recent years. Xuefei Yang, 36, is said to have been the first guitar major at the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing and the first Chinese guitarist with a significant international career.

Some of the whales beached themselves and died, while others appeared destined for the same fate despite rescuers’ efforts.

headline: Vowing to Slay the (Already Subdued) Stop-and-Frisk Dragon
abstract: In announcing that William J. Bratton would be the police commissioner come January, Bill de Blasio promised that he would succeed in changing stop-and-frisk policing.
lead_paragraph: Standing next to the next police commissioner on Thursday morning, Bill de Blasio promised that he would bring an end to “stop-and-frisk as we knew it.”

lead_paragraph: For days, Jon Horvath has testified at the insider trading trial of his former boss, a onetime top hedge fund executive, that he was pressured to obtain confidential corporate information to do his job.

abstract: The coalition is trying to marginalize a group that contends that the liberalism of leaders like Senator Elizabeth Warren will lead Democrats “over the populist cliff.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a sign of the left’s new aggressiveness, a coalition of liberals is trying to marginalize a centrist Democratic policy group that was responsible for a Wall Street Journal op-ed article this week that said economic populism was “disastrous” for the party.

headline: Sister Mary Nerney, Advocate for Women in Prison, Dies at 75
abstract: Sister Mary founded an organization that helps women imprisoned for killing their batterers, as well as a program to teach female ex-convicts construction trades.
lead_paragraph: Sister Mary Nerney, a Roman Catholic nun who was a nationally known advocate for female convicts, in particular those who were survivors of domestic violence, died on Nov. 27 in Manhattan. She was 75.

headline: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Attacks Convoy in the North
abstract: A suicide car bomber struck a security force’s convoy on Thursday in northern Somalia, killing at least seven people and wounding 37.
lead_paragraph: A suicide car bomber struck a security force’s convoy on Thursday in northern Somalia, killing at least seven people and wounding 37, local officials and witnesses said. The convoy, which was attacked in the town of Boosaaso in the semiautonomous region of Puntland, included members of the Puntland Marine Forces and two foreigners who were training the local security forces. Details about the casualties were not immediately available, and no group claimed responsibility after the explosion. President Hassan Sheik Mohamud of Somalia condemned the attack, saying that “terrorists have lost the war on the battlefield and are now devoting all their efforts in harming innocent civilians.” The Shabab rebel movement has been waging an insurgency for years to impose a strict interpretation of Islamic law in Somalia, but Puntland has been relatively peaceful compared with other parts of the country.

headline: Picture Book Will Preside With Bratton
abstract: Little-known and long out of print, the children’s book “Your Police” was discovered by William J. Bratton in a library when he was a boy.
lead_paragraph: If there was an unexpected star at the news conference on Thursday announcing that William J. Bratton would be New York City’s next police commissioner, it was a faded yellow copy of “Your Police,” a children’s picture book published in 1956, that Mr. Bratton tenderly held in his hands.

headline: Obama Gets Real
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: With a big inequality speech, the president is finally sounding like the progressive many of his supporters thought they were backing in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Much of the media commentary on President Obama’s big inequality speech was cynical. You know the drill: it’s yet another “reboot” that will go nowhere; none of it will have any effect on policy, and so on. But before we talk about the speech’s possible political impact or lack thereof, shouldn’t we look at the substance? Was what the president said true? Was it new? If the answer to these questions is yes — and it is — then what he said deserves a serious hearing.

headline: Christopher Evan Welch, 48, a Versatile, Busy Actor, Dies
abstract: Mr. Welch’s New York debut in “Scapin” led to many roles on New York stages, as well as high-profile film work.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Evan Welch, an in-demand character actor who appeared in everything from Shakespeare to “The Sopranos,” including films by Woody Allen, Steven Spielberg and Charlie Kaufman, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 48.

headline: The Irony of Despair
abstract: The rise in suicide rates prompts a sober confrontation of old and new questions around the will to overcome.
lead_paragraph: We’ve made some progress in understanding mental illnesses over the past few decades, and even come up with drugs to help ameliorate their effects. But we have not made any headway against suicide.

headline: Heroines at the Box Office
abstract: The success of “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” and “Frozen” should put to rest the assumption that audiences don’t want to see female-centric action stories.
lead_paragraph: The two most popular movies in America have something in common: they feature female protagonists. Jennifer Lawrence plays Katniss Everdeen in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” which took in $110.1 million over the long Thanksgiving weekend. Kristen Bell is the voice of Princess Anna in “Frozen,” which grossed $93 million over the same period.

headline: Saying Farewell, Mayor Delivers a Rare Display of Public Emotion
abstract: In his first major goodbye speech, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg highlighted what he said were the quintessential New York values that animated his mayoralty.
lead_paragraph: The voice of the man behind the microphone quivered, at first imperceptibly.

headline: Families See Colorado as New Frontier on Medical Marijuana
abstract: More families are migrating to the cannabis-friendly state because of the promise of a marijuana-based oil known as Charlotte’s Web to treat their children’s seizures.
lead_paragraph: FOUNTAIN, Colo. — As their children cooed from wheelchairs and rocked softly in their arms, the marijuana migrants of Colorado clasped hands, bowed their heads and said a prayer of cautious thanks.

headline: The Devils’ Succession Plan Appears Back on Track
abstract: After a poor start with little offensive support, Devils goalie Cory Schneider, an off-season acquisition, has begun once again to look like Martin Brodeur’s heir apparent.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Cory Schneider’s first three months in New Jersey have been quite a roller-coaster ride.

headline: Bratton Is Expected to Reshape Police to Rebuild Relationship With Public
abstract: The incoming New York police commissioner, William J. Bratton, is said to be planning significant changes in personnel, priorities and how the department is organized and run.
lead_paragraph: The incoming New York police commissioner, William J. Bratton, provided few details on Thursday about his plans for his second stint running the nation’s largest police force, but people familiar with his thinking said there would be significant changes in personnel, priorities and how the department is organized and run.

headline: Money to Fight Global Diseases
abstract: Other nations have failed to pledge enough to take full advantage of a generous American offer to give $1 for every $2 donated.
lead_paragraph: Donor nations have pledged $12 billion over the next three years to a global fund that finances programs to curb three devastating infectious diseases in mostly poor or low-income countries. The amount falls short of the $15 billion goal set by the fund’s leaders, but it is, nevertheless, a vote of confidence in the programs at a time when many nations face fiscal constraints.
