abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The de Blasio Team Takes Shape
abstract: The mayor-elect made two solid appointments: Anthony Shorris as first deputy mayor and William Bratton as New York police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio, who has promised a new vision for New York, has appointed two familiar, seasoned veterans to help him manage the nation’s largest city government.

headline: Obama’s Path Was Shaped by Mandela’s Story
abstract: President Obama recalled that his public career began at an anti-apartheid rally in 1979, imbued with the hope Nelson Mandela had generated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Without Nelson Mandela, there might never have been a President Obama.

headline: One or More Spins Before Feasting
abstract: Laura R. Walker, president of New York Public Radio, begins her day with a round of biking, aqua cycling or spinning, and continues with enthusiastic eating.
lead_paragraph: As president and chief executive of New York Public Radio, Laura R. Walker, 56, oversees metropolitan area stations including WNYC, WQXR and New Jersey Public Radio. The organization produces more than 375 hours of programming each week, including “Radiolab,”  “Freakonomics Radio” and “Studio 360.” She lives in Brooklyn Heights with her husband, Bert Wells, 56, a lawyer, their 14-year-old daughter, Claire, and their cockapoo, Aki. Their son, Evan, 22, is a senior at Yale and often comes home for the weekend because he is writing his senior thesis on the 9/11 museum.

abstract: The Bronx Spanish Evangelical Church is feeding more people than ever in one of the nation’s poorest communities.
lead_paragraph: The food line started before light outside the stone church with red doors in the South Bronx on a recent Friday. There were grim-faced old men next to weary mothers with children and Spanish-speaking immigrants with handcarts and milk crates.

headline: A Pioneer of Rap Music Craves 9-to-5 Stability
abstract: Lamar Hill and two friends recorded some of the first hip-hop records as the Treacherous Three. Today, he is searching for full-time work.
lead_paragraph: Lamar Hill began his first career on a central Harlem street corner, in the pre-MTV days of boomboxes and mix tapes. He and two pals, calling themselves Kool Moe Dee and Special K, recorded some of the earliest hip-hop records as the Treacherous Three. abstract: Laws passed by the City Council have sought to restrict prisoner transfer agreements with federal authorities, prompting guarded celebration among immigrants’ advocates.

headline: What’s On Friday

(Sundance) VANILLA SKY (2001) David Aames (Tom Cruise), a 33-year-old master of the universe, finds his life upended after a car crash in Cameron Crowe’s erotic science-fiction adaptation of “Abre los Ojos,” Alejandro Amenábar’s Spanish romantic thriller. Cameron Diaz plays Julie Gianni, the latest plaything in David’s endless succession of beautiful women. Penélope Cruz (above, with Mr. Cruise), who starred in Mr. Amenábar’s original, is Sofia Serrano, whom Julie discovers David flirting with at the birthday party he neglected to invite her to. And suddenly the simple offer of a ride the next morning becomes a suicide leap as Julie drives her car off a bridge, leaving her dead and David condemned to wearing a latex mask. “With its roller-coaster plot and surreal special effects, ‘Vanilla Sky’ is not the kind of film one associates with Mr. Crowe,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The most warmhearted of mainstream Hollywood directors, Mr. Crowe has in the past extended to his characters the affection of an unusually careful and sympathetic listener.” In this film, “that ear is not as sharp,” he continued. “Still, the movie carries a lingering tug of sweetness, most apparent in the film’s heady soundtrack,” which “evokes the dream of eternal youth that infuses ‘Vanilla Sky.’ ”

headline: A Flight Diversion

lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — I was woken by the pilot’s voice. In the drowsy hum of the airplane, his words crackled, and I thought I heard something about preparing to land. Could I have slept so long? I looked at the time. It was only three hours into the Lagos-to-Atlanta flight. The flight attendants were hurrying back and forth. The pilot was still speaking. “We have an emergency onboard, and we have had to divert the flight to Dakar.” I could feel the plane descending. It seemed too fast. A sweeping hollowness. My fog of sleep cleared instantly. Something was wrong, the pilot was too cryptic, the flight attendants too blank-faced, snatching up cups, urging seats straight. I thought: If I die, I hope it’s quick and I don’t know.

abstract: Dana Rotberg, the Mexican director of New Zealand’s submission for the Oscar, explains how she came to make a film in Maori.
lead_paragraph: The director Dana Rotberg came to make “White Lies,” New Zealand’s entry in the competition for the best foreign-language film Oscar, by a circuitous and unlikely route. A Jewish-Mexican, she spent part of the 1990s in Sarajevo, then returned home to Mexico City as the mother of a young child, only to find her own country in a spiral of violence.

headline: Lowest Jobless Rate in 5 Years Raises Odds of a Fed Move
abstract: November’s strong jobs report closes a week of strong economic news and gave President Obama’s administration a rare bit of good news.
lead_paragraph: After years of frustrating fits and starts in the wake of the financial crisis and the Great Recession, the United States economy finally appears to be generating jobs at a healthier, more sustainable pace that many analysts now think will continue into 2014. The official unemployment rate fell in November to its lowest level since 2008.

headline: Pro-Government Ukrainians Take to Streets to Denounce European Social Values
abstract: Orthodox Christians who oppose European integration marched through the capital to denounce homosexuality, which they said would accompany a closer European alliance.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Pro-government demonstrators deployed a new tactic on Friday to counter protests in favor of European integration, marching through the capital, Kiev, to oppose homosexuality, which they said would accompany a greater European Union role in Ukrainian affairs.

headline: Nestlé Selling Stake in Swiss Fragrance Company
abstract: The sale of the stake, valued at more than $1 billion, is the latest in a series of divestitures aimed at streamlining Nestlé’s offerings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The food giant Nestlé said on Friday that it was selling its 10 percent stake in Givaudan, the Swiss flavors and fragrance company.

headline: My Health Insurance Was Canceled
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Now I am panicked and irritated — but also hopeful that I can get a reasonably priced policy.
lead_paragraph: I’m one of the many people in the United States who have had their individual health insurance policy canceled since the full implementation of the Affordable Care Act began Oct. 1. I own the Quintessence Group, a marketing consulting company based in Philadelphia. I have seven employees, but I’ve dodged the staff health insurance bullet for years because all of my employees have either had insurance through their spouses or have worked as independent contractors.

headline: When White House Photos Are ‘Visual Press Releases’
abstract: The Times has backed an effort to fight restrictions on photographers but could go further.
lead_paragraph: For Doug Mills – the longtime White House photographer for The Times – what happened on Veterans Day was more than annoying. It was wrong.

headline: Seemandhra Region of Andhra Pradesh Shuts Down After Cabinet Passes Telangana Blueprint
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Irrigation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Strikes']
abstract: Political and union leaders called for an indefinite strike to protest the Indian cabinet’s approval of a plan to create a new state out of Andhra Pradesh.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — The Seemandhra region of Andhra Pradesh ground to a halt on Friday after political and union leaders called for an indefinite strike to protest the Indian cabinet’s approval of a plan to create a new state of Telangana out of Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Kerry, Invoking Mandela, Says Peace in Mideast Is Possible
abstract: “We are closer than we have been in years” to an agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, Secretary of State John Kerry said, without citing specific examples.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Invoking the memory of Nelson Mandela, the South African statesman who died Thursday, Secretary of State John Kerry said Friday, “We are closer than we have been in years” to a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: The Three Stooges Theory of Fiscal Policy
abstract: Austerity, because it feels so good when you stop.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in one of the Three Stooges movies — if any readers know which one, please let me know — in which we see Curly banging his head repeatedly against a wall. Moe asks why he’s doing that, and Curly says, “Because it feels so good when I stop.”

headline: The Day a Newly Freed Mandela Came to New York
abstract: Twenty-three years have passed since Nelson Mandela first visited the city after his release from prison in South Africa, but the experience of seeing him still touches many New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Uhuru Williams remembers the seven words she shouted: “Nelson, I named my son after you.”

headline: Wanted: More Unemployment
abstract: The jobless rate is an odd measuring stick for the health of the labor market, since it falls not only when people find work, but also when they stop looking.
lead_paragraph: It is bad news for the American economy that the unemployment rate fell in November. Yes, you read that correctly: We need higher unemployment.

headline: Biden Finds Political Instincts Handy in Asia
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. honed his political instincts over the decades, and they came in handy on a trip to Asia this week.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Greeting Chinese leaders at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Wednesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. reminded them that he had first been there in 1979, as a young senator, to meet Deng Xiaoping, the reformist Chinese leader. He told President Xi Jinping, 11 years his junior, that he had met enough world leaders to take their measure.

headline: Skills Practice | Listening and Taking Notes, Via Times Podcasts
abstract: This week, find a quiet place and investigate a feature of The Times that is totally auditory. You’ll hit on components from one of the four Common Core literacy anchor standards for college and career readiness — speaking and listening.
lead_paragraph: This week, find a quiet place (or some earbuds) and investigate a feature of The Times that is totally auditory.

headline: New Luster for a Rink in Amsterdam
abstract: At Ice*Amsterdam there is skating in the shadows of the Rijksmuseum — and a restaurant with a heated terrace and bar.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Hans Brinker, the fictional Dutch boy who enters an ice-skating race to win a pair of silver skates, can practice their moves at Ice*Amsterdam, the recently opened skating rink in the shadows of the majestic Rijksmuseum, on Museum Square.

headline: Updates on Mourning for Mandela
abstract: The Lede continues to follow the global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela, on a day of tributes to the man who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and then served as its first freely elected president.
lead_paragraph: The Lede continues to follow the global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela, on a day of tributes to the man who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and then served as its first freely elected president. (For an overview of the first reactions on Thursday, please see our previous post.)

headline: Updates: 2014 World Cup Draw
abstract: The American squad landed in a tough group that included Germany, Portugal and its World Cup nemesis Ghana in the World Cup draw in Costa do Sauipe, Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The American squad landed in a tough group that included Germany, Portugal and its World Cup nemesis Ghana in the World Cup draw in Costa do Sauipe, Brazil. To follow the draw as it happened, read on.

headline: More Hours, More Earnings
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Working Hours']
abstract: The average workweek and hourly earnings among the labor force for private employers both grew last month, gains that could translate into increased consumer spending.
lead_paragraph: Here’s some good news in this good-news jobs report: Earnings climbed last month. That means that while many more Americans are finding jobs, the ones that are already working got a boost, too.

headline: 30 Takes of One Song? No Sweat for ‘Llewyn’s’ Star
abstract: Oscar Isaac, star of “Inside Llewyn Davis,” explains why he worried that he would be “the one guy to ruin the Coen brothers’ movie.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:37 p.m. | Michael B. Jordan is not the only actor this season whose life changed thanks to one film. “On a practical level, as soon as Joel and Ethan cast me, the doors opened up for more parts,” said Oscar Isaac, the star of the Coen brothers’ “Inside Llewyn Davis,” which opens on Friday.

headline: Hagel Seeks to Assure Gulf Allies of U.S. Commitment
abstract: The defense secretary said that the Pentagon would not reduce its military deployments to the region or its focus on countering shared security threats.
lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, opening a week of travels meant to reassure Persian Gulf allies nervous about an interim nuclear deal with Iran, vowed Friday that the Pentagon would not reduce its military deployments to the region or its focus on countering shared security threats.

headline: The Dutch-Elm Disease of Creative Minds
abstract: Self-doubt can be a powerful ally in the battle against bad writing. It can also be a powerful obstacle to writing anything at all.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I attended something called the Web Summit, a massive tech-industry conference held in Dublin over the course of a couple of days. The event had a two-tier structure: on one level, it was a vast, teeming trade show at which early-stage start-ups were given the opportunity to set out their stalls and sell themselves — to venture capitalists, angel investors, media people — and to network with one another; but on a more elevated plane, it was a grand conclave of the tech industry’s high priests, who came from all over the world (though mostly Northern California) to deliver talks and public interviews to audiences of several thousand.

headline: Life Along the 100th Meridian
abstract: The middle of the country is gorgeous from the air — and a very hard place on the ground.
lead_paragraph: In the western panhandle of Nebraska, where it is not uncommon for newcomers to be asked, “So how long are you staying in our country?” the question of continuity repeats itself each day anew.

headline: Costly Mistakes and Voter Suppression
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Friendship', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Partisan discrimination vs. racial discrimination.
lead_paragraph: I own a small manufacturing company, and recently I made a special order for a friend. He and I agreed on a certain price. My bookkeeper misunderstood my billing instructions and sent an invoice for less than the agreed-upon price. I discovered the mistake two weeks later. I contacted my friend to notify him of the mistake and to tell him we were sending out a corrected invoice. He said, “Your mistake is not my problem,” and that he would only pay the incorrect amount on the original invoice. Who is right? STEVE COHEN, BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y.

headline: I Guess I’ll Manage
abstract: The terror of having my very own employee.
lead_paragraph: “You’re in management,” my mother said. “You have to wear a bra.” She looked as if I’d shown up for breakfast wearing a codpiece and snorkel. I glanced down and realized that, indeed, I’d forgotten to wear a bra beneath my sweater. It hardly made a difference in the geography of the region, but I was ashamed of my absent-mindedness. A mother’s reproach is never sharper than at 7:30 on a Monday morning.

headline: The 11.24.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHO SAID GIRLS CAN’T JUMP?

headline: Sarita Choudhury’s Anti-Education
abstract: Doctors bumping fists; Sarajevo to St. Louis; J. R. R. Tolkien takes on the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Doctors bumping fists; Sarajevo to St. Louis; J. R. R. Tolkien takes on the Knicks.

headline: Lenny Kravitz’s Halfway Mark
abstract: The musician on his Bed-Stuy nickname, designing condos and living to 100.
lead_paragraph: You grew up between the Upper East Side and Bed-Stuy. Which neighborhood did you feel more comfortable in?  Well, after I was in first grade, Monday through Friday was Upper East Side going to P.S. 6, and Friday night through Sunday night was Bed-Stuy. But I didn’t like one more than the other. I had two different lives, and in fact two different names. My name in Bed-Stuy was Eddie.

headline: Who Made That Energy Drink?
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Energy and Sports Drinks']
abstract: The Asian imports that gave us Red Bull, Monster and Rockstar.
lead_paragraph: The energy drink, as we know it, started in Japan. In the postwar period, amphetamines were very popular until laws were passed to curb their use in the 1950s. Then in 1962, a company called Taisho introduced Lipovitan D — a legal, energizing tonic sold in minibar-size bottles. By the 1980s, such vitamin-fortified, extra-caffeinated beverages were being regularly consumed by Japanese executives struggling to get ahead. One television ad showed Arnold Schwarzenegger bursting from a flagon like a juiced-up genie. Another had a hero in suit and tie, signing deals and making presentations as he raced around the world. “Can you fight for 24 hours a day?” he chanted with his chin upturned. “Businessman, businessman, Japanese businessman!”

headline: Pour the Port, Hold the Stodginess
abstract: You’re not alone if you think port is only an after-dinner drink, but you’re wrong.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a fancy bar, the place where I work, but we do carry port. Just one brand is enough for our purposes. In my nearly four years of working there, I’ve only seen one person order it: a middle-aged man who shows up maybe once every six weeks (on my shift, anyway; I suspect he comes at other times too), drinks three glasses and leaves.

headline: This Is What It Looks Like at the Center of America
abstract: A photo portolio by Andrew Moore of some of the most sparsely populated regions west of the 100th meridian.
lead_paragraph: A photo portolio by Andrew Moore of some of the most sparsely populated regions west of the 100th meridian.

headline: Capturing America at Its Plainest
abstract: To create his large-format photographs of the Great Plains region, Andrew Moore chartered a two-person plane and attached his camera to the wing.
lead_paragraph: To create his large-format photographs of the Great Plains region, Andrew Moore chartered a two-person plane and attached his camera to the wing.

headline: Food Allergies Less Deadly Than Accidents
abstract: A new study finds that people with food allergies have far less chance of dying from an allergic reaction than from an accident.
lead_paragraph: A fatal allergic reaction is a dramatic event, often involving a young person, so it naturally attracts attention. But that attention itself may lead people to overestimate the risk.

headline: Big Band
abstract: Terry Teachout’s biography of the enigmatic jazz titan Duke Ellington.
lead_paragraph: Eighty years before “branding” had become the familiar hard-nosed term for the packaging and selling of entertainers, Duke Ellington was a dreamlike synthesis of image, talent and social relevance. As a black jazz titan in a racist age — he rose to stardom in the 1920s — the aristocratic maestro took on a weighty double role: to lift jazz to the level of concert music and to win respect for his race.

headline: Bebop
abstract: Two new biographies of the revered and influential saxophonist and composer Charlie Parker.
lead_paragraph: When you’re writing about the movies, the film critic and painter Manny Farber said, the language ought to emulate the art. “I don’t think you can be mimetic enough,” Farber told an interviewer. That is to say, screen violence calls for barbarous prose; romance requires a warmness of tone. This principle could be applied to writing about all the arts, or most of them — including jazz, as the cultural critic and novelist Stanley Crouch has demonstrated with his judicious, strategically crafted new book about Charlie Parker, the revered and immeasurably influential alto saxophonist and composer. “Kansas City Lightning: The Rise and Times of Charlie Parker” is, like the music made by its subject in his abbreviated life, free-flowing and severe, volatile, expansive, allusive and indulgent. From bravura sentence to serpentine paragraph, the book is a virtuoso performance of musical-literary mimesis.

headline: Children’s Books
abstract: Six beautiful large-format books take readers on imaginative journeys.
lead_paragraph: Six beautiful large-format books take readers on imaginative journeys.

headline: Picturing World War I
abstract: A photographic history of World War I.
lead_paragraph: When I saw the title of this volume, I expected one of those encyclopedias in which texts by historians are interspersed with grainy images that bring the arguments to life. “The Great War” could not be more different. The images presented here are not illustrations for a narrative; they are the narrative. Hilary Roberts, the head curator of photography at the Imperial War Museums in Britain (home of the world’s most extensive collection of World War I photographs), provided the historical and contextual expertise. Mark Holborn is a celebrated editor of illustrated books and a master of photographic mise-en-scène. The result of their collaboration is a book of extraordinary power and clarity.

headline: The Somme
abstract: In a wordless, 24-foot-long panorama, Joe Sacco illustrates the first day of the Battle of the Somme.
lead_paragraph: The Battle of the Somme was immortalized even before the fighting had ceased. The intensive British and French assault along the chalk ridges of the Somme River Valley began on July 1, 1916; scarcely two months later, a silent film — shot within and behind the British trenches — screened in London cinemas. The Somme, like so many other battles of the Great War, was also commemorated in real time by such trench-line poets as Alan Seeger, who composed what became, in short order, their own epitaphs (“I have a rendezvous with Death”) as German shells shook the wet earth beneath them.

headline: Short-Term Gains, Long-Term Trouble
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The number of people out of work for less than five weeks is now below pre-recession levels, but the ranks of long-term unemployed continue to exceed previous cycles.
lead_paragraph: Most of the job numbers, even when they look good, are still not even close to what they were before the Great Recession, which officially began in December 2007.

headline: Fine Arts
abstract: Six illustrated art books reflect periods of intense conflict and social change.
lead_paragraph: Six illustrated art books reflect periods of intense conflict and social change.

headline: Comics
abstract: Charting the development of the superhero from its roots in the pulp novels of the early 1900s to its contemporary ubiquity.
lead_paragraph: Collectors divide the history of comic books into discrete eras evocative of Olympic medals: golden age, silver, bronze. But the culture that comics have inspired, comprising as it does more than seven decades of fractious characters, creators and commentary across a variety of media, doesn’t surrender itself to so tidy a ­taxonomy.

headline: Guilty Pleasures
abstract: Chris Nashawaty explores the career of the film producer Roger Corman with a mixture of oral history, critical essays and colorful photos.
lead_paragraph: Roger Corman, the producer of hundreds of low-budget films with titles like “The Slumber Party Massacre,” has been mythologized not to death so much as to bland respectability, which some fans might argue is worse.

headline: New York Views
abstract: New books about Sept. 11, urban design, Lincoln Center and mapping the city.
lead_paragraph: THE STORIES THEY TELL  Artifacts From the National ­September 11 Memorial Museum: A Journey of ­Remembrance  Skira Rizzoli, $19.95.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE INVENTOR AND THE TYCOON: The Murderer Eadweard Muybridge, the Entrepreneur Leland Stanford, and the Birth of Moving Pictures,  by Edward Ball. (Anchor, $16.95.) At the height of his genius, Eadweard Muybridge, a British immigrant whose advancements in photography in the late 1800s gave rise to the motion picture industry, killed his wife’s lover in cold blood. Ball weaves an account of that crime, and the sensational trial that followed it, into the larger story of Muybridge’s complicated relationship with his patron, the railroad magnate Leland Stanford.

headline: Tracking a Thief, Once You Know There Is One
abstract: Financial elder abuse statistics are not easy to pin down. It can also sometimes be hard to recognize that there is a problem.
lead_paragraph: The first time my father was ever robbed, decades ago, he was vacationing in England with my mom. A certified public accountant, he had certain fiscal habits, one of which was to count and order his money, highest denomination bill to lowest, all facing the same way in his wallet. He did this constantly, usually at home after work. In England, though, he performed the rite in the hotel pub. My mother was furious. For good reason.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: James Patterson’s “Cross My Heart,” new at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, is Patterson’s seventh novel to reach that list in 2013.
lead_paragraph: No. 1 Dad: James Patterson’s latest thriller, “Cross My Heart,” is new at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list. It’s Patterson’s second Alex Cross book to top the list this year and, impressively, his seventh novel to reach the hardcover list in 2013. (That’s not counting appearances on the middle-grade list, the young adult list, the mass-market paperback list, the e-book list or the manga list — and the year isn’t over yet.)

headline: Cooking
abstract: The yearly avalanche of cookbooks offers something for everyone, from “Fifty Shades of Kale” to “The Eat-a-Bug Cookbook.”
lead_paragraph: When the seasonal cookbook offerings include titles like “Fifty Shades of Kale” and an updated edition of “The Eat-a-Bug Cookbook,” choice is not a problem. The yearly avalanche includes something for everyone. There are books from star chefs and famous restaurants, the latest go-rounds from tried-and-true food writers, the now customary exercises in vegetable-worship, armchair-tourist cookbooks and one book that defies description.

headline: A Speakeasy Experience
abstract: The Heath at the McKittrick Hotel in Chelsea is a recreated supper club complete with a jazz band and a faux smoky room where five finance types gathered recently.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere between the formality of a dinner theater and the cheesiness of a theme restaurant, the Heath at the McKittrick Hotel is — to use the phrase favored by marketing professionals — “a culinary experience.” Opened two weeks ago by Punchdrunk, the British theater company that also runs that immersive — sorry — theatrical experience, “Sleep No More,” in the same hotel in Chelsea, the Heath is a recreated speakeasy/supper club, complete with a jazz band, suspendered barmen, and haze of fake (i.e., health department-compliant) cigarette smoke. “When the band started playing,” said Ian Smith, one of five finance types who ate at the Heath last week, “I felt like I was in an episode of ‘Boardwalk Empire.’ ”

headline: Travel
abstract: Food is the springboard for much of this season’s best travel writing.
lead_paragraph: Food is the springboard for much of this season’s best travel writing. From the novice who opens a Western-style restaurant in Kigali to the critic who gags over a series of bad meals in Cairo, the search for corporeal sustenance proves a reliable source of inspiration. But, as Lawrence Osborne reminds us, this quest isn’t always about food. Frequently — to borrow from Woody Allen — there must be a beverage.

headline: Gardening Yesterday
abstract: Books that look back to the past stir the imagination.
lead_paragraph: December is, of course, the holiday season, but for gardeners it’s also the reading season. In the garden, we play out fantasies, desires and longings, and the ensuing tussle with nature — sometimes gentle, sometimes violent — is for a beauty we can make. Like sex, quite a lot of gardening happens in the mind. This season, a few books that look back to the past may well stir your imagination.

headline: Interiors
abstract: Portfolios and visual memoirs by decorators attest to lives rich with clients.
lead_paragraph: It must be the whisper of time as it bends over the horizon, a susurration of mortality none can escape. What else could have prompted so many decorators to publish their portfolios, visual memoirs that attest to lives rich with clients? Decorating is one of the most evanescent of the visual arts. It’s painful to walk into a room in which every inch has been lavished with attention, imagination and money, only to learn that the wrecking ball is about to arrive, commissioned by the next decorator. Devastating — when it isn’t good riddance to bad rubbish. Sometimes it takes a while to tell the difference.

headline: Photography
abstract: New books of photography by Sergio Larrain, Josef Koudelka and more.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the world of photography books can seem not unlike that of popular music on disc, with endless repackaging of the classics — each new volume containing pictures that haven’t been previously reprinted, so that if you are a devotee or a completist you will have to shell out for another tome. And yet major surprises continue to arrive, dispatches from the past. Consider, for example, the work of the Chilean photographer Sergio Larrain (1931-2012), whose career was both extraordinary and unusually abbreviated. It was only after studying forestry at Berkeley that he began seriously taking pictures in the mid-1950s, and then an encounter with the Bolivian mystic Oscar Ichazo in 1968 caused him to retreat for the remainder of his life into meditation and yoga, taking small, quiet photos only occasionally, as complements to his inner quest. But for the decade or so that he was in the world and regularly taking pictures, his work, as amply illustrated in SERGIO LARRAIN (Aperture, $85), edited by Agnès Sire, was a constant source of wonder.

headline: Gardening Today
abstract: Five books offer gardeners a chance to study other people’s work and pick up a few pointers.
lead_paragraph: For gardeners, winter is a period of rest, if not entirely of relaxation. The trees are bare, the flower beds dormant, the pruners and trowels packed away in the toolshed. All those hours once spent weeding and mowing can now be devoted to recalling our triumphs and brooding over our failures. There’s also, finally, enough leisure time to study other people’s gardens and pick up a few pointers. And yet, infuriatingly, many of those gardens are also in sleep mode. What to do? The answer to that question — as to so many others — can be found in a book. Five of them, to be precise.

headline: Antarctica
abstract: Two new books show off the staggering beauty of Antarctica and consider the future of this last clean place on earth.
lead_paragraph: Antarctica is a life-changing place. From its first explorers to today’s hardy souls who live and work there, it has always drawn certain people to its austere and compelling majesty. If you go to Antarctica, it may or may not change your life. But what matters is that Antarctica itself is changing and, at the same time, changing us. These two books will first open your eyes to the staggering beauty of the place. Then they will chill you. At the bottom of the world, strange and terrifying things are happening miles above and beneath the icy surface, some of them understood, some not; many man-made, some irreversible and all determining the future of this last clean place on earth, and of earth itself.

headline: Covering the Waterfront, in Photographs
abstract: John Skelson has been photographing the big ships arriving in New York Harbor since 1970; the crew members know him and wave as they pass.
lead_paragraph: Many of the freighters and tankers arriving

headline: Screen Gems
abstract: David Thomson’s latest book is full of assured declarations, chatty asides and free-associative essays accompanying images from 71 films.
lead_paragraph: The moment held forever on the cover of “Moments That Made the Movies” is a lulu: Joe Gillis floating facedown in Norma Desmond’s swimming pool in “Sunset Blvd.” The water is lit from below; the palette is 5 a.m. City of Angels black-and-white. Gazing at the image even in silence, anyone who loves movies can conjure the voice-over narration of the dead man, talking to the audience directly, describing to us how he, “just a movie writer with a couple of B pictures to his name,” has wound up at the decaying mansion of a faded movie star with two shots in his back and one in his stomach. The poor dope. Maybe an advanced movie lover can even hear the unique voice of the speaker — William Holden as Gillis — telling the tale that won the picture 11 Oscar nominations in 1951.

headline: Image of the Day: December 6
abstract: Mr. Mandela, 95, died in Johannesburg, South Africa, after a long illness.

headline: Star Style
abstract: A panoramic celebration of Hollywood fashion in words, still photographs and drawings.
lead_paragraph: It may approach a Tom Swifty, but costume designers have an image problem. As fashion designers have inflated to dirigible proportions — stamping their initials on baby bootees, plotting I.P.O.’s and presiding like some kind of self-appointed Warren court over the quivery aspirants of “Project Runway” — their kinfolk in the movie business have receded ever more into the shadows. They emerge only around Oscar time, even then making little impression on the culture at large. Almost two decades have passed since Lizzy Gardiner, one-half of the Australian team that outfitted “The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,” accepted her statuette, jangling gently in a dress she’d made from 254 American Express gold cards. “I’m broke,” she explained, “and I didn’t have anything to wear.”

headline: L’Amour
abstract: “The Libertine” is a new volume of 18th-century French erotica edited by the literary historian Michel Delon.
lead_paragraph: Long before Cole Porter observed that birds, bees and educated fleas do it, the French poet Alexis Piron made the same point in his X-rated “Ode to Priapus.” Anthologized in “The Libertine,” the literary historian Michel Delon’s delectable new volume of 18th-century French erotica, it catalogs an array of fauna (“Dromedary, whale, and duck, / Insect, critter, man”) united in their lusty predilection for verbs and nouns too obscene to print in this newspaper, though collectively identifiable by Porter’s own euphemistic pronoun of choice: “Everything does it, reasonable or not.” Reminiscent, too, of the catalog aria from Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” — an enumeration of the skirt-chasing hero’s thousands of conquests by age, rank, nationality and hair color — Piron’s dirty laundry list underscores both the dogged ubiquity of the sex instinct and the inexhaustible variety of its ­expressions.

headline: Tradition!
abstract: Alisa Solomon’s look at the making of “Fiddler on the Roof” and the way the show reflects evolving Jewish cultural identity in America and around the world.
lead_paragraph: In my family, we have a ritual. (Tradition!) After a particularly wonderful Shabbat or holiday dinner, we channel my great-grandmother Pearl Gottler and chant in unison, “Ach, I’m stoffed. I’m bloated. I couldn’t eat another bite.”

headline: Stuffed Animals
abstract: Alexis Turner, the founder of London Taxidermy, shows off some of his stuffed and pickled props.
lead_paragraph: The 337 images in “Taxidermy” are artful and immaculate — everything that a taxidermy workshop, with its dust, fumes, stench, viscera and decay, is not. This book is eye candy (the frontispiece is, in fact, a surprisingly delectable array of glass eyes), which makes sense because Alexis Turner is the founder of London Taxidermy, a business that supplies natural history artifacts to the fashion and film industries, among other clients. You can see his stuffed and pickled props in the “Harry Potter” films, “Sherlock ­Holmes,” “Pirates of the Caribbean,” “Les ­Misérables,” “Anna Karenina,” “Skyfall” — and now in this book.

headline: Release the Hounds
abstract: Two new books combine rich storytelling with science to explain dogs — the roles they play in our lives and we in theirs.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Berns wasn’t sure if his pug Newton really loved him. Newton wagged his tail and gave kisses, but that wasn’t enough. Berns, a neuroscientist, wanted hard data. He also hoped to uncover “what makes for a strong dog-human bond” and how that might improve canine welfare. So he built a special M.R.I. machine, and trained dogs to lie still inside it, allowing him to study their brains. Though the results may seem obvious to dog lovers (that humans and dogs experience emotions similarly), they’re not a given for science. Berns’s book is a beautiful story about dogs, love and neurology that shows how nonhuman relationships are inspiring researchers to look at animals in new ways, for their benefit and ours.

headline: Public Painting
abstract: “Murals of New York City: The Best of New York’s Public Paintings From Bemelmans to Parrish” features more than 30 large-scale works around the city.
lead_paragraph: Walls in New York sometimes do more than divide space. A few of them are also pages of the city’s history writ large — testament to the shifting civic vision of generations of New Yorkers. In “Murals of New York City: The Best of New York’s Public Paintings From Bemelmans to Parrish,” which features more than 30 large-scale works around the city, the muralist Glenn Palmer-Smith and the photographer Joshua McHugh tutor natives and tourists alike in how these walls — and a few ceilings — can best be appreciated.

headline: Razzle Dazzle
abstract: Sam Wasson’s biography of Bob Fosse explains the choreographer’s achievement in prose meant to summon the spirit of a Fosse show.
lead_paragraph: An instructive way of getting a sense of the power of Bob Fosse’s choreography is by listening to the original cast album of a 1959 musical called “Redhead.” The show ran for 452 performances, a head-­scratcher since the songs are merely serviceable. But the photos reveal all. The songs were irrelevant: What made “Redhead” a hit was the genius of Fosse’s dances.

headline: The Splendid Splinter
abstract: Ben Bradlee Jr.’s biography of Ted Williams does not materially alter our picture of the Red Sox star, but fills it in with much greater detail and nuance.
lead_paragraph: The people at the Alcor cryonics facility, in Scottsdale, Ariz., would have us believe that Ted Williams really is immortal. They have his body there, the head severed from the rest, flash-frozen in a giant thermos-like tank and awaiting only the scientific advancement that will allow him to be thawed, resuscitated and rejuvenated. Meanwhile, with every passing season, his longevity in the statistical department seems more and more certain. While other baseball records fall with actuarial regularity, Williams’s 1941 batting average of .406, the highest in nearly 90 years, shimmers ever more brightly, a landmark that even a hitter like Barry Bonds was unable to approach.

headline: Cat Fancy
abstract: Paintings of cats and girls by Balthus, and poetry and prose about cats from The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: Look — how can you not? — at the supple creature stretched across the divan. Legs bent and parted, arms folded overhead, eyes trained on some distant vision. She could lounge that way for hours, it seems, staring at the wall, or through the human who gazes on her, he confounded by her aloofness, tormented by what he cannot know: What does she feel? What does she desire? What does she think of me?

headline: Aerosol Art
abstract: Graffiti and street art from New York City and around the world.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, the filmmaker Charlie Ahearn went to see his friend Martin Wong the day before that artist and collector gave away his life’s work. Wong had recently received a diagnosis of H.I.V. and had decided to bestow his collection on the Museum of the City of New York, then head home to San Francisco to be with family. Ahearn describes the moment as a visit to “Ali Baba’s cave of secret art treasures,” where “Chinese ceramics, Christmas ornaments, gold frames and antiques, fireman jackets and hats, stacks of canvases and art hung to the ceiling.”

headline: Springsteen’s Handwritten Lyrics to ‘Born to Run’ Sell for $197,000
abstract: An early version of Bruce Springsteen’s lyrics for “Born to Run” sold for double the estimated price.
lead_paragraph: The handwritten lyrics to an embryonic version of Bruce Springsteen’s “Born to Run” were sold for $197,000 at an auction at Sotheby’s on Thursday, a spokesman for the auction house said.

headline: Sweet Soul Music
abstract: Robert Gordon profiles the singers, songwriters and producers behind Stax Records.
lead_paragraph: “Knock on Wood,” “Soul Man,” “Hold On, I’m Coming,” “In the Midnight Hour,” “These Arms of Mine,” “I’ve Been Loving You Too Long,” “Green Onions,” “I’ll Take You There,” “Who’s Making Love” and, of course, the theme from “Shaft”: The list of hits produced by Stax could fill this page by itself. But Robert Gordon’s “Respect Yourself: Stax Records and the Soul Explosion” — “Respect Yourself” as performed by the Staple Singers, that is — is much more than a nostalgia trip or a soundtrack on paper. Gordon, a Memphis resident who has written books about his city’s music and a well-received biography of Muddy Waters, profiles singers, songwriters and producers. But he has also written a social history, viewing the company that for more than 15 years produced some of the most popular and important music in America as part of the history of Memphis and of the civil rights movement.

headline: Prequel
abstract: Anjelica Huston’s memoir about growing up in Ireland, London and New York doubles as a social history of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Before most American celebrity-watchers became aware of her as Jack Nicholson’s notably elegant girlfriend, in the mid-1970s — and before her acting career took off in 1985, when she was 34 (an Oscar award for “Prizzi’s Honor” and nominations for “Enemies: A Love Story” and “The Grifters”) — Anjelica Huston had a magical, if sometimes star-crossed, life in Ireland, England and New York. She was the daughter of the larger-than-life director John Huston (“The Treasure of Sierra Madre,” “The Maltese Falcon,” “The African Queen”), a man of great appetites and macho endeavor with whom “not only women but men of all ages fell in love . . . with that strange loyalty and forbearance men reserve for each other,” his daughter writes. Huston’s mother, Ricki Soma, a ballerina and the daughter of an Italian-restaurant owner in New York, was John Huston’s fourth wife. They eloped when she was 18 and he was in his mid-40s. Huston was their second child and — with her mother now transformed into the beautiful couture-clad “translucent and remote” mistress of a vast West Ireland estate — she was raised amid multiple servants, visiting film-world eminences and colorful locals in the kind of world that has disappeared, other than, say, in movies starring Keira Knightley.

headline: Hard Knocks
abstract: Nicholas Dawidoff’s case study of the N.F.L., after a year spent with the New York Jets.
lead_paragraph: Football, George Will once argued, “combines the two worst things about America: violence punctuated by committee meetings.” But in fact those “committee meetings,” with their militaristic strategies and tribal rituals, help explain the National Football League’s popularity in America. Sure, the violence might be problematic, especially in light of recent head trauma studies. But did you see that hit in the 49ers game?! Pass the bean dip.

headline: American Songbook
abstract: John Shaw’s book tells the story of two American anthems: Irving Berlin’s “God Bless America” and Woody Guthrie’s “This Land Is Your Land.”
lead_paragraph: In late 1938, with the world on the brink of war, Kate Smith asked Irving Berlin, the world’s most famous songwriter, for a patriotic song she could sing on her annual Armistice Day radio broadcast. He dusted off and reworked a number he had begun writing in 1918 but abandoned. Before introducing the song to her vast national audience, Smith predicted that it “will be timeless — it will never die — others will thrill to its beauty long after we are gone.”

headline: Heeeere’s Johnny!
abstract: Henry Bushkin, who worked as a lawyer for Johnny Carson, has written a gossipy, breezy memoir about the late-night host.
lead_paragraph: The day after he was hired by Johnny Carson, an obscure young lawyer named Henry Bushkin tagged along with him and some thugs in the night as they broke into an apartment searching for proof of Carson’s wife’s infidelity. They found plenty, as Bushkin tells it, and Carson leaned against a wall and wept, revealing the .38 he was carrying in case things went wrong. That was in 1970, when Carson had already settled into his role as superstar host of “The Tonight Show.” Over the next 18 years, Bushkin was his lawyer, fixer, friend and liege, “like all those guys on ‘Entourage,’ except there was only me.”

headline: Cooking Light With Seafood
abstract: Light fish and seafood dinners make good choices for meals in between holiday parties, notes Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: Many of you, still full from Thanksgiving, may be anticipating holiday parties to come and wondering how to balance things out with some of the meals in between. With this in mind, I decided to work on light fish and seafood dinners for this week’s Recipes for Health. They should provide you with a respite from rich food during this shortened window between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

headline: Allure
abstract: Virginia Postrel lays out the case for glamour as a life-shaping force, whether for good or for ill.
lead_paragraph: The jury is still out on glamour. Some critics see it as the scourge of modern society, an illusory opiate doled out by a ruling elite to dazzle the masses into submission. For others glamour is a fragile and endangered species, the inspirational product of simpler times — before, say, a photograph of Scarlett Johansson tripping and falling could become, in the space of an hour, an Internet meme — as our tell-all society collapses the distance between us and our idols irrevocably.

headline: Classical Pottery
abstract: An illustrated overview of the main styles and production centers of Greek figurative pottery.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, developing an informed appreciation for Greek vases, in particular fineware with painted scenes, was no easy matter for anyone aside from serious students and dedicated connoisseurs with access to the world’s museums. As for illustrated books, there wasn’t much between the affordable volumes of John Boardman’s Thames & Hudson paperback series, with their masterly text and plentiful but small and hard-to-see photographs in black and white, and expensive volumes with magnificent photos, mostly relegated to academic libraries. That’s all changed, largely because of the Internet, where high-resolution photographs of individual vases — on academic and curatorial websites with expert analysis, certainly, but also on the Flickr accounts of museumgoing tourists — let you zoom in on the tiny details in which much of the delight of Greek vase painting lies. But the lower cost of printing has also put beautifully printed large-format books within reach, and for readers getting interested in Greek vases for the first time, a coherent illustrated overview of the subject is invaluable and much more manageable on the page than on-screen.

headline: Paris-London
abstract: Jonathan Conlin offers a series of strolls through the history of Paris and London.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to frills and fashions, London defers to Paris. It was ever so. Jonathan Conlin, the American-born author of an admired history of London’s National Gallery, starts his series of sprightly strolls through these two great cities by imagining the journey of a “fashion doll,” a child-size mannequin that could be kitted out in the latest Paris style and brought back via Calais or Ostend for an astute dressmaker to use as her model when arraying London’s titled fashion lovers. The first such doll crossed the Channel — ready for the latest take on wimples, ladies? — in the 14th century. Prudently, the author confines his study in cultural crossings to the two centuries leading up to the Great War.

headline: Muppet Man
abstract: A biography of the puppeteer whose influence has hardly waned in the more than two decades since his death.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy being a puppeteer. Consider the opening sequence of 1979’s “The Muppet Movie,” in which Kermit the Frog performed “The Rainbow Connection,” the ­follow-up to his breakout number, “Bein’ Green.” Kermit strummed his banjo while perched on a log in the middle of a swamp. The set had been carefully constructed on a studio back lot, but even fake swamps have real water. This required Jim Henson, Kermit’s creator and performer, to execute the complicated sequence submerged. As Kermit crooned, Henson lurked beneath the surface of the ersatz bayou, his lanky frame folded into a ­custom-made diving bell, his oxygen pumped in through a tube. To make his frog sing, the puppeteer had to become amphibious.

headline: Music Lessons
abstract: Memoirs about two very different musical journeys.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen pages into “Play It Again: An Amateur Against the Impossible,” Alan Rusbridger offers readers an implicit dare. Here the typeface changes from words to musical notes — not just any notes, but excerpts from Frédéric Chopin’s Ballade No. 1 in G minor, Op. 23, one of the most complex and challenging pieces in piano repertoire.

headline: Composers
abstract: A new book about Richard Wagner, who relentlessly recorded his daily life, and another about Bach, who left hardly any paper trail.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1, 1869, the mother of two of Richard Wagner’s children, though not quite yet his wife, began keeping a diary. Though, calling the 14-year account that Cosima Wagner eventually produced a diary is like calling a battleship a boat. At the start of his idiosyncratic new book, “Richard Wagner: A Life in Music,” Martin Geck notes that Cosima’s journals ended up running nearly one million words. Full of mythologizing and after-the-fact edits, they give us, in conjunction with Wagner’s own copious writing and correspondence, an unprecedented opportunity: For no other cultural figure of his significance do we have a record of daily life so relentlessly extensive.

headline: The Chelsea
abstract: Sherill Tippins aims to tell the definitive story of New York’s Hotel Chelsea in “Inside the Dream Palace.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s a sad irony of New York life that over time, the fabled buildings and institutions that first attract us to the city fade into invisibility.” So begins Sherill Tippins’s thorough, if not groundbreaking, Hotel Chelsea history. For the past dozen or so years, the Chelsea has been raging against invisibility. Former guests and residents as different as Dee Dee Ramone, Abel Ferrara and Ethan Hawke have featured it in their work. Current residents have waged a very public battle with its recent owners. In anticipation of a potentially soul-killing renovation, two new books capture its lovably scuzzy spirit. One is an evocative coffee-table book by the photographer Victoria Cohen, HOTEL CHELSEA (Pointed Leaf Press, $95), which treats the oddly painted rooms’ quirky mix of old and new furniture, worn carpeting and garish bedspreads as something like sacred relics. The other is Tippins’s doorstop-hefty ­“Inside the Dream Palace,” which aspires to tell the “definitive story.”

headline: Pre-Fab Four
abstract: The first of a projected three-volume biography of the Fab Four.
lead_paragraph: Approaches to retelling the Beatles’ story slice in two distinct directions: narrow or wide. Some authors choose a single figure and bore down deep, which has brought the count of Paul McCartney life stories to at least 10, with more in the pipeline. Others frame the narrative from more expansive angles, weaving in the era’s social texture, politics and cultural context (see Devin McKinney’s shrewd “Magic Circles” from 2003 or Jonathan Gould’s peerless “Can’t Buy Me Love” of 2007).

headline: An App to Find Holiday Light Displays
abstract: Christmas and Holiday Light Displays, a mobile app, allows users to mark any place where they find a particularly dazzling showing.
lead_paragraph: If there were a Charlie Brown Christmas tree of apps, it would be Christmas and Holiday Light Displays.

keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many thought Thad Cochran was going to retire after 34 years in the Senate, but now Mississippi faces a tough Republican primary for his seat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thad Cochran, a Mississippi Republican who was first elected to the Senate in 1978, set up a generational and ideological clash in the state’s Republican primary when he announced Friday that he would seek a seventh term in 2014.

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on Scott Cooper’s drama “Out of the Furnace,” the period Coen brothers film “Inside Llewyn Davis” and the documentary “Lenny Cooke.” See all of this week’s reviews.

abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: handmade goods from Japan.

headline: Eli Broad, at Art Basel in Miami, Focuses on Los Angeles
abstract: The billionaire collector and philanthropist shared some details about the art museum he is planning to open in Los Angeles next year.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire collector and philanthropist Eli Broad picked up an early John Baldessari work at the Dominique Lévy gallery on the first day of the giant Art Basel art fair in Miami. But over lunch at the Setai Hotel on Thursday afternoon, he was much more interested in talking about what may be his Baldessari’s newest home: the $140 million contemporary art museum that Mr. Broad and his wife, Edythe, are building on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles. The architectural team of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio were on hand to show off the work in progress, which is scheduled for completion in the fall of 2014.

abstract: This week, the Book Review editors Sarah Smith, Alida Becker, Barry Gewen, Gregory Cowles and Parul Sehgal discuss the year’s notable books; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Time for an Equestrian Transformation
abstract: The first all-new Mustang in a decade has been restyled and modernized to attract new buyers, while still satisfying traditionalists.
lead_paragraph: For the Ford Mustang and its loyal fans, there’s only one question: Where has the time gone? A 22-year-old college graduate wowed by the first, illustrious Mustang would be roughly 72 today — and, as Ford surely hopes, may still be excited by the latest model, whether to drive it or to recommend it to a grandchild.

lead_paragraph: SOWETO, South Africa — Tumelo Mabitle shifted his weight from foot to foot and took a few sturdy jabs at the heavy bag.

abstract: The recalls involve various safety problems, from rusting control arms on Hyundais to an engine control software problem on BMW motorcycles.
lead_paragraph: Hyundai will recall about 15,500 Entourage minivans from the 2007-8 model years for a corrosion-related steering problem, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

abstract: Justice Cynthia S. Kern ruled that arguments accusing New York City Housing Authority officials of violating state law and excluding the City Council were premature.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council and a group of public housing tenants have lost a bid to stop the Bloomberg administration from making any deals to lease public housing land to private developers.

abstract: An article in the bank’s magazine notes a more unusual employee achievement.
lead_paragraph: Big banks occasionally like to highlight their employees’ achievements, including career milestones, charity work or even running a marathon.

abstract: Fans of “Smash,” the canceled NBC show about the making of a Broadway musical, will get a chance to experience what that production might have been like at three concerts on Sunday and Monday.

headline: 25 More Cookbooks
abstract: An additional selection of some of the season’s notable cookbooks.
lead_paragraph: THE A.O.C. COOKBOOK. By Suzanne Goin. (Knopf, $35.) The author of “Sunday Suppers at Lucques” follows up with recipes from her small-plates, wine and cheese restaurant in Los Angeles. Caroline Styne, her business partner and wine director, provides wine notes for pairings.

headline: In Six Neglected Films, a Universe of Yearning
abstract: On Tuesday the Criterion Collection releases “Martin Scorsese’s World Cinema Project,” a set of six neglected foreign films that amounts to a masterly mini-festival.
lead_paragraph: Appropriation can be a funny thing, as Djibril Diop Mambéty’s galvanizing “Touki Bouki” demonstrates.

headline: Awful Children
abstract: In two short novels by Susan Hill, youthful misbehavior receives its just punishment, and then some.
lead_paragraph: “We blot out bad things from our minds and especially when they have been bad things we ourselves have done, in childhood perhaps most of all.” So says the narrator of “Dolly,” the second of two short novels by Susan Hill in which bad things done in childhood refuse, despite grown-up minds’ best efforts, to stay blotted. Nasty stuff of this sort may resurface after years of psychoanalysis or — less therapeutically if more efficiently — in the course of a compact, elegantly constructed ghost story, which happens to be one of Hill’s specialties. Her nerve-­shaking 1983 novel “The Woman in Black” is a modern classic of the genre, in the whispery manner of M. R. James and Robert Aickman. (It was made into a movie, unmemorably, last year; a stage adaptation has been running in London since 1988.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE HEIR APPARENT: A Life of Edward VII, the Playboy Prince,  by Jane Ridley. (Random House, $35.) He was vain, gluttonous, promiscuous and none too bright, but “Bertie” emerges as an appealing character in Ridley’s superb book.

headline: Scholars Explore Christian Perspectives on Animal Rights
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion and Belief', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: As Christians ask how their faith requires them to treat animals, they may force animal rights activists, a mostly secular lot, to reconsider their views on Christians.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — “There was a time when Rebecca, our eldest, was desperate to have a pet,” David Clough told me when we met at the American Academy of Religion conference, held in Baltimore before Thanksgiving. “And she was in the unhappy position of having a father who had reflected ethically on the question at some length” — a father with misgivings about the human use of animals, even for companionship.

headline: Getting Back to Even
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Since the downturn began in December 2007, the economy has had a net decline of about 1 percent in its nonfarm payroll jobs.
lead_paragraph: For the 38th consecutive month, the country added jobs: 203,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in November, to be more precise.

headline: What I Said
abstract: VSPs, for real.
lead_paragraph: I’m in a meeting of the Bavarian Illuminati Group of 30; very interesting discussion, all off the record. But I can’t resist mentioning that one participant, arguing that we should end easy-money policies despite the continuing depressed state of the economy, warned of potential costs and declared that these costs have been stressed by “very serious people.” The participant clearly did not have capital letters on the words, even implicitly. But I did have a hard time not laughing.

headline: Hell on Shoe Leather
abstract: William B. Helmreich, armed with a pedometer and a tape recorder, explored a “city with 120,000 blocks” and came out with “The New York Nobody Knows.”
lead_paragraph: During the golden weeks of autumn, it seemed as if everyone in the world wanted to go for a walk with William B. Helmreich. The journalist from Norway. Students who have lapped up his courses at City College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. The publicist at Princeton University Press, which just published “The New York Nobody Knows: Walking 6,000 Miles in the City,” his doorstop-size account of four years of trekking into every corner of the five boroughs, dead-end streets and desolate industrial areas included.

headline: Spending Again, Mets Lure Granderson
abstract: The Mets agreed with outfielder Curtis Granderson on a four-year, $60 million deal, making him the club’s highest-paid free agent in Sandy Alderson’s tenure.
lead_paragraph: When Curtis Granderson said earlier this week that he had the salmon while having lunch with Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, the comment, almost predictably, turned into comic material. The Mets could not afford to offer Granderson a steak, the Twitter jokes went. The Mets had to split the bill. And of course Granderson ended up eating salmon; the Mets, after all, are always swimming upstream.

headline: A Spoonful of Sugar for a Sourpuss
abstract: Richard M. Sherman, the surviving brother in the Disney songwriting duo who worked on “Mary Poppins,” recalls contending with P. L. Travers, the author of the children’s book that inspired the film.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — What happens when Richard M. Sherman hunches over a baby grand piano and leads a singalong? Judging from a recent evening on the patio at the Polo Lounge here, people not only warble the ditties but are magically transported back to childhood.

headline: Cano Said to Leave for Mariners; Beltran Reportedly Heads to Yanks
abstract: The Yankees offered $25 million annually along with their tradition and mystique, but they did not give Robinson Cano the one thing he wanted: a 10-year deal.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, shortly before they were scheduled to meet with the Seattle Mariners, representatives for Robinson Cano placed a call to the Yankees, saying they believed their client could get a 10-year deal for more than $230 million. They wanted to know how the Yankees would respond.

headline: ‘Idol,’ Meet the Trapps: The Perils of Tinkering With Favorite Things
abstract: NBC tried to graft audiences’ love for a 1965 movie onto the fascination with reality shows Thursday night in a live “Sound of Music,” starring Carrie Underwood.
lead_paragraph: Nobody could solve the problem of this Maria.

headline: A Fanboy Shows Superheroes the Way
abstract: Greg Berlanti’s “Arrow” has found a formula for success and now he’s working another superhero show, about the Flash.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Greg Berlanti, watching from a distance, couldn’t stop smiling as he sidled up to members of his creative team on the set here of “Arrow” — his second-season CW network adaptation of the “Green Arrow” comic book character — gushing like the adolescent fanboy he used to be.

headline: T HOLIDAY
abstract: Rei Kawakubo, the singular designer of Commes des Garcons, is bringing her multibrand store Dover Street Market to New York City.
lead_paragraph: Rei Kawakubo, the singular designer of Commes des Garcons, is bringing her multibrand store Dover Street Market to New York City.

headline: No Rehearsals for a Prestige Cast
abstract: The director Scott Cooper explains how he wrote “Out of the Furnace” for Christian Bale, but chose to forgo rehearsals.
lead_paragraph: In terms of Oscar nominees and winners per frame, the ensemble films “August: Osage County” and “American Hustle” may be tough to beat this season. (Honorable mention: “Prisoners,” starring Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Melissa Leo and Paul Dano.) But “Out of the Furnace,” from the writer-director Scott Cooper (whose “Crazy Heart” earned two Oscars, including a long-overdue statue for Jeff Bridges) and starring Christian Bale (Oscar winner), Casey Affleck (nominee), Woody Harrelson (nominee) and Forest Whitaker (winner) makes a strong showing.

headline: Undaunted by Giants
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers', 'Small Business']
abstract: For a stubborn, fiercely independent coterie of small real estate brokerages, success is measured in repeat clients, laserlike focus and resilience.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of residential real estate expertise in real estate-obsessed New York City. Upward of 20,000 licensed professionals are eager to step in and, for a seemingly small commission, assist sellers and buyers in negotiations with high-impact consequences. The brokerages employing the vast majority of agents are real estate’s equivalent of corporations, with multilayered staffs equipped to unflinchingly process multitudes of transactions. Their success is measured in quantifiable dollars; their reputations precede them.

headline: Review: 2014 Lexus LX 570

Goldberg, an unusually affable internist who bears the look of a scholarly Robert De Niro, sat in his office on the Upper East Side and described the realities of practicing general medicine in the Manhattan of the 21st century. Dr. Goldberg, who also retains a specialty in gastroenterology, opened his practice in 1993 and accepted insurance for the first 16 years. By 2008 his reimbursements for office visits had been, in some cases, reduced to a tenth of what they were in the previous decade, he said. Colonoscopies, which had once rendered him $1,800 per procedure, were now bringing in $350.

headline: Beneath Malta’s Beauty, a Tangled History
abstract: The Mediterranean island-nation of Malta couples a tranquil, movie-set surface with an astoundingly rich past.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas de Piro doesn’t look like a warrior monk. As the bespectacled grandfather padded around his 16th-century palazzo, pointing out curiosities like a gilded sedan chair and silver medical tools, he appeared more likely to offer me a cup of tea than slay anyone in the name of Christ. And yet that is the sort of thing Mr. de Piro’s order, the Knights of Malta (officially the Sovereign Hospitaller Order of the Knights of St. John of Jerusalem, of Rhodes and of Malta), were known for in their heyday. Drawn from the most noble families of Europe, they left their homelands, took vows of chastity and obedience and dedicated themselves to fighting infidels. The order no longer wages war, focusing instead on caring for the sick and poor. Until I arrived at Mr. de Piro’s doorstep on the Mediterranean island-nation of Malta, though, I’d had no idea that the Knights of Malta still existed.

headline: Mandela’s Socialist Failure
abstract: If we want to remain faithful to Mandela’s legacy, we should focus on the unfulfilled promises his leadership gave rise to.
lead_paragraph: In the last two decades of his life, Nelson Mandela was celebrated as a model of how to liberate a country from the colonial yoke without succumbing to the temptation of dictatorial power and anti-capitalist posturing. In short, Mandela was not Mugabe, South Africa remained a multi-party democracy with free press and a vibrant economy well-integrated into the global market and immune to hasty Socialist experiments. Now, with his death, his stature as a saintly wise man seems confirmed for eternity: there are Hollywood movies about him — he was impersonated by Morgan Freeman, who also, by the way, played the role of God in another film; rock stars and religious leaders, sportsmen and politicians from Bill Clinton to Fidel Castro are all united in his beatification.

The N.R.A. has so far stayed silent on the measure’s bipartisan renewal. headline: Quirky Kikkerland Opens Its First Retail Store

lead_paragraph: Kikkerland, a New York company that has been selling quirky, colorful accessories for more than 20 years, has opened its first retail store. The shop — a 1,000-square-foot space in the West Village — offers the company’s entire collection, including lightning-bolt-shaped power strips and bottle openers resembling Mexican wrestlers, along with products from other manufacturers. Kevin Brynan, an owner of the home store Mxyplyzyk, which closed its Greenwich Avenue location last year after more than two decades, was hired to assist in the creation. “I was actually one of their first customers,” in the early ’90s, Mr. Brynan said, adding that he and Kikkerland’s owner, Jan van der Lande, have long shared an appreciation for amusing design. The store’s interior, designed by FormNation, is as playful as the products, with display structures shaped like buildings, tables reminiscent of haphazardly stacked boxes and a central shelving unit that doubles as a floor-to-ceiling ladder to nowhere. Kikkerland is at 493 Avenue of the Americas (West 13th Street). Information: 212-678-2250 or kikkerland.com.

headline: Hyundai Reverses Policy on Settling Warranty Disputes
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Before the change, the company’s policy required some matters to be settled through binding arbitration.
lead_paragraph: Until Friday evening, owners of Hyundais who had not studied a supplement to their owner’s handbooks might have been surprised if their cars developed problems that resulted in disputes over warranty coverage. The jolt would come in the form of a policy that required some warranty disputes to be settled through binding arbitration — unless owners notified Hyundai, within 90 days of purchasing the vehicle, of their decision to opt out of the arrangement.

headline: Reading for Enthusiasts of Every Level
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Books and Literature', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: A clever racing history meant for young children and adults; an account of Mustang’s first five decades; and a travelogue of a biker’s world journey are among six recently published automotive books.
lead_paragraph: For car and motorcycle enthusiasts a book can be a lasting and appreciated gift, but what book? These six reviews can help in sorting through publishers’ recent offerings. Among them is a clever racing history meant for young children and adults; a compendium of stories, some very bizarre indeed, about cars and the people who collect them; an account of Mustang’s first five decades; and a travelogue of a biker’s around-the-world journey.

headline: A Singer Is Part of the Big Picture
abstract: Cécile McLorin Salvant is the latest answer to the question of what jazz has to do with you.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a 25-foot-tall photograph of the jazz singer Cécile McLorin Salvant has been on view outside the main entrance to Jazz at Lincoln Center, at 60th Street and Broadway. Such a distinction happened quickly by jazz-world standards. She’s 24, and her first album with any distribution, “WomanChild” (Mack Avenue), came out only six months ago. But it’s not surprising that Jazz at Lincoln Center should want to go out on a limb to promote her. Though she writes her own songs, she puts original, idiosyncratic and virtuosic force on old repertory, some of it from the high era of American songbook standards, some of it older than jazz itself.

headline: Commemoration and Celebration
abstract: The superb violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is back in town this week, and celebration is on her agenda.
lead_paragraph: The superb violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is back in town this week, and celebration is on her agenda. On Tuesday night, she will join the New York Philharmonic to herald her new Deutsche Grammophon CD, a red-blooded account of Dvorak’s rich, robust Violin Concerto. Manfred Honeck, who conducts the Berlin Philharmonic on the disc, will also direct her Philharmonic rendition of the work, presented alongside Dvorak’s “Carnival” Overture and “New World” Symphony. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

headline: New Home for a Festival
abstract: The eclectic, genre-busting festival Migrating Forms, now in its fifth year, has itself migrated — to BAMcinématek.
lead_paragraph: The eclectic, genre-busting festival Migrating Forms, now in its fifth year, has itself migrated — to BAMcinématek. As for forms, expect all types, from experimental shorts to features by the Hong Kong auteur Johnnie To. The festival opens on Wednesday with an art-gallery-meets art-house punch: four shorts by Ryan Trecartin first presented as an installation at the Venice Biennale. Mr. Trecartin — he “seems bound for greatness,” the art critic Roberta Smith wrote in The New York Times — will introduce the films.

headline: Footwork With Fury
abstract: It’s easy to associate flamenco with wild stamping, and Soledad Barrio can stamp with fury.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to associate flamenco with wild stamping, and Soledad Barrio can stamp with fury. But she can also do more than that — much more. Her dynamic and emotional range helps make her one of today’s leading exponents of this traditional Spanish form. In her company, Noche Flamenca, she is surrounded by excellent dancing partners, guitarists and singers, and the little troupe can seem like a family onstage. In her solos, Ms. Barrio invests old flamenco forms with new life, showing herself capable of both light dartings and outbursts of raw passion, her footwork recalling laughter at one moment and gunfire the next.

headline: A (Big) Bit of Egypt in Central Park
abstract: The oldest man-made, outdoor object in New York is the towering, granite obelisk in Central Park known as Cleopatra’s Needle: It’s nearly 3,500 years old.
lead_paragraph: The oldest man-made, outdoor object in New York is the towering, granite obelisk in Central Park known as Cleopatra’s Needle: It’s nearly 3,500 years old. The story of the 69-foot-tall, 220-ton, hieroglyphic-covered, Egyptian monolith is examined in “Cleopatra’s Needle,” an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that includes drawings, prints, photographs and textiles. One of a pair — the other, with the same name, is in London — the ancient obelisk and its companion were commissioned by Thutmose III in about 1450 B.C. for a sun temple in Heliopolis.

headline: Long Journey for Mother and Child
abstract: Donna Uchizono’s new work, “Fire Underground,” is inspired by her 12 years of struggling to adopt her daughter from Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Dances that keep going around in circles or in which the performers endlessly spin are usually joyful or ecstatic or in pursuit of a mystical transcendence. In “Fire Underground,” the piece by Donna Uchizono that debuted at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, she and Rebecca Serrell Cyr spin and spin and circle each other, but the effect is shattering. This dance is a heartbreaker.

(Every movement needs them.) But if you could have seen it all from above, you’d have seen it going all over the place: funk, minimalism, surf, prog, noise, theater, comedy.

headline: Photographing Outside Apartheid’s White Bubble
abstract: João Silva, a New York Times staff photographer who grew up in apartheid South Africa, recalls his awakening as a photojournalist, on the eve of Nelson Mandela’s release from prison in 1990.
lead_paragraph: João Silva was among a handful of photographers who made their reputation chronicling the fall of apartheid in South Africa. While he has gone on to cover conflicts in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere, he still lives and works in South Africa, even photographing mourners gathering in front of Nelson Mandela’s home on Friday (below). Mr. Silva recalls covering those momentous years leading up to and after Mr. Mandela’s election as South Africa’s first black president in a conversation with Shreeya Sinha, an editor at the international desk, which has been edited. More photos by Mr. Silva of Mr. Mandela, and recollections by other photographers, were published Friday in a multimedia feature.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Futurism in Men’s Wear
abstract: An alien would have met his match with New Yorkers in high-tech style.
lead_paragraph: The cutting edge of fashion is definitely reflected in the young men experimenting with new technologies in fabrics and daring cuts and colors. From the upper left, diagonally to the lower right, two artists from Atlanta, Trey Wadsworth and Trever Nichols, landed in New York at 2 a.m. with an alien in a spaceship “crashing” near the Flatiron Building. headline: Q. & A. With Anthony P. Carnevale
abstract: An outspoken advocate for changing the education system to produce more graduates with tech skills.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Carnevale, an economist who is director of the Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce, has been one of the most outspoken advocates for changing the education system to produce more graduates with skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (known as the STEM fields). He and his colleagues at the center produced an influential 2011 report showing that the United States needs to do more than produce an elite corps of STEM workers — it needs to raise those skills in the vast majority of students. More than a third of all STEM jobs by 2018 will be for those with less than a bachelor’s degree, the report found, raising the importance of high school engagement, community colleges and two-year associate degrees.
