abstract: The new policies at Cooper Union and City College, part of the City University of New York, could alter how, when and where students are allowed to express dissent.
lead_paragraph: At Cooper Union, it was outrage over a new tuition policy. At City College, it was anger over the closing of a community center. At both Manhattan colleges, student protest shut down buildings, garnered headlines and largely defined campus life over the past year. Now those two very different institutions are considering policies that could restrict how, when and where students can express dissent, while raising the penalties for those who disobey.

headline: On Horseback, Mallet in Hand, Breaking Barriers for Women
abstract: Sunny Hale, who may be the most famous female polo player in the world, has led a revolution in which female players are fueling the growth of the sport.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Under a soft blue sky at Houston Polo Club last month, Sunny Hale set the strategy as the team captain and was the leading scorer with five goals in Goose Creek’s 7-6 victory in the United States Open women’s polo championship. She was also one of the reasons the tournament has existed for the more than 20 teams and nearly 100 women who were there. Although she is hardly as well known as Nacho Figueras, the polo star and face of Ralph Lauren, Hale may be the most famous female polo player in the world. In 2000, she became the first woman on a winning team in the United States Open, and she has been named the most valuable female player seven times.

headline: Hail to the Police Chief

That was my job as a civil rights lawyer, and at that time, we had a rogue police force that refused civilian control, rejected court orders, abused people of color and acted with terrifying impunity.

headline: Iraq: 13 Sunnis Killed, Then 12 Shiites
abstract: Seven Sunni construction workers were killed by unidentified gunmen who fired on them from a speeding S.U.V. in Abara, a majority-Sunni village in Diyala Province, police and medical officials said.
lead_paragraph: Seven Sunni construction workers were killed by unidentified gunmen who fired on them from a speeding S.U.V. on Tuesday morning in Abara, a majority-Sunni village in Diyala Province, police and medical officials said. When their families took the bodies to a ritual washing hall, a bomb exploded, killing six family members, two women and four men. That evening, a suicide bomber targeted a Shiite shrine in Diyala, killing 12 Shiites. “Al Qaeda has succeeded in its strategy,” said Haider al-Musawi, a security expert and former army officer. “Now Sunnis think that the Shiites are killing them, and the Shiites think that the Sunnis killed them.” He said the situation could become worse than Syria barring an immediate solution, which would be “a miracle.” The 25 were among 31 people killed in Iraq on Tuesday.

headline: Israel: Law Reduces Migrant Detention
abstract: The Israeli Parliament passed legislation on Tuesday allowing for the detention of African migrants and asylum seekers who enter the country illegally for up to a year without trial.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli Parliament passed legislation on Tuesday allowing for the detention of African migrants and asylum seekers who enter the country illegally for up to a year without trial. The bill amended previous legislation allowing detention without trial for up to three years. Israel’s Supreme Court overturned that law in September, ruling that it violated principles of human dignity and freedom. The amendment also allows the state to hold migrants already in Israel indefinitely in what it called “open” detention facilities. About 60,000 Africans have entered Israel since 2005.

headline: Arizona: Auctioned Artifacts to Be Returned to Tribes

The Hopi artifacts are colorful and intricate masklike items held to be imbued with divine spirits. Gregory Annenberg Weingarten, a vice president of the Los Angeles-based Annenberg Foundation, said it had decided to buy the items, at a cost of $530,000, once it became clear that the Paris auction house EVE would not delay the sale to allow the tribes time to gather proof that the items had been stolen from their lands long ago. “These are not trophies to have on one’s mantel,” he said.

headline: The 10 Best Pieces at This Year’s Design Miami
abstract: The 2013 edition of the fair had a throwback feel, with numerous appealingly intimate objects from the ’40s to the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Design Miami, the nine-year-old satellite fair to Art Basel in Miami Beach, is known for showcasing works by modern masters like Jean Prouvé and Charlotte Perriand. This year proved no different, with prefab houses by both on display (Prouvé’s built within the Design Miami tent, Perriand’s on the beach behind the Raleigh Hotel). But in addition to the large-scale showstoppers, there were numerous more intimate works of interest. Many dealers showed jewelry or decorative objects alongside furniture. Several galleries created complete residential settings in which they installed their pieces. Demish Danant, for example, felt like a Parisian apartment from the 1970s with its boiserie and wall-to-wall carpeting. And while a few galleries did show new work, objects from the ’40s to the ’70s were predominant, adding to the fair’s throwback feel. Here is some of the best this year’s Design Miami had to offer.

lead_paragraph: Someone once asked David Hume Kennerly if he ever held back when he was President Gerald R. Ford’s White House photographer. Though it was sometimes difficult — as when the Fords cried after his 1976 election loss — Mr. Kennerly said he did not. “I think it comes from my background,” he said. “It comes from journalism.”

headline: David O. Russell: In Conversation
abstract: The director of “American Hustle” on redirecting his own career.
lead_paragraph: You could argue that, with his new film, “American Hustle,” coming on the heels of “The Fighter” and “Silver Linings Playbook,” David O. Russell has put together the best trifecta of any active American filmmaker. “The Fighter” earned seven Oscar nominations; “Silver Linings” received eight; and “American Hustle” was just named the year’s best film by the New York Film Critics Circle. Early in his career, Russell developed a reputation as a brilliant but difficult director; George Clooney said the two actually came to blows on the set of Russell’s third film, “Three Kings,” and later a YouTube video circulated of Lily Tomlin and Russell in a full-throated, expletive-laced shouting match on the set of his fourth film, “I Heart Huckabees.” Whether­ the characterization was fair, Russell has since undergone a personal, artistic and, ultimately, professional transformation. He regards “Hustle,” a highly fictionalized version of the Abscam scandal of the late ’70s and early ’80s, as the third in a loose trilogy of films about ordinary people trying to live passionate lives. It’s a journey he has had some experience with firsthand.

headline: How Do You Know if What You Read Online Is True?

headline: Who Goes to Work to Have Fun?
abstract: Trying to make employees happy may achieve the reverse.
lead_paragraph: “ONE of our core values is to inject fun and quirkiness into everything we do,” Neil Blumenthal, a founder of the online eyeglass retailer Warby Parker, recently told The New York Times. This is a philosophy currently enjoying a resurgence in the tech and retail industries, among others. As we enter the season of office holiday parties, it’s a safe assumption that the workplace quirkiness quotient will skyrocket. Which means it’s also the season for the curmudgeons among us to renew our passionate entreaty: Please — no, really, please — can we stop trying to “make work fun”?

headline: Potential Misunderstandings
abstract: Supply, not demand.
lead_paragraph: Izabella Kaminska reports on a “strongly worded” riposte to the secular stagnation hypothesis, in which analysts at Independent Strategy declare that we don’t have inadequate demand, we have debt causing the economy to grow above potential. Unfortunately, the paper itself isn’t available, only Kaminska’s description, so I can’t see how strong the wording is. If her description is accurate, however, some other stuff is … not so strong. For it seems that like so many writers in this area, the authors don’t understand the meaning of potential output.

headline: Upstairs, Downstairs, Outside
abstract: Our outsourced servant class.
lead_paragraph: Via Mark Thoma, David Cay Johnston has a great piece noting that today’s service economy is in many ways like the Edwardian-era economy in which a small number of wealthy people employed a large number of servants — except that we tend to outsource the service, relying on restaurants and cleaning services instead of cooks and maids. And our outsourced servants are, he notes, arguably paid and treated worse than the in-house servants of the past, even in absolute terms — let alone relative to per capita GDP.

headline: A Dangerously Divided Ukraine
abstract: Political compromises and economic help from the European Union could ease the crisis that continues to deepen.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s president, Viktor Yanukovich, took a tentative step toward defusing his country’s political turmoil earlier this week by convening a “round table” with former Ukrainian presidents to discuss possible responses to the protests engulfing the capital, Kiev. But he promptly negated any value in that gesture by ordering security police to clear the demonstrators’ encampment in Independence Square early Wednesday morning. Though the police appeared to pull back by midday, the confrontation plunges Ukraine deeper into crisis.

headline: Feasts for the Eyes, 1,001 Nights’ Worth
abstract: The film critic A. O. Scott picks his favorites of 2013 from an ever-broadening field.
lead_paragraph: By the time midnight strikes on Dec. 31, The New York Times will have reviewed almost 900 movies in the course of 2013. This number, which grows every year, nonetheless represents a tiny fraction of the moving-picture entertainment made available to the public over the previous 12 months on television, video on demand and streaming services and at the festivals that span the globe and the calendar. In such circumstances, the traditional 10-best list, always arbitrary, seems downright cruel — to filmmakers, to readers and to the overwhelmed critic who must kill, or at least neglect, some of his darlings and subject himself to the self-flagellation of second-guessing. (Oh dear: “Kill Your Darlings” — shouldn’t I have made room for that one?)

headline: The Festival World, and What’s Beyond
abstract: “American Hustle” and “12 Years a Slave” are among a critic’s favorite films of the year.
lead_paragraph: We are living in an era of cinematic abundance, so why does this feast sometimes feel like a famine? That’s the question every American critic needs to ask as she weighs the year’s bounty. From one angle, 2013 looks terrific. Critics began sending the cheering news about thinking-adult entertainment from the Cannes Film Festival in May (where “The Great Beauty,” “Inside Llewyn Davis” and “A Touch of Sin” sent filmgoers into raptures), good news that continued once the fall — a.k.a. festival, a.k.a. Oscar — season kicked off in August at Venice and Telluride, which offered up the likes of “All Is Lost,” “Gravity” and “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Yuval Adler on ‘Bethlehem’ and Heidegger
abstract: The Israeli director Yuval Adler came to film in a roundabout way that includes a doctorate in philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:54 p.m. | Before beginning a career in film, Yuval Adler, the director of “Bethlehem,” Israel’s submission for the foreign-language Oscar, worked in a lot of different fields. He also earned a Ph.D in philosophy from Columbia University, writing his dissertation on finger-pointing as an example of a linguistic phenomenon called indexicality.

abstract: Yes, Basel and its brethren were a mad blur of dollar signs, branding, V.I.P. check-ins and, of course, Kimye. But as tedious as all that could be, there were still a few moments that mattered.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest about the art fairs that concluded on Sunday in Miami. They were about one thing: money — the making of it, by selling art, and the spending of it, on having a decadently good time. And the art sold well. Very well. Dealers at the two biggest fairs, Art Basel in Miami Beach, at the Miami Beach Convention Center, and NADA (the New Art Dealers Alliance), at the Deauville Beach Resort in North Beach, boasted that despite predictions of Basel burnout, plenty of collectors attended and sales were stronger than in recent years. So rest assured that these tropical rituals of end-of-year excess will continue for the foreseeable future.

headline: Obamacare’s Many Possible Futures
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: There’s a lot of room in the space between “ringing success” and “abject failure.”
lead_paragraph: The latest data on Obamacare signups is yet another rorschach test for the law’s supporters and skeptics: The accelerating rate of signups is either evidence that enrollment might yet achieve escape velocity or an indicator (given how low, in absolute numbers, private enrollment remains) that even with a smoother website experience the program is never going to reach its “multiple millions of private enrollees” goal. I’ve been writing lately about the latter possibility, and sketching scenarios where low enrollment leads to adverse selection and makes the entire mandate-regulate-subsidize setup unsustainable. But the new numbers provide a good opportunity to note that “unsustainability” is a shorthand phrase that obscures as much as it reveals, and there are many, many likely outcomes for Obamacare that fall somewhere between “meets its supporters expectations” and “collapses under its own weight.”

headline: Beatles by the Volume, Not Shy on the Footnotes
abstract: “Tune In,” the first volume of Mark Lewisohn’s planned three-part series on the Beatles, chronicles the band members up to 1962.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 12 or Oct. 13, 1961, Paul McCartney and John Lennon visited the Hôtel de Beaune in Paris, near the Seine, to have their hair cut by a friend. Mark Lewisohn, billed on his book jacket as “the world’s only professional Beatles historian,” may know more about this seminal pop-cultural event than anyone else on the planet, including Mr. McCartney. The budding Beatle might have been too caught up in the moment to remember its exact details. Mr. Lewisohn has had some 50 years to parse them.

headline: Novelties at a Miami Art Basel Exhibition
abstract: At a pop-up during Art Basel, arty collectibles from names like Zaha Hadid, Damien Hirst, Thom Browne, James Franco and Pharrell Williams.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — Pharrell Williams’s bulletproof vest might not stop a snowflake. But that’s fine with Mr. Williams, who stopped at Art Basel Miami Beach last week to take in the art fairs and hawk a few wares of his own. His channel-quilted vests ($1,495) and mirrored shades ($595), created in collaboration with Moncler, were selling at a good clip at the Colette Art Drive-Thru, a pop-up installation by the influential Parisian retailer and the Alchemist shops on Lincoln Road here.

lead_paragraph: On Monday readers were invited to ask Op-Ed columnist Nick Kristof questions on any topic. Dozens of readers asked Nick about subjects like the freedom of the press in China, President Obama’s second term agenda, whether the Middle East will ever have a Mandela-like figure, what he leaves out of his columns and more.

headline: European Copyright Laws Lead to Rare Music Releases
keywords: ['Music', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Rock Music']
abstract: Previously unissued works by the Beatles, Bob Dylan and others will be released, albeit in very limited editions, to safeguard their European copyright protections.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a provision in the European Union’s new copyright law, fans of some musicians who made recordings in the 1960s are likely to be treated, for the foreseeable future, to annual batches of previously unissued material. But because artists and record labels are apparently unhappy about being forced to release material they would rather keep in the vaults, collectors need to be quick and alert: So far, the most tantalizing recordings have turned up in limited, hard-to-find editions. And where labels are normally eager to publicize their releases, they are doing their best to keep these ones secret.

headline: Fall North American Championships
abstract: On the final day of the Fall North American Championships in Phoenix, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — On the final day of the Fall North American Championships here on Sunday, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco: Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. They finished just over two boards ahead of Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala from Italy, Krzysztof Buras and Grzegorz Narkiewicz from Poland, and Aleksander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov from Russia. Third were Martin Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Zia Mahmood of New York City, Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J., Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.

headline: Staying Aloft in Different Styles (With or Without Dress Suits)
abstract: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented an eclectic program of works by Paul Taylor, Rennie Harris, Ohad Naharin and Robert Battle at City Center on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: For its second week in residence at City Center, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater reprised the three works that Robert Battle added to the company’s repertory when he became artistic director in 2011. Paul Taylor’s “Arden Court,” Rennie Harris’s “Home” and Ohad Naharin’s “Minus 16” afford a thorough, generous look at three styles: American modern dance, hip-hop and Gaga, the movement form invented by Mr. Naharin, an Israeli choreographer. How can a performer’s presence alter the stage’s canvas? How does subject matter, however veiled, become universal?

headline: Serving Up Folky Americana With Holiday Toppings
abstract: Kathleen Edwards, Beth Orton, Nick Lowe, Glen Hansard and Amos Lee were among the artists joining Calexico at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, the songwriter Sam Beam, who records as Iron and Wine, and the Tucson band Calexico released an EP they recorded together, “In the Reins,” giving Mr. Beam’s songs some of Calexico’s Southwestern, country-mariachi flavor. Christmastime brings family reunions, and for its annual Holiday Cheer benefit concert, on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, the Americana-loving public radio station WFUV (90.7 FM) brought Iron and Wine and Calexico back together, adding other sometime collaborators and kindred spirits: Kathleen Edwards, Beth Orton, Nick Lowe, Glen Hansard and Amos Lee. Calexico backed them all, jovial and versatile.

headline: One Best Actor, So Many Possibilities
abstract: The competition for the best actor prize is exceedingly tight this season, with a dozen leading men altering their bodies and bringing harrowing and often true stories to the screen.
lead_paragraph: Christian Bale more or less looks like himself in “Out of the Furnace,” which is something of a feat. As an ex-con mill worker in Scott Cooper’s working-class drama, Mr. Bale, a performer capable of extreme physical transformation, sports longish hair and a goatee, as he often does off screen. And, on his neck, a tattoo of the ZIP code of Braddock, Pa., where the movie is set.

Just inside, color-coded cocktails are served in tiny cups: for Blue’s partisans, a concoction of rum, Blue Curaçao and lime juice; for Black’s, bourbon and coffee liqueur. Later, for some, there will be doughnut holes.

Yet its very ordinariness makes the case of Ali v. Obama worth a few minutes’ consideration as another detention year, the 12th, draws to a close.

headline: Fashion Logo Parodies, Strictly Tongue in Chic
abstract: Logos are targets for those with a sense of humor and a license to print T-shirts.
lead_paragraph: Some people spend hundreds, even thousands of dollars to ensure that designers’ logos are prominently featured on their handbags, sneakers and jackets. But for $28, a different kind of fashion-insider cachet, knowing and impudent, can be bought. That’s the price of a T-shirt from Reason Clothing, whose apparel uses nearly identical fonts of high-fashion labels to turn Dior into “Poor,” Fendi into “Trendi,” or Balmain into “Nawman.”

headline: Mourning Son Killed at 15, and Celebrating His Life
abstract: Sharon Cherry, 45, has parties each year, on the anniversary of the death of her son, who was fatally shot in 2010, and on his birthday.
lead_paragraph: The living room of Sharon Cherry’s third-floor apartment in Harlem looks out over a playground, yet feels like a shrine. Two walls are adorned with poster-size photographs of a fresh-faced teenage boy, staring straight at the camera; Ms. Cherry wears a T-shirt printed with an image of the same face. “My son,” she said, tears already starting to stream down her face, “George White.”

headline: As Winter Nears, Chinese Capital Is Blanketed in Green
abstract: In a city crowded with BMWs, upscale malls and produce-packed supermarkets, the stockpiling of cabbage speaks to an era of scarcity that still haunts Chinese of a certain age.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Sooty skies are not the only reliable indicator that winter has finally descended on the Chinese capital. Vendors selling roasted sweet potatoes occupy street corners with their repurposed oil-drum ovens. To ward off the sniffles, Beijing cabdrivers nibble on cloves of raw garlic, making taxi rides especially trying.

headline: How to Truly Honor Mandela

abstract: A meaningful way to uphold the spirit of Nelson Mandela would be to speak out for human rights and political freedom.
lead_paragraph: World leaders, including President Obama, are jostling for the chance to celebrate Nelson Mandela this week, which would surely make Mandela smile. He had a mischievous sense of humor, and he knew better than anybody that the United States and other countries now embracing him had spurned him when he could have actually used the help.

Mr. Mandela contemplated the sight, and though he was president at the time, he promptly and inexplicably took over.

Getting rid of the sequester for domestic programs was a high priority for Congressional Democrats, and they achieved much of what they wanted in a budget deal reached on Tuesday that in other important respects was disappointing.

headline: New Act Proposes National Paid Family Leave Policy
abstract: The proposed Family and Medical Insurance Leave Act offers a way to provide paid family leave to all employees without straining employers or the federal budget.

That failing has contributed to the United States’ being condemned for human rights violations by Human Rights Watch.  The United States also ranked last in breast-feeding support by Save the Children. The case for national paid family leave has been brought up by everyone from feminist academics to Fox News anchors — and me.

headline: Pass the Cassoulet ... And the Memories

lead_paragraph: Stamped with symbols representing life experiences (a mountain, a torn heart and a pizza slice, to name just a few), Grail, a cassoulet dish from the design firm Grain, is intended to inspire mealtime conversation. “We used contemporary icons of things you would encounter in the city, traveling or online, but applied them to a more timeless piece, almost like Egyptian hieroglyphs,” said James Minola, who founded the Bainbridge Island, Wash., company with his wife, Chelsea. “We imagine people sitting around it at a table; maybe one of these icons speaks to you and reminds you of a story to share.”

headline: Rare Gems from Ettore Sottsass

lead_paragraph: Ettore Sottsass designed furniture, ceramics, dishware, jewelry, fashion boutiques, an apartment for Gianni Agnelli and, perhaps most famously, the red Valentine typewriter for Olivetti. This Austrian-born, Milan-based architect and designer also led a Zelig-like social life, founding the influential Memphis group and becoming friends with a diverse coterie that included Allen Ginsberg, Helmut Newton and Karl Lagerfeld.

headline: Stopping by the Woods at Dusk (or Dawn)
abstract: From Trove, a wallpaper inspired by a road trip through Yellowstone.
lead_paragraph: The wallpaper company Trove’s latest pattern, called Trace, was inspired by a summer road trip through Yellowstone. “There had been a fire, and as we drove through we saw many stages of the forest, in growth but also in death,” said Jee Levin, a founder of Trove with Randall Buck. The couple, who were introducing their 7-year-old son, Sebastian, to the park, photographed trees that were rugged and imperfect. Back in New York, they designed what Ms. Levin called “our own forest.” The result is a romantic image of a silhouetted woods at dusk sitting above its hand-drawn mirror image. Flip the piece and it looks like a forest at dawn. Trace is one of three patterns in Trove’s winter collection, which will be formally released next month. It is 12 feet high with a 67-inch-wide repeat, and is $16 a square foot. Information: 212-268-2046 or troveline.com.

headline: Fabrics Put Through the Wringer
abstract: Les Indiennes sells Indian cotton textiles at bargain prices at a new shop in Hudson, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Since 2000, Mary Bergtold Mulcahy has been designing block-printed organic cottons with Srinivas Pitchuka, a textile artisan in India. Working in a tradition called kalamkari, Mr. Pitchuka bleaches the textiles in the sun, washes them in the river, beats them against stones to make them soft and boils them. Then he prints them with vegetable dyes. Last month, Ms. Mulcahy opened Les Indiennes, a shop in Hudson, N.Y., that sells the fabric as quilts, pillow covers, tablecloths and yardage, along with miscellaneous home accessories. Most of the items cost up to 70 percent less than the same goods sold online or through other retailers. Eighteen-inch-square pillow covers are $25. Painted eggshell ornaments from the Czech Republic are $5 each. Les Indiennes is at 444 Warren Street, Hudson, N.Y. Information: 518-828-2811 or lesindiennes.com.

headline: With a Whoosh and a Zoom: Cleaning Tools

As vice president of New York’s Little Elves, a cleaning firm used by many designers and contractors, she takes the job to a level that would satisfy the most obsessive germaphobe.

headline: Embracing Miami’s Past and Future
abstract: Allan Shulman on his new Miami Center for Architecture and Design and the rapidly changing city it occupies.
lead_paragraph: Allan Shulman, the 51-year-old principal of the architectural firm Shulman & Associates in Miami, first became known for historic preservation. He rescued the 1915 Browns Hotel on lower Ocean Drive, which was built of pine. And he found a way to save much of the Art Deco Lincoln Theater on Lincoln Road, turning it into a stylish glass-walled H & M store. His new, 5,000-square-foot Miami Center for Architecture and Design (known as MCAD) opened last Friday in part of the 1912 main Miami Post Office, on Northeast First Avenue, in Downtown Miami. Over the years, the building had suffered much indignity, including a spell as an Office Depot. Now, as the new headquarters of the American Institute of Architects Miami chapter, it will be a place for free community events as well as professional gatherings. Speaking by phone from his office in the Miami Design District, Mr. Shulman, president of the Miami chapter, offered details about MCAD and opinions on the city’s building scene. (The interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:30 A.M. (Starz) TO ROME WITH LOVE (2012) In Woody Allen’s tribute to the Italian cinema of the 1950s and ’60s, a retired and overly psychoanalyzed music promoter (Mr. Allen) travels with his wife (Judy Davis) to Rome, where their daughter (Alison Pill) has lost her heart to a lawyer devoted to left-wing causes (Flavio Parenti). Meanwhile, in this shuffled anthology, a young newlywed loses her way to the Trevi Fountain and falls into the arms of a movie star while her befuddled husband tries to keep his relatives in the dark, substituting a prostitute (Penélope Cruz) for her at dinner. An ordinary Roman (Roberto Benigni) is plunged into a swirl of media celebrity. And a fledgling architect (Jesse Eisenberg) finds his relationship with his kind, if bland, girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) in shreds when her neurotic actress friend visits. Alec Baldwin plays the older architect — a ghost? a specter of the younger man’s self? — who witnesses the ordeal. “One of the most delightful things about ‘To Rome With Love’ is how casually it blends the plausible and the surreal, and how unabashedly it revels in pure silliness,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The movie’s limitations, “as frothy as the milk atop a cappuccino, are finally inseparable from its delights.” Complaining, he added, “would be as superfluous — though also, perhaps, as inevitable — as psychoanalysis.”

headline: Inside the Power of the N.R.A.
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: It has been a year since the Newtown shootings. Federal gun laws haven’t changed. Here is why.
lead_paragraph: To get to Joe Manchin’s private office in the Hart Senate Office Building, you first pass through a lobby where you encounter a small bronze statue of an Old West lawman holding a firearm — an award given to Manchin several years ago by a chapter of the National Rifle Association for his unswerving defense of gun rights. Then you turn down a hallway, past several framed photographs of children who were victims of the massacre a year ago at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn. The combination of the bronze rifleman in the lobby and the young faces on the wall suggests a particular viewpoint — I stand with gun lovers; I stand with victims of gun violence  — that qualifies, in Washington anyway, as being nuanced, which is to say politically ill advised if not suicidal.

A large Mickey Mouse plush toy appears from time to time to provide an extra touch of humor and warmth. But it would be unfair to dismiss this picture, directed by John Lee Hancock from a script by Kelly Marcel and Sue Smith, as an exercise in corporate self-promotion. It’s more of a mission statement.

headline: At Paris Brasseries, Cuisine to Match the Scene
abstract: In recent years, the city’s brasseries have gained a reputation for mediocrity. But at these four spots, diners can find both a lively atmosphere and satisfying food.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in the Gare St.-Lazare, in the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, is the restaurant Lazare. This new spot from Eric Frechon, the chef who earned three Michelin stars at Epicure, is charming and satisfying. But it’s notable for another reason: It’s leading a revival of the Parisian brasserie. That’s good news for anyone who loves the fast-paced restaurants that once epitomized glamour while offering good simple Gallic grub and first-rate people-watching, but in recent years have gained a reputation for mediocrity after many became part of restaurant chains more interested in the bottom line than good cooking.

headline: Drawing Yourself Into the Scene
abstract: How can art deepen the travel experience? Following the trail of artists ranging from Dalí to Vermeer reveals some answers.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Saturday in early fall, a small group gathered for a Surrealist show at Cap de Creus, the craggy easternmost point of Spain where the artist Salvador Dalí had lived. The performers were wearing carnival-type costumes with black lace tutus and gold lamé gloves and were playing guitars and drums. They scrambled across the rocks and those of us in the audience followed — as much participants in the spectacle as viewers of it. When we arrived at a large and particularly oddly shaped outcropping, we were given paper and pens and asked to draw what we saw.

headline: The Radicalism of Lincoln’s 10 Percent Plan
abstract: The president’s scheme for bringing the Confederate states back into the Union was savvier than his critics allow.
lead_paragraph: Scores of students have been taught that Abraham Lincoln’s Proclamation of Amnesty and Reconstruction, appended to the presidential message to Congress of December 1863, offered rebels an easy way to get back into his good graces: as soon as they took an oath of loyalty to the Union and promised to support emancipation, he would pardon them and return their confiscated property (except for emancipated slaves, of course). Moreover, as soon as 10 percent of the 1860 electorate in any rebel state had taken the oath, he would permit that 10 percent to commence home rule and elect state officials.

headline: Are Today’s New Surgeons Unprepared?
abstract: A new study suggests that since limits on training hours went into effect, fewer than half of new young surgeons can operate on their own, and nearly a third of them are incapable of performing even the most basic operations.
lead_paragraph: The surgeon had no prestigious named professorship, no N.I.H. grant and no plum administrative position in the hospital’s hierarchy. But to the other surgeons-in-training and me, he was exactly who we wanted to be.

headline: What is Really at Stake in the Thai Protests
abstract: Guest blogger Lizzie Presser looks at what is fueling massive demonstrations in Thailand, and why we should be hopeful about the outcome.
lead_paragraph: In a trim garden outside her pink plaster house, 62-year-old Amnuay Warayot recounted her past life. Before moving here, she lived in a slum by the trains, where electricity and water were hard to come by and the wooden homes were no match for the northeast Thai rainy season. The man who gave her all this, she tells me, has won over her heart. His name is Thaksin Shinawatra, and he’s the former prime minister.

headline: Escapism at the Movies? Not Exactly
abstract: Movies like “Nebraska,” “Gravity” and “The Wolf of Wall Street” express a creeping sense of powerlessness in modern society.
lead_paragraph: “Generalized anxiety.” That is by far the most common complaint voiced by the clients of a prominent New York psychiatrist whom I recently asked to identify the malaise of the moment. As much as that term evokes a sense of foreboding behind the glittering facade of Manhattan, it also describes the wary, embattled tone of world cinema in 2013.

While many owners of small companies have a low tolerance for mistakes, which I believe is one reason many of them never get bigger, Ms. Wade realizes that mistakes are learning opportunities.

headline: From Brecht to Jukebox Musicals
abstract: New plays by Amy Herzog and Annie Baker — as well as usual classics and unusual genres — are among a year’s most pleasurable productions.
lead_paragraph: Reflecting on the highlights of my year in theatergoing, I was often brought up short by a sense of renewed surprise. How odd, really, that a production of a play by Bertolt Brecht — a genius of 20th-century theater, yes, but often about as much fun as a doctor’s visit in production — provided more giddy fun than most Broadway musicals. The idea of listening in on eight hours of a phone conversation could hardly sound more tedious, but the show derived from that very source was among the most inspired and imaginative I saw this year. Herewith, in alphabetical order, are the shows that gave me the most pleasure, often by catching me off guard.

headline: Q. & A. With Carol S. Dweck
abstract: A psychologist who has done extensive research on why women tend to avoid careers in math and science.
lead_paragraph: Carol S. Dweck, a psychologist at Stanford University, has done extensive research on why women tend to avoid careers in math and science. Her work has shown that women and girls who think that science and math ability are innate tend to perform worse and have less interest in those fields than females who believe that those skills can be acquired through hard work. As she describes the distinction, one is a “gift” mindset and the other a “growth” mindset.

Readers from a variety of fields and economic backgrounds responded with an outpouring of experiences: the Connecticut stay-at-home father who tells white lies about his lack of employment (“which career is it this week?”); the wife who said the role reversal made her marriage “more egalitarian and respectful.”

lead_paragraph: Ronald D. Liebowitz, who has greatly expanded the reach of Middlebury College, will step down in 2015, after 11 years as president, he said Thursday. Under Dr. Liebowitz, Middlebury, a selective small college in rural Vermont, took over the Monterey Institute of International Studies in California, opened new schools overseas and expanded its summer language schools. Dr. Liebowitz said a major remaining concern is enrollment of minority and low-income students, where Middlebury trails most other elite colleges. Middlebury also announced a governance overhaul, giving each trustee broader oversight duties.

Any deal would be both big and logical, since Ziggo and a unit of Liberty, UPC, dominate the local market. And Liberty already owns a dominant stake in Ziggo. lead_paragraph: Irving Rosenfeld, the con man running the great scam in “American Hustle,” isn’t, his mistress admits, much to look at. He has a belly the size of a beer keg and a torturously complicated comb-over that he arranges with the fastidiousness of a Michelin-starred pastry chef. Appearances are not everything to Irving (Christian Bale), but rather just part of the swindle that is his life’s work, his passion and genius. The confidence game is his honey pot: It’s what lines his pockets, lights his fire and cigars, and has transformed the mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), into his equal in theft and dissimulation, making her the Rosalind Russell to his Cary Grant in a romp that’s pure Scorsese screwball.

lead_paragraph: Spend an afternoon dipping in and out of galleries on the Lower East Side, and you are likely to encounter many examples of geometric abstraction — much of it offhand and whimsical. But if you want to see the work of an artist who cares deeply about geometry, pay a visit to Dorothea Rockburne’s austere, bracing exhibition of drawings at the Museum of Modern Art. The difference is instructive.

There are three often-overlooked historic homes there where you can stretch your legs and your imagination for a high-flying ride through war, sex scandals and a shooting from over two centuries ago.

If you were in class, and the alarm went off, you got under your desk with your hands on your head. How was that supposed to save you from bombs? You didn’t know. You just hoped it would.

headline: In the Middle of Middle-earth
abstract: Part 2 of Peter Jackson’s trilogy based on the one-part “Hobbit,” “The Desolation of Smaug,” has lots of battles, an original character and Orlando Bloom.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug,” the second part of Peter Jackson’s extended-play adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien’s children’s book, Bilbo Baggins has a sword called Sting and One Ring to Rule Them All — eventually. We have a ways to go. As everyone on Earth and in Middle-earth surely knows, Mr. Jackson, having turned Tolkien’s trilogy “The Lord of the Rings” into three hit films, has given its prequel a blockbuster do-over in three separate 3-D movies. The first, “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” a soporific 170 minutes released in 2012, lived up to its subtitle principally by moving at a snail’s pace. At 161 minutes the new one by contrast feels like a sprint. (The third, “The Hobbit: There and Back Again,” is set for world domination in December 2014.)

headline: A Tension Between the Sacred and the Profane
abstract: “Brancusi in New York 1913 — 2013” and “Arman the Collector: The Artist’s Collection of African Art” showcase tribal art.
lead_paragraph: What is it about African tribal art that so allures us denizens of the modern, industrialized world? I wonder this whenever I encounter tribal artifacts in museums and galleries, and I’m prompted to again by two exhibitions presented by Paul Kasmin Gallery in Chelsea. In Kasmin’s 10th Avenue gallery, there’s “Arman the Collector: The Artist’s Collection of African Art,” a stunning presentation of works collected by the artist known for accumulating many similar objects into absurdist sculptures. Then, around the corner, in Kasmin’s West 27th Street gallery, there’s “Brancusi in New York 1913 – 2013,” a glowing display of five polished bronze works celebrating the 100th anniversary of Constantin Brancusi’s participation in the New York Armory show of 1913.

headline: A Cellar for Any Situation, Any Price
abstract: Wine suggestions for several possible types of holiday gatherings, from romantic dinners for two to football takeout.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need me to remind you the holidays are here (as if you could forget). While it’s easy to bemoan the crass commercialization and artifice, it’s also easy to overlook the opportunities for all sorts of gatherings and the real joys that come with them. Let’s just stipulate that in the hierarchy of pleasures, people come first. Now that we agree on that, good food and drink can help make any party better. Here are some suggestions for several possible types of gatherings. The suggestions are not rigid: if you see something you like better in another, go for it. Above all, these should be gifts to yourself.

headline: He Wants Her Back. She’s Not Interested.
abstract: In “Some Velvet Morning,” directed by Neil LaBute, a man rings a former lover’s doorbell and tells her he has left his wife.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to discuss “Some Velvet Morning,” the latest movie from Neil LaBute, without giving away too much. This is by design. Set entirely inside a Brooklyn brownstone — with a brief trip to the backyard — this gendered gabfest has been constructed along familiar LaButian lines. A man and a woman pace like inmates, jawing and clawing and drawing metaphoric (or not) blood, and then Mr. LaBute, rather like a mean O. Henry, tosses in a detonating surprise that either changes what you’ve thought until that moment or ticks you off. This audience baiting is also very much by design, of course, and can be playful or sadistic or both, or neither.

headline: Legacy, Memory, Inspiration, AIDS
abstract: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performs Bill T. Jones’s “D-Man in the Waters” at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Bill T. Jones choreographed “D-Man in the Waters” in 1989, when the mortal danger of AIDS was at a high tide. The work celebrates the buoyant spirit of the dancer Demian Acquavella, who had AIDS and died the following year, but swimming in its waters are many others, including Mr. Jones’s partner, Arnie Zane, who had died the previous year. And at City Center on Wednesday, when Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed “D-Man” for the first time, there was inevitably one more spirit present: Alvin Ailey, whose AIDS-related death came the year the dance was made.

headline: A Blade, Then Blood
abstract: Sondra Radvanovsky sang the title role in Luc Bondy’s bleak version of “Tosca” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Some opera productions are defined by what’s not there. Luc Bondy’s bleak “Tosca” has been part of the Metropolitan Opera’s repertory since 2009, when it opened the season to lusty booing. That was due in great part to the grim sets, which have none of the historical detail of the Franco Zeffirelli production. Only bare brick walls and what appear to be Ikea folding chairs offer respite for a viewer tired of puzzling over that Lucian Freud painting that has somehow found its way into the church, perhaps dumped there by Napoleonic troops after an art looting expedition into the future. Also missing in Mr. Bondy’s “Tosca” are the crucifix and candles she places on and around the body of the villainous Scarpia after she has stabbed him to death.

headline: Now Screening | Putting a Human Face on the African AIDS Epidemic
abstract: In the new documentary “The Carrier,” the first-time director Maggie Betts cuts to the heart of the problem by getting to know the people affected by it.
lead_paragraph: The central figure in the director Maggie Betts’s affecting documentary, “The Carrier,” 28-year-old Mutinta Mweemba, is H.I.V.-positive and pregnant. A partner in a polygamous marriage in a small Zambian village, Mweemba is following a Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission (P.M.T.C.T.) program, receiving medication to keep the disease from being transmitted to her child. The film tracks Betts’s interactions with her family members (her husband and one of his two other wives are also infected) and her community, creating an unexpectedly intimate, nonjudgmental snapshot of the African AIDS epidemic. It shows how universal a mother’s fear of harming her child is, regardless of social or economic differences. “There’s no way an innocent baby who hasn’t even been born yet could have done anything to deserve this fate,” Betts says.

headline: Out of Prison, Back in the Life
abstract: “Friend 2: The Legacy,” a sequel to a popular gangster tale in South Korea, is full of nods to “The Godfather: Part II.”
lead_paragraph: The South Korean director Kwak Kyung-taek is from Busan, the setting for much of the action in “Friend 2: The Legacy,” a sequel to his breakout gangster hit from 2001. Unlike the hardscrabble characters in his new movie, Mr. Kwak is from a family of doctors. He abandoned medical school to study film at New York University, and both his style and themes seem indebted to New York-based films by his fellow alumnus Martin Scorsese and by Francis Ford Coppola.

headline: Young, Naïve and Selling Sex
abstract: “Tricked” looks at women forced into prostitution in the United States and their unpunished exploiters.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of “Tricked,” Jane Wells and John-Keith Wasson’s exposé of human trafficking in North America, the despicably smooth-talking Robert Money explains that all women are either prostitutes or whores. A preening pimp, he should know: His sordid taxonomy is the foundation of his entire business plan.

headline: Good Heavens, They’re Atheists
abstract: In the documentary “The Unbelievers,” the prominent secularists Richard Dawkins and Lawrence Krauss travel the world accompanied by a rock soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: The ghost of Christopher Hitchens hovers disapprovingly over “The Unbelievers,” a self-professed rock ’n’ roll tour film about science and reason that plays like a publicity stunt for its secular stars.

headline: Doctor, Cellist, Clown, Humanitarian
abstract: The documentary “Beatocello’s Umbrella” focuses on Dr. Beat Richner and his efforts to fund his hospitals for children in Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: The King of Cambodia seems really nice in “Beatocello’s Umbrella,” Georges Gachot’s heart-melting documentary. He has a wide, warm smile, and he pats the children’s heads when he visits them at the hospital. But the star here is Dr. Beat Richner, who is royal in his own rumpled, noble way.

headline: What Happens When the Kids Wander Off
abstract: In “Here Comes the Devil,” directed by Adrián García Bogliano, a family falls apart after a mysterious night on a forbidding hillside.
lead_paragraph: Graphic sex and bloody violence are inextricably linked in “Here Comes the Devil,” a muddled supernatural thriller that fails to capitalize on either its horrific prologue or eerie location.

headline: Saving a Newborn One Breath at a Time
abstract: In “Hours,” Paul Walker of “The Fast and the Furious” fame plays a man trying to keep his fragile daughter alive after Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: It might be hard to watch the signature “Fast and the Furious” movies of Paul Walker for a while because of his death last month in a car crash. But “Hours,” in which he stars and is rarely off screen, is a solid alternative. No speeding cars in this combination ticktock thriller and psychological study. Mr. Walker’s character, Nolan, spends almost the entire movie in a single building.

headline: Govern in Poetry
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Poetry and Poets', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Wallowing in the worst slump of his presidency, President Obama should reach for some words that will outlive him.
lead_paragraph: In advance of a long drive through the coulee country of eastern Washington, my friend Sam gave me an audio companion — a CD of the greatest presidential speeches of the 20th century. Um, thanks. I would sooner listen to Sarah Palin on Aristotle — you got that Greek philosophy thing going there — than hear the scratchy voices of long-dead politicians.

Neither the United Nations, which confers legitimacy, nor all the European Union, whose members are divided on the question, much less Serbia, from which Kosovo broke away, recognize the birth of a new European nation.

The nominee, Abdiweli Sheikh Ahmed Mohamed, has a background in economics and development work around the world. He will have to be endorsed by Parliament before taking office.

headline: Spain: Catalonia Calls Vote on Split
abstract: Catalonia, Spain’s economic powerhouse, headed toward a standoff with Madrid on Thursday after separatist parties in the region announced a date next year for an independence referendum.
lead_paragraph: Catalonia, Spain’s economic powerhouse, headed toward a standoff with Madrid on Thursday after separatist parties in the region announced a date next year for an independence referendum. The threat to hold a vote — and potentially break apart Spain — drew an immediate rebuke from Spanish officials who called it a violation of the Constitution. Catalan officials, however, say the vote would not be a constitutionally defined binding referendum, but rather “a popular consultation.”

headline: Pakistan: Justice’s Crusade Closes
abstract: After a tumultuous eight-year term, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, 65, stepped down as Pakistan’s chief justice on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous eight-year term in which he defied and outplayed the military ruler Pervez Musharraf, terminated a prime minister and changed the Supreme Court’s role from political pawn to power player, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, 65, stepped down as Pakistan’s chief justice on Thursday. As his legacy, he leaves a court that has now proved able to call even the country’s powerful generals to account. But he also polarized public debate, drawing accusations that he had become a power-drunk crusader who brought an elected Pakistani government to the brink of collapse. His successor, Justice Tassaduq Hussain Jillani, is generally considered to be more mild-mannered, and he will have less than a year in the post before reaching the retirement age of 65.

headline: California: Guilty Plea Is Planned in Navy Case
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Contracts']
abstract: A Navy criminal investigator, John B. Beliveau II, plans to plead guilty to accepting bribes from a Malaysian contractor, representing the first conviction in a major ship-supply scandal.
lead_paragraph: A Navy criminal investigator, John B. Beliveau II, plans to plead guilty on Tuesday to accepting bribes from a Malaysian contractor, representing the first conviction in a major ship-supply scandal, his lawyer, Gretchen Von Helms, said Thursday. Federal prosecutors in San Diego have accused Mr. Beliveau of accepting trips and prostitutes in exchange for alerting the contractor, Leonard Glenn Francis, to inquiries into his billing practices. Mr. Beliveau, who is expected to cooperate with investigators, is one of six Navy officials connected to the scandal. Prosecutors contend that Mr. Francis overcharged the Navy by at least $20 million.

headline: A Poor Apology for a Word
abstract: It is peculiarly English to use the word “sorry” to defuse the potential for conflict while drawing attention to it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I am sitting in a cafe in a leafy part of South London. A teenager inadvertently bashes me in the face with his rucksack and I say “sorry,” as if on his behalf. Five minutes later, a young woman flattens my foot with her stroller and each of us blurts another “sorry.” Getting up to leave, I knock over my cup. A waitress descends on this little embarrassment with a cloth and an accusatory “sorry,” while I twice utter the same word.

headline: The Great War’s Ominous Echoes
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: If we cannot determine how World War I happened, how can we hope to avoid another such catastrophe?
lead_paragraph: Oxford, England — Earlier this year, I was on holiday in Corsica and wandered into the church of a tiny hamlet in the hills where I found a memorial to the dead from World War I. Out of a population that can have been no more than 150, eight young men, bearing among them only three last names, had died in that conflict. Such lists can be found all over Europe, in great cities and in small villages. Similar memorials are spread around the globe, for the Great War, as it was known before 1940, also drew soldiers from Asia, Africa and North America.

headline: 36 Hours in Colombo, Sri Lanka
abstract: Visitors often bolt from the capital soon after arriving, headed to Sri Lanka’s outdoorsy attractions. Here’s what they’re missing by not lingering a little longer.
lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka is so jam-packed with alluring outdoorsy activities that visitors often high-tail it out of the capital a day or two after arriving, choosing instead to spend their vacation days lounging on a southern beach, whale-watching off the coast or leopard-spotting in a national park. Yet Colombo is fast becoming a draw in itself. This city of 555,000 people has been on fast-forward since a 25-year civil war ended in 2009. Checkpoints have come down, trendy lounge bars have opened up, and the vibe is one of cautious optimism combined with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook. Today, this colorful city on the Indian Ocean, with its laid-back island ambience, palm trees, decaying colonial buildings and smattering of modern office blocks, is the perfect place to get a sense of where Sri Lanka is going after so many tumultuous years.

headline: Rithy Panh on ‘The Missing Picture’ and Living With Tragedy

lead_paragraph: Of the 76 entries for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, Rithy Panh’s “Missing Picture,” representing Cambodia, is one of only two documentary films submitted in the category. But there’s never been a documentary quite like “The Missing Picture,” in which Mr. Panh uses clay figures, dioramas, period music and archival film footage recovered through detective work to tell the story of how his family — parents, siblings and nephews — and 1.8 million others perished in the Khmer Rouge genocide.

headline: A Health Care Mystery Explained
abstract: What do Republicans want?
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein is puzzled (or at least says he is; I suspect he understands it perfectly) by Republican hypocrisy on health care. For many years the GOP has advocated things that are supposed to bring the magic of the marketplace and individual incentives to health care: higher deductibles to give people “skin in the game”, competition among private insurers via exchanges — competition that would include reducing costs by limiting networks — and, of course, for cuts in Medicare. lead_paragraph: More than half of the potential Oscar best actor nominees became Golden Globes hopefuls on Thursday, helped by the Globes comedy and drama categories, which means Oscar Isaac (“Inside Llewyn Davis”) doesn’t have to compete against Chiwetel Ejiofor (“12 Years a Slave”). It’s still a crowded field, though, with many big-screen heroes in high-stakes roles. Oscar-caliber tales are often about survival, but rarely have so few been literally death-defying.

headline: Army Coach Faces Tough Call at Quarterback
abstract: Rich Ellerson, whose Black Knights are seeking to halt an 11-game skid against Navy, must choose between Angel Santiago and A. J. Schurr.
lead_paragraph: Mired in a record 11-game losing streak against Navy, Army may resort to a late-season quarterback change when the storied series resumes Saturday in Philadelphia for a 114th meeting.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Coolest Small Businesses in America
abstract: Competing with Amazon. Overcoming toxic employee behaviors. How to teach your children to be entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: On a Tragic Anniversary, Turning Off the News
abstract: An unexpected remembrance of Newtown on the car radio led to a conversation about my daughter’s fears, and a reminder that we are lucky to be able to can choose how—and whether—our children mark this anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Last year, at this time, we were listening to a lot of holiday music on the radio in the car.

headline: Rights Advocate Is Indicted in China Over Role in Campaign Against Corruption
abstract: The activist, Xu Zhiyong, was charged for his role in a grass-roots campaign that prompted street rallies across the country.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese prosecutors have formally indicted a prominent rights advocate for his role in an anticorruption campaign that prompted street rallies across the country and deeply alarmed Communist Party leaders, his lawyer said Friday.

headline: Strange Moors
abstract: Minae Mizumura reimagines Emily Brontë’s “Wuthering Heights” set in postwar Japan.
lead_paragraph: “A True Novel” is a riveting tale of doomed lovers set against the backdrop of postwar Japan, with characters familiar to a Western audience: a rags-to-riches antihero, a tempestuous heroine who dies too young, a loyal housekeeper who tells their story. So how does the Gothic excess of “Wuthering Heights” translate to a culture better known for emotional restraint, even repression?

headline: Tough Guise
abstract: In these novellas, Jim Harrison lets his hero, B. D., loose in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: My all-boys high school A.P. English class was presided over by a glamorous, overqualified woman known to us as Dr. Lerner. I might have been in love with her. She smelled wonderful, like lemon trees on a hot day. Knowing she was a doctor of literature didn’t prevent me from imagining various medical situations in which she saved my life.

headline: Maestro
abstract: Leonard Bernstein’s correspondence reveals a man torn by competing drives, both artistic and personal.
lead_paragraph: Whenever a generous collection of correspondence like “The Leonard Bernstein Letters” appears, one rejoices, but sadly. People still write one another, though usually through electronic and social media that discourage leisurely soul-searching or digressions. Lenny was lucky he didn’t live later, or we’d have “The Leonard Bern­stein Tweets.”

headline: Patronizing the Arts
abstract: Alain de Botton and John Armstrong contend that the primary purpose of art is to offer therapeutic assistance.
lead_paragraph: Who’s afraid of Alain de Botton? At 43, he’s already an elder in the church of self-help, the master of spinning sugary “secular sermons” out of literature (“How Proust Can Change Your Life”), philosophy (“The Consolations of Philosophy”), architecture (“The Architecture of Happiness”). He has a remarkably guileless face and a friendly, populist vision of art. Why then do I keep checking my pockets? And why the grumbles that he condescends to his subjects and regards his readers, as the British writer Lynn Barber put it, as “ants”?

headline: Seduced by Naples
abstract: More than Florence, Rome or Venice, the author argues, it is Naples that is one of the most romantic cities in the world.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t take long to understand Naples.

headline: Bon Appétit
abstract: This fall brings four more books over which Julia Child’s long shadow looms.
lead_paragraph: In the creation myth of modern American food, Eden is played by pre- and postwar France. It was at its tables that a handful of people well attuned to pleasure had their worlds blasted open. Their ensuing desire to build lives around the joys of food and cooking caused a revolution in the United States — and it isn’t over yet.

headline: Tips for Smart Shopping in Marrakesh
abstract: The designer Laetitia Trouillet offers advice for bargaining, avoiding buyer’s remorse and exploring shops beyond the souks.
lead_paragraph: The souks in Marrakesh have long charmed visitors with miles of closet-size shops selling Skittles-colored slippers; carpets intricately woven from camel wool and cactus silk; embroidered, buttery soft leather purses; and other wares that mark the city’s distinctive style.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘American Hustle,’ ‘Saving Mr. Banks’ and ‘The Hobbit’
abstract: Times critics on “American Hustle,” “Saving Mr. Banks” and “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics look at David O. Russell’s latest film “American Hustle,” Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug” and “Saving Mr. Banks,” featuring Tom Hanks as Walt Disney.

headline: Home Cooking
abstract: A batch of books about American cuisine reminds us how food defines who we are, where we’ve been and who we want to be.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, this big, messy country united. Culinarily, at least. We all sat down to our Thanksgiving tables and ate (mostly) the same thing at (mostly) the same time, before retreating to our big, messy corners to cook and eat the diverse, constantly evolving cuisine we call American. The latest batch of narrative food books (not to be confused with strictly recipe-driven cookbooks) explores some of those corners, reminding us how food defines who we are (Patriots? Capitalists? Shameless Worshipers of Celebrity?), where we’ve been and — ­perhaps most American of all — who we want to be.

headline: Reanimated
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: The artists of some of this season’s graphic novels transform history into broad comedy or rollicking adventure.
lead_paragraph: Comics can tell certain kinds of stories that prose, photographs and films can’t. They can also tell familiar stories in drastically different ways. The artists of some of this season’s graphic novels transform history into broad comedy or rollicking adventure. Others show us worlds frighteningly different from our own, or aestheticize the realities we know with something as simple as a set of squiggly lines or a canny splash of color.

headline: Call of the Weird
abstract: A “new American food culture” involves insects, strange body parts and raw milk.
lead_paragraph: Dana Goodyear writes with wit, grace and a contagious sense of humor about some of the most disgusting food you may never see fit to put in your mouth. Dining with a forensic entomologist who is an advocate of insects as comestibles, she reports that “he had arrived at his latest culinary discovery, he said, while experimenting with mediums for preserving maggots collected from murder victims. . . . He soaked large sarcophagid maggots in baths of grapefruit, lemon, lime, and pomelo juice, and voilà! Maggot ceviche! ‘It’s a little chewy,’ he said, ‘but tasty.’ ”

headline: Dying for Attention
abstract: The imperious forensic scientist Kay Scarpetta is in a more meditative mood than usual in Patricia Cornwell’s “Dust.”
lead_paragraph: Patricia Cornwell’s imperious forensic scientist, Kay Scarpetta, shows uncharacteristic signs of vulnerability at the beginning of DUST (Putnam, $28.95), after she returns from a traumatic trip to Newtown, Conn., to help with autopsies of victims of the mass murders at Sandy Hook Elementary School. The experience has left her in an “amnesiac” state of mind. “I can’t recall or share what at last I could explain to devastated people after I’ve taken care of their dead.”

headline: Naughty or Nice? Not Everyone Is Jolly About SantaCon Coming to Town
abstract: As thousands are preparing to don a costume and descend on New York’s streets for an annual daylong bar crawl, many bars are telling them to stay away.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have long endured other people’s celebrations.

headline: Southern Literature
abstract: New books by Daniel Woodrell, Michael Farris Smith and Claudia Zuluaga.
lead_paragraph: THE MAID’S VERSIONBy Daniel WoodrellLittle, Brown, $25.

headline: What’s the Best Bet When Weighing Cornucopians and Catastrophists?
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Earth', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Population', 'Wildfires']
abstract: Bill Gates explores society’s fascination with overstated arguments in a review of a book on resource debates.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gates has posted a valuable review of “The Bet: Paul Ehrlich, Julian Simon, and Our Gamble Over Earth’s Future,” by Yale historian Paul Sabin. Gates nicely summarizes the book’s analysis of the famous wager over the limits of natural resources between the ecologist Ehrlich, author of the portentous bestseller “The Population Bomb,” and Simon, a champion of free markets and human ingenuity (called the “Doomslayer” by Wired).

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: I AM THE CHANGE: Barack Obama and the Future of Liberalism,  by Charles R. Kesler. (Broadside/HarperCollins, $14.99.) Kesler, a conservative scholar and the editor of The Claremont Review of Books, sees President Obama as the “latest embodiment of the visionary prophet-statesman” — the fourth phase of the Progressive experiment begun at the turn of the 20th century, following Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WONDER OF WONDERS: A Cultural History of “Fiddler on the Roof,” by Alisa Solomon.  (Metropolitan/Holt, $32.) A smart social analysis of the making of the musical and its reflection of changing Jewish identity in America.

headline: Holiday Meat-and-Greet
abstract: We all know what to cook on Thanksgiving. But Christmas? New Year’s Day? Sam Sifton provides recipes and video guides for five protein-heavy main courses.
lead_paragraph: We all know what to cook on Thanksgiving. But Christmas? New Year’s Day? Sam Sifton provides recipes and video guides for five protein-heavy main courses.

headline: Playing Both Sides
abstract: Hugh Wilford traces the efforts and influence of the first generation of C.I.A. operatives in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: “The genius of you Americans,” the Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser teasingly told a senior C.I.A. official, Miles A. Copeland Jr., in the late 1950s, “is that you never made clear-cut stupid moves, only complicated stupid moves.”

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton shows how to make a ham fit for any special occasion.

headline: Talk of the Town
abstract: Daniel Menaker’s memoir recalls his time at The New Yorker and at Random House.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Menaker loves words, and you can see it in every clause, in the rhythms of his language, even in the length of the sentences in his bracing memoir, “My Mistake.” A veteran editor at The New Yorker and Random House, an insider who has always felt like an outsider, he was jolted by lung cancer several years ago into re-­examining his past. He grabs the reader with urgency as he grapples with big questions: What shaped me? Where did I go right and wrong? What has my life meant? His clever, fast-paced prose makes you stop and think and wonder, meandering down your own byways, contemplating the ways his story ­reverberates.

headline: Waiting Out the Dark
abstract: Ivan Klima, the Czech novelist and playwright, reflects on a life spent under Nazi and Communist regimes.
lead_paragraph: Why did people join the Communist movement back in the day? Ivan Klima, the distinguished Czech writer, raises the question in the prologue to his memoir, “My Crazy Century,” and he raises the temperature, too, by defining Communism as “a criminal conspiracy against democracy.” People did join, though. Klima acknowledges a little sheepishly that he was among them, in his younger years. He offers a schematic preliminary explanation: Young people need to rebel, they yearn for simple theories of the world and so forth. And then, with his prologue behind him and his anger and mortification exposed, he devotes the next 400 pages to the real explanation, which turns out to be sadder and more complicated.

headline: Dickens Without the Darkness
abstract: Paper Mill Playhouse stages a cheery and lively rendition of the lighthearted musical “Oliver!” based on a bleak tale of workhouses and thieves.
lead_paragraph: Paper Mill Playhouse’s revival of “Oliver!” takes a lighthearted musical and whisks it up into an even cheerier one.

headline: Three-Ring Circuses
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Elephants', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Hucksterism and exploitation loom large in the 200-year history of elephants in America.
lead_paragraph: Staying informed about animal issues doesn’t mean reading exclusively about the fun stuff — a Border collie who knows 1,000 words, or the recent discovery that elephants recognize the gesture of pointing, much as we do. Animal lovers must also confront darker subjects, such as the link between terrorism and the slaughter of elephants for their ivory. Soul-bruising as it is, the awful truth can point the way toward remedies.

headline: Confessions of a Daydreamer
abstract: Every era gets the Walter Mitty it deserves.
lead_paragraph: I have, over the course of four decades, fought Rommel on the desert plains of North Africa. I have drummed for the Who at the Railway Hotel in Wealdstone and the Rochester Community War Memorial auditorium. I have clinked drinks with the wits at the Algonquin Round Table and won a Pulitzer for publishing an exposé on the slums of Mumbai, low-fiving the ghost of Henry Luce on my way to allowing Richard Avedon to shoot my portrait.

headline: The First Amendment Right to Nonpolitical Homework
abstract: Giving points for climate-change activism.
lead_paragraph: For my daughter’s high-school biology class, the students are required to take a public action addressing climate change. They have a wide range of options of what they can do: write a letter to a public official, design a website, develop a public-service announcement or organize a flash mob. They are required to submit proof that they presented their work publicly — that is, that they mailed the letter, launched the website, etc. Is it ethical for the school to require students to speak publicly on a specific issue? Or even to give extra credit for doing so? Does the students’ right to free speech also give them the right not to speak publicly on this topic? KATHARINE LONDON, CAMBRIDGE, MASS.

headline: What Happened When Claire Danes Met the Real C.I.A.
abstract: The “Homeland” star on state secrets, spoiler alerts and the “Carrie Cry Face.”
lead_paragraph: Did you consider yourself a good secret-keeper before you got the role of Carrie Mathison on “Homeland”? I would not say that secret-keeping is one of my finer skills, actually.

abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: MAKING A SCENE

headline: Who Made Those Cop Shows?
abstract: “The Wire” before “The Wire.”
lead_paragraph: When David Simon, the creator of “The Wire,” pitched his pilot to HBO, he promised to deliver “a cop show that seizes the highest qualitative ground through realism, good writing and a more brutal assessment of police, police work and the drug culture.” His show would reveal the gritty truth of law enforcement — with all its politics and sleaze — and give the lie to other cop dramas like “CSI” and “Law & Order,” where “every punch was pulled.”

headline: ‘How You Doing, Baby?’
abstract: Learning to get on with the neighbors in Oak Park, Ill.
lead_paragraph: One fall evening in 1995, I dialed the number of a woman who rented an apartment in the building I had just begun managing in Oak Park. Oak Park, home to Hemingway and Frank Lloyd Wright, is known for its progressive housing policies and integration efforts, especially around Austin Boulevard, which was three blocks away from my building and divides Oak Park from Chicago. The West Side of Chicago is famous, too — for gangs, for drugs, for crime. And before that, for discriminatory housing practices. But Oak Park created a series of programs based on the Fair Housing Act of 1968 as a way to right the wrongs of housing discrimination, including creating my job as a resident manager.

headline: Qualcomm Picks Insider as New Chief Executive
abstract: Steven M. Mollenkopf, the chip maker’s chief operating officer, had been reported to be in the running to be Microsoft’s next chief. He succeeds Paul E. Jacobs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Qualcomm, the wireless technology company that is one of the largest chip makers in the world, said on Friday that its chief operating officer, Steven M. Mollenkopf, would become its new chief executive.

lead_paragraph: And then there were 10. This week, we reveal our 10 Best Books of the year, culled from last week’s 100 Notable Books. While many of the authors will be familiar to readers of the Book Review, all of them appear on the list for the first time.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Tom Clancy, who died on Oct. 1, is atop the hardcover fiction list with “Command Authority,” the third Jack Ryan thriller he wrote with Mark Greaney.
lead_paragraph: Jack’s Back: When Tom Clancy died on Oct. 1, he and his recent collaborator Mark Greaney had just completed a new Jack Ryan thriller, “Command Authority” — and here it comes, crashing onto the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. That’s a familiar position for Clancy’s books, but it somehow eluded the novel that introduced him (and Ryan) to the world: “The Hunt for Red October” spent 28 weeks on the hardcover list in 1985, but never reached the top spot. (It did hit No. 1 in paper­back.) Not that Clancy needed to worry. By the time Ryan made his second appearance, in 1987’s “Patriot Games,” he debuted at No. 1.

headline: Nuts About Greens
abstract: The Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to mix greens and walnuts.
lead_paragraph: I was planning to devote this week’s Recipes for Health to walnuts, as the California walnut harvest took place just a few weeks ago and the walnuts I am buying in my farmers’ market couldn’t be fresher (well, they could be a little fresher – slightly moist, the way fresh, undried walnuts are sold in French produce markets. But the California growers dry their nuts before sending them to market, as the spoilage risk for moist fresh walnuts is high.) I began working on recipes, and once I had written out and begun testing I realized that each dish was a winter greens recipe that included walnuts. The two foods go wonderfully together.

headline: Yanks Offer Welcome to Ellsbury and Some Rebuttals to Cano
abstract: At a news conference on Friday to welcome Jacoby Ellsbury, Yankees executives expressed surprise that Robinson Cano felt disrespected by the team’s $175 million offer to him.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday at Safeco Field in Seattle, the Mariners introduced Robinson Cano, a former Yankee who claimed his old team had disrespected him during contract negotiations by not offering enough money. On Friday, the Yankees introduced Jacoby Ellsbury at a news conference at their stadium, and he had quite a different impression of the team that gave him $153 million over seven years to leave Boston.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Some European bankers making more than €500,000 a year may be able to avoid caps on their bonus compensation if their jobs do not cause potential financial risk to the bank, according to new draft rules introduced on Friday by a European regulator.

headline: A Disappearing Spy, and a Scandal at the C.I.A.
abstract: When Robert A. Levinson disappeared in Iran in 2007, U.S. officials insisted he was a private investigator. In fact, he was a C.I.A. contractor.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Levinson was an overweight bear of a man who once worked as an F.B.I. agent and desperately wanted to recapture the life of international intrigue he relished as an expert on Russian organized crime. But as he sat in a hotel room in Geneva in early 2007, he was anxious about a secret mission he had planned to Iran.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The chief executive of the British insurer RSA Group stepped down on Friday after the company said for the second time in just over a month that it would have to significantly increase the reserves for its Irish business and for the third time in six weeks warned that its profit would be lower.

headline: Giving Feedback That Works
abstract: The real challenge in feedback is to influence behavior, and shaming and finger-pointing is not the best way to do that, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: So here’s the conundrum: Each of us requires critical feedback to get better at anything, but most criticism feels like condemnation, judgment, disapproval and disparagement. In short, it’s painful and destabilizing. So what is a leader or a manager to do?

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan budget deal that sailed through the House on an overwhelming, bipartisan vote is running into difficulty in the Senate, where Republicans — some furious, some conservative and some running for office — are vowing to vote against the measure, which would roll back broad spending cuts.
