abstract: Mr. Rosenberg led the American rowing team to gold in the 1964 Olympics and brought an analytical approach to what was a sport of brute strength.
lead_paragraph: Allen Rosenberg, a coxswain-turned-coach whose innovations in rowing technique helped produce Olympic and world champions, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 82.

headline: Charter Readies Offer to Acquire Time Warner Cable
abstract: Charter Communications has been vocal about its desire for a deal with Time Warner Cable, and it is preparing an offer that mixes cash and Charter stock.
lead_paragraph: Charter Communications is preparing to make an offer of less than $135 a share for Time Warner Cable, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Talking Talent | Alex Borstein, Star of HBO’s ‘Getting On’
abstract: The veteran actress, long known as the voice of Lois on Seth MacFarlane’s animated sitcom “Family Guy,” discusses her starring turn on the new black comedy.
lead_paragraph: Alex Borstein, an Emmy-nominated actress and writer — and the voice of Lois Griffin on the animated Fox series “Family Guy” — currently stars as Nurse Dawn Forchette on HBO’s black comedy “Getting On,” based on the BBC show about a women’s extended care facility in a Long Beach hospital. Alongside her co-stars Laurie Metcalf and Niecy Nash, Borstein brilliantly exercises her comedic chops and exquisite timing to create the most memorable nurse since Ratched. Having honed her gift for impressions, namely as Ms. Swan on “MADtv,” Borstein, a mother of two, will soon not just be recognized for her brilliant voice, but also for her tremendous talent.

headline: Violence in Central African Republic Killed Over 600 in a Week, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency said the crisis was worsening in the country, which has been convulsed by sectarian violence and lawlessness.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — More than 600 people have been killed in the last week in the sectarian violence and lawlessness convulsing Central African Republic, and the crisis is getting worse, the United Nations refugee agency said on Friday.

headline: Shuffling Staff, Obama Strives for a Recharge After a Tough Fifth Year
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: As the president closes another year in office, he is seeking to recapture lost momentum and confront the daunting challenges of the midterm election season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he finishes a fifth year in power that proved far more vexing than his fourth, President Obama is shuffling his staff to recapture lost momentum and confront the daunting challenges of the midterm election season.

headline: Where the Aromas are Welcoming
abstract: Aladin, which opened in July, offers both fiery and subtle flavors. Guests are welcomed with scents of curry, ginger and other spices.
lead_paragraph: Aladin Indian Bistro, which opened in July, is hidden in plain sight on a busy hill on the east side of Norwalk, near an Orvis outlet store and one of Stew Leonard’s vast complexes. One lunchtime I zoomed past twice before I found it. It is easier to spot at night, with its big neon sign in front.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald to Settle 9/11 Lawsuit Against American Airlines
abstract: The Wall Street firm, which lost 658 of its nearly 1,000 New York employees on Sept. 11, had accused the airline of negligence and demanded as much as $1.1 billion in damages.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street firm Cantor Fitzgerald has agreed to settle a 2004 lawsuit against American Airlines and its insurers over Cantor’s business and property losses resulting from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: What I Love | Jim Brett
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: A look inside the Dumbo home of the president of West Elm.
lead_paragraph: A look inside the Dumbo home of the president of West Elm.

headline: Jim Brett’s Three-Dimensional Diary
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Jim Brett, president of West Elm, lives near the company headquarters in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Jim Brett has figured out the elusive work/life balance. The president of West Elm — the international chain of 58 hip home-furnishings stores — he has seamlessly integrated the personal and professional by living across the street from the company’s headquarters in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn.

headline: At Syracuse, Mirror Images a Decade Apart
abstract: Trevor Cooney, Syracuse’s second leading scorer, reminds the assistant Gerry McNamara of himself, and not only by the way he shoots the 3.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — In the final few minutes of a practice this week, Trevor Cooney received a pass on the wing, dribbled once to create a sliver of space and let fly an effortless jump shot from beyond the 3-point arc. He was fading left, his body leaning toward the sideline, as the ball leapt from his fingertips, a perfect gooseneck follow-through guiding it toward the hoop.

headline: Songs That Transcend the Tricks
abstract: Albums from the young jazz singer Cecile McLorin Salvant, the band Deafheaven and the duo Body/Head lead Ben Ratliff’s favorites for 2013.
lead_paragraph: 1. Cécile McLorin Salvant “WomanChild” (Mack Avenue) A young jazz singer of radical talent, who teaches you in her own terms — with high clarity and zero pedantry — that singing old songs has nothing to do with transmitting an outdated sensibility, and that jazz is necessarily part of a bigger and greater story of American music, and that American music is necessarily part of a bigger and greater story of modern art.

headline: South Africa Looks Into Claims of Interpreter’s Criminal Past
keywords: ['Sign Language', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: The South African authorities said they were aware of news media reports that Thamsanqa Jantjie had been accused of murder in 2003.
lead_paragraph: QUNU, South Africa — The South African government said on Friday that it was looking into news media reports that the man hired to provide deaf interpretation at Nelson Mandela’s memorial service had once been accused of murder and other serious crimes. The reports added intrigue to the scandal surrounding the supposed interpreter, who used incomprehensible sign language and later said he was a violence-prone schizophrenic who hallucinated.

headline: Body and Mind, Rebounding
abstract: Hardship probably isn’t the first word that springs to mind when you think of the actress Gwyneth Paltrow.
lead_paragraph: Hardship probably isn’t the first word that springs to mind when you think of the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and the trainer Tracy Anderson, who helped Ms. Paltrow firm up her jiggly bits with such success that they became business partners. Now the twosome is moving beyond the starry realm with “The Restart Project,” available for streaming starting Monday on AOL On, that celebrates mere mortals who have overcome adversity, whether career-ending injuries or debilitating obesity, through fitness and diet.

headline: A Straussian Tale of Thwarted Lust
abstract: Critics like to rib Leon Botstein for excessively square conducting that can drain some of the flair from the music.
lead_paragraph: Critics like to rib Leon Botstein for excessively square conducting that can drain some of the flair from the music. But his style has improved over the years, and he remains one of the most creative minds in American music, known for restless — some might say relentless — advocacy of the unexplored and underappreciated. He has long been a champion of Richard Strauss’s lesser-known operas, and on Sunday he leads his American Symphony Orchestra in “Feuersnot,” whose difficult-to-translate title the ensemble has rendered as “In Need of Fire.”

headline: Mistletoe, Vindicated
abstract: Museum of ruined dinners; the tipsy witness; how to ask smart questions.
lead_paragraph: Museum of ruined dinners; the tipsy witness; how to ask smart questions.

headline: A Bausch Rarity Set to Stravinsky
abstract: Groups of students from the Tanztheater Wuppertal and Juilliard are performing “Wind von West,” offering a rare glimpse of Pina Bausch’s early career.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, not much more than a year after Pina Bausch had become the director of the Tanztheater Wuppertal and well before she had become an international name, she choreographed a three-part Stravinsky evening for her company. The final section was “The Rite of Spring,” now one of the most famous dance versions of the piece, but the first two works were not to be seen again until a recent revival in Wuppertal brought together students from the local Folkwangschule and Juilliard to collaborate on a revival of “Wind von West” (“Wind from the West”), set to Stravinsky’s 1952 “Cantata.”

headline: Abrasive Tactics Lead to Notable Tunes
abstract: Albums from Drake, Kanye West and Ashley Monroe are among Jon Caramanica’s favorite releases of the year.
lead_paragraph: 1. Drake “Nothing Was the Same” (Young Money/Cash Money/Republic) Drake is all the emoji: the prayer hands, the dancing girls, the diamond ring, the blown kiss, the laughing through tears. This is his rowdiest album so far, but all that means is he’s matured enough to know how to punch hard while still hopelessly lost in his feelings.

headline: Unlikely Trio on the Lam
abstract: Jim Jarmusch’s “Down by Law” would have been attention-getting for its casting alone.
lead_paragraph: Jim Jarmusch’s “Down by Law” would have been attention-getting for its casting alone. The three misfits at the center of the story, who find themselves in a New Orleans jail, are played by John Lurie, Tom Waits and Roberto Benigni. But what makes this odd comedy really distinctive is the black-and-white cinematography by Robby Muller. “We are seeing a true filmmaker at work,” wrote Vincent Canby, reviewing the movie in The New York Times in 1986, “using film to create a narrative that couldn’t exist on the stage or the printed page of a novel.”

headline: Modern-Jazz Spin on the Sad Jester
abstract: Much of what you need to know about Geri Allen can be found in the second track of her most recent album.
lead_paragraph: Much of what you need to know about Geri Allen can be found in the second track of her most recent album, “Grand River Crossings” (Motéma), which bears the subtitle “Motown & Motor City Inspirations.” The track is a solo piano version of Smokey Robinson’s “Tears of a Clown,” refurbished with modern-jazz harmony but otherwise faithful to the structure of the tune. Ms. Allen’s fondness for the material shines through her erudition; she isn’t dabbling, showing off, or using the song merely as a springboard. Her elaborations feel grounded in earthly realities and respect.

headline: The Old West, Exalted in Bronze
abstract: The lyrics of the chestnut “The Wheel of the Wagon Is Broken” mourn an Old West irretrievably passed.
lead_paragraph: The lyrics of the chestnut “The Wheel of the Wagon Is Broken” mourn an Old West irretrievably passed: “My days on the prairie are over. There’s weeds round the old ranch door.” The sculptor Frederic Remington, who probably more than any other artist enshrined the myth of the frontier in art, put it even more mournfully: “My West passed utterly out of existence so long ago as if to make it merely a dream. It put on its hat, took up its blankets and marched off the board.”

headline: A Mix of Sounds, Generations and Styles
abstract: Standout records from Wayne Shorter, Andy Bey, Earl Sweatshirt and Cécile McLorin Salvant.
lead_paragraph: 1. Craig Taborn Trio “Chants” (ECM) The deep, seductive intelligence at work in “Chants,” Craig Taborn’s first piano trio album in a dozen years, suggests an ocean of influences distilled into an original potion. Unpacking his terse compositions in communion with the bassist Thomas Morgan and the drummer Gerald Cleaver, Mr. Taborn gives each oblique maneuver a purpose, and often a flicker of intrepid grace.

headline: In Obama’s Praise of Mandela, a Nudge to Africa
abstract: President Obama called again for more accountability in sub-Saharan Africa, but some see a gap between his words and deeds on the continent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama delivered his eulogy of Nelson Mandela in Soweto, South Africa, on Tuesday, he intended it as both a celebration of Mr. Mandela and a chastisement, not just of himself for failing to live up to the Mandela legacy, but of the African leaders who listened to him in the pelting rain.

headline: Is ‘Entitlements’ the Best Word for Social Security and Medicare?
abstract: A reader protests and an editor responds about the use of a charged word
lead_paragraph: A New York City reader, Judith Abrams, wrote with a complaint about the use of the term “entitlements” in federal budget articles. In so doing, she raised other questions that are worth consideration.

headline: And a Teenager Shall Lead Them
abstract: Popular acts like Laura Marling, Nine Inch Nails, M.I.A., Janelle Monáe and David Bowie made room for the newcomer Lorde among a list of the best albums of the year.
lead_paragraph: 1. Lorde “Pure Heroine” (Universal) In hip-hop, keyboard-centered processionals often accompany self-congratulatory boasts. “Pure Heroine,” the debut album by Lorde — the songwriter and singer Ella Yelich-O’Connor, from New Zealand — commandeers those wide-open spaces with her lustrous voice and angel-choir harmonies carrying serious thoughts. Lorde writes about suburban provincialism, peer pressure, insecurity, determination and — in the irresistible “Royals” — about pop-culture fantasies and class-conscious realities. She’s 17.

headline: The Best Albums and Songs of 2013
abstract: Ben Ratliff, Jon Caramanica and Jon Pareles discuss their picks for the year’s best in pop and jazz.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff, Jon Caramanica and Jon Pareles discuss their picks for the year’s best in pop and jazz.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Hobbit'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug."

headline: Italian Standards New to a Familiar Spot
abstract: Sapori, a cozy space on the outskirts of White Plains, serves many Italian favorites, including an array of homemade pastas.
lead_paragraph: Sapori (Italian for “flavors”) is the newest and the fanciest restaurant to arrive on the outskirts of White Plains near the County Center. At once cozy and elegant (save for some dated upholstery), the restaurant has an intriguing layout. Many rooms, alcoves and private nooks suddenly open and then close out of sight as you take the snaking path past a trim bar toward the back of the restaurant.

headline: So Much Operatic Life, and a Fatality
abstract: New York City Opera ends with “Anna Nichole” and “Mosè en Egitto,” as Nico Muhly has a debut with a Metropolitan Opera-Lincoln Center Theater coproduction.
lead_paragraph: The year in classical music was rich with memorable orchestra concerts, chamber-music programs and recitals. Yet what stood out most for me were opera performances, not all of them in opera houses.

headline: Early Handel Operas Are Current Again
abstract: Four productions of Handel operas — an “Almira,” an “Aci, Galatea e Polifemo” and two takes on “Radamisto” — testify to the popularity of early music.
lead_paragraph: New York a hotbed of early music? No one would have said so 20 years ago (when some of us were saying the opposite) or even 10 years ago. But a remarkable shift has occurred over the last decade or so, thanks to a web of interlocking factors, including the formation of a curriculum in historical performance at the Juilliard School, the exponential growth of the music program at Trinity Wall Street, the enterprise of groups like Tenet and the Sebastians and the work of the service organization Gotham Early Music Scene.

headline: Golden Moments in Their 30s
abstract: The Pulitzer-winning Caroline Shaw and the opera composer Nico Muhly are among several younger classical stars with early successes.
lead_paragraph: You could call 2013 the Year of the 30-Something, as two of classical music’s most prestigious bastions opened their doors to children of the 1980s. The polymathic Nico Muhly, born in 1981, became the youngest composer to have a commissioned work performed at the Metropolitan Opera when his “Two Boys” had its American premiere in October. In April, Caroline Shaw (1982) was the youngest recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in Music for her rapturous “Partita for Eight Voices.”

headline: Giving Sound Itself a Starring Role
abstract: Janet Cardiff, Rand Steiger, Kevin James and other artists have incorporated room acoustics into provocative compositions.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, I stopped taking the sound of music for granted. To be sure, I’ve always experienced music in a visceral way. Reviewing the Budapest Festival Orchestra’s performance in January, I marveled at how, under its conductor, Ivan Fischer, it created “volleys of sound so vividly three-dimensional that you sometimes had to resist the impulse to duck.”

headline: Delicate Touches Strongly Felt
abstract: Performers like Diana Damrau and Chris Thile bring sensitive craft to transformative shows.
lead_paragraph: Virtuosos often impress with their ability to produce unlikely sounds from their instruments. It’s such a pleasure when a pianist coaxes beautiful, singing lines from a percussive object and a singer produces trills and effects that seem impossible to have come from a human voice.

headline: Movie Review: 'Saving Mr. Banks'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Saving Mr. Banks.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Saving Mr. Banks.”

headline: Big Ticket | Gardens in the Backyard for $32 Million
abstract: A brick-and-limestone mansion, built for a department store magnate, is ready to be restored.
lead_paragraph: Ripe for restoration, the mansion at 41 East 70th Street, a 28-foot-wide neighbor of the Frick museum that was built in 1929 for Walter N. Rothschild, a department store magnate, and his wife, Carola Warburg Rothschild, sold for $32 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price for the mansion, whose backyard is part of the private gardens known as the Lehman Gardens, was $40 million.

headline: Robert Redford Had His Doubts About ‘All Is Lost’
abstract: The actor-director says he wasn’t sure the film would connect with audiences.
lead_paragraph: When J.C. Chandor was putting the finishing touches on “All Is Lost,” he worried that having a nearly two-hour, nearly silent meditation about survival on the open sea might not quite connect with audiences.

headline: Duets, Trilogies and Revisiting Motown
abstract: The last 12 months have brought a fine crop of new choreography and experimental works.
lead_paragraph: The last 12 months have brought a fine harvest of new choreography. My Top 10 consists solely of works new either to me or altogether.

headline: In the Footsteps of Lara Croft
abstract: Though some games, like Tomb Raider, offer heroines, some gamers are personally filling a gap by creating strong female characters of their own.
lead_paragraph: The men behind some of the most popular and celebrated video games in the medium’s not-as-short-as-you-think history concede that they haven’t spent an enormous amount of time pondering the portrayal of women in their work. “Seemingly not as much as I should have” was the sheepish acknowledgment Sam Houser, a founder of Rockstar Games, gave me during a long interview in Manhattan in September about Grand Theft Auto V, his newest game.

headline: Movie Review: 'American Hustle'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "American Hustle."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "American Hustle."

headline: Acura, Harley-Davidson and Suzuki to Issue Recalls
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Nearly 20,000 new Acura MDX utility vehicles, close to 20,000 Harley-Davidson motorcycles and 142 Suzuki motorcycles will be recalled.
lead_paragraph: Acura will recall about 19,000 of its 2014 MDX utility vehicles in the United States because of a powertrain problem, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website. The automaker said it was possible that one or two of the four bolts securing the propeller shaft could be loose. If the propeller shaft detached the all-wheel-drive system could be damaged and the vehicle would lose power.

headline: A Time for Farewells and Comebacks
abstract: Trisha Brown Dance Company presented what were announced to be her last works, and Pam Tanowitz bounced back from the misstep of “Untitled (Blue Ballet).”
lead_paragraph: This year in dance dawned with an ending. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January, the Trisha Brown Dance Company presented what were announced to be her final works. They weren’t her best, but the whole program, sampling from 45 years of choreographing, was of the quality that sets the high end of my critical scale.

headline: When Ballerinas Get Brassy
abstract: Indelible moments in 2013 from American Ballet Theater, New York City Ballet and downtown dance.
lead_paragraph: Dancers aren’t just the tools of choreographers and directors, but their lifeblood. It comes down to trust: Once a dancer steps onstage, the symbiotic studio relationship is transformed. Alone, the dancer balances that evanescent power of responsibility and freedom.

headline: Restraining the N.S.A.
abstract: Don’t expect government surveillance programs to change dramatically any time soon.
lead_paragraph: After the Edward Snowden leaks started, President Obama said absolutely everything was being done to safeguard Americans’ privacy and rights. Then he called for a “vigorous public debate” about surveillance and eventually ordered reviews of National Security Agency programs — to make sure that all those promised safeguards were, in fact, in place.

headline: Review: 2014 Chevy Malibu
abstract: When the 2013 Malibu failed to excite critics (and more importantly, buyers), Chevy quickly refreshed it. The 2014 model gets more style, room, power and cornering fun.
lead_paragraph: When the 2013 Malibu failed to excite critics (and more importantly, buyers), Chevy quickly refreshed it. The 2014 model gets more style, room, power and cornering fun.

headline: For Top Earners, a Bigger Tax Bite This Year
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Taxation', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Tax policy has stayed out of the headlines, but higher rates, new laws and disappearing deductions mean that higher-income taxpayers are likely to pay more.
lead_paragraph: LESS than a year ago, people were worried about a variety of tax increases in 2013, from income and investment taxes going up to the exemption on estate and gift taxes going down. This year, without any last-minute negotiation around major tax policy, people are far less focused on taxes, and that has accountants and tax lawyers worried.

headline: Underdog Against Amazon, Best Buy Charges Ahead
abstract: Best Buy stock is one of the best-performing stocks in the Standard & Poor’s 500, leading rival retailers to wonder how the company did it.
lead_paragraph: It was a lonely holiday season last year for David Strasser, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. Of the 25 analysts covering the electronics retailer Best Buy, he was the only one to make a buy recommendation. And the stock kept going down.

headline: Rare Victory in Hong Kong for Victims of Insider Trading
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The ruling on behalf of nearly 300 investors — the first of its kind in Hong Kong — is a big victory for regulators. Insider trading wasn’t even a criminal offense there before 2003.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 300 Hong Kong investors are about to share an early $3 million Christmas present. That’s the amount that the former Morgan Stanley banker Du Jun has been told to pay the unwitting victims of his insider trading in 2007. White-collar criminals should beware, but investors shouldn’t expect a rush of future payments.

headline: Video: Chevrolet Breathes New Life Into the 2014 Malibu With a Turbo
abstract: Although its first impression left something to be desired, Chevrolet’s engineers worked on the new Malibu, curing what ailed it.
lead_paragraph: When Chevrolet introduced the 2013 Malibu in the spring of 2012, the only model available for the first six months was the Eco. Critics were not impressed. Its eAssist mild hybrid power plant added cost and wasn’t overly fuel-efficient. The trunk-mounted battery cut into cargo capacity and flexibility. The back seat was tight on knee and legroom. Despite a quiet and stylish cabin, Malibu failed to make the all-important good first impression.

headline: Popcast: The Best Albums and Songs of 2013
abstract: Ben Ratliff, Jon Caramanica and Jon Pareles discuss their picks for the year’s best in pop and jazz.
lead_paragraph: This week: The New York Times pop and jazz critics discuss their top 10 albums of 2013.

headline: I Want It Steamy, and I Want It Now
abstract: Juicy escapism predominated on television this year, with series like “Scandal,” “Revenge” and “House of Cards” eclipsing offerings like ‘The Newsroom.’
lead_paragraph: This was the year that prose turned purple, binge viewing trumped appointment television, and “Scandal” took the place of “Breaking Bad” as the hot drama everyone wanted to talk about. Television is still in a golden age, but the best of 2013 looked a little brassy, more Aaron Spelling than Aaron Sorkin.

headline: A Golden Age With an Imported Shine
abstract: Many of Mike Hale’s favorite television series this year — “The Hollow Crown,” “Prisoners of War” and “Moone Boy” among them — were produced abroad.
lead_paragraph: Here are my 12 favorite television shows of 2013 — the ones you won’t find piling up on my DVR, because I have to watch each new episode as soon as it appears. (Which means, of course, by the end of the next day.) Are they the 12 best shows of the year? Who knows. I didn’t come close to watching everything on TV, and neither did anyone else. All I know is that 10 wouldn’t have been enough.

headline: Grandfather Makes the Pastas
abstract: Trento, with a sleek, two-tiered dining room, is a more ambitious undertaking than Emilio Branchinelli’s five other restaurants on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Trento in Farmingdale is a big, bold and beautiful new restaurant that is a far cry from the last enterprise on this site: the Crazy Donkey, a rock club. Emilio Branchinelli extensively renovated the property before opening it in June.

headline: Staring at the End, in Several Senses
abstract: Fictional series had their share of death this year, but so did reality programming — which added extra interest in bare bodies.
lead_paragraph: It was a year dominated by the naked and the dead.

headline: Art Matters | Taking Back the Steel Drum From the Hippies
abstract: A multiday event at the Manhattan co-working space Neuehouse celebrated the rich history of the instrument and the legacy of one of its great innovators, an 82-year-old Trinidadian named Elliott Mannette.
lead_paragraph: “The steel drum is the most misunderstood instrument in the world,” says the Trinidadian curator Everard Findlay. He admits that for many people, it evokes “guys on a cruise ship, with a smile and dreadlocks.” On Tuesday and Wednesday, Findlay hosted “7 Drums 7 Artists,” a cross-disciplinary tribute to the steel pan at NeueHouse, a co-working space in the Flatiron district that opened in April. Designed by Rockwell Group, NeueHouse, which bills itself as “a new way to work,” features art magazines hanging from wall-mounted racks and glass-globe chandeliers that lower from pulleys at night when the space becomes a venue. The co-founder, Joshua Abram, says that “learning happens at the edge of one’s network”; as part of that philosophy, NeueHouse offers evening cultural programming for its members that brings together artists, scientists, filmmakers and musicians.

headline: Video: David O. Russell on ‘American Hustle’
abstract: The director discusses what went into the making of a crucial scene in the film.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a good week for “American Hustle.” The film, which opened to very strong reviews today, picked up a nomination from the Screen Actors Guild for best ensemble (the guild’s equivalent to best picture) on Wednesday and the next day picked up seven Golden Globe nominations.

headline: Pairing Christmas Dinners With White Wines
abstract: Two wines made at the Wölffer Estate Vineyard pair well with traditional Christmas dinners, such as glazed baked ham or juicy roast goose.
lead_paragraph: Winemakers I know across Europe prepare different kinds of culturally rooted, traditional Christmas dinners. Some of the most festive are in Germany.

headline: Obama Nominates Hollywood Exec to Arts Council
abstract: Thomas E. Rothman, the chairman of TriStar Productions, must be confirmed before joining the National Council on the Arts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The National Council on the Arts, which helps manage the National Endowment for the Arts, will have a new high-profile member from Hollywood’s ranks if a nomination from President Obama goes through as expected. The White House announced on Thursday that Thomas E. Rothman, chairman of TriStar Productions, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment, has been nominated to the 18-member council, which advises on the endowment’s policies and programs and makes recommendations on grant applications. He must be approved by the Senate before joining the Council.

headline: Garden Offers a Week’s Worth of Treats
abstract: Syracuse, Ohio State, Duke, Memphis, Florida and U.C.L.A. are among the teams set to play in a seven-day stretch starting on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Howie Garfinkel has been to thousands of college basketball games, but he has not seen a week filled with the kind of marquee matchups that begin Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Finish Worthy of Hollywood
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Vows (Times Column)']
abstract: The actress Meredith Baxter is married to Nancy Locke, a California contractor.
lead_paragraph: It could have been a meet-cute scene in a movie.

headline: Billionaire Drops Plan for Casino in Spain
abstract: Some civic and religious groups in Spain sought to block the EuroVegas project, but advocates saw it as a potential stimulus to the weak economy.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Sheldon G. Adelson, the billionaire casino magnate, on Friday abandoned his plans to build a $30 billion gambling and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid after failing to win financial concessions and other favors from the Spanish government.

headline: So Your Duck Won’t Go South
abstract: For a festive occasion, a burnished whole duck makes quite an impression: fancier than chicken and more elegant than turkey.
lead_paragraph: Preparing a whole duck for dinner is something I don’t usually do. For the home cook, braising or roasting just the legs is definitely easier, and grilling large duck breasts is more or less like cooking a steak. For a festive occasion, though, a burnished whole bird makes quite an impression: fancier than chicken and more elegant than turkey.

headline: Mexico’s Oil May Be Opened to Outsiders
abstract: Ciudad del Carmen, a hub of the Mexican oil industry, has boomed since large reserves were discovered in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Ciudad del Carmen, a hub of the Mexican oil industry, has boomed since large reserves were discovered in the 1970s.

headline: Bacon of Moore Capital Buys Taos Ski Valley Resort
abstract: Louis M. Bacon, an outdoorsman and conservationist, will buy out a family-owned mountain ski resort.
lead_paragraph: The ski areas of the American West are a familiar stomping ground for Wall Street titans, and a house in Aspen or Vail can be a prized asset.

headline: Individual Problems, Joint Solutions
abstract: For many couples, marriage is equal parts romance and support network. The way they confront joint obstacles like substance abuse or military deployment can affect their relationships.
lead_paragraph: Couples who are about to marry often share tales about how the things they have in common — whether cultural, religious or personality-wise — have brought them together and sustained their relationships. But there’s a special subset: those whose bonds were forged in part by mutual problems, some quite serious, that they’ve agreed to face together.

headline: ‘Twas the Night Before Christmas’ and Its Ties to Chelsea
abstract: A reader asks whether Clement Clarke Moore, known for a famous holiday poem, was indeed the primary developer of the Chelsea section of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Q. I know that Clement Clarke Moore is famous for the poem “ ’Twas the Night Before Christmas,” but is it true he was the major developer of Chelsea?

headline: Your Suggestions For 2014
abstract: Readers tell Nick Kristof what topics they are interested in for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: Readers, thanks for your many insightful answers to the two questions I asked of you this week. To address your answers to my second question first, it’s great to hear many of you think I do a decent job engaging with you already, and I appreciate your suggestions for ways to try new forms of outreach and social media. That’s something I will try to do in 2014, so stay tuned!

headline: A Night Swim for Atlantic Herring
abstract: The Atlantic herring are running in the shallower bays and shorelines of New York City, and they aren’t very difficult to catch.
lead_paragraph: On a windless December evening, sunset faded to shimmering violet over Jamaica Bay. Icy Atlantic waters pushed past Canarsie Pier, filling the bay for the second time that day. Now, two hours from high tide and almost dark, overhead lamps cast shadows deep into Brooklyn’s watery depths. It takes a great leap of faith to believe anything survives in the frigid dark below, but thousands of Atlantic herring (Clupea harengus) are hidden there.

headline: Listen Up, It’s Neutrino Time
abstract: Enough already with the Higgs boson. The neutrino is the new particle in town.
lead_paragraph: HAVE you noticed how the Higgs boson has been hogging the limelight lately? For a measly little invisible item, whose significance cannot be explained without appealing to thorny concepts of quantum field theory, it has done pretty well for itself. The struggling starlets of Hollywood could learn a thing or two about the dark art of self-promotion from this boson.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Musicians to Play a 10-Concert Season
abstract: The musicians, who have been locked out by orchestra management for over a year, will play 10 concerts in the spring.

And in a sign of where the music world’s sympathies are, they have lined up a few big-name guests, most notably the violinists Itzhak Perlman and Joshua Bell.

headline: Cleaning the Place, and Clearing the Mind
abstract: The actress Taryn Manning, a recent arrival to Greenwich Village, hangs out with her dog and her friends, and sometimes does Buddhist chanting.

Sundays tend to be a combination of those interests, along with shopping and hanging out.

headline: Finding Poetry in Multiplicity

lead_paragraph: Tere O’Connor’s “Bleed” is an hourlong dance. It is not a story. It is not music made visible. It does not follow an established or predictable form. It is not random. It is not dull.

headline: Noble Molecules Found in Space
abstract: European astronomers say they have detected noble gas molecules in space for the first time, even though they were not looking for them.
lead_paragraph: Atoms of noble gases like helium, neon and argon — odorless, colorless, single-atom gases with low chemical reactivity — have long been known to exist in outer space. But molecules involving them have escaped detection, despite years of searching.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — To some Pakistanis, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry will always be the “dictator slayer” — the judge who defied the military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf, helped evict him from office and went on to repurpose a once supine judiciary as a fiercely independent force.

headline: The Romance of Falling Temperatures
abstract: Poems about encounters in the snow were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: If the warmth of summer and the natural fertility of spring are classic metaphors for romance, what about winter? The snow and the cold, despite their off-putting aspects, can indeed cause sparks, inspiring closeness and a necessary swapping of body heat. The following poems about the passionate effects of chilly weather were found in recent days in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: The Hero and His Adversaries, Played Out With Fanfare
abstract: Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos is conducting the New York Philharmonic in Richard Strauss’s “Ein Heldenleben.”
lead_paragraph: A music critic has something of a professional interest in resenting Richard Strauss’s “Ein Heldenleben” (“A Hero’s Life”). After all, this sprawling, semi-autobiographical tone poem takes aim squarely at the writers who doubted the young Strauss, who was in his mid-30s when he completed it in 1898. The work’s second section, known as “The Hero’s Adversaries,” paints his critics in strident, self-important lines in the woodwinds and tuba before vanquishing them with brass fanfares.

headline: Ohio: School Officials Plead Not Guilty After Rape
abstract: The superintendent and three current or former city school officials in Steubenville, Ohio, pleaded not guilty on Friday to charges related to the 2012 rape of a 16-year-old girl.
lead_paragraph: The superintendent and three current or former city school officials in Steubenville, Ohio, pleaded not guilty on Friday to charges filed following a grand jury investigation of the August 2012 rape of a 16-year-old girl. The superintendent, Michael McVey, 50, who is free on a personal recognizance bond, has been accused of evidence tampering, obstruction of justice and two other charges. After the hearing, his lawyer said he was confident the charges would prove unfounded, according to The Associated Press. The rape case drew national attention and led to the conviction in March of two Steubenville High School football players. Afterward, the Ohio attorney general, Mike DeWine, convened a special grand jury to examine whether officials covered up the crime, and the panel returned indictments against six people. But only some of those charges stem from the first rape case, while others relate to separate accusations investigated by the grand jury, including some stemming from allegations of the sexual assault of a 14-year-old student four months earlier, as well as other charges of theft and stolen property.

If a state has no plan or an inadequate one, the E.P.A. can impose its own.

headline: Iran: Nuclear Talks Interrupted
abstract: Iranian diplomats interrupted nuclear talks after the United States announced an expanded list of companies and individuals whose trading activities it would try to block for evading sanctions against Iran.
lead_paragraph: Iranian diplomats involved in nuclear talks with six world powers in Vienna interrupted the discussions on Friday after the United States announced an expanded list of companies and individuals whose trading activities it would try to block for evading sanctions against Iran. The Iranians, suggesting that they needed to consult with officials in Tehran, responded angrily to what the Obama administration characterized as enforcement actions. They said the measures undermined the interim deal reached last month, when Iran was given sanctions relief in exchange for suspending some parts of its nuclear program for six months. “This two-sided game and confusion we are witnessing is not beneficial for the atmosphere of the talks,” Iran’s top negotiator and deputy foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, told the semiofficial Tasnim news agency on Friday. A spokesman for Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s foreign policy chief and the coordinator of the negotiations with Iran, said the discussions were expected to resume in the near future. But in Tehran on Friday, some politicians called for the acceleration of Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) JACK THE GIANT SLAYER (2013) In Bryan Singer’s retooling of the “Jack and the Beanstalk” tale, a chivalrous farmhand (Nicholas Hoult) fights for a kingdom and the love of an abducted princess (Eleanor Tomlinson), reigniting an ancient war between humans and a race of giants. Bill Nighy plays General Fallon, the leader of the cannibalistic brotherhood in an otherworld called Gantua; Ewan McGregor, above, in Errol Flynn mode, plays a knight who almost becomes finger food; and Stanley Tucci is the shifty fellow to whom the royal lass has been promised. “For its first 90 minutes, ‘Jack the Giant Slayer’ is painlessly diverting,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The visual design for the giants and the beanstalks keeps your eyes busy, even when the story sets your mind to wandering.” Still, she added, “in the metaphorically rich original tale, a boy wakes to discover he’s produced a mighty stalk. Here, the boy is now a man, and while the stalk is still impressive, the movie just doesn’t have staying power.”

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FXX) MR. POPPER’S PENGUINS (2011) Jim Carrey — his limbs not quite as elastic in this comeback vehicle, directed by Mark Waters — manages not to be upstaged by a half-dozen flightless birds, above, as he plays Popper, a real estate wheeler-dealer and lousy father who ends up with a strange bequest from his own lousy dad. Carla Gugino is the ex-wife Popper is trying to woo back; Angela Lansbury is the reluctant seller he’s trying to persuade to part with Tavern on the Green; and David Krumholtz is the neighbor who objects to the goings-on in Popper’s snow-filled Manhattan duplex. “Mr. Carrey is the kind of performer whose shtick reliably trumps psychological sense, and the film’s blithe incoherence with respect to its main character is one of its virtues,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It turns sentimental now and then, but it knows — Mr. Carrey knows — that what the audience wants from him is silliness.”

lead_paragraph: Anyone who can watch you will watch you.

headline: A West Side Obstacle Course Of Potholes and Cave-Ins
abstract: On a stretch of 11th Avenue near 27th Street in Manhattan, a bumpy ride has prompted dozens of calls to the city’s 311 help line.
lead_paragraph: New York City is a rough ride, no doubt about it, with roads pocked with enough bumps and divots that driving one mile here feels as if it takes as much out of your car as driving 70 miles anywhere else.

lead_paragraph: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa spoke at Nelson Mandela’s funeral service, as did some of Mr. Mandela’s grandchildren.

headline: All in the Family
abstract: What happened when Lincoln’s pro-Confederate half sister came to visit.
lead_paragraph: An old adage states, “You can pick your friends, but not your relatives.” The truth of this maxim was brought home to Abraham and Mary Lincoln when Mary’s half sister, Emilie Todd Helm, visited the White House in late 1863.

headline: European Union Suspends Trade Talks With Ukraine
abstract: A top official all but accused President Viktor F. Yanukovich of dissembling over a deal that protesters have been demanding.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The European Union on Sunday broke off talks with Ukraine on the far-reaching trade deal that protesters here have been demanding for weeks, and a top official issued a stinging, angry statement all but accusing Ukraine’s president of dissembling during the negotiations.

headline: Parties Agree on Leader Ahead of Vote in Tunisia
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']

lead_paragraph: CASABLANCA, Morocco — Tunisia’s political parties agreed on the selection of a new prime minister late Saturday, breaking months of political deadlock between the Islamist-led government and secular opposition parties.

headline: Peter O’Toole, Whose Acclaim Began With ‘Lawrence of Arabia,’ Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. O’Toole’s performance in the epic 1962 film earned him overnight fame and established him as one of his generation’s most charismatic actors.
lead_paragraph: Peter O’Toole, an Irish bookmaker’s son with a hell-raising streak whose performance in the 1962 epic film “Lawrence of Arabia” earned him overnight fame and established him as one of his generation’s most charismatic actors, died on Saturday in London. He was 81.

headline: New ‘Hobbit’ Film Opens at No. 1
abstract: But this installment, “The Desolation of Smaug,” fell 13 percent below the opening amount collected last year by “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey.”
lead_paragraph: Initial box-office results for “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug” (Warner Brothers) came with a tinge of disappointment: Hollywood expects ticket sales for sequels to go up, and the initial total for “Desolation of Smaug” fell 13 percent below the opening amount collected last year by “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey.”

headline: Random House Acquires 1800s Prison Memoir
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Manuscripts', 'Prisons and Prisoners']

lead_paragraph: The recently discovered manuscript believed to be the first prison memoir by an African-American was swiftly acquired by Random House, the publisher said on Sunday. The 304-page manuscript, by Austin Reed, was recently authenticated by scholars at Yale University.

headline: China Focusing Graft Inquiry on Ex-Official
abstract: The decision by President Xi Jinping to investigate the former head of the domestic security apparatus is the first time that such a high-level official has been the focus of a formal corruption inquiry.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Sending tremors across China’s political landscape, President Xi Jinping and other party leaders have authorized a corruption inquiry against the powerful former head of the domestic security apparatus, Zhou Yongkang, according to sources with elite political ties.

headline: Smart Gifts, and Old Devices Made New Again
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Electronics', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Gifts', 'Energy Efficiency']
abstract: Companies and environmentalists are looking for ways to cut energy use and ensure that more old electronics are reused or recycled.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — From solar-powered Christmas lights and cellphone chargers to smart home thermostats, there are plenty of gifts available for technology lovers interested in saving energy.

headline: Developing Cures or Hyping Up Demand?
abstract: Can drug companies' influence over treatments for conditions like A.D.H.D. be reduced?

headline: St. John’s Finds Hope in a Loss to Syracuse
abstract: In the first game between the rivals since the Orange joined the A.C.C., C. J. Fair and Tyler Ennis each scored 21 points to lead No. 2 Syracuse to a win at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: For 15 minutes of the second half against Syracuse on Sunday, St. John’s looked as if it might upset the No. 2 Orange at Madison Square Garden, scramble the national rankings and light up the New York college basketball scene once again.

headline: Mandela Laid to Rest
abstract: Thousands of relatives, friends and dignitaries gathered Sunday in Qunu, South Africa, for the state funeral of Nelson Mandela.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of relatives, friends and dignitaries gathered Sunday in Qunu, South Africa, for the state funeral of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Gunmen in Iraq Kill an Official and His Family
abstract: The gunmen stormed the house of a Health Ministry employee north of Baghdad and killed him, his wife and their three children, the police said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Unidentified gunmen stormed the house of a Health Ministry employee in a city north of the capital on Sunday and killed him, his wife and their three children, the police and medical officials said. Other attacks across the country left at least 14 more dead, officials said.

headline: Ancient Egypt as the Stuff of Fantasy, From the Grand to the Goofy
abstract: In “Egyptomania,” Bob Brier traces the centuries-old lure of ancient Egypt and the kitsch it has inspired.
lead_paragraph: It takes a lot of devotion to Egyptiana to earn the nickname “Mr. Mummy,” as Bob Brier has. His books and documentaries cover subjects from pyramids, mummies and tombs to the murder of King Tut (film rights optioned by the director of “Godzilla”), and he is an avid collector of the paraphernalia he calls Egyptotrash. So “Egyptomania” promises to be the most accessible, entertaining and kitschiest of his books so far.

headline: Saudi Prince Criticizes Obama Administration, Citing Indecision in Mideast
abstract: Prince Turki al-Faisal, a former intelligence chief, said efforts to secure a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians would founder without clear commitment from President Obama.
lead_paragraph: MONACO — An influential Saudi prince blasted the Obama administration on Sunday for what he called indecision and a loss of credibility with allies in the Middle East, saying that American efforts to secure a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians would founder without a clear commitment from President Obama.

headline: Drubbing by Seahawks Assures Giants of a Losing Record
abstract: Eli Manning threw a career-high five interceptions, and Russell Wilson and Marshawn Lynch helped Seattle send the Giants to their ninth defeat.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the locker room Sunday, moments after the Seattle Seahawks thrashed his Giants, 23-0, Coach Tom Coughlin took the blame for the humiliating defeat.

headline: Two Personal Stories Become One Film
abstract: The Polish director and cinematographer Wojciech Staron turns the camera on his own family in “Two Lessons.”
lead_paragraph: With his enthralling documentary “Two Lessons,” the Polish director and cinematographer Wojciech Staron fulfills a longtime plan to unite two separately filmed personal stories into a single work. The result is a captivating record of two journeys, two relationships and one family’s transformation.

headline: In Praise of Failure
abstract: There is a danger in our quest for a more perfect future — that failure will become obsolete.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever a time to think seriously about failure, it is now.

headline: Senate Prepares to Wrap Up Sluggish 2013
abstract: The Senate’s final week in session this year promises to be memorable for something less inspired than its accomplishments: the vast amount of time it spends doing nothing in particular.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s final week in session this year promises to be memorable not for legislative business like the pending budget and defense bills but for something far less inspired: the vast amount of time it spends doing nothing in particular.

headline: Life Master Pairs and Edgar Kaplan Blue Ribbon Winners
abstract: The winners of the two main pair events at the Fall Nationals in Phoenix this month had at least two things in common.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the two main pair events at the Fall Nationals in Phoenix this month had at least two things in common. First, the partners had not played together in a pair event before. Second, one player in each pair is an American, and the other was born and raised in one country but has represented another country internationally.

headline: A Well-Dressed Wolf Who Is Still Bad to the Bone
abstract: Isaac Mizrahi directed (and designed) this staged production of “Peter & the Wolf” at the Guggenheim, balancing humor for parents with drama and tension for children.
lead_paragraph: If the Devil has the rights to all the best tunes, nobody told Prokofiev. In his 1936 musical fable, “Peter & the Wolf,” the predatory Wolf doesn’t get much of a melody. His menace is usually rendered instead by creepy harmonies from a trio of horns. Peter, the Cat, the hapless Duck, even the grumpy Grandfather: Theirs are the famous tunes that have introduced generations of children to the instruments of the orchestra.

headline: Wide Repertory Invites Plenty of Meandering
abstract: MGMT played to two constituencies: those who know the happy-sounding hits and those who are willing to follow the band’s more abstruse ambitions.
lead_paragraph: A handful of hit singles gives a band some leeway, and MGMT used all it has at Barclays Center on Friday. MGMT — led by the singer Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser, who both play guitars and keyboards — strategically doled out the three hits from its 2008 debut album, “Oracular Spectacular”: “Time to Pretend” early in the set and “Electric Feel” and “Kids” near the end, each one drawing arena-wide squeals of recognition.

headline: Mining Tchaikovsky, and Finding More Amid the Snowflakes
abstract: Layers of fun and vitality mark American Ballet Theater’s “Nutcracker” production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Watching American Ballet Theater perform “The Nutcracker” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this month is entirely a pleasure, mixed with several elements of happy surprise. It’s just so unusual for American ballet to display character acting as vivid and widespread as it is here from a large number of performers. The servants, mice, parents and guests of the opening scenes seem to have stepped out of Gogol or Dickens. They’re played with varying degrees of caricature, very finely judged; the degrees of subtle, funny exaggeration are in proportion to their psychological distance from the child heroine. Everyone seems to be bubbling over with vitality.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Ambitions That Rise Long Before Curtains Do
abstract: “Playwright: From Page to Stage,” on the PBS series “Independent Lens,” follows two playwrights, Rajiv Joseph and Tarell Alvin McCraney, as they have new works produced.
lead_paragraph: Capturing the creative process in a documentary is next to impossible, and “Playwright: From Page to Stage,” on Monday on PBS’s “Independent Lens,” doesn’t succeed any better than previous efforts. But the film, which follows two young playwrights as they have new works produced in prominent regional theaters (culminating, for one, in a Broadway run), does have a few candid moments that go deeper than we’re used to seeing.

headline: Fire Investigation at Detroit Art Site
abstract: An interactive public art installation in Detroit has been the site of eight suspicious fires since May, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: The Heidelberg Project, an interactive public art installation covering two blocks in Detroit, has been the site of eight suspicious fires since May, causing investigators to wonder why the project, which has existed in some form since 1986, has become a target, The Associated Press reported. The most recent fire took place on Dec. 8, destroying an abandoned house that had been repurposed as a canvas for paintings, recycled materials and found objects. Since October, five structures have been destroyed by fire. This is not the first time parts of the site have been destroyed. In 1991 and 1999, the city bulldozed large portions of the installation, viewing the collection of random items and hodgepodge paintings not as art, but as trash. Originally created by the artist Tyree Guyton to combat urban blight and decay, the Heidelberg Project has expanded its goals to provide art education and to promote community development. It is also something of a tourist destination, with over 275,000 visitors annually. There are no suspects in the fires. A private donor has offered a $25,000 reward in the case.

headline: Boyhood Longing (and Lobbying) for a BB Gun
abstract: A musical stage version of “A Christmas Story,” the Jean Shepherd holiday classic, looks as if it will settle in as a seasonal perennial.
lead_paragraph: Making a musical out of “A Christmas Story” must have hardly seemed like work to Joseph Robinette, the book writer, and Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, who provided the music and lyrics. How easy was it? When the second-act curtain went up on opening night of the production now running at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, a flagpole received a smattering of applause.

headline: Chilean Voters Return a Former President to Power
abstract: Michelle Bachelet received about 62 percent of the vote, according to preliminary results, amid continuing unease over high levels of inequality in Chile.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Chilean voters handed a landslide victory to Michelle Bachelet on Sunday, returning her to the presidency amid continuing unease over high levels of inequality in Chile despite an enviable stretch of rapid economic growth.

headline: To Thine Own Algorithm Be True
abstract: “A Piece of Work,” Annie Dorsen’s “algorithmic” take on Shakespeare’s Danish prince, is scrambled by computer codes and chatbots.
lead_paragraph: Woe to the reporter who seeks to track Annie Dorsen’s speech patterns. The same combination of speed, breadth and complexity that makes her a thrilling conversationalist means any note taker faces a Sisyphean task.

headline: All Roads Lead to It
abstract: A smooth debut by Greg Johnson.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It seems a shame that Greg Johnson is saying GOODBYE to us just as he’s making his debut. We were just getting to know him.

headline: ‘The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic’
abstract: Scenes from the show at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the show at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: The End, if It’s Up to You
abstract: In “The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic,” Robert Wilson stages the life and imaginary death of this performance artist.
lead_paragraph: That familiar fantasy of spying on one’s own funeral has come spectacularly true for at least one of us mortals, the performance artist Marina Abramovic, whose work dates back to the 1970s and who has become a slavishly adored fixture on the art-celebrity circuit over the past decade. In “The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic,” a new music-theater piece being presented through Saturday in the Drill Hall of the Park Avenue Armory, Ms. Abramovic is lying plushly in state on a giant stage draped in black and lit by glowing white neon bars.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 16
abstract: The insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, of SAC Capital, is expected to finish, and BlackBerry is set to post third-quarter results on Friday.
lead_paragraph: EURO ZONE European Union finance officials begin convening in Brussels on Tuesday in an attempt to create a system to wind down failed banks, known as the Single Resolution Mechanism. Officials were unable to reach a deal last week amid disagreement on crucial issues of funding and resolution authority. Heads of state will be in town Thursday and Friday to sign off on any final agreement.

headline: Jingle Ball 2013
abstract: Scenes from the concert at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Bad Girl Meets Bad Santa
abstract: Miley Cyrus generated intense anticipation at the Z100 Jingle Ball, but her performance was a pointed rejection of the concert’s rhythm, in which the upbeat mood must rule.
lead_paragraph: “THE INTENSITY FOR MILEY IS REAL,” read an audience member’s live tweet above the stage during the Z100 Jingle Ball on Friday night. Stone truth. Up to the moment of Miley Cyrus’s appearance, whenever her name was mentioned — by a live being like Elvis Duran, host of the Z100 “Morning Show,” or in a recorded announcement — the massed screaming had something extra, a sound of acrid immediacy, released into the air of Madison Square Garden like the smell of burning wires.

headline: ‘Indie Essentials’
abstract: A look at the Museum of the Moving Image’s new exhibition of “local multiplayer” games.
lead_paragraph: A look at the Museum of the Moving Image’s new exhibition of “local multiplayer” games.

headline: Multiplayer Games With a Local Touch
abstract: “Indie Essentials: 25 Must-Play Video Games,” a playable exhibition at the Museum of the Moving Image, provides the easiest way to experience “local multiplayer” games.
lead_paragraph: Video games are the art form that computation has given us, and the shifting reputation of games and their players has roughly tracked that of computer users. Games were a lonely and isolating novelty until they were connected to the Internet, which turned them into a crowded and abusive novelty.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’
abstract: Scenes from a new production from the Gelsey Kirkland Ballet.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a new production from the Gelsey Kirkland Ballet.

headline: Toys Still Come to Life, but Candy Is Missing
abstract: The Gelsey Kirkland Ballet’s inaugural production, a new staging of “The Nutcracker,” was performed at Pace University’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts.
lead_paragraph: As a pre-eminent dancer with American Ballet Theater in the 1970s and ’80s, Gelsey Kirkland was known for her storytelling. With her fabled vulnerability and big, sad eyes, she carried many a full-length ballet: “Giselle,” “Romeo and Juliet” and, perhaps most famously, “The Nutcracker.” In a 1978 review of Mikhail Baryshnikov’s version (the same one that lit up the nation’s living rooms via PBS), the critic Anna Kisselgoff wrote in The New York Times that Ms. Kirkland, as Clara, “has found one of her deepest roles.”

headline: Revelations That Ikea Spied on Its Employees Stir Outrage in France
abstract: The case has spurred anger in a country that has put a high priority on privacy, and it remains unclear why the Ikea unit is said to have engaged in the practice so widely.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Virginie Paulin’s voice still trembles when she recounts how she was fired from what she considered her dream job at Ikea in France.

headline: Leftover Projects

lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration has been pushing a number of last-minute real estate projects through the approval process in the mayor’s last few months in office. Here are some, with estimates of the cost to develop.

abstract: The big aircraft leasing unit, regarded as one of the crown jewels in A.I.G.’s empire, was sold a competing business, AerCap Holdings of the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:30 a.m. | The American International Group has agreed to sell its big aircraft leasing unit, the International Lease Finance Corporation, to a competing business, AerCap Holdings of the Netherlands, for about $5.4 billion in stock and cash.

lead_paragraph: This animated Op-Doc explores why J.J. Cale, who wrote such classic songs as “After Midnight,” “Cocaine” and “Call Me the Breeze,” never achieved stardom.

headline: Ukrainians Gear Up for Holidays as Protests Continue
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Though Kiev, the capital, has been fixated on political demonstrations for more than three weeks, it is still holiday season, and for most of the city, life goes on.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Like hundreds of thousands of her fellow citizens, Olga Begun, 29, was in Independence Square on Sunday, fretting about the future of Ukraine, but not about the push-and-pull between Europe and Russia, or if the government will resign. Instead, she was thinking about outfits for the future Ukrainian that she is set to give birth to next month.

headline: One Brother Reaches Out to Another Across the Economic Divide
abstract: Mike Remboulis once thought his older brother was invincible, but bad luck and stiff competition for jobs have left him struggling in a city of plenty.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, Mike Remboulis can almost forget. For an hour or so, in the crush of a crowded restaurant, he feels like any other guy with a beautiful girlfriend and a comfortable salary savoring the good life in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Naturally, J.J. Cale’
abstract: This animated Op-Doc explores why J.J. Cale, who wrote classics like “After Midnight,” “Cocaine” and “Call Me the Breeze,” never achieved stardom.

headline: Charles M. Vest, 72, President of M.I.T. and a Leader in Online Education, Dies
abstract: Dr. Vest was trained as a mechanical engineer and became a champion of women in science and engineering.
lead_paragraph: Charles M. Vest, who as president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology oversaw an expansion in research and online education and increased the number of women and minority members in leadership positions, died on Thursday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 72.

headline: Jets’ Fourth-Quarter Mistakes, Unusual and Familiar, Hurt Playoff Hopes
abstract: The Jets stayed within 3 points of the Carolina Panthers for three quarters, before falling, 30-20, and needing a Baltimore loss on Monday to keep their playoff chances alive.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Rex Ryan approached the lectern at Bank of America Stadium late Sunday evening with the countenance of a man who needed a big hug, a generous pour or both. His voice was a bit hoarse, his eyes a bit droopy, as he recounted how the Jets’ 30-20 loss to the Carolina Panthers unfolded like a compressed version of their season.

headline: A Grand Weekend Out for Pennsylvanians
abstract: Politicians, lobbyists and business leaders from the Keystone State spent the weekend in Manhattan at the Pennsylvania Society meeting, continuing a tradition begun in 1899.
lead_paragraph: It was 1899 when the Pennsylvania Society first gathered for oysters and Delmonico steaks at the Waldorf-Astoria, a gilded era when, the story goes, the industrialists and bankers who owned Pennsylvania lived in New York City.

headline: A Microsoft Star Goes to Google
abstract: Blaise Agüera y Arcas, a respected engineer and software designer at Microsoft, has left the company to join its rival Google. At Microsoft, he was involved with development projects in a variety of fields, including augmented reality, wearable computing and natural user interfaces.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Blaise Agüera y Arcas, a respected engineer and software designer at Microsoft, has left the company to join its rival Google.

headline: The Documented Life
abstract: We constantly interrupt our experiences to make a record of them.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — LAST spring, I had the occasion to spend a day with the actor and comedian Aziz Ansari discussing our mutual interest in the psychology of texting. As we walked through Los Angeles, people approached him every few minutes not to ask for an autograph, but to demand a photograph. Mr. Ansari is gracious to his fans. He explained that instead of a photograph, he would offer a conversation. He inquired about their taste in music, what they liked about his performances, his stand-up, his sitcom “Parks and Recreation.” His fans were mollified but they were rarely happy. They had to walk away with nothing on their phones.

headline: Victims of Misclassification
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Collective Bargaining']
abstract: Misclassifying workers as independent contractors harms the employees and costs billions in lost tax revenue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — LAST month, a Michigan construction worker named Matt Anderson testified in a Senate hearing about being a victim of employee misclassification. Mr. Anderson said that his employer forced him, after six years as an employee, to switch to “independent contractor” status. Though the move stripped Mr. Anderson of basic employee rights and protections, he went along with the change, he said, because “my fellow workers and I had families to support and we saw how bad the economy was.”

headline: NPR Gets $17 Million in Grants to Expand Coverage and Develop Digital Platform
abstract: The grants, to be announced Monday, come just three months after NPR, which is facing financial difficulties, said it would cut 10 percent of its staff.
lead_paragraph: NPR has amassed nearly $17 million in grants to increase substantially its coverage of education and global health and development, and finance creation of a new mobile and web platform that is expected to allow it to reach more listeners and better compete with outside aggregators of public radio content.

headline: Abraham Briloff, Accounting Professor, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Briloff practiced accounting, but it was the articles he wrote for Barron’s that turned him into something of a celebrity.
lead_paragraph: Abraham J. Briloff, an accounting expert whose trenchant and sometimes scathing analyses of corporate financial records often sent investors scurrying to dump their stocks, died on Thursday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 96.

headline: Bankruptcy Court Hearing Examines Mystery at Wine Storage Business
abstract: After water poured into the cellars of WineCare Storage during Hurricane Sandy, most of its clients have been unable to get anywhere near their rare and valuable bottles.
lead_paragraph: Derek L. Limbocker, a onetime financial adviser, publisher of rare art prints and society figure in Newport, R.I., and New York, has been stiff-arming his clients for the past 13 months.

headline: Gaza, Vexed by Floods, Gets Fuel and Power
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Gaza’s lone power plant sputtered back to life for the first time in seven weeks after Qatar paid for fuel shipped from Israel.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Gaza’s lone power plant sputtered back to life on Sunday for the first time in seven weeks, bringing relief to the Palestinian coastal enclave where a lack of cheap fuel has contributed to the overflow of raw sewage, 21-hour blackouts and flooding after a ferocious winter storm.

headline: Fear of Dying Alone Drove a Panhandler to Seek Drug Rehabilitation
abstract: Jobless, grieving for his mother and hooked on heroin, Rickey Henegan spent years panhandling until his fear drove him to seek treatment.
lead_paragraph: It had grown dark, and Rickey Henegan was seeking refuge for the night in a spot behind two Dumpsters. But the spot was occupied by the corpse of a fellow homeless man, who had been dead long enough for his body to start decomposing.

headline: Why Inequality Matters
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The economic populists have it right.
lead_paragraph: Rising inequality isn’t a new concern. Oliver Stone’s movie “Wall Street,” with its portrayal of a rising plutocracy insisting that greed is good, was released in 1987. But politicians, intimidated by cries of “class warfare,” have shied away from making a major issue out of the ever-growing gap between the rich and the rest.

headline: Russia vs. Europe
abstract: Czar Vladimir takes on the decadent West.
lead_paragraph: The world needs Nelson Mandelas. Instead, it gets Vladimir Putins. As the South African hero was being sung to his grave last week, the Russian president was bullying neighboring Ukraine into a new customs union that is starting to look a bit like Soviet Union Lite, and consolidating his control of state-run media by creating a new Kremlin news agency under a nationalistic and homophobic hard-liner.

headline: Writing About Gangsters, as Far Back as He Can Remember
abstract: Jerry Capeci has been chronicling the Mafia in New York City for nearly four decades and has produced half a dozen gangster-themed books.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Capeci was trying to get his mitts around an international tale written in blood, a case that put together a Mafia boss in Montreal and murders in Brooklyn and Acapulco, Mexico.

headline: Scholars’ Group to Disclose Result of Vote on an Academic Boycott of Israel
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Boycotts', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The American Studies Association put a resolution to a vote of its almost 5,000 members, who had until Sunday night to cast their ballots online.
lead_paragraph: A growing campaign among American professors to isolate Israel reaches a milestone on Monday when a large group of scholars is expected to reveal whether its members endorsed an academic boycott of Israel to protest Israeli treatment of Palestinians.

headline: Wilson Has Sights Set on Snow and Super Bowl
abstract: By winning their final road game on the schedule, Russell Wilson and the Seahawks have improved the odds of a return trip to MetLife Stadium for the Super Bowl in February.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Maybe next time. Maybe if Russell Wilson can make it back to MetLife Stadium in another month and a half for the annual orgy of excess known as the Super Bowl, the weather will cooperate more and be less of a tease.

headline: Airbnb Campaign Uses Birdhouses to Widen Its Reach
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Airbnb, an online service that connects travelers with people who want to rent out their homes, is beginning its first integrated national advertising campaign.
lead_paragraph: AIRBNB, which lets travelers rent accommodations in private residences worldwide, is introducing its first integrated, national advertising campaign on Monday, using birds and birdhouses as a metaphor for its customers and their accommodations.

headline: Going Out With Building Boom, Mayor Pushes Billions in Projects
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Zoning', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Bloomberg administration officials are determined to finish public reviews for a number of “legacy projects” before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg leaves office.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration has been pushing through more than $12 billion worth of real estate projects in its waning days, trying to solidify the mayor’s claim to having transformed the face of New York City and lock in plans before Bill de Blasio takes over Jan. 1.

headline: Breadwinner Moms, Caregiving Dads

lead_paragraph: America’s longest-running sitcom “The Simpsons” has a secret: It’s also one of the smartest shows on TV. Look past the antics of Homer and Bart and you’ll find the show filled with an abundance of mathematics references, thanks to its remarkably nerdy cast of writers. headline: By Design | Zaha Hadid, Jewelry Designer

lead_paragraph: Zaha Hadid, the Iraq-born, London-based Pritzker prize-winning architect with more than 40 buildings around the globe, also makes jewelry. In 2010, she created a collection for Swarovski, and now she has followed it up with a set of rings and a cuff from lattices of gold filigree for Caspita, the Swiss jewelry brand. Inspired by naturally occurring cell structures, the pieces in the collection, which is called Skein, look like golden honeycomb, as if assembled by bees. Some are studded with diamonds. Polygons form a delicate mesh that envelops the finger, a shape that is reminiscent of Hadid’s Al Wakrah stadium in Qatar. In fact, she acknowledges, “There is a lot of fluidity now between jewelry design, architecture and art — a lot more cross-pollination in the disciplines.” The collection was introduced earlier this month at Colette’s pop-up at Art Basel in Miami Beach and at the Zaha Hadid Design Gallery in London last week. It goes on sale online today at Latest Revival.

headline: Can Peace Come to a Family a Brother ‘Destroyed’ Because His Sister Is Gay?
abstract: A woman caught between her gay sister and anti-gay brother wants to know if they can reunite years later.
lead_paragraph: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: Almost 30 years ago, my older brother gave my parents an ultimatum — disown my little sister, who had just revealed she was gay, or he would cut himself and his family off from the rest of us. My parents refused to do such a thing and my brother made good on his threat and destroyed our family. I stood with my sister and have not seen or spoken to my big brother or any of his family since his declaration so long ago. Neither has my sister. Time has not healed the wounds of our family. On his deathbed, my dad asked me never to forget what my brother did to all of us and I promised him I would not — and I refuse to forgive him. My mother has forgiven my brother — and I’m glad for her. I also know my mom dearly wishes to have her family together before she dies. My question: Should I honor my father’s deathbed request or my mother’s final wish? — Straight Sister in the Middle

But sneakerheads, too, have something to look forward to when the multibrand store opens in Kips Bay on Dec. 21. Nike, a longtime collaborator with Comme des Garçons and the original Dover Street Market, will introduce its newest take on one of its most popular styles, the Nike Air Python. First released in 1987, the now legendary basketball sneaker was the first of the brand’s shoes to hit stores sans the signature swoosh. The new Nike Air Python DSM NYC ($160) is part of an exclusive five-piece capsule collection that will also be available at the other two Dover Street Market locations in London and Tokyo. It includes a bomber jacket ($600) and fitted baseball cap ($40) in addition to the all-black sneakers, which feature python-printed leather and reflective tape detailing, an unconventional combination well suited for Dover Street Market’s avant-garde clientele. Two graphic T-shirts ($50 each) round out the collection, a nod to the Air Python’s roots in ’80s street culture. Nike Air Python DSM, $160, doverstreetmarket.com.
