lead_paragraph: AMERICA’S GREAT GAME: The CIA’s Secret Arabists and the Shaping of the Modern Middle East,  by Hugh Wilford. (Basic Books, $29.99.) How the C.I.A., pushed by John Foster Dulles, lost the respect of the Arab world in the 1950s.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SHOOTING VICTORIA: Madness, Mayhem, and the Rebirth of the British Monarchy,  by Paul Thomas Murphy. (Pegasus, $18.95.) Between 1840 and 1882, while thrones across Europe toppled, there were eight unsuccessful attempts on Queen Victoria’s life. Murphy’s book — a learned ramble through history, literature, penology, constitutional theory and even ballistics — argues that the would-be assassins cemented Victoria’s popularity and helped preserve the British monarchy.

headline: Survival Skills
abstract: In Katherine Rundell’s middle-grade novel, an orphan befriends children who live on top of Parisian buildings.
lead_paragraph: In many classic children’s novels, parents are a problem best dispensed with early on. Life only gets interesting — if, typically, more unpleasant — once they are out of the way. Hence the popularity of the orphan plot, from Dickens to Rowling, and, lately, its contemporary cousin, the single-parent plot (see “The Hunger Games” and “Twilight”).

headline: Lights, Camera, Dysfunction
abstract: A boy is overwhelmed by rage when his deeply unhappy family appears on a TV show.
lead_paragraph: In a 2009 episode of the television show “Wife Swap,” a pudgy 7-year-old named Curtis was paired for a while with a mom from another family who emphasized good eating habits, waking up early and other affronts to 7-year-olds everywhere. Curtis’s on-air retorts, including “Bacon is good for me” and “Chicken nuggets is like my family,” made him a meme online, where he is still known as King Curtis.

headline: More Precious Than Rubies
abstract: Women’s bodies are the battlegrounds in Susann Cokal’s novel of palace intrigue set during the Scandinavian Renaissance.
lead_paragraph: Like a fairy tale, “The Kingdom of Little Wounds” starts with a pin’s prick and a drop of blood. Ava Bingen, a seamstress and the book’s main character, must quickly mend Queen Isabel’s gown, which has ripped in the midst of a ball. Her needle slips and she pricks royal flesh. It’s 1572 in the Scandinavian city of Skyggehavn, and Ava, for her incompetence, is thrown into the dungeon.

headline: Winter Wonders
abstract: Thoughts of snowstorms — real or imagined — preoccupy the children in three picture books.
lead_paragraph: My 3-year old daughter knows nothing of snow. She’d only just turned 2 when we moved to Rome — a spellbinding city in many ways but one where snow rarely falls. (In 2012, a blizzard ground the city to a halt, and Romans are still talking about it with wide-eyed amazement.) My daughter can’t possibly remember the winters of her New York babyhood, but suddenly, about six months ago, she began to ask me when the snow would come. When would we play in the snow? Where was the snow hiding? I could only guess she was exhibiting a child’s sixth sense for wonder: Snow is a portal out of the ordinary churn of life, forcing even grown-ups to go out and play. Coincidentally, and luckily for my daughter, three new picture books herald the majesty of snow, bringing its almost magically transformative power to any child who yearns for it.

headline: Reigning Heavyweight
abstract: Josef Joffe disputes the popular perception that America’s supremacy is on the wane.
lead_paragraph: Vice president Joe Biden was wrong when he said, at last year’s Democratic Convention, “It’s never been a good bet to bet against the American people.” In fact, claiming that America is going to hell in a handbasket has been among the more reliable routes to both the Oval Office and the best-seller lists. Josef Joffe, the publisher-editor of the German weekly Die Zeit, points out in his new book, “The Myth of America’s Decline,” that the United States has been dogged for much of its history as a superpower by warnings of doom.

headline: In Other Words
abstract: From lost phrases to newly coined terms, three works present a range of definitions.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever doubted that individual words can be a window into a whole culture, “The Book of Jezebel,” “The Horologicon” and “Wordbirds” will change your mind.

headline: Correspondence to Self
abstract: Paul Auster’s memoir traces the history of his psychological development from childhood to early adulthood.
lead_paragraph: Writing multiple novels is generally considered a triumph, writing multiple memoirs a somewhat shameful habit. Still, I’ve never heard anyone sniff about Paul Auster’s autobiographical recidivism; perhaps his 16 acclaimed novels compensate for it. In any case, on the basis of his five memoirs alone, Auster should be recognized as one of the great American prose stylists of our time.

headline: Continental Drifters
abstract: The lives of Anne Marie Wirth Cauchon’s young narrators intersect in a Montana town.
lead_paragraph: “The strain of holding the I together adheres to the I in all stages; and the temptation to lose it has always been there with the blind determination to maintain it.” This quotation, from Theodor Adorno and Max Horkheimer’s “Dialectic of Enlightenment,” is the first of the three epigraphs of “Nothing,” Anne Marie Wirth Cauchon’s bluntly apocalyptic and psychologically attentive first novel. Her two I’s, Ruth and James, who take turns narrating the book’s brisk chapters (until later, when Ruth takes over most narrating duties), are young drifters who seem to be in their early 20s and have separately left Minneapolis for the valley town of Missoula, Mont.

headline: A Law Unto Himself
abstract: The most notorious operative of Pinkerton’s detective agency, James McParland was a thorn in the sides of unions and outlaws.
lead_paragraph: The lobby of the Idanha Hotel in Boise, Idaho, was the scene of great excitement in the spring and summer of 1907. There, most mornings, sat a large man with a luxurious, curled mustache, smoking cigars and loudly holding forth, surrounded by newspaper reporters and gawping onlookers. Behind him, guarding against the threat of assassination, stood a former cowboy, armed with a Colt .45 and a 20-inch blade hidden inside a walking stick. “Most pass by with awed looks,” a witness wrote, “while some few are proud to be seen sitting alongside and basking in the great man’s halo.” One of those who stopped to stare was the actress Ethel Barrymore, in town with a touring company. The object of curiosity introduced himself: “I’m a Pinkerton man.”

headline: Transcendent States
abstract: The narrators of linked novellas relate tales of loss and the search for spiritual solace.
lead_paragraph: Certain writers are driven by a distilled, coherent rage. This rage may have started as a red-hot boil, but the best of these writers don’t approach the page until the original insult has cooled and the words crackle like ice. Personally, I find these folks terrifying. I like to read them, but I’m not so sure I want to know them. Their humor is barbed, their policy, scorched earth. So let’s just say that if I were to catch a glimpse of Bruce Wagner — the grumpy, gimlet-eyed, savagely funny chronicler of all things West Coast — across a crowded room, I’d likely slink out the door.

headline: Looking for Home
abstract: Returned from Iraq, a young man searches for a new life in Europe.
lead_paragraph: What is the distance between here and there, between now and then, between right and wrong? In Greg Baxter’s pellucid first novel, “The Apartment,” it may be simply the length of a day — but a day in which one travels surprisingly far, literally and figuratively. Baxter, whose only previous book is a work of nonfiction, “A Preparation for Death,” which details his implosion and rebirth as a writer and a person, has written a novel of subtle beauty and quiet grace; I found myself hanging on every simple word, as tense about the consequences of a man finding an apartment as if I were reading about a man defusing a bomb. And, possibly, that is what “The Apartment” is as well: the analysis of an explosion deferred, or narrowly avoided, a hairbreadth escape. It is one of the best novels I have read in a long time.

headline: In Store | Exotic Jewelry and Rare Company in Orange County
abstract: At A’maree’s, the one-of-a-kind luxury shop in Newport Beach, a friendly crowd gathered last month for an exhibition of work by Mika Damascou, the jewelry designer and mother of the T contributor Konstantin Kakanias, who designed the invitation.
lead_paragraph: Last month A’maree’s, the family-owned fashion and design shop in the surprising location of Newport Beach, Calif., hosted an exhibition of jewels by Mika Damascou, the mother of the artist (and T Magazine contributor) Konstantin Kakanias, who organized the show with the L.A. stylist Danielle King. The occasion was right in line with the spirit of the store, which marches to its own drummer in terms of what it stocks — fashion, furniture, jewelry, bicycles — and who it supports. The current iteration of A’maree’s is run by the sisters Dawn Klohs and Denise and Apryl Schaefer, whose mother founded it in the 1970s. For the past three years it has existed in a sublime 1960 building on the water by Ladd & Kelsey, the architects of Pasadena’s Norton Simon Museum, a dreamlike Modernist pavilion with arched windows and a scalloped roofline.

headline: A Test Run at Russia’s Olympic Hopeful
abstract: With Sochi, Russia, preparing to host the Winter Olympics in February, the author gets an early taste of the area’s developing ski experience.
lead_paragraph: Before I could board the gondola at Rosa Khutor, a ski area that is part of Sochi, the site of next year’s Winter Olympics, I first had to trundle through a metal detector manned by Russian soldiers with machine guns and furry hats. This is not something I’m used to. At chairlifts in the American West, where I typically ski, you find cheerful young attendants who are stoked to be on their feet all day because that’s what it takes to live the dream.

headline: A Family Connection to Skiing History
abstract: The author of an article on the ski resort at Sochi, Russia, the site of the coming Winter Olympics, digs up a family connection: ski posters created by his grandfather, some of skiing in Russia.
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s ski issue, I write about Rosa Khutor, a new ski resort above the city of Sochi, Russia, that is the site of the alpine events for the coming Winter Games. Built with the Olympics in mind, Rosa Khutor has ambitions to become a world-class ski area that attracts Russian skiers, who might otherwise flee to the Alps, and international visitors, who might otherwise never think of Russia when planning a ski vacation. It’s a great mountain, with great potential.

lead_paragraph: It felt like a scene from a surrealist film.

headline: No Widespread Misconduct Is Found in the Secret Service
abstract: The agency has not “fostered an environment that tolerates inappropriate behavior,” the inspector general of the Homeland Security Department said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service does not have widespread misconduct, and the agency’s leadership has not “fostered an environment that tolerates inappropriate behavior,” according to a review of the agency’s culture by the inspector general’s office for the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: South Africa’s Biggest Trade Union Pulls Its Support for A.N.C.
abstract: The move is likely to erode the dominance of the African National Congress ahead of elections and reorder the politics of a country it has governed with huge majorities since the end of white rule.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s largest trade union withdrew its support for the African National Congress on Friday, a move that is likely to erode the party’s dominance ahead of national elections next year and reorder the politics of a country the party has governed with huge majorities since the end of white rule two decades ago.

headline: Spike Jonze, Video Game Character
abstract: The director relieved the stress of rewrites on “Her” by voicing the foul-mouthed video game character that appears in the film.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:25 p.m. | In some ways, the Spike Jonze romance “Her” is a different beast for the inventive director-writer-prankster – it’s the first feature he wrote on his own – and in some ways it’s a lot like his other films (“Where the Wild Things Are,” “Being John Malkovich,” “Adaptation”). All take a long time in the editing room, up to a year. They’re naturalistic in performance, but not heavily improvised – though the story can sometimes change after they finish filming.

lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Museum of Art on Friday announced that it had acquired of one of the most important collections still in private hands of Deccan and Mughal painting from India’s major Islamic courts of the 16th century through the late 18th century.

headline: Beating Back Pain
abstract: When his back pain returned after more than 25 years, Tony Schwartz writes, he decided it was time to address his fears directly.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, I stepped into a shower in a hotel room in Baton Rouge, La., and felt a slight twinge in my back. I didn’t pay it much mind. I’ve experienced twinges from time to time, but for more than 25 years, I have been essentially free of back pain.

headline: City Opera Ticket Holders Have to Get in Line With Other Creditors
abstract: A judge overseeing New York City Opera’s bankruptcy case said the company could not yet refund money to people who bought tickets for performances that were canceled.
lead_paragraph: When the New York City Opera filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 3 it asked the court if it could refund $323,000 worth of ticket income to subscribers who had faith in the increasingly shaky company. At the same time, it mailed a letter to those ticket buyers, expressing confidence that the court would grant that request but suggesting that patrons could also waive their right to a refund and donate the money to the failed company instead. Enough ticket buyers agreed to reduce the debt by about $30,000.

headline: Dream Leads Hindu Priest to Flushing Store With Temple
abstract: When Kumar Natarajanaidu was 10 years old in India, he had a vision that led him to Flushing, Queens, where he opened a shop with DVDs, flowers and religious apparel in the front and a temple in the back.
lead_paragraph: Kumar Natarajanaidu flipped the cassette in his old tape player and resumed his trance, kneeling on a folded New York Jets blanket and rapidly chanting prayers in Tamil, leaping up each time a customer entered seeking DVDs or flowers.

headline: Wells Fargo Poised for Wall Street Run
abstract: The California bank will start knocking more loudly on the door of the bulge-bracket Wall Street firms, asserts Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo will start knocking more loudly on the bulge bracket’s door. The California lender is already one of the top 10 global investment banks by fees, according to data from Thomson Reuters. Much of that comes courtesy of middle-market clients. But if the bank run by John Stumpf starts going after bigger fish, it could put Wall Street’s bigwigs on the defensive.

abstract: Are you a parent, teacher or student who has experienced a school lockdown? Let us know what you experienced.
lead_paragraph: This month, when an 18-year-old student walked into Arapahoe High School in Colorado with a pump-action shotgun and began shooting, teachers and students and administrators knew almost immediately how to respond. Classroom doors slammed shut. Students huddled in the corners and stayed quiet. A resource officer inside the school sprang to action. Nearby, other schools locked down until they knew whether they, too, faced any threat.

headline: A Day of Music, and Movement Therapy, for a Conductor
abstract: Julian Wachner, the music and arts director at Trinity Church, has to balance his many conducting dates while recovering from a shoulder injury that temporarily stilled his baton.
lead_paragraph: Was it really just two years ago that Trinity Wall Street church scaled back its music program in what an article in this newspaper later called a “seeming brush with death”? The church’s music and arts director, Julian Wachner, 44, is now rushing to erase such memories. Austerity is out. In its place: a four-month festival of Benjamin Britten’s music, Bach cantatas every Monday and a series celebrating the 12 nights of Christmas, which runs from Dec. 26 to Jan. 6. That’s between Mr. Wachner’s side gigs conducting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music or the Juilliard Opera Theater and as music director of the Washington Chorus, all while he recovers from a summer shoulder injury that temporarily stilled his baton. Mr. Wachner lives in TriBeCa with his wife, the Rev. Emily Wachner, the church’s priest for welcome, liturgy, hospitality and pilgrimage, and the couple’s American bulldog, Sophie, and cat, Rowan.

headline: Engaging Shenanigans, Big Surprises
abstract: Unusual and memorable marriage proposals that all seemed to do the trick.
lead_paragraph: The question was written in the sand. It was asked under the big top and with bells on. There was a bended knee followed by a “Will you marry me?” on an elevator ride, and a proposal made on a hotel rooftop to a soundtrack of whirling propellers. There are many other memorable and creative ways to ask that age-old question. So, since that query is often posed during the holiday season, now may be a good time to review some of the most interesting proposals submitted this year to the Vows pages of The Times.

headline: Art and Entertainment That Makes Us Feel Old Before Our Time
abstract: Spike Jonze’s film “Her,” like a recent exhibition of work by the artist Daniel Arsham in Miami, explores our new fear that we, like our gadgets, are destined for rapid obsolescence.
lead_paragraph: For much of the 20th century, scientists believed that the slower one’s metabolism, the longer one’s life. This is called the rate of living theory, and although it is not actually true for humans, it feels increasingly accurate of our machines. The faster our computers get, the faster they seem to break, burn out or become obsolete. The average life span of an American cellphone is 18 months. No wonder the members of my superconnected demographic — young, urban, educated, “creative,” often described as “millennials” — are all afraid we’re shooting to obscurity.

The bullet went through Kenzo’s shoulder and into his heart. The young basketball player and graffiti artist was killed.

headline: Enduring Virtues Onstage in London
abstract: Though the Royal Ballet of London is no longer exemplary from top to bottom, the troupe retains enduring virtues, of which the British are rightly proud.
lead_paragraph: Between 1949 and 1976, the Royal Ballet of London was the most frequent foreign ballet company to visit the United States. Beloved for both theatricality and purity of style, it made annual or biennial visits to New York and other American cities. Two of its coast-to-coast tours lasted five months each. New York became its second home; one of its seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House was eight weeks long. Its stars included Margot Fonteyn, Moira Shearer, Beryl Grey, Svetlana Beriosova, Nadia Nerina, Antoinette Sibley, Lynn Seymour, Merle Park and Anthony Dowell, with Rudolf Nureyev its most celebrated guest artist. For many Americans, it was the yardstick by which to judge all other kinds of ballet classicism.

headline: Levine and Mahler, Laredo and Mozart
abstract: During Christmas week, Carnegie Hall is surprisingly active, starting on Sunday afternoon at 3, when the Met Orchestra performs an all-Mahler program conducted by James Levine.
lead_paragraph: During Christmas week, Carnegie Hall is surprisingly active, starting on Sunday afternoon at 3, when the Met Orchestra performs an all-Mahler program conducted by James Levine. The compelling baritone Peter Mattei will be the soloist in “Song of a Wayfarer.” Then Mr. Levine will lead the teeming, episodic yet inexorable Seventh Symphony, an 80-minute workout for a maestro and orchestra. Then the conductor Jaime Laredo presents two programs with the New York String Orchestra, a group of select young musicians in training. On Tuesday, Christmas Eve, at 7 p.m., he leads Mozart’s Overture to “Le Nozze di Figaro” and “Paris” Symphony, as well as Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto with Bella Hristova as soloist. On Saturday at 8 p.m., the esteemed pianist Leon Fleisher will be heard in Prokofiev’s Concerto No. 4 for left hand and orchestra, on a program that opens with Elgar’s “Introduction and Allegro” and ends with Tchaikovsky’s “Pathétique” Symphony. (212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: An Indie Rapper, Loud and Proud
abstract: The indie rapper Le1f (born Khalif Diouf) is an oddball and an empire builder: an openly gay rapper with a degree in dance who also runs a label, Camp & Street.
lead_paragraph: The indie rapper Le1f (born Khalif Diouf) is an oddball and an empire builder: an openly gay (or as one of his songs puts it, “gayngsta”) rapper with a degree in dance who also runs a label, Camp & Street. He produced the Das Racist track “Combination Pizza Bell and Taco Hut” before starting his own busy, prolific career, including two generous free mixtapes. He has a low voice, a startling wardrobe and an ear for sparse but insistent tracks.

headline: The Land of Sweets Sheds Its Tutus
abstract: A dancegoer’s options are fairly limited this week: There’s “The Nutcracker,” and then there’s “The Nutcracker.”
lead_paragraph: A dancegoer’s options are fairly limited this week: There’s “The Nutcracker,” and then there’s “The Nutcracker.” But two of the season’s most popular renditions couldn’t be more different. At Lincoln Center, New York City Ballet soldiers on in its six-week run of George Balanchine’s classic version, with its pristine dancing and reverence for childhood fantasy. A darker sort of fantasy is playing out at the Minetta Lane Theater, home to Company XIV’s burlesque twist on this E. T. A. Hoffmann tale.

headline: Cash for Cab Drivers
abstract: The owner of one of the largest taxi fleets in New York has agreed to pay over $1.2 million in fines and back pay to drivers.
lead_paragraph: New York’s incoming mayor, Bill de Blasio has enjoyed strong support from taxicab fleet owners, while the current Taxi Commissioner, David Yassky, has been a strong advocate for taxicab drivers. Perhaps not surprisingly, Mr. de Blasio has made it clear that Mr. Yassky, will be one of the first people out the door come January 1.

headline: A Cappella Contest Makes a Comeback
abstract: “The Sing-Off,” never became a ratings juggernaut and was apparently dead at the end of its third season in 2011. Then the network had a change of heart.
lead_paragraph: “The Voice” has paid a lot of bills for NBC, but another good singing competition, “The Sing-Off,” never became a ratings juggernaut and was apparently dead at the end of its third season in 2011. Then the network had a change of heart. It decided to bring “The Sing-Off” back this month for a two-week, seven-episode Season 4 and gave its premiere “The Voice” as a lead-in.

headline: Star of the Show? The Art Dealer
abstract: Trace the history of the finest pieces of postwar art, and many of them lead back to Ileana Sonnabend, the gallery owner and collector, who died in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Trace the history of the finest pieces of postwar art, and many of them lead back to Ileana Sonnabend, the gallery owner and collector, who died in 2007. Andy Warhol’s “Liz #1 (Early Colored Liz),” which sold at Sotheby’s for $18 million last month? Sonnabend. Robert Rauschenberg’s 20th-century mixed-media collage “Canyon,” which the Museum of Modern Art won over the Metropolitan Museum last year? Sonnabend.

headline: Loverly Memories of a Director
abstract: Spend Christmas Day at the Walter Reade Theater revisiting three of the most memorable films directed by George Cukor.
lead_paragraph: Spend Christmas Day at the Walter Reade Theater revisiting three of the most memorable films directed by George Cukor, whose work is being surveyed through Jan. 7 by the Film Society of Lincoln Center in its series called The Discreet Charm of George Cukor.

abstract: Before taking questions from reporters, the president delivered an opening statement, saying he firmly believed 2014 could be a breakthrough year for America.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jackie Calmes asked the president about his statement that “if you like your plan, you can keep it” being called the “Lie of the Year” by PolitiFact.

headline: Analyzing the American Express Surcharge Settlement
abstract: Merchants will now have the opportunity to levy surcharges on credit card transactions, but will they use it?
lead_paragraph: In August 2012, lawyers for merchants won a settlement from MasterCard and Visa, an agreement that on close inspection struck many merchant advocates as not much of a victory.

headline: Calculating the Number of Windows in Buildings in Manhattan
abstract: A reader wanted to know how many windows there were in all the buildings in Manhattan, a question that might be asked during an internship interview.
lead_paragraph: Q. Like many first-year M.B.A. students, I am preparing to interview for summer internship positions. A typical interviewer may ask a question such as “How many windows are there in all the buildings in Manhattan?” to test your critical reasoning skills. There are ways to estimate, but I’d love to know for sure: Just how many buildings are there on the island of Manhattan, and how many windows do they contain?

headline: Trudging Somberly to Their Deaths, as a Lone Soul Mourns
abstract: Megan Kendzior’s “Witness” invokes the horrors of the Holocaust with slow footsteps, shivers and shoes as props at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of Megan Kendzior’s dance “Witness” is a question: How can we observe atrocities and look away? The production, an exploration of indifference and trauma, was inspired by her research into the Holocaust and her visit to the Auschwitz death camp. Her tools are bodies — 15 dancers, to be exact — the plaintive sound of the accordion and many pairs of shoes, which refer to the horrifying room of victims’ shoes at Auschwitz.

headline: Ballads Punctuated by Frenzy
abstract: The Mike Stern Band, led by the guitarist Mike Stern, reaches a blues-rock bliss state in its shows at the Iridium.
lead_paragraph: The guitarist Mike Stern reached peak combustion at an unlikely point in his first set at the Iridium on Thursday night, while cutting a path from one guileless ballad to the next. He enlisted only his tough-minded drummer, Dennis Chambers, for this excursion, issuing no directive beyond a tempo. In no time they achieved a blues-rock bliss state, goading each other toward notions of strenuous metaphysical abandon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Nepal.

headline: Boasting a Power That Pepé Le Pew Would Admire
abstract: In “Mr. Stink,” Hugh Bonneville of “Downton Abbey” fame plays a homeless man who is befriended by a kind-hearted girl.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Stink” is a charming holiday fable with an added draw for “Downton Abbey” fans: the sight of Hugh Bonneville, the distinguished Earl of Grantham in that series, reduced to an almost unrecognizable state of vagrancy in playing the title character.

headline: No Space Too Small, No Lease Too Short
keywords: ['Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']

lead_paragraph: When Kanye West brought his Yeezus tour to New York last month, he needed somewhere to sell his merchandise. Instead of a concert booth, he opened a pop-up shop at 355 Bowery and sold $35 snapback hats and $20 tote bags.

headline: Maria Bello: Partnerships, Love and Conversations, to Be Continued

lead_paragraph: “Why now?”

headline: The World at Her Fingertips
abstract: Natalie Massenet has already made Net-a-Porter a powerful force in the fashion world. Now, with a new, high-profile post and a print magazine on the way, she is charting a new course.
lead_paragraph: When Natalie Massenet ascended the stairs of the Carnegie Hall stage a month ago to accept a Woman of the Year trophy from Glamour magazine, she outdid Jennifer Lawrence at the 2013 Oscars ceremony, nearly tripping on her Alessandra Rich white lace gown (soon available for upward of $3,000 at Net-a-Porter, the online luxury retailer she founded) before impaling the hem with her high-heeled sandals.

headline: The High Priest of Horology
abstract: Benjamin Clymer, the founder of the watch-enthusiast website Hodinkee, carves a niche in the underground and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Jay Z asked him to pick out a watch for his two Carnegie Hall concerts last year (he wore a Jaeger-LeCoultre Reverso).

headline: Climate Scientists, Then and Now, Espousing ‘Responsible Advocacy’
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Politics and Government', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A climate scientist charts a responsible path from climate science to advocacy.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long appreciated Gavin A. Schmidt‘s approach to doing and communicating climate science. Schmidt, deputy director of NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, has endured many slings and arrows, not to mention hacks and legal tangles, in building RealClimate.org into what I’ve called a vital online touchstone for anyone trying to understand research on the human influence on the planet’s thermostat.

headline: Ho, Ho, Ho? Oh, No, No, No!
abstract: Traditional Christmases aren’t for everyone, but that does not mean the spirit of the holiday should be rejected.
lead_paragraph: We skitter, we dodge. My boyfriend and I will be flying to India on Christmas Day. Jetting off on Santa’s Judgment Day is not unusual for me; I’m among that tiny percentage of the population who hears “Santa’s helpers” and thinks “skycaps.” Part of my seasonal wanderlust lies in the belief that a Christmas celebrated by two adults and no children can be eerily quiet, a Beckett play performed in a canyon on the moon. But the larger part lies in my conviction that the most beautiful and tinselly bauble to be found on Dec. 25 is reduced airfare.

headline: Federal Judge Rules That Same-Sex Marriage Is Legal in Utah
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The judge said that Utah’s amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the United States Constitution. If the ruling is upheld, Utah will become the 18th state to permit same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Salt Lake County began issuing marriage licenses to jubilant same-sex couples on Friday, hours after a federal judge ruled that Utah’s amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the United States Constitution.

headline: Who Will Keep Financial Reform Going?
abstract: There will be no tried-and-true reforms on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
lead_paragraph: In late November, nine Democratic senators sent President Obama a letter about a vacancy on the five-member Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the agency charged under the Dodd-Frank law with regulating most of the multi-trillion dollar market in derivatives.

headline: For Millennials, a Generational Divide
keywords: ['Youth', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Age, Chronological', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Young adults do not think and act alike, as it turns out. In fact, some do not want to be called millennials at all.
lead_paragraph: You know them when you see them. They are tapping on their smartphones, strolling into work late and amassing Instagram followers faster than a twerking cat. They complain. They “disrupt” stuff. They simultaneously (and somewhat improbably) like both Kanye West and Kenny Chesney.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Disappointing Response
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Editorials', 'Privacy']
abstract: In his news conference, the president, yet again, offers little more than bland reassurances on the government’s runaway surveillance policy.
lead_paragraph: By the time President Obama gave his news conference on Friday, there was really only one course to take on surveillance policy from an ethical, moral, constitutional and even political point of view. And that was to embrace the recommendations of his handpicked panel on government spying — and bills pending in Congress — to end the obvious excesses. He could have started by suspending the constitutionally questionable (and evidently pointless) collection of data on every phone call and email that Americans make.

headline: Uh-Oh: George Clooney Is Drooling Again
abstract: A celebrity’s name may help a potential adopter form a bond with an animal, shelter directors say.
lead_paragraph: When Heather Allard, an entrepreneur from Pawtucket, R.I., saw the dog with the red bow tie on the Internet, she had to have him. It was partly the mixed boxer’s commanding jaw and the steadiness of his eyes, but it was mostly his name: James Earl Jones.

headline: One Mushroom Ragoût, Five Meals
abstract: I know that I can recycle the leftover mushroom ragoût into a number of dishes, from omelets to tarts, risottos to tacos, writes Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: I have never been a gravy fan, but I am a fan of what I call “Mushroom Ragoût Gravy,” which is not a gravy at all but a mushroom ragoût, or stew. I always make too much. I double the recipe if we are going to be a dozen people, which we usually are during holiday gatherings, even though I know that nobody will have enough room on their plates for more than a spoonful.

headline: Many Arms and Many Splendors
abstract: The pace at Octopus Garden, a Brooklyn store, turns frenzied before Christmas Eve when Italian-Americans celebrating the Feast of Seven Fishes crave octopus, cuttlefish and calamari.
lead_paragraph: The pace at Octopus Garden, a Brooklyn store, turns frenzied before Christmas Eve when Italian-Americans celebrating the Feast of Seven Fishes crave octopus, cuttlefish and calamari.

headline: A Treasure House of Shifting Aspirations
abstract: As it grows in size and ambition, the Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens is finding inventive ways to explain its purpose and mission.
lead_paragraph: SAN MARINO, Calif. — What does a 15th-century illuminated manuscript of “The Canterbury Tales” have in common with an “Old Mission Brand” label from a crate of oranges? What is the connection between the novelist Thackeray’s 1853 drawing of a black girl in South Carolina and plantings meant to echo the famed Chinese gardens of Suzhou? What could possibly connect 19th-century light bulbs and Gainsborough’s much-loved painting “Blue Boy”?

lead_paragraph: On the way home from a bar in the wee hours of the morning, Branden Eastwood, 29, managed to break his ankle stepping into a cab. He wasn’t insured, so it became an expensive night out: He received $42,000 in medical bills from a Georgetown hospital.

headline: Octopus Garden Prepares for Feast of Seven Fishes
abstract: In the days before Christmas Eve, many who celebrate a Feast of Seven Fishes stock up at Octopus Garden in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Most times of the year, no one can be seen in Octopus Garden save the workers in the back trimming squid beaks or keeping an eye on the octopus-washing machines. Vincent Cutrone, the owner of the store (hidden off Avenue U in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and marked with a sign made of stick-on letters from the hardware store), often is not at the counter. When the rare walk-in customer appears, his staff just hollers to him in the office.

headline: Agustin Madala Wins the Goren Trophy
abstract: The Goren Trophy is awarded to the player who wins the most masterpoints during the Fall North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: The Goren Trophy is awarded to the player who wins the most masterpoints during the Fall North American Championships. This year’s winner was Agustin Madala, who hails from Argentina but represents Italy. He amassed 402.22 points, 83.32 more than Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.

headline: Survival Goes to Extremes
abstract: Discovery’s “Dude, You’re Screwed” transforms survival into sport.
lead_paragraph: A former Navy SEAL, Jake Zweig got his start on reality TV as a small-minded loudmouth on the third season of “Top Shot,” the underappreciated marksmanship competition show on the History Channel. He was a talented shooter, but also petty and sulky and disruptive; his elimination came as a relief.

headline: Telecom Italia Shareholders Reject Bid to Remove Board
abstract: A sizable percentage of votes supported the dissidents, who are trying to reduce the influence of the Spanish giant Telefónica.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders in Telecom Italia on Friday voted against a proposal to remove its board in a battle over the company’s future. But a sizable percentage of votes supported the dissidents’ plan.

headline: Google Bus Vandalized During Protest
abstract: Another protest erupts against the tech buses in the Bay Area, just as a leading venture capitalist introduces his plan to break up the state.
lead_paragraph: Activists blocked three buses carrying Bay Area tech workers to their Silicon Valley jobs on Friday, breaking a window of one of the vehicles. It was the second demonstration this month targeting the buses, which are rapidly becoming a symbol of the surging animosity between the tech world and everyone else in the Bay Area.

headline: Putting on the Blintz
abstract: For a New Year’s Eve supper, drink Champagne alongside an extravagant version of chicken blintzes with wild mushrooms.
lead_paragraph: The fabulously feline chanteuse Eartha Kitt inspired these blintzes. In an otherwise insipid song called “Mink, Schmink,” recorded in the 1950s, she sings about how wealth and riches don’t mean a thing if you haven’t got love, rhyming “princes, schminces” with “caviar and chicken blintzes.”

headline: New Center, but Woes at Historic Site
abstract: Even as it prepares to open a $34 million cultural building, the Weeksville Heritage Center in Brooklyn faces money problems.
lead_paragraph: The Weeksville Heritage Center in Crown Heights in Brooklyn started out operating from a cluster of small wood-frame houses, the remnants of a free black community established in 1838. The organization has preserved those three houses, along with documents and artifacts. Now, a new 23,000-square-foot, $34 million building just yards from the houses presents a chance for Weeksville to create a national showcase for black history and culture.

headline: NASA Solves Helmet Leak With Makeshift Snorkels
abstract: Two astronauts preparing for a spacewalk to fix a broken pump at the International Space Station will don helmets fitted with improvised safety measures.
lead_paragraph: NASA, in preparation for a spacewalk on Saturday, has devised makeshift snorkels that would allow an astronaut in a spacesuit to continue breathing even if a sudden water leak should fill the helmet, as happened to an Italian astronaut who almost drowned in July.

headline: Ethiopian Funkster, Back After Long Break
abstract: Hailu Mergia, a onetime star of Ethiopian music now driving a cab in Washington, led an earthy evening of funk at Baby’s All Right in Williamsburg on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: There’s a back story behind the African funk that had the whole room dancing on Thursday night at Baby’s All Right, the new club in Williamsburg. Hailu Mergia, the keyboardist leading the band, was playing his first American show since 1991. For the last two decades, he has been driving an airport taxicab in Washington.

headline: During Religious Season, Nonbelievers Assert Right to Celebrate
abstract: New York secular groups — like atheists and agnostics; skeptics and rationalists; humanists, freethinkers and nontheists — attend potlucks, solstice celebrations and even karaoke outings.
lead_paragraph: In the darkness of an Upper West Side concert hall last weekend, 150 audience members holding twinkling plastic candles sang and swayed to celebrate reason and the season. Snow fell with abandon outside.

abstract: Christmas time in New York.
lead_paragraph: Decorations and whimsical expressions transformed the city into smiles and joy for the annual SantaCon celebrants, and even a large police presence this year couldn’t dampen their spirits. Private homes and spectacular store windows at stalwarts like Lord & Taylor, Bergdorf Goodman, Tiffany’s and Bloomingdale’s turned often-harsh streets into a winter wonderland.

abstract: Home-cooked meals: More, please.
lead_paragraph: Apparently these are cropping up all over the place. This one is near Washington, D.C.’s Union Station. Email your own to bittmanstuff@gmail.com.

abstract: The Olympic torch has begun its journey from Moscow to Sochi, and it’s been anything but a smooth one. Along the record-breaking 40,389-mile route, the torch has had its fair share of mishaps.

headline: A Favor Economy in Which Kind Acts Come With Expected Reciprocity
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gifts', 'Philanthropy', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The performance of gestures, services and kind acts has quite likely been a driving force of life in New York at least since the days of the New Amsterdam colony. But we roll now in ways the Dutch could not have foreseen.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, I had a friend who moved to New York with various aspirations, and until they were fulfilled he supported himself working at a restaurant. The place was cultish and bohemian — artists had started it — and interesting people worked there. Eventually my friend got to know the daughter of a famous actor there. On various occasions, he ate out with this woman and her father, noticing that when they did, the bill rarely arrived. This led my friend to one of his most astute and enduring observations about New York: “Only rich people eat for free.”

abstract: Ada Colau’s group, the Platform for People Affected by Mortgages, has blocked hundreds of evictions and pressed for changes in Spain’s hard-line mortgage laws.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — ADA COLAU was sitting in a cafe here on a recent evening when another customer, heading for the door, recognized her and veered toward her table.

headline: For a Mayor on His Way Out, a Subway Station on Its Way In
abstract: A subway station not expected to open to the public until the summer gets a special visit from New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: For years, Michael R. Bloomberg has been a subway rider of singular distinction: a mayor who often took the train to work, as common New Yorkers do, albeit after a chauffeured drive from his townhouse to an express stop a mile away.

headline: Israel: Palestinian Killed Near Border
abstract: Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man who approached the border fence separating Gaza from Israel and wounded five others at several points along the fence, Palestinian medical officials said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces on Friday fatally shot a Palestinian man who approached the border fence separating Gaza from Israel and wounded five others at several points along the fence, Palestinian medical officials said. The Israeli military said that Palestinians had thrown rocks at soldiers near the fence and fired a mortar shell into Israel. Ouda Hamad, 22, was the third Palestinian to be killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers this week. On Wednesday and Thursday, Israeli forces in the West Bank killed two Palestinians, one during arrest raids in the Jenin refugee camp and one in Qalqilya. The military said the man killed in Qalqilya had fired on the soldiers. A spokesman for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, condemned the West Bank killings as a “dangerous Israeli escalation” meant to undermine peace negotiations.

headline: China: Tibetan Sets Himself on Fire
abstract: A monk in a Tibetan region of western China died after setting fire to himself on Thursday afternoon, according to two Tibet advocacy groups based outside China.
lead_paragraph: A monk in a Tibetan region of western China died after setting fire to himself on Thursday afternoon, according to two Tibet advocacy groups based outside China. The monk, Tsultrim Gyatso, was the 125th person inside a Tibetan area of China to commit self-immolation as an act of protest since 2009, according to Kate Saunders, a spokeswoman for the International Campaign for Tibet. Another group, Free Tibet, put the total at 123, with 27 this year. The latest protest took place in a town that Tibetans call Amchok, in the Chinese province of Gansu.

headline: Murray Hill Church’s Neighbors Would Prefer to Look at the Clock
abstract: The bells at the Church of Our Saviour in Midtown Manhattan used to toll twice a day, but a new pastor stepped up the chime schedule to 13 times a day, irritating some neighbors.
lead_paragraph: The Christmas season, with its silver bells, silent nights and packed pews, might not be the most opportune time to take issue with your local Catholic church. But a group of neighbors of the Church of Our Saviour in Midtown Manhattan are doing just that, complaining that — of all things — the incessant ringing of church bells has produced a heavy helping of bad cheer.

headline: Youkilis Joins Star Pitcher’s Team in Japan
abstract: Kevin Youkilis, who spent a disappointing 2013 season with the Yankees, is joining the Rakuten Golden Eagles, Masahiro Tanaka’s team.
lead_paragraph: Whether the Japanese star Masahiro Tanaka stays with the Rakuten Golden Eagles for the 2014 season or pitches in the United States remains unclear. But one established major leaguer has decided to leave the majors and join Rakuten, no matter where Tanaka ends up.

headline: Radio Stations Find Ratings ‘Rocket Fuel’ in Switch to Christmas Format
abstract: More and more radio stations are trying an all-Christmas-music format to bolster their ratings temporarily.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is over — the in-laws are gone — and Christmas is not yet here. It’s a cold weekend day, not much happening, and you head to the strip mall. Flat-screens beckon, Chromebooks too, and assorted pads, pods and tablets. You turn on the radio, find your trusty Lite-FM station, and settle in for some Elton, Celine, Shania and Mariah.

The executive apologized on Sunday after she was fired on Saturday.

headline: Having a Servant Is Not a Right
keywords: ['Domestic Service', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: India’s outrage at the treatment of a diplomat who underpaid her housekeeper points up its complicity in an exploitative system.
lead_paragraph: AT the heart of the fracas surrounding the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York who promised to pay her housekeeper $9.75 per hour, in compliance with United States labor rules, but instead paid her $3.31 per hour, is India’s dirty secret: One segment of the Indian population routinely exploits another, and the country’s labor laws allow gross mistreatment of domestic workers.

lead_paragraph: The beige buildings collectively known as Industry City form narrow cobblestone canyons perpendicular to the Sunset Park waterfront. The loud roar of vehicles speeding down the nearby Gowanus Expressway gives way toward the west to the slow rumble of trucks creeping across the uneven streets.

lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — For the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011, the independent militias that dominated Libya’s biggest cities and sometimes cowed the central government have fled from the streets, chased away by a combination of civilian protesters and armed groups.

headline: Revitalizing Our Forests

lead_paragraph: THIS Christmas season, I am roasting chestnuts by the fire. American chestnuts, to be exact. These nuts, once widespread, were almost wiped out by a fungal blight. For a century, most of the chestnuts we eat, like the sweet Castanea sativa variety, have been imported from Europe and Asia.

headline: John Bell Hood’s Leg
abstract: The Confederate general’s convalescence after losing his leg shows what life was like for men injured in battle.
lead_paragraph: It happened so fast. As Maj. Gen. John Bell Hood of the Confederacy led his soldiers into action at the battle of Chickamauga on Sept. 20, 1863, a Minié ball struck his right leg; later that day his leg was amputated four inches below the hip. Although such operations resulted in an 80 percent casualty rate throughout the Civil War, Hood survived, and traveled with his damaged appendage to the residence of the Little family, 15 miles away from the battlefield.

lead_paragraph: It has been nearly eight months since the collapse of a building in Bangladesh killed more than 1,100 garment factory workers and left many others with grave injuries. But most of those victims and their families have yet to receive adequate financial help or medical care.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Stops Joking About Casting Problems
abstract: After being criticized for its lack of onstage diversity, “Saturday Night Live” is poised to hire a black female cast member.
lead_paragraph: After coming under intense criticism for its lack of onstage diversity, “Saturday Night Live” is poised to hire its first black female cast member since Maya Rudolph left the show in 2007. Lorne Michaels, the executive producer, told The New York Times that “S.N.L.” recently held special auditions and that one or two black women would most likely join the cast in January — a good thing for notions of balance, of course, but also for the show’s relevance.

headline: Britain: Judge Rejects Libyan’s Rendition Case
abstract: A Libyan dissident, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, cannot pursue in a British court his “well founded” claim that he was unlawfully abducted in 2004, and later tortured.
lead_paragraph: A Libyan dissident, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, cannot pursue in a British court his “well founded” claim that he was unlawfully abducted in 2004 in a joint MI6-C.I.A. operation, and later tortured, because the case involved other countries and could damage Britain’s relations with the United States, a British high court judge ruled Friday. The judge, Peregrine Simon, ruled, “with hesitation,” that Mr. Belhaj could not sue MI6, the foreign intelligence service, and a former foreign secretary, Jack Straw, even though parliamentary oversight and police investigations were “not adequate substitutes” for a decision by a court. He dismissed the case, he said, because American, as well as British, officials were involved in the rendition of Mr. Belhaj and his pregnant wife to Libya in 2004 and agreed with the British government that a case in open court would harm its relations with Washington. Mr. Belhaj will appeal.

headline: Law Will Tighten Oversight of Special Education Providers

headline: Plan Sought to Protect Food Supply From Terrorism
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration proposed a rule that requires major food producers to develop a plan to prevent intentional attempts to contaminate the food supply.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration proposed a rule on Friday to require major food producers to develop a plan to prevent intentional attempts to contaminate the food supply. The agency said it favored the rule, not because such a criminal act is likely, but as an extra precaution. Under the rule, open to public comment until the end of March, companies would need plans to address vulnerabilities in production processes, particularly to acts of terrorism. They would have one to three years to comply.

Beltran was in a fine mood, actually, having just formalized his three-year, $45 million contract with the Yankees.

lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Finnish Flash rolled through New Jersey one last time on Friday, and as with all the stops on Teemu Selanne’s N.H.L. farewell tour, it was a special occasion. The game between the Anaheim Ducks and the Devils was the last regular-season appearance for Selanne, 43, in the metropolitan area and, almost certainly, the last time he would play in the N.H.L. against Jaromir Jagr, 41, the league’s other ageless wonder.

abstract: These early contests offer intriguing matchups pitting some of the nation’s best college football players.
lead_paragraph: Who says all the good bowl games are in January? And that is just one of the intriguing matchups to watch before the end of 2013. This may be your last chance to see quarterbacks Teddy Bridgewater, Johnny Manziel and Jordan Lynch before they start playing on Sundays.

headline: EuroVision Star Becomes Voice of Protest
abstract: Ruslana, a Ukrainian pop singer, has been an inspiration and a force for calm. Just don’t call her a leader of the popular movement against the government.
lead_paragraph: When Ukrainian security forces stormed Kiev’s central square on Dec. 11, the pop singer Ruslana was on stage and attempting to defuse the situation. “I kept a quiet confidence in myself, and I believe that my voice kept them calm,” she said recently. Ruslana, the 2004 winner of the EuroVision Song Contest, has been a constant presence at Independence Square, also known as Maidan, since demonstrators gathered there in late November to protest the government’s decision to postpone an economic agreement with the European Union. She is on stage every night from midnight until sunrise, keeping thousands of demonstrators upbeat and energized in freezing temperatures. Many protesters consider her to be one of the leaders of the movement, but she vehemently disagrees. “We said that one cannot lead Maidan, one can only join Maidan,” she said.

This year, my husband and I are entertaining a dozen friends and family on Christmas Eve in our small Welsh hillside cottage, where there is no electricity. headline: The Not-a-Scientist’s Assistant
abstract: How to give away a revolutionary idea? For one college student in the late 1990s, it would take a lot of work.
lead_paragraph: I was 20 years old, going to college in New York and in need of a job. My roommate waitressed at a restaurant where she made huge tips, but I didn’t have the bone structure or hair texture to be hired somewhere like that. Instead, I waited outside the Village Voice offices. It was the late ’90s, and every Wednesday when the paper came out, a line of people stretched down the sidewalk to get a first look at the classified ads. That’s how different things were before the Internet. Back then, people would unbend their legs and assume a vertical position, known as standing.

(Just as a reminder — this does NOT mean that wage flexibility would improve our current situation — on the contrary, thanks to the overhang of household debt, it would make things worse).

abstract: There are ways to lower costs. Is there the will?
lead_paragraph: HAVING spent the last year reporting for a series of articles on the high cost of American medicine, I’ve heard it all. There was Fred Abrahams, 77, a skier who had surgery on both ankles for arthritis — one in New York for more than $200,000 and one in New Hampshire for less than $40,000. There was Matthew Landman, 41, billed more than $100,000 for antivenin administered in an E.R. after a small rattlesnake bite. There was Robin Miller, a Florida businessman, who needed to buy an implantable defibrillator for his ill brother, who was uninsured; the machine costs tens of thousands of dollars, but he couldn’t get a price for a make or a model.

I had spent the morning at my office writing a neuroscience textbook, and was looking forward to returning home to spend some time with my 3- and 7-year-old daughters, Skylar and Lara. But the news I received from my husband as I walked through the door was devastating. The girls had been exploring in the attic — a space I’d thought was the perfect hiding place for Santa’s gifts. It was more than a week before Christmas and they had just seen their presents!

headline: Kenneth A. Schechter, 83, Dies; With Help, He Flew Blind
keywords: ['Korean War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Pilots']
abstract: Mr. Schechter, then Ensign Schechter, a Navy pilot during the Korean War, was at the heart of one of the most electrifying air rescues in American military history.
lead_paragraph: “On the ninth of my planned 15 bomb runs, at 1,200 feet, an enemy antiaircraft shell exploded in the cockpit. Instinctively, I pulled back on the stick to gain altitude. Then I passed out. When I came to a short time later, I couldn’t see a thing. There was stinging agony in my face and throbbing in my head. I felt for my upper lip. It was almost severed from the rest of my face. I called out over the radio through my lip mike (which miraculously still worked), ‘I’m blind! For God’s sake, help me! I’m blind!’ ”

headline: Reflections on the Killing of Chico Mendes 25 Years Ago
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Earth', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Twenty five years after the assassination of Chico Mendes, a campaigner for forests and the people who live in them, his legacy continues to shape conservation efforts on dangerous resource frontiers.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard for me to believe that it’s been 25 years since a cattle rancher ordered his son to shoot Chico Mendes, a rubber tapper and unionist who had become an effective international campaigner for sustainable use of the Amazon rain forest. I spent the year following Mendes’s assassination piecing together “The Burning Season,” my book on his life, death and influence. But I haven’t been back to that corner of the Amazon since the trial of his murderers in 1990. The Guardian has published an excellent article assessing his legacy. Linda Rabben, an anthropologist and activist focused on human rights and the environment, is the lead organizer of a conference on Mendes and grassroots environmentalism next spring. headline: A Nureyev Ballet, With a Hint of Ambivalence, Takes Its Time
abstract: “The Sleeping Beauty” being performed by the Paris Opera Ballet is notable for its length and what Rudolf Nureyev may have been trying to convey between the lines.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Rudolf Nureyev’s “The Sleeping Beauty,” currently being performed by the Paris Opera Ballet, is ornate, ceremonious and very, very long. It also hints at Nureyev’s ambivalence toward the Russia he left behind when he defected to the West in 1961 at 23 while on tour with the Kirov Ballet.

headline: After the Deluge, the Restoration
abstract: Giorgio Vasari’s “The Last Supper,” a work from 1546 that was all but ruined in a 1966 flood, is slowly coming back to life in Florence.
lead_paragraph: More than most Renaissance artists, Giorgio Vasari knew the perilous existence of human creations. In “The Lives of the Artists,” the chronicle of the great quattrocento painters and sculptors for which he is best known, he describes how a stone bench, hurled off a parapet by an anti-Medici mob in Florence in 1527, “chanced, as Fortune would have it,” to land on Michelangelo’s “David,” breaking one of its arms into three pieces.

headline: Haunted by Holiday Shows Past
abstract: Surely the holiday-theme variety television specials of yesteryear — Carol Burnett’s, Danny Kaye’s, Dean Martin’s — were superior to this season’s offerings, right? Guess again.
lead_paragraph: The spurious “war on Christmas” bemoaned on Fox News notwithstanding, a war really has been going on in recent years at the holidays: a war between traditional television Christmas specials and that aggressive musical interloper, the singing-competition finale. It’s a mismatch. With December now dominated by singing competitions — “The X Factor” and “The Voice” wrapped up last week; “The Sing-Off” ends Monday night — the old-fashioned variety-show-style Christmas special feels as if it could go extinct any year now.

headline: You Can’t Save Them All
abstract: The Walking Dead: Season Two is approachable for the gaming illiterate while also demonstrating the promise of video games as something more than a vehicle for fast-twitch excitement.
lead_paragraph: You don’t play video games, but you’re curious about them. How should you get started? That’s a question that Steve Gaynor, the writer and director of the independent game Gone Home, has taken to asking guests on his podcast (Tone Control: Conversations with Video Game Developers): What would they recommend to someone who is entirely new to the medium?

headline: Strategy Remains Elusive for Ukraine Opposition
abstract: Protest turnout was again large on Sunday, but the day’s tenor was one of acknowledgment that the movement was ebbing as opposition leaders struggle to convey their next step.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — One of the most effective, and affecting, sights on Maidan, the independence square that antigovernment protesters have made theirs for the past month, is a simple wall of wooden blocks. There are hundreds, in jagged formation, each with the name of a village, town or city etched in black.

headline: Jets Ride Ryan’s Power of Persuasion to Victory Over Browns
abstract: With Rex Ryan delivering impassioned pleas to the officials and his players, the Jets scored 17 straight points on their way to a solid win over the Cleveland Browns.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rex Ryan stamped. He shouted. He cursed and snarled and appealed, releasing a reservoir of fury on a man who was in position to make a very important decision. When he had finished pleading, Ryan had what he wanted.

headline: Book Theft in Italy, With a Hint of Politics
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: A former Italian senator who received books that went missing from the Girolamini Library in Naples is trying to distance himself from one of the biggest rare-book-theft scandals in history.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — For years, the books kept coming. A precious edition by Thomas More. Leather-bound volumes from the Italian Renaissance. Some stolen from the Baroque-era Girolamini Library in Naples, given as gifts to an influential longtime consigliere to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: Make Music Winter
abstract: The celebration in Prospect Park was marked by a participatory performance and unseasonably warm weather.
lead_paragraph: The celebration in Prospect Park was marked by a participatory performance and unseasonably warm weather.

headline: A Romp, Meant to Ring in the Cold, Feels Like Spring
keywords: ['Make Music Winter (Festival)', 'Make Music New York (Festival)', 'Music', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: The Make Music Winter celebration in Prospect Park was marked by a participatory performance and unseasonably warm weather.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Make Music Winter, the annual solstice celebration of participatory performance, took place with an emphasis on its final word. I joined in “Winterize,” the baritone Christopher Dylan Herbert’s peripatetic outdoor version of Schubert’s “Winterreise,” at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on a raw, gray afternoon as chilly as the melancholy score.

headline: Reaching for Soul’s High Ground
abstract: Bobby Womack, 69, despite advancing age and what he said was Alzheimer’s disease, was in fine fettle on Friday at City Winery.
lead_paragraph: Classic soul singing is, among countless other things, the art of the interjection. “Whoo!” “Mmmmm.” “Ohhhhhh.” “HahahaHA!” “Owww.” “Yeah, yeah!” “Am I lying?” Can I take my time?” “Listen to me!” “Do you feel it?” Used right, those interjections can be percussion, comedy, respiration, tension, release and more. Bobby Womack, 69, used them all at City Winery on Friday night, wearing a red leather suit, a red hat and red sunglasses as he started a three-night stand.

headline: Q. and A.: U.S. Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker on China Trade Talks
keywords: ['Government Procurement', 'Industrial Espionage', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Following annual trade and commerce talks with China, a senior Obama administration official discusses hopes for economic reforms announced in a Communist Party conference last month and progress on a government procurement deal and protection of trade secret and patents.
lead_paragraph: Since a key Communist Party conference issued a plan in November to advance market reforms, a series of foreign envoys have rolled through China seeking to capitalize on some of its more business-friendly initiatives. Top American trade officials took the same tack during talks in Beijing last week, but made clear afterward that it would take time for United States businesses to reap dividends from the conference, known as the Third Plenum.

headline: China Deal Gives Apple Big Market to Court
abstract: The agreement to bring the iPhone to China Mobile could, at least initially, give Apple a big lift into the vast Chinese market, analysts say, increasing its global sales.
lead_paragraph: Just about any way you slice it, 763 million customers is a huge potential pie.

headline: An Affection for Books, Dogs, One Tough Nun and, Yes, a Husband
abstract: Ann Patchett’s new essay collection reinforces the impression of an uncommonly kind person who is not above self-interest but loves books, her grandmother, her husband and her dog.
lead_paragraph: The best advertisement for Ann Patchett’s new collection of nonfiction is anything else Ms. Patchett has written. Her novels (“Bel Canto” remains the most exquisite), memoir about a friend (“Truth & Beauty”) and assorted speeches and essays all share unusual frankness and drawing power. Ms. Patchett’s style is not overly confessional, but it is beguiling in ways that make her sound like someone you’d want to know. Her new book, “This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage,” reinforces the impression of an uncommonly kind person who is not above self-interest but loves books, her grandmother, the toughest nun who taught her in grade school, her husband and her darling dog.

headline: Enough Anxiety to Fill Two Books
abstract: Scott Stossel and his sister, Sage, each have written a book that reveals how anxiety disorders have gripped their family.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are countless American families braving the usual anxieties of the holiday season: frantic shopping, exasperating travel and tedious relatives.

headline: Monaco Triumphs at Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
abstract: The premier event at the Fall North American Championships last month in Phoenix was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco.
lead_paragraph: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, the premier event at the Fall North American Championships last month in Phoenix, was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco: Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. They finished just over two boards ahead of Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala from Italy, Krzysztof Buras and Grzegorz Narkiewicz from Poland, and Aleksander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov from Russia. Third were Martin Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Zia Mahmood of New York City; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.; and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.

headline: Passengers on Bus Near Tel Aviv Flee Just Before a Bomb Explodes
abstract: Alert passengers and a bus driver are credited with saving the lives of those aboard the bus.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A bomb exploded on a bus in Bat Yam near Tel Aviv on Sunday minutes after the passengers were asked to get off, preventing casualties. The police said that initial evidence pointed to an attempted terrorist attack, presumably by Palestinian militants, the first of this kind in just over a year.

headline: Don't Get in Bed With Assad
abstract: Anti-terror cooperation with the Syrian regime would be immoral and misguided.
lead_paragraph: Beirut — One might think that America’s policy toward Syria couldn’t get any worse, but the rise of extremists there is generating dangerous thinking in Western capitals. High-level advisers and former officials have recently started to talk about Bashar al-Assad as a lesser evil than whatever comes next; some even see him as a potential partner in fighting jihadi terrorists.

headline: The Weight of the Past
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Careers and Professions', 'Football', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Who is able to confidently say they have already lived the best year of their life?
lead_paragraph: This column is about Edward Snowden. And the National Football League. And, I suspect, most of the rest of us.

headline: Japan’s ‘Proactive Pacifism’
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has approved a plan to strengthen the nation’s military.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has approved a plan to strengthen the nation’s military.

headline: Nets, Built to Win Now, May Need to Cut Losses
abstract: General Manager Billy King’s master plan for winning an N.B.A. championship appears to have fractured like the fifth metatarsal in Brook Lopez’s right foot.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It may be futile when one is chased by a shark in deep water to question the decision to have gone swimming in the first place. But regret is a common human experience, and so it is fair to wonder if Billy King is feeling any as his master plan for winning an N.B.A. championship appears to have fractured like the fifth metatarsal in Brook Lopez’s right foot.

headline: Obama Says ‘Further Action’ Possible in South Sudan
abstract: President Obama sent a letter Sunday to top congressional leaders in which he said he might take “further action to support the security of U.S. citizens, personnel, and property, including our embassy, in South Sudan.”
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — After an attack on three United States aircraft attempting to evacuate American citizens from South Sudan, President Obama sent a letter Sunday to top congressional leaders in which he said he might take “further action” to support United States citizens and interests in the contested region.

headline: Believe You Me
abstract: In which we give credit to Michael Blake and Andrea Carla Michaels for a smooth Monday solving experience.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There is nothing better for my solving ego than a Monday Andrea Carla Michaels puzzle, and it’s not just because it’s Monday. It’s because she, along with her collaborator, Michael Blake, fills her puzzles with wonderful things that they and Will Shortz clue in such a way that my pencil never stops moving until the entire grid is filled. And when it’s done, I might not remember filling in all of the entries because it was just that smooth, but I know that I’ve had a good time. You really can’t ask for more than that on a Monday.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 23
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Monday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 23
abstract: In a holiday-shortened week, the Commerce Department will release data on personal income and spending in November, and durable goods figures for November will be reported.
lead_paragraph: INCOME AND SPENDING On Monday, the Commerce Department will announce the data on personal income and spending in November. Economists on Wall Street are looking for an increase of 0.5 percent for both figures, according to Bloomberg, but a stronger reading would allay fears of weak overall economic growth in the fourth quarter of 2013. Growth is expected to slow substantially from the robust 4.1 percent annual pace recorded in the third quarter, but recent data has been a bit more positive so experts will be watching to see if that continued in November with personal income and spending.

headline: Our Teaching Methods, and Theirs
abstract: Readers reply to editorials in the “Numbers Crunch” series, about school systems here and abroad and about gifted students.

headline: Cincinnati Streetcar Plan Pits Desire for Growth Against Fiscal Restraint
abstract: After much contentious debate, construction on a 3.6 mile streetcar line in Cincinnati is moving ahead, with financial support from a foundation.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — It has been a long time since a streetcar was just a streetcar here.
