abstract: This short film celebrates the life and work of Ireland’s most famous contemporary poet, Seamus Heaney.

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Syrian Violence, Even Amid Preparations for Peace Talks
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: At least 25 people were killed in Aleppo, antigovernment activists reported, while a suicide car bombing killed at least 10 people in the central province of Homs.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 25 people were killed in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo on Sunday, antigovernment activists reported, in the eighth straight day of intense government bombardment of rebel-held areas there, while a suicide car bombing that the state news media blamed on insurgents killed at least 10 people in the central province of Homs.

headline: Focus on Ocean’s Health as Dolphin Deaths Soar
abstract: The resurgence of a marine mammal virus on the Eastern Seaboard and “unusual mortality events” in the Gulf region have puzzled scientists.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Like a macabre marine mystery, the carcasses — many badly deteriorated and tossing about in the surf — first turned up along the coast of New Jersey in June. Soon, droves of them washed up in Virginia, the Carolinas, Georgia and most recently Florida, their winter home.

headline: Living Wage Ruling Gives Queens Casino Workers a Fighting Chance
abstract: In October, 1,375 employees at the Resorts World Casino had their paychecks doubled after a ruling ordered the casino management to pay them a living wage.
lead_paragraph: For the fast-food workers who demonstrated across the country this month, it is only a dream. For many economists and policy makers, it is the subject of intense debate. But there is nothing hypothetical about the living wage for Sandra Charles, a security officer and single mother. For her, it is real, tangible and gloriously life-changing.

headline: Super Bowl Concerts Will Spill Well Past the Meadowlands
abstract: Corporate-sponsored concerts around the big game include the Foo Fighters and the Roots, courtesy of Bud Light; Red Hot Chili Peppers, presented by CBS Radio; and John Legend and Band of Horses, put on by Citibank.
lead_paragraph: BY the time Bruno Mars sings his first note at the Super Bowl XLVIII halftime show on Feb. 2, a musical lollapalooza will already have made its way through New York and New Jersey, fueled by corporate sponsorship and the growing affinity between pop music and sports.

headline: Parting Ways, for Now, to Help His Son
abstract: An out-of-work taxi driver is living apart from his son while he finds them both a safer home.
lead_paragraph: Abdoulaye Fall knows about sacrifice. He made his biggest one more than two decades ago, enduring a lengthy separation from his three young children as a consequence.

headline: The Affluenza Society
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: Four roadside deaths, but little outrage, in the North Texas suburbs.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — THE case of Ethan Couch — the drunk 16-year-old who mowed down four bystanders in a Fort Worth suburb with his “super duty” F-350 pickup truck, but got off with 10 years’ probation after his defense team’s psychologist blamed “affluenza,” or a state of immense, amoral privilege, for the crime — has become something of a national outrage.

headline: At a Vestige of El Barrio’s Past, Hope Is Still for Sale
abstract: Jorge Vargas sells religious objects and incense at a botanica in gentrifying East Harlem to those seeking prosperity and spiritual cleansing.
lead_paragraph: A thin veil of cigar smoke swirled around Jorge Vargas, who was perched on a stool surrounded by thousands of saints, candles, beads, ointments, herbs and incense. Classic Cuban songs played on the radio, their rhythms — like the religious objects in his East Harlem botanica — conjuring visions of Africa. Though no customers had come by, he remained upbeat.

headline: Bumpy Start for Teacher Evaluation Program in New York Schools
abstract: Principals and teachers expressed frustrations with the new system, which some say creates more work and tests and has a temperamental computer program.
lead_paragraph: Over the 24 years Lily Din Woo has been the principal of Public School 130 in Lower Manhattan, her typical day changed very little: sick or misbehaving students, budgets, curriculum woes and meetings with parents, many of whom do not speak English.

headline: Bits and Barbarism
abstract: From real gold to virtual gold, we’re digging our way back to the 17th century.
lead_paragraph: This is a tale of three money pits. It’s also a tale of monetary regress — of the strange determination of many people to turn the clock back on centuries of progress.

headline: Strong Profit Margin at Paramount Pictures Underlines a Hollywood Shift
abstract: Brad Grey of Paramount Pictures has chosen to produce fewer films, giving up revenue, but increasing profitability as the industry moves into survival mode.
lead_paragraph: The weather wobbled between snow and rain, with ankle-deep slush in gridlocked streets. But Brad Grey, the chief executive of Paramount Pictures, refused to fret about whether the mess would keep the Manhattan elite away from a gala premiere of Martin Scorsese’s “The Wolf of Wall Street” last Tuesday.

headline: In Tech Buying, U.S. Still Stuck in Last Century
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Despite the furor over the rollout of HealthCare.gov, there is little evidence that the Obama administration is moving quickly to change how the government hires and manages private technology companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four years after President Obama vowed to “dramatically reform the way we do business on contracts,” the spectacular failure of the HealthCare.gov website has renewed calls for changes in how the government hires and manages private technology companies.

headline: Seeing a Need for Oversight of New York’s Lordly Towers
abstract: The rise of skyscrapers that dwarf their neighbors, sometimes elegantly but too often not, has prompted an argument: Should New York City put more limits on its skyline?
lead_paragraph: They’re arriving along 57th Street like a clutch of preening runway models, super-tall and skinny, the expensive playthings of Russian oligarchs and Chinese tycoons. A coupling of technology and wealth has bred this new, local hothouse species: leggy, cloud-piercing, sliver-thin residential towers.

headline: Putting Injuries Behind Him, Jermain Taylor Fights On
abstract: The middleweight Jermain Taylor, 35, suffered two terrifying knockouts and a brain bleed but is determined to come back. “Man, what else am I supposed to do?”
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — It was about 4 p.m. at a cavernous Alamodome that, in only a few hours, would hold 11,000 screaming boxing fans. But at this moment, in the middle of a Saturday afternoon in December with the sun still shining and the television cameras turned off, Jermain Taylor entered the ring for a bout for the first time in 14 months. If the approximately 200 fans who had filtered into the arena by that point recognized Taylor from his past, they did not act like it.

headline: Amid Steady Deportation, Fear and Worry Multiply Among Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deportation']
abstract: Immigrant leaders see a broad community impact as deportations separate parents from children and undocumented immigrants from those here legally.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Karen Sandoval’s promising life in this city fell apart in one day last summer when she went to buy school supplies for her two daughters.

headline: Stewart and Unbeaten UConn Ace Another Test
abstract: Breanna Stewart’s 29 points and 10 rebounds paced top-ranked UConn over No. 24 California in the Maggie Dixon Classic at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut, the defending women’s national champion, began this season by obliterating a series of opponents it was expected to steamroll as part of a season-opening, 10-game winning streak. But the next two opponents were expected to provide significant tests.

headline: Americans Evacuated From South Sudan
abstract: Americans were flown out of a besieged United Nations compound, a day after a first attempt was fired upon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American citizens were evacuated from a contested area of South Sudan on Sunday after a local rebel commander provided assurances that there would be no interference, Western officials said.

headline: Leave These Southwest Ruins Alone
abstract: Tourists with GPS are endangering fragile Anasazi sites.
lead_paragraph: WATERTOWN, Mass. — IT has been called the best preserved ruin in the Southwest. Built in the 13th century by Ancestral Puebloans, its 20-odd rooms splendidly fill an oval sandstone alcove in an obscure canyon on the Navajo reservation in Arizona. When I visited the place in 2009, official permit in hand, I was content to admire the ruin through binoculars from the opposite rim and from the creek bed at its base, for the Navajo Nation forbids all access to the site. When I wrote about it, I described its location no more precisely than I have here.

headline: A Small Step Toward More Mercy
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama’s sentence commutations are welcome, but they are too few.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s decision on Thursday to commute the outrageously long drug sentences of eight men and women showed a measure of compassion and common sense. But it also served to highlight the injustice being done to thousands of prisoners under federal sentencing laws.

headline: Dark Days in Egypt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The country’s military dictators seem unwilling to stop their crackdown until all the opposition is silenced.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Egypt’s military dictators stormed the offices of a prominent human rights organization and charged Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president, with participating in a fantastical terrorist plot. The news from Egypt has become so unrelentingly bad that it is difficult to see how this nation can recover from a self-inflicted spiral of repression, violence and paranoia.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 22, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Congress’s Temerity on Gun Safety
abstract: The failure to pass meaningful gun safety laws is part of the tragedy of the Newtown school massacre.
lead_paragraph: Despite lawmakers’ copious sympathy for the 26 victims of the Newtown, Conn., school massacre, all members of Congress were able to manage in the way of gun safety as they left town was renewal of the ban on the manufacture of plastic firearms. This is a type of arcane weapon that figured not at all in the Sandy Hook Elementary School rampage in 2012, nor in the mass shootings featuring adapted weapons of war that have occurred on average every two weeks somewhere in America.

headline: Lawrence O. Kitchen, Steady Hand for Lockheed, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Kitchen rose through the ranks of the aerospace company during a 30-year career and led the company through rocky tussles with governments during the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence O. Kitchen, a former Marine who never finished college but successfully led the Lockheed Corporation, the aerospace company, through turbulent times, died on Dec. 15 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 90.

headline: At Temple, Spirit of Amateurism Is Abandoned by a River
abstract: Unlike football and basketball, sports that do not generate revenue and which often embody the spirit of amateurism in college sports are being cut.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever taken a train out of Philadelphia, you may have seen Boathouse Row, a strip of 15 Victorian boathouses on the banks of the Schuylkill that look made of gingerbread. Those buildings and that river have been the center of rowing in the United States for generations.

headline: Investment Strategy Rises From Obscurity
abstract: Since the financial crisis, the popularity of a securities structure, the master limited partnership, has soared, and it is outperforming the broader stock market.
lead_paragraph: When the billionaire Carl C. Icahn took control of CVR Energy last year, critics thought the dog had finally caught the car.

headline: After a Battle of Blunders, the Giants Get It Right When It Counts
abstract: Both teams struggled with errors and wasted opportunities throughout the game, but a gutsy fourth-down play in overtime set up the winning field goal.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was an act of faith, notable in a season of wavering trust, that Giants quarterback Eli Manning lobbied Coach Tom Coughlin to go for a first down during overtime Sunday.

headline: Insights Into Democracy, Refined in a Russian Prison
abstract: After his surprise release, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, once the richest of Russia’s oligarchs, challenged his fellow citizens to “take responsibility for their own fate.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “I tried to look at my situation pragmatically,” Mikhail Khodorkovsky said quietly, trying to explain how he kept himself going for 10 years in prison and labor camps. “I said, O.K., so they got me; O.K., so the situation is bad. But it has certain possibilities.”

headline: When ‘60 Minutes’ Checks Its Journalistic Skepticism at the Door
abstract: Viewers expect and deserve the show to bring its A game when it takes on a huge issue like the N.S.A., to serve as a stand-in for the American people and ask the uncomfortable questions.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a study commissioned by the president concluded that the National Security Agency had reached too far into the private lives of Americans. The study, which came after a series of journalistic revelations exposing the agency’s surveillance practices, recommended numerous reforms that would curb the N.S.A.’s prerogatives. President Obama said he was “open to many” of the suggestions.

headline: Partying Until Drunk and Disorderly in Britain
abstract: British officials are considering solutions as large numbers of British youths go out on the weekends to get thoroughly, blindingly and often violently drunk.
lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, England — It was just after 4 a.m., the last clubs were closing and the police had three young men pinned against a brick wall and a fourth on the ground. The young men, gloriously incoherent, some of them bleeding, could barely stand, let alone answer the questions from the officers, who were responding to a fight. As the scene in downtown Northampton unfolded, another drunken young man slugged a passer-by, then fled.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Endangered Species
abstract: Houston vs. San Antonio on Christmas Day features two teams built around traditional centers, albeit ones separated in age by nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Q. and A. With Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky
abstract: A group of Russian-speaking journalists on Sunday interviewed Mr. Khodorkovsky, newly freed after a decade of being a political prisoner.
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from an interview of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky by an invited group of Russian-speaking journalists in Berlin on Sunday, as translated by The New York Times:

headline: A Snowier Silicon Valley in BlackBerry’s Backyard
abstract: The Waterloo area in Ontario remains a magnet for the high-tech industry, despite the misfortunes of its best-known success story.
lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Ontario — BlackBerry is down, but its hometown is far from out.

headline: Inequality for Dummies
abstract: Here is a citizen’s guide to the great debate.
lead_paragraph: Inequality is in. The president, you have probably heard, has declared income inequality to be “the defining challenge of our time.” (Except he didn’t quite, but we’ll get to that.) Politicians, pundits and activists on the left have seized on the president’s words, along with the rising fortunes of progressive idols Elizabeth Warren and Bill de Blasio, to refute the apostles of austerity (mostly Republicans these days) and lay down early populist markers for the 2016 elections. Liberals of a more centrist bent — notably the former Clintonites at the Third Way think tank — have refused to join the chorus and been lashed by fellow Democrats for their blasphemy. Senator Warren has suggested that liberals who disagree with her are in the pocket of Wall Street. Third Way executives took to the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal to accuse the populists of indulging a “ ‘we can have it all’ fantasy.”

headline: Plan for Tribune Spinoff Raises Concerns for Future of Newspaper Operations
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'News and News Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The new company being created to publish The Chicago Tribune and other papers will have to pay rent and a dividend to its former parent.
lead_paragraph: A plan by the Tribune Company to separate eight newspapers, including The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, from its more profitable digital and television businesses could threaten their survival, staff members, industry analysts and a congressman said last week.

lead_paragraph: For advocates of the Affordable Care Act, a central reform to help small businesses buy health insurance was the creation of state-run exchanges. It could then offer its employees a choice from among several policies, even from different carriers — a benefit few companies now use. It could enroll in those plans online, and if the business were small enough, it could get temporary tax credits to offset the cost.

headline: The Bitcoin Mines of Iceland
abstract: On the flat lava plain of Reykjanesbaer, Iceland, near the Arctic Circle, you can find the Bitcoin mines. | The Federal Reserve moved to curb a maneuver that banks can exploit to make themselves look stronger. | A deal by Carl C. Icahn illustrates the growth of an obscure but increasingly popular securities structure. | The Fed has allowed JPMorgan into a variety of markets for basic goods.
lead_paragraph: INTO THE BITCOIN MINES  |  On the flat lava plain of Reykjanesbaer, Iceland, near the Arctic Circle, you can find the Bitcoin mines, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. There, more than 100 whirring silver computers, each in a locked cabinet and each cooled by blasts of Arctic air, are the laborers of the virtual mines where Bitcoins are unearthed. The custom-built machines, running an open-source Bitcoin program, perform complex algorithms 24 hours a day, seeking to win a block of 25 new Bitcoins from the virtual currency’s decentralized network.

On Friday night, NBC presented “It’s A Wonderful Life,” the Jimmy Stewart-Donna Reed classic, and drew 5.37 million viewers, according to Nielsen figures, while Fox attracted 2.64 million viewers with “Happiness Is a Warm Blanket, Charlie Brown,” the most recent (2011) Peanuts Christmas special.

headline: The Preacher and the President
abstract: Samuel B. McPheeters was an apolitical pastor in a political war, and he paid the price for it.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War caused numerous churches and denominational bodies to deliberate over secular matters and oftentimes to pass political resolutions. Indeed, many patriotic church members entirely disapproved of pastors who failed to give outspoken support to the federal cause, because they considered the Civil War to be a providential means for refining and preserving the sacred Union. The story of one Presbyterian minister who resisted that pressure to bring politics into pulpit, Samuel B. McPheeters, illustrates the perils of public neutrality and reveals how the war complicated church-state relations.

The past year has been a bright one for the mouthy comedian, actress and singer, 58, who landed a recurring role as an art teacher on ABC Family’s “Switched at Birth.” “Sandyland” already enjoyed a successful run this month at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, where the local critic wrote, “Few performers are as vulnerable,” as Bernhard, “nor as indomitably strong.” Bernhard chatted to T about what audiences can expect from the show and what her ambitions are for 2014.

lead_paragraph: I ALWAYS laugh when people ask me if I still enjoy traveling, especially for business. The answer is simple: Of course I do. As a woman of 88 years young, that’s right, young, I still enjoy seeing the world, meeting interesting people, and I don’t even mind trying to negotiate the airport lines. I think it is all very exciting. Travel helps keep me young, so I am going to keep doing it as long as I can. One of the things that I do know is when you get as many rings on your tree as I now have, it is important to look forward to something every hour of every day.

headline: So Long, It’s Been Good to Know You
abstract: In my last column, I find myself making a point about the kind of point I’m not making, doing what I do just after having announced that I will no longer be doing it.
lead_paragraph: In 1995 I got a call out of the blue from an editor at this newspaper who invited me to write an op-ed. “About what? I asked. “Anything you like,” she replied. That was obviously an offer I couldn’t refuse, so I set about writing, schooled by my wife, who had been a book reviewer for The Raleigh News and Observer. She taught me to forgo the academic habit of withholding the goods until the end and explained how in this genre the main point should be announced immediately because readers might not wait around while I indulged myself in the pleasures of building a pretty argument. (This is a lesson I have hewed to only intermittently.) The result was a piece titled “How the Right Hijacked the Magic Words.” The editors liked it, readers seemed interested, and I was hooked.

An archetypal daydreamer introduced to the public by James Thurber as a henpecked suburban husband and later impersonated on screen by Danny Kaye as a misunderstood, starry-eyed sweetheart with a lovely singing voice, Walter has evolved into a modern office drone with an unusually active fantasy life. He is also, in some respects, the opposite of just about every other comic hero in American movies today, including many played by Mr. Stiller. And “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,” directed by Mr. Stiller (who takes the title role), has a dreamy, melancholy tone quite different from what you might expect to find in a big-budget holiday comedy.

headline: An Old Flame Shows Up, but Who Invited the Witch and Monsters?

lead_paragraph: Between the prospect of Hollywood’s sexing up a legendary Japanese story with rampaging C.G.I. monsters and the eager reports of a protracted production, there has been ample opportunity to hobble “47 Ronin” long before its warriors finally emerge in theaters. But say what you will about this fantasy adventure, set in “a land shrouded in mystery” (per the opening voice-over), it’s still a studio movie adaptation of a story that ends — centuries-old spoiler! — with mass ritual suicide. Credit due for that bit of faithfulness, I suppose — and Merry Christmas, by the way.

Then as now, the movie is likely to be the subject of intense scholarly debate: Does it offer a sustained and compelling diagnosis of the terminal pathology that afflicts us, or is it an especially florid symptom of the disease?

headline: It’s the Most Unknowable Time of the Year
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Families and Family Life', 'New Year', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Editorials']
abstract: For a Jewish kid, in Leningrad and then Queens, disguises were mystifying. They still are.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my first childhood memories: New Year’s Eve, Leningrad, 1976. The doorbell rings, my mother opens it, and a bear walks in on his hind legs. Four-year-old me starts trembling. Bear! Bear! Soon I will be eaten. No, my mother tells me: “It’s Grandfather Frost,” the secular, socialist-friendly Russian equivalent of Santa Claus, with New Year’s standing in for Christmas. And it’s true. On top of his shabby gray-white fur that makes him so uniquely ursine, the bear sports a red hat and a flowing white beard made of cotton balls.

headline: Postal Service Raises Price Again but Says It’s Not Forever
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Stamps (Postal)']

headline: Brazil: Floods and Landslides Kill 30
abstract: Heavy rains in Espírito Santo and Minas Gerais, two states in southeastern Brazil, have left at least 30 people dead and forced about 50,000 people from their homes.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains in Espírito Santo and Minas Gerais, two states in southeastern Brazil, have left at least 30 people dead and forced about 50,000 people from their homes, civil defense authorities said Tuesday. Dozens of cities in both states declared states of emergency after some victims died in landslides and flash floods. President Dilma Rousseff flew to Vitória, the capital of Espírito Santo, where she announced that more than $260 million in public funds would be channeled to disaster relief efforts. Brazil’s army was also being mobilized to repair bridges in affected areas, officials said. Meteorologists in Espírito Santo said that parts of the state were struggling with the heaviest rains in 90 years.

headline: This Day of Good Cheer
abstract: On Christmas, an archaic phrase comes to life.

Death tolls globally far exceed those from such devastating infectious diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. According to recent reports from international health agencies, global mortality from those three diseases has, in fact, been cut substantially — by nearly half in the case of malaria — over the past decade.

I was warmed, then moved, by this recent history of indies, spartanly staged in low light, each a gem of shining creativity.

headline: The Rat Takes the Cheese
abstract: Two new books featuring mice and rats shouldn’t be missed, even if you have to perch on a chair to read them.
lead_paragraph: Eek! Mice and rats are constantly scampering around children’s literature (Aesop’s fables; E.T.A. Hoffmann’s “Nutcracker and Mouse-King”; Beatrix Potter’s “The Tale of Two Bad Mice”), but there’s usually a difference between the two. Though mice are often portrayed as naughty, they are rarely as utterly repellent as rats. The sweet “Mouse House Tales,” by Susan Pearson with illustrations by Amanda Shepherd, and the hilarious and down-and-dirty “Cheese Belongs to You!,” by Alexis Deacon with illustrations by Viviane Schwarz, perpetuate this traditional polarity. But whatever your feelings about rodents, these two books shouldn’t be missed, even if you have to perch on a chair to read them.

headline: Classical Playlist: Thomas Adès, Benjamin Hochman, Angela Hewitt and More

Mr. Adès, a formidable pianist, plays the pieces with Mr. Isserlis on an exciting recording along with works by Liszt, Janacek, Fauré and Gyorgy Kurtag — an inspired grouping of diverse composers that highlights surprising musical connections between their styles. lead_paragraph: A weekend in South Beach ought not to begin with “What to pack?” but rather, “What to pursue?” Do you long for the South Beach of painted-on dresses, frozen margaritas and electric neon? The South Beach of stylish new (or renovated) hotels (Gale, Lord Balfour, SLS South Beach) and restaurants (Yardbird Southern Table & Bar, Khong River House, Tongue & Cheek)? Or the South Beach of yesteryear, of pastel Art Deco buildings, museums and monuments? Perhaps you simply crave ...the beach. Miami can be whatever you want it to be — laid back, decked out, gay, straight, a family recess, a single’s playground — which is precisely what makes it such an effortless getaway. In this dreamland at the southern tip of Miami Beach, you can choose your own adventure.

headline: Pope, Off Script, Nods to Atheists in Holiday Call for World Peace
abstract: Pope Francis, celebrating his first Christmas as the Roman Catholic leader, called on atheists to unite with believers of all religions and work for a peace that can spread across the world.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis used the first Christmas address of his papacy on Wednesday to make a broad call for global peace and an end to violence in Syria and parts of Africa, urging atheists and followers of other religions to join together in this common cause.

headline: A Savvy Investor’s Spiritual Exploration
abstract: A documentary on Bloomberg TV focuses on the life of John M. Templeton and his founding of the Templeton Prize.
lead_paragraph: A biographical film about a brand-name investor might not seem like holiday fare, but in two respects “Contrarian,” a documentary about John M. Templeton, seems just right for the day after Christmas.

headline: Christmas Around the World
abstract: From a NATO camp in Afghanistan to a picturesque beach in Australia, here’s a look at how people across the globe celebrated the holiday.
lead_paragraph: From a NATO camp in Afghanistan to a picturesque beach in Australia, here’s a look at how people across the globe celebrated the holiday.

headline: A Teasing Online Return for ‘Sherlock’
abstract: Audiences got an early taste of a resurrected Holmes in a seven-minute episode that made its debut this week.
lead_paragraph: There was never a doubt that Benedict Cumberbatch would return to the role of Sherlock Holmes, the modernized incarnation of Arthur Conan Doyle’s consulting detective he plays on the hit BBC series “Sherlock.” Despite a second-season finale in 2012 that seemed to show Holmes falling to his death, Mr. Cumberbatch’s star has risen considerably since then (in films like “Star Trek Into Darkness” and “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug”), and besides, the BBC had already committed to a third season of “Sherlock.” (The series is shown in the United States on PBS’s “Masterpiece.”)

headline: Bypassing Fear and Embracing Networking
abstract: Cut off from the world for much of her life, Hanny Lerner built her business in part by learning how to ask for help.
lead_paragraph: We just published a conversation with Hanny Lerner, the founder and president of MOD Restoration, a furniture reupholstering company in Brooklyn. In the interview, Ms. Lerner, 29, who grew up in a Hasidic community with limited information about the outside world, discussed how she managed to get up to speed and grow her business, which had 2013 sales of just under $2 million and employs about 10.

headline: Mapping a Darker Side of New York
abstract: Terence Winter, creator of “Boardwalk Empire,” talks about crime and locations in the city.
lead_paragraph: New York City has long been associated with crime, in drama and in reality. From early bootlegging and street hustles to stock market frauds that have caused the global financial market to shudder, it’s fair to say that the city has had its share of bad actors.

headline: A Brooklyn Church Uncovers a Long-Hidden Celestial Scene
abstract: At Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights, undergoing a $5 million renovation, a professional cleaning with sponges, rags, water and a gentle detergent brought thousands of stars back to light.
lead_paragraph: At Christmas, thoughts at many churches turn to a certain star.

headline: Egypt, Dealing a Blow to the Muslim Brotherhood, Deems It a Terrorist Group
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The action signals the government’s determination to cut off any air to the more than 80-year-old Islamist organization.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-backed leaders on Wednesday designated the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist organization, outlawing the country’s most successful political movement and vowing to treat anyone who belongs to it, or even takes part in its activities, as a terrorist.

headline: Nets’ Effort Questioned, by Fans and by Coach
abstract: The Nets delivered yet another halfhearted performance in a loss to the Chicago Bulls, and the fans at Barclays Center let them know about it.
lead_paragraph: The chorus of boos and jeers started with about half a minute left in the game, when Tornike Shengelia tried to dribble the ball behind his back but instead felt it stripped away. Shengelia, an infrequently used reserve, was far from the object of the fans’ ire, but he was the Nets player unfortunate enough to be standing there when it all finally boiled over.

headline: Handel Well Populated, Onstage and Off
abstract: Kent Tritle led the Oratorio Society in Handel’s “Messiah” for a capacity crowd at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Oratorio Society, under the direction of Kent Tritle, performed Handel’s “Messiah” in front of a capacity crowd on Monday at Carnegie Hall. The stage was also filled to capacity. The society’s choir has close to 200 singers. The alto section alone, with 59 members, is more than twice as big as, say, the entire Choir of Trinity Wall Street, whose “Messiah” I also reviewed this month.

headline: Feeling For | Ugo Rondinone’s Miniature, Wearable Art
abstract: The artist created a limited edition of seven tiny gold masks, one to represent each day of the week. Today’s is a silly cure for a case of the Mondays.
lead_paragraph: Art is my job and my passion. I look at it, think about it, talk about it and write about it. Now, thanks to the artist Ugo Rondinone, I dream of wearing it. Rondinone made a splash earlier this year when an installation of his nine colossal stone sculptures, often likened to Stonehenge, inhabited Rockefeller Center. A few months later, in collaboration with the creative couple Sebastien and Stephanie Jannssen, Rondinone created mythical little masks that fit into the palm of your hand. The seven 23-karat-gold sculptures, created in a limited edition of six (plus three artist’s proofs), represent each day of the week and can be worn as a pendant. This enigmatic piece is sure to cure any case of the Mondays by making even the most cynical among us smile. Like most great works, it’s an investment piece. But as any art lover will tell you, it’s impossible to own all the art you want. That’s what dreams are for. Price upon request; sorrywereclosed.com.

headline: Dempsey to Help Fulham, and Himself
abstract: Clint Dempsey is ready to return to Craven Cottage and England’s Premier League on a short-term loan.
lead_paragraph: Clint Dempsey has heeded the call of Jurgen Klinsmann, coach of the United States national team, to get some playing time in Europe during Major League Soccer’s off-season and has heeded the desperate call of Fulham, one of his former teams, to help rescue the London club from relegation.

headline: How a Bridge Deal Can Resemble a Boxing Match
abstract: Bridge deals, though, can resemble a boxing match. One side tries to deliver the telling blow, when the other sidesteps and lands the lethal counterpunch.
lead_paragraph: In Britain and other countries in the Commonwealth, Dec. 26 is known as Boxing Day. It has nothing to do with pugilism. Instead, in the Middle Ages, the landed gentry would deliver gifts in boxes to their serfs on this day.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: New books by Sam Thompson, Anne Michaels, Bernice Eisenstein, Darwyn Cooke, Caitlin R. Kiernan, Susie Moloney, Andy Diggle and Jock.
lead_paragraph: This month, a novel that conjures an imaginary city, an elegant book of poems complemented by haunting paintings, two dark collections of short stories where nothing is as it seems, and two rugged graphic novels with enjoyably ragged edges.

headline: Liu Ping’s Christmas in Jail
abstract: For Liu Ping, a Christian, and one of three campaigners for democracy and public disclosure of leaders’ assets detained and tried on charges their supporters say are false, this Christmas is very different.
lead_paragraph: Liu Ping, a democracy advocate, doesn’t talk much about her Christian faith, preferring to talk about politics. But Christmas means something to her.

headline: From One Garage in Queens, a World of Fakes
abstract: Court papers in one of more than a half dozen lawsuits filed against a defunct Manhattan gallery, Knoedler & Co., reveal just how far the fakes it sold had spread before the fraud was discovered.
lead_paragraph: Court papers in one of more than a half dozen lawsuits filed against a defunct Manhattan gallery, Knoedler & Co., reveal just how far the fakes it sold had spread before the fraud was discovered.

headline: A Honcho in Winter With More Tales to Tell
abstract: “The Fat Lady Sang” is a warts-and-all follow-up to Robert Evans’s earlier memoir, “The Kid Stays in the Picture.”
lead_paragraph: In 1998, Robert Evans, the least bashful producer in Hollywood, suffered three strokes in rapid succession. Their combined effects were so debilitating that it was not clear whether Mr. Evans would ever walk, talk or chase women again. But as his new memoir, “The Fat Lady Sang,” makes clear, at least Mr. Evans’s capacity for bragging and self-promotion remained mercifully unimpaired. He is still able to say “Wham, bam, there I am” in as many ways as this stubbornly upbeat book will allow.

headline: Apples for a Seasoned Acting Teacher
keywords: ['Theater', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The venerated acting teacher Wynn Handman, 91, is celebrated in a new book, “Wynn Place Show,” and by former students like Chris Cooper.
lead_paragraph: As other acting students watched in a darkened rehearsal studio, Alan Safier, a 64-year-old theater veteran, stepped toward a spotlight to begin a monologue from Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra.” His eyes wide, Mr. Safier delivered his first line in a low, awe-struck tone.

headline: The Confidence, and the Art, Looked Real
abstract: Though Jose Carlos Bergantiños Diaz was living life on a grand stage, prosecutors say that he led collectors to spend more than $80 million on phony masterworks.
lead_paragraph: To many people, the art dealer Jose Carlos Bergantiños Diaz seemed like an enviable man.

headline: Finding the Drama in the Boss and Dylan

lead_paragraph: Nobody knows better than the British chanteuse Barb Jungr that even the most seemingly banal pop song lyrics have hidden wellsprings of intense feeling. It is the performer’s job to dig into the ground and bring up a gusher.

headline: Trove of Information From the 1930s, Animated by the Internet
abstract: The University of Richmond’s Digital Scholarship Lab has added modern bells and whistles to the landmark Atlas of the Historical Geography of the United States, published in 1932.
lead_paragraph: In 1932, when Charles O. Paullin published his monumental Atlas of the Historical Geography of the United States, reviewers were overwhelmed by its nearly 700 maps covering seemingly every facet of the country’s social, economic and political life, including maps, then novel, showing county-by-county results for presidential elections going back to the beginning of the Republic.

abstract: Bo Burnham’s new comedy special, released online, is more theatrical and personal than his previous work.
lead_paragraph: If any comedian could have a midlife crisis at 23, it would be Bo Burnham.

abstract: The Samurai Startup Island, in a low-rent office district built on a landfill on Tokyo Bay, is at the vanguard of what many hope is a new generation of innovators.
lead_paragraph: The Samurai Startup Island, in a low-rent office district built on a landfill on Tokyo Bay, is at the vanguard of what many hope is a new generation of innovators.

headline: Start-Up Spirit Emerges in Japan
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: While prejudice against entrepreneurs lingers in Japan, the nation is increasingly trying to encourage business start-ups as a key to the future.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The 20-somethings in jeans sipping espresso and tapping on laptops at this Tokyo business incubator would look more at home in Silicon Valley than in Japan, where for years the surest signs of success were the gray suits of its corporate salarymen. But for those hoping the nation’s latest economic plan will drag Japan from its long malaise, the young men and women here at Samurai Startup Island represent a crucial component: a revival of entrepreneurship.

headline: Owner of Forgotten Clock Finds a Name (and Hands) to Put With the Face
abstract: Barry Lubetkin was researching Homer and Langley Collyer, brothers known in the 1930s and ’40s as the Hermits of Harlem, when he spotted a familiar artifact.

lead_paragraph: One afternoon this fall Tyler, the Creator, and his buddies Earl Sweatshirt and Jasper Dolphin, of the rap collective Odd Future, turned up on a street corner in downtown Los Angeles. Their agenda: to shoot a cameo for the music video “Happy,” by Pharrell Williams.

abstract: Long before oil was discovered in the North Sea, industrial pioneers figured out how to extract mineral oil from the coal and shale deposits near Grangemouth.

abstract: The Grangemouth refinery complex has roots to the 1920s glory days of British industry and is a linchpin to the nation’s economy.

headline: Scotland Fights to Keep Energy Lifeline
abstract: The petrochemical complex at Grangemouth has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.
lead_paragraph: GRANGEMOUTH, Scotland — The vast petrochemical complex at Grangemouth is a constellation of lights and glowing plumes of steam west of Edinburgh that has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.

headline: Snowden's Christmas Message
abstract: Edward J. Snowden delivered an alternative Christmas message on British television. The former American security contractor warned of the dangers posed by the loss of privacy.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden delivered an alternative Christmas message on British television. The former American security contractor warned of the dangers posed by the loss of privacy.

headline: Barbara Branden, Biographer of Ayn Rand, Dies at 84
abstract: Ms. Branden, once a member of Ms. Rand’s inner circle, wrote an unauthorized biography, “The Passion of Ayn Rand,” published in 1986, that angered some Rand followers.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Branden, who helped popularize Ayn Rand’s philosophy of self-interest in the 1960s but caused a schism among Ms. Rand’s followers with an unauthorized biography she wrote after the theorist’s death, died on Dec. 11 in West Hollywood, Calif. She was 84.

headline: A Work Still in Progress
abstract: A new exhibit at the National Archives, “Record of Rights,” makes clear that the Constitution is still a work in progress.
lead_paragraph: When the country observed the Constitution’s 200th anniversary back in 1987, two narratives vied for public acceptance. There was the triumphalist narrative celebrated in Philadelphia, where a quarter-million people took part in a 15-hour-long gala, lining the route for a parade with floats that included a 40-foot replica of a parchment scroll.

headline: An Ode to Spam
abstract: It’s so nice to open your email and find so many holiday messages full of good cheer, and, of course, the pleas from people you’ve never met in desperate need of a money transfer.
lead_paragraph: I would like to take time now to thank everyone who sent me holiday messages via the Internet: The wishes of good cheer, the reports of family achievements in the year past, and the multiple requests for my email or bank password.

headline: Common Knee Surgery Does Very Little for Some, Study Suggests
abstract: A new study suggests that thousands of people with a torn meniscus may be undergoing unnecessary arthroscopic surgery and that for many, options like physical therapy may be as good.
lead_paragraph: A popular surgical procedure worked no better than fake operations in helping people with one type of common knee problem, suggesting that thousands of people may be undergoing unnecessary surgery, a new study in The New England Journal of Medicine reports.

lead_paragraph: The largest crocodile in South America is on the verge of extinction, and government and private efforts to rescue the species are having limited success.

headline: Venezuela’s Fitful Effort to Save a Scaly Predator

lead_paragraph: MANTECAL, Venezuela — Stealing the eggs from an enraged, 10-foot crocodile is a delicate operation.

headline: Highlights from Pope's Christmas Message
abstract: Pope Francis delivered his first Christmas message from the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis delivered his first Christmas message from the Vatican.

headline: Week 17 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Romo’s Bad Rap
abstract: Tony Romo ranks among the top quarterbacks in the league in what ultimately matters: helping his team win games. But statistics also show that he’s a boom-and-bust performer.
lead_paragraph: The final game of the regular season will decide the winner of the N.F.C. East. The Eagles visit a wounded Cowboys team that will very likely be without its starting quarterback, Tony Romo. The conventional wisdom about Romo is that he’s a very skilled quarterback who can put up solid numbers each year, but that he somehow lacks the nerves to succeed in the clutch.

headline: An Entrepreneur Who Wouldn’t Be Stopped by Anything
abstract: Hanny Lerner grew up in what she calls an “ultra-Hasidic” home, where information about the outside world was limited. Today she is an online merchant with sales just under $2 million.
lead_paragraph: Hanny Lerner estimates that 80 percent of her customers find her company, MOD Restoration, at the website she designed. Ms. Lerner, 29, does not code, but she has experience in user-interface design and created the screen blueprints for her site.

keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: To claim a valuable tax credit for the first 10 years of power production, those in the industry must meet certain project guidelines by year-end.
lead_paragraph: As the rest of the world prepares to toast the new year, the wind industry is hard at work on its own year-end tradition, rushing to make sure projects qualify for an important subsidy before it is set to vanish at the stroke of midnight on Tuesday.

headline: The Night Pittsburgh Became a Baseball Town Once Again
abstract: Pirates fans had endured 2o losing seasons, but they were ready to unleash their passion again when the team took on the Cincinnati Reds in the National League playoffs.
lead_paragraph: For many years, the Pittsburgh Pirates played their home games at Three Rivers Stadium, a home they shared with the Steelers at the confluence of the Allegheny, Ohio and Monongahela Rivers. It was a picturesque setting, except that the upper bowl encircled the ballpark and blotted out any sense of place.

headline: Pettersen Stars in a Supporting Role
abstract: Suzann Pettersen of Norway did not reach No. 1 even as she won four tournaments, a testament to how competitive the L.P.G.A. has become.
lead_paragraph: Suzann Pettersen of Norway won four tournaments, including her second major at the Evian Championship. She recorded two third-place finishes and a tie for fourth in three of the year’s other majors, faltering only at the United States Women’s Open, where she missed the cut. She had 10 top-three finishes on the L.P.G.A. Tour and was on the victorious Solheim Cup team, which in any other year would have won her mountains of attention and possibly the Player of the Year award.

headline: In California, a Mayor’s Rise Is a Sign of the Times
abstract: Robert Jacob, the mayor of Sebastopol, Calif., is the first person from the marijuana industry to lead an American city, cannabis advocates say.
lead_paragraph: SEBASTOPOL, Calif. — When Robert Jacob ran for the City Council here last year, he had already made the list of “Forty Under 40 of 2012” in a local business magazine. So it was to be expected that his business gave him face recognition among voters on the campaign trail, many of whom greeted him by exclaiming, “You’re the pot guy!”

headline: Gifts Sent by U.P.S. Miss a Big Deadline
abstract: Some customers were left without Christmas gifts as the United Parcel Service failed to meet delivery deadlines in the face of bad weather and an unexpectedly large surge in demand.
lead_paragraph: Santa delivered sacks stuffed with i.o.u.’s this Christmas.

headline: In a Car-Culture Clash, It’s the Los Angeles Police vs. Pedestrians
abstract: A crackdown on jaywalkers has raised questions about whether the police are siding with the automobile at a time when the city’s pedestrian culture is taking off.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a city of seemingly endless highways — with its daily parade of car accidents, frustrating traffic jams and aggressive drivers — the Los Angeles Police Department these days is training its sights on a different road menace: jaywalkers.

headline: In Final Weeks, a Push to Put Bloomberg’s Stamp on Major Legal Cases

abstract: New York City’s Law Department has been trying to settle or define its position on some of its longest-running court battles, with the corporation counsel, Michael A. Cardozo, fighting on behalf of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: In the Bloomberg administration’s final weeks, New York City’s Law Department has been actively trying to settle some of its longest-running court battles and, where that has failed, to at least put its stamp on significant legal cases before Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio takes office.

headline: Small Theaters in Adirondacks Face Choice in Switch to Digital: Pay or Perish
abstract: As many independently owned theaters struggle to comply with an industry-imposed transition, a nonprofit has spearheaded a “Go Digital or Go Dark” fund-raising campaign.
lead_paragraph: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — Some nights, it is so cold that not even those who live here venture outside, so the Palace Theater closes early rather than show movies to an empty house.

headline: Despite New Evidence, Review of Conviction in 1989 Brooklyn Killing Stalls
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Witnesses']
abstract: Jonathan Fleming says he was wrongly convicted of murder, but his and other cases remain in limbo as Charles J. Hynes hands over the office to the incoming Brooklyn district attorney.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Fleming had been in prison for 23 years — for a murder he insisted he did not commit — before things began to look up this spring: After reinterviewing witnesses who had implicated him in his 1990 trial, his lawyer turned up evidence that he said could lead to Mr. Fleming’s release.

headline: In Need of Help, but Not the Emergency Room
abstract: A program in Wake County, N.C., trains paramedics to perform mental health exams on patients in the field.
lead_paragraph: A program in Wake County, N.C., trains paramedics to perform mental health exams on patients in the field.

keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Hospitals', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The cost of emergency room care for the mentally ill shows no sign of ebbing, but a North Carolina hospital is experimenting to save money and better help patients.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — As darkness fell on a Friday evening over downtown Raleigh, N.C., Michael Lyons, a paramedic supervisor for Wake County Emergency Medical Services, slowly approached the tall, lanky man who was swaying back and forth in a gentle rhythm.

headline: Eczema and Holy Water
abstract: The priest blessed the baby, while the baby drooled on my arm.
lead_paragraph: My 9-month-old son’s first time on a plane — a 10-hour journey from J.F.K. to Istanbul — was a disaster. The dry air of the cabin, the confinement and possibly some allergen on the in-flight menu all contributed to an unprecedented eruption of his eczema. It was demoralizing. His skin had been cracking and inflamed for months, but we had taken such pains with it — daily applications of heavy cream and austere dietary restrictions — in anticipation of introducing him to his relatives in Turkey.

headline: Through Art, Coping With Depression and a Death
abstract: Last May, Robinette Christian, 64, lost her partner of 37 years, but even before the death, Ms. Christian had a tenuous grip on happiness.
lead_paragraph: Disorder has come to characterize Robinette Christian’s life of late.

headline: Poison Gas Kills Eight Left in Dark After Storm
keywords: ['Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Carbon Monoxide', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Weather', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: After hundreds of thousands spent Christmas without electricity, carbon monoxide from gasoline-powered generators was blamed for deaths in the Northeast and Midwest.
lead_paragraph: With downed power lines forcing hundreds of thousands to spend Christmas without electricity, ice storms that raged through the Northeast and the Midwest continued to have a deadly effect as carbon monoxide given off by gasoline-powered generators killed three Americans and five Canadians, officials said.

headline: Homeland Security’s New Chief
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: With the confirmation of Jeh Johnson, the former Pentagon counsel, there’s an opportunity to bring immigration enforcement into balance.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has confirmed Jeh Johnson, once the Pentagon’s top lawyer, to lead the Department of Homeland Security. Mr. Johnson brings a sharp legal mind and reputation for probity to the job. He will need both to manage the department, a daunting agglomeration of agencies and missions and chronic management problems.

headline: Getting Out of Discount Game, Small Colleges Lower the Price
abstract: Many institutions that charge high tuition but also offer steep discounts are rethinking the allure of that model.
lead_paragraph: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — A higher education riddle: When can a college slash tuition by almost half, without losing revenues? Answer: When nobody much pays full tuition anyway.

headline: A Rivalry Goes Unfulfilled as the Lakers Fall to the Heat
abstract: With Kobe Bryant out with a fractured kneecap, the overmatched Lakers lost to the Heat as LeBron James, Chris Bosh and Dwyane Wade made enough plays when they needed to.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant, a creature of habit and one of symbolism, too, acknowledged it was a strange feeling to wake up on Christmas morning for the first time in 15 seasons without a basketball game to play.

headline: A Step Toward Affordable Housing
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Editorials']
abstract: To cope with a worsening crisis, the Federal Housing Finance Agency should jump-start a trust fund program.
lead_paragraph: Representative Melvin Watt, a Democrat of North Carolina, who was confirmed earlier this month as the director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, will need to use all of his agency’s powers to cope with a worsening affordable housing crisis that is placing poor and elderly Americans at risk of homelessness and forcing many of the nation’s 43 million renters to skimp on food and medical care to meet the rent.

headline: Mistaken Ruling on Contraception
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Religion and Belief', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A federal judge did not recognize that the threat to religious liberty comes from employers trying to impose their religious views on workers.
lead_paragraph: The contraception mandate in the new health care reform law accommodates religious beliefs. It exempts houses of worship from having to provide contraceptive coverage without a co-pay. Church-affiliated organizations like schools and hospitals need only send a short form to their insurance administrator, which takes care of the coverage.

headline: Farewell
abstract: After 16 years of stories that raised as many thoughts and ideas as animals and pets, this is the last installment of The Rural Life.
lead_paragraph: The first Rural Life appeared on the editorial page nearly 16 years ago. This is the last. This seems a good season to leave, with a long winter ahead, the wood stove burning, and plenty of hopes and plans for the coming year. When The Rural Life began, I didn’t imagine that it would last so long or chart so many changes in my life. Nor did I imagine that it would find so many good readers. But it has, and I’m grateful for that.

headline: Bloomberg Checking In on Fallen Workers’ Families
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been trying to call the family of every police officer, firefighter, sanitation worker or other city employee who died in the line of duty during his tenure.
lead_paragraph: The phone call came as a surprise.

headline: Yankees Know Risks of Splurging on Japanese Aces
abstract: After the 2006 signing of Kei Igawa became an expensive disappointment, the Yankees hope history does not repeat itself as they get ready to jump into the free-agent sweepstakes for Masahiro Tanaka.
lead_paragraph: Friday is the seventh anniversary of one of Brian Cashman’s more disastrous moments in his long run as general manager of the Yankees. On Dec. 27, 2006, Cashman signed off on a five-year, $20 million contract for the Japanese left-hander Kei Igawa, a pitcher who, in the seasons that followed, went on to win two games for the Yankees while spending most of his time out of sight and out of mind in the minor leagues.

headline: New Tests for Brain Trauma Create Hope, and Skepticism
abstract: Researchers at U.C.L.A. hope a new test will help them find degenerative brain disease among former football players who are still alive. But experts say claims of the tests’ validity are premature.
lead_paragraph: Revelations in recent years that thousands of former football players might have severe brain trauma from injuries sustained on the field have set off a rush in the medical community to seize the potentially lucrative market for assessing brain damage. But experts say claims regarding the validity of these assessments are premature and perhaps unfounded.

headline: In Announcing Unfavorable News, Timing Is Everything
abstract: The timing of disclosures on Christmas Eve by two New York political families followed a pattern by newsmakers hoping to minimize unwanted publicity.
lead_paragraph: In the celebrated tradition of dumping unfavorable news on holidays, weekends or days when the media is otherwise preoccupied, New York City’s political folk spun a little frenzy before ducking out on Christmas Eve.

abstract: After an appeal for help, the United States is rushing dozens of missiles and surveillance drones to help Iraqi forces combat violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is quietly rushing dozens of Hellfire missiles and low-tech surveillance drones to Iraq to help government forces combat an explosion of violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency that is gaining territory in both western Iraq and neighboring Syria.

abstract: Beno Udrih’s performance in the first half of the Knicks’ loss to the Thunder may have been the most miserable of his career.
lead_paragraph: Beno Udrih’s first pass on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden was intercepted by Russell Westbrook.

headline: Identical Twins? Yes. Identical Wins? No Way.
abstract: New York’s hapless N.B.A. teams — the Knicks and the Nets — have the same record (9-19) through Wednesday’s wipeouts.
lead_paragraph: New York’s hapless N.B.A. teams — the Knicks and the Nets — have the same record (9-19) through Wednesday’s wipeouts. They have lost on the same day seven times this season. Not once have they won in tandem.

headline: Japanese Premier Visits Contentious War Shrine
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The visit by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to the Yasukuni Shrine revived a practice that has long strained relations between Japan and its Asian neighbors.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visited a contentious Tokyo war shrine early on Thursday, provoking swift condemnation from China and South Korea, both victims of Japan’s wartime aggression.

headline: Obamas Celebrate Christmas in Hawaii
abstract: The president took a break from opening gifts with his family and spoke to about 580 troops at the Marine Corps Base Hawaii, praising them for their service.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — President Obama took a break from opening gifts and singing carols with his family on Christmas Day, and spoke to about 580 military troops in Hawaii, where he and his family are spending their winter break, thanking them for their service.

headline: Tropical Prints that Transport
abstract: Despite the winter wonderland outside, it’s decidedly tropical in stores thanks to the bright colors and warm-weather prints in this season’s resort collections.
lead_paragraph: Despite the winter wonderland outside, it’s decidedly tropical in stores thanks to the bright colors and warm-weather prints in this season’s resort collections. The chic grandchildren of the Hawaiian shirt, statement separates like a colorful, palm-printed skirt from Fausto Puglisi beg to be paired with basic palettes and clean lines. And from the bright stones on an Annelise Michelson necklace, an upscale version of Panamanian street market finds, to the sandy-colored backdrop on a Prada bag emblazoned with a vintage hula girl, the often-kitschy theme is being reinvented into a motif that the modern woman can get behind without having to travel to a hot and humid destination.

headline: Preventing Civil War in South Sudan
abstract: Economic pressure focused around South Sudan’s oil resources seems the best chance for outsiders to prevent civil war, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: A Nurse Gains Fame in the Days of Polio
abstract: Elizabeth Kenny’s emphasis on the care of individual polio patients and close bedside observation could not be more relevant in today’s era dominated by randomized controlled trials.
lead_paragraph: In the years after World War II, polls perennially showed that Eleanor Roosevelt was the woman whom Americans admired most in the world. But in a 1951 Gallup poll, that distinction went to an Australian nurse, Elizabeth Kenny, popularly known as Sister Kenny.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:35 A.M. (Cinemax) SHAUN OF THE DEAD (2004) In this horror comedy directed by Edgar Wright, Simon Pegg plays Shaun, a worthless layabout who seems content to go nowhere fast just as long as he can hang out at his favorite pub with his best friend, Ed (Nick Frost), and his girlfriend, Liz (Kate Ashfield). But when Liz dumps Shaun, he decides to get his life together to win her back. Of course there’s also the small matter of a zombie apocalypse going on outside his door. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that the film skillfully satirized the zombie genre by “implying that Britain may already be populated with the living dead, metaphorically speaking.” He added, “The motley Londoners who face down the creatures are so inept and unthinking in their response to the catastrophe that the uncharitable part of you may decide that they deserve their probable (but not guaranteed) fates during what panicked television commentators label Z-Day.”

headline: With Shrine Visit, Leader Asserts Japan’s Track From Pacifism
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A visit to the Yasukuni Shrine highlighted Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s willingness to take on big political risks as he tries to build a more powerful Japan.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe’s past year as prime minister has concentrated chiefly on reviving Japan’s long-ailing economy. Yet in Mr. Abe’s mind, the country’s newfound economic prowess is a means to an end: to build a more powerful, assertive Japan, complete with a full-fledged military, as well as pride in its World War II-era past.

headline: Thai Election Body Urges Vote Delay as Unrest Flares
abstract: After violent clashes in Bangkok, the Election Commission of Thailand called for the postponement of a vote scheduled for Feb. 2, adding to the political uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — After chaotic clashes between the police and antigovernment protesters in Bangkok on Thursday left one police officer dead and dozens of people injured, the Election Commission of Thailand urged that national elections scheduled for Feb. 2 be postponed, further clouding the country’s future after a month of debilitating street protests.

headline: Documenting the World for 125 Years
abstract: A new book collects images from the round-the-globe travels conducted for National Geographic magazine, the investigative eye for the rest of the world since 1888.
lead_paragraph: So, you want to see the Great Sphinx, but don’t have the big bucks for an Egyptian jaunt. Easy — go to your computer, type a few words into a search engine and within seconds thousands of images pop up for your viewing pleasure. Prefer to see the timeless creature at sunset, drenched in warm orange hues? Sure. Curious to see different angles? No problem.

lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — As clashes between government troops and rebels continued in South Sudan on Thursday, diplomats moved swiftly to drag the warring sides to the negotiating table but announced none of the breakthroughs they had hoped for.

headline: Bad Scripts and Politics Make for a Bad Year in Tollywood
abstract: The Telugu-language film industry is facing its worst financial slump in a decade.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — Bollywood, the movie-making machine based in Mumbai, may be the best-known Indian film industry globally, but farther south in Andhra Pradesh, there is another that churns out more films each year and has a more intensely devoted following, so much that entertainment is inextricably linked with the state’s turbulent politics.

headline: Egypt Broadens New Crackdown on Brotherhood
abstract: With dozens of arrests and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles, Egypt’s new rulers signaled that they had opened a wide-ranging war on every facet of the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Just a day after Egypt’s military-backed government declared the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist group, a more aggressive crackdown was already emerging Thursday, as the authorities announced dozens of arrests across the country, and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles belonging to the Islamist movement’s members.

headline: Software for Sorting Out Child Support
abstract: Millions of people in the United States owe money for child support from former marriages, and want to be involved with the children’s lives. One divorced entrepreneur thinks they shouldn’t have to figure it out on their own.
lead_paragraph: Getting divorced, particularly when children are involved, can be a hard and messy business, rife with mediators, lawyers and courts. It’s little remarked how hard the realities of the situation can be afterward, when people are on their own.

headline: Prosecutor Overseeing Turkish Graft Inquiry Is Removed From Case
abstract: The removal of the prosecutor, Muammer Akkas, is a new sign of a profound power struggle over Turkey’s judiciary and police forces.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul prosecutor who had been overseeing a sprawling corruption investigation of the prime minister’s inner circle was removed from the case on Thursday, in a new sign of a profound power struggle over Turkey’s judiciary and police forces.

headline: Game Theory: BioShock Infinite and Video Game Reviews
abstract: The latest release from Irrational Games was praised as a work of art by many critics after its introduction in March. But is it good art?
lead_paragraph: After years of debate about the artistic merit of video games, the question of the medium’s artistic worth looks to have finally been decided. I say this in reference to the critical reaction surrounding BioShock Infinite, the first-person shooter from Irrational Games and one of this year’s most popular titles.

headline: Home Fires, Acridly Burning
abstract: The word “acting” is inadequate for what the cast of “August: Osage County” is doing. It’s more of a thespian cage match.
lead_paragraph: Sam Shepard kicks off the screen adaptation of “August: Osage County” with a foggy reference to T. S. Eliot and a succinct account of some of the family pathology that will occupy his kin (and the audience) for the next couple of hours. “My wife takes pills,” he says, “and I drink.” Mr. Shepard is Beverly Weston, a poet living in a big, faded farmhouse in northeastern Oklahoma. Beverly’s wife, Violet, soon makes her wobbly, cackling entrance in the person of Meryl Streep. She takes pills. He drinks. And then Mr. Shepard quits the scene. You will miss him. You might also envy him.

headline: The Salt Wars
abstract: How the Union helped destroy the South by destroying its access to the mundane but absolutely crucial spice.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas Eve 1863, the Union steamers Daylight and Howquah set out from Beaufort, N.C., with volunteers from the 158th New York State and Ninth Vermont onboard. Their destination was Bear Inlet, where they were to join the warship the Iron Age to destroy local salt works, as well as a cargo of salt offloaded by a Southern blockade runner that had been captured the previous day. Arriving at low tide, the steamers were unable to land their troops until Christmas morning. Once onshore, the federal forces set about destroying three Confederate salt works, as many as 400 sacks of salt and dozens of empty turpentine barrels. By 5:30 that afternoon, the expedition had returned unscathed to Beaufort.

headline: Daily Report: Japanese Start-Ups Channel Samurai Spirit
abstract: Analysts and investors report that hundreds of new Internet and technology-related companies have sprung up in the last two to three years, creating an ecosystem to foster early-state start-ups in hopes of cashing in.
lead_paragraph: The 20-somethings in jeans sipping espresso and tapping on laptops at a Tokyo business incubator would look more at home in Silicon Valley than in Japan, where for years the surest signs of success were the gray suits of its corporate salarymen. But for those hoping the nation’s latest economic plan will drag Japan from its long malaise, Martin Fackler reports from Tokyo, the young men and women at Samurai Startup Island represent a crucial component: a revival of entrepreneurship.

headline: New Cruises for Rollin’ on the River
abstract: New big wheels will start turning on the Mississippi, Snake and Columbia rivers.
lead_paragraph: A lazy cruise down the Mississippi River, sipping cocktails while watching the paddlewheel turn: it’s not just a vision of bygone days. Europe’s boom in river cruising has reached the United States, in the form of luxury paddlewheelers.

lead_paragraph: Five people were shot and killed in two separate shootings in and around Newark on Wednesday, an outbreak of violence that led to renewed questions about public safety in New Jersey’s largest city.

headline: The Birth Parents Move In
abstract: I didn’t think I could lie in my warm apartment, my daughter sleeping next to me, knowing that her birth parents were struggling to keep warm and dry.
lead_paragraph: “This will either end really well, or really badly,” I thought as I loaded the rabbit cage into the car. My normally fearless, fierce 2½-year-old daughter, Grace, was terrified of this small nervous bunny, the first she had ever seen outside of a book. Grace’s birth parents, Bridgett and Bill, grabbed two guitars, a suitcase and a few small bags from their rain-soaked tent. And then we all went home together to the small apartment Grace and I share.
