headline: Chamber Opera and Rachmaninoff
abstract: Gotham Chamber Opera has earned a strong reputation in recent seasons.
lead_paragraph: Gotham Chamber Opera has earned a strong reputation in recent seasons, presenting unusual repertory, innovative productions and excellent young singers. Here it partners with the equally estimable music forces of Trinity Church for a staging in St. Paul’s Chapel by Andrew Eggert of “La Descente d’Orphée aux Enfers” (“The Descent of Orpheus to the Underworld”). This chamber opera by Marc-Antoine Charpentier will be conducted by Neal Goren, Gotham’s artistic director. The cast includes Daniel Curran as Orphée. (7 p.m., Wednesday and Friday, Broadway and Fulton Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-868-4460, gothamchamberopera.org.)

headline: Legendary Ways to Ring in the Year
abstract: Where and how to ring in the New Year is a perennial question. If you’re feeling festive and want to make a full night of it, there are several theater-related offerings to choose from.
lead_paragraph: Where and how to ring in the New Year is a perennial question. If you’re feeling festive and want to make a full night of it, there are several theater-related offerings to choose from.

headline: Armchair Travels, to Amsterdam
abstract: “The New Rijksmuseum,” Oeke Hoogendijk’s beautifully shot film presents the countless concerns that went into a $500 million transformation of Amsterdam’s signature museum.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if the Metropolitan Museum of Art suspended operations for almost a decade to undergo a major makeover. That gives you an idea of the scale in “The New Rijksmuseum,” Oeke Hoogendijk’s almost-four-hour documentary, playing as a Film Forum double feature through Wednesday. Ms. Hoogendijk’s beautifully shot film presents the countless concerns — among them unending revisions demanded of architects; a transition between general directors; and contentious meetings with politicians, contractors and the very vocal Dutch Cyclists Union — that went into a $500 million transformation of Amsterdam’s signature museum.

headline: Holiday Soul and Illusion
abstract: New York City Ballet presents final performances of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” while Momix continues its illusionary, body-conscious spectacle at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: It’s that end-of-December feeling: The last thing you want to do is step into a shop. Mercifully, there are mood-altering alternatives. New York City Ballet presents final performances of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” while Momix continues its illusionary, body-conscious spectacle at the Joyce Theater with Moses Pendleton’s “Momix reMIX.” And for some holiday soul, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater continues its season with three programs. On New Year’s Eve, “Revelations” will feature Ailey veterans of the past and present, including Linda Denise Fisher-Harrell, Renee Robinson, Guillermo Asca, Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish, Dudley Williams and Donna Wood Sanders. Next Sunday, there’s the season finale, showcasing excerpts from Ailey’s dances and the season’s new works along with “Revelations” in its entirety. It would have been Ailey’s 83rd birthday. Bring your party hat.

headline: Pro Skier Hacks Into Challenging Run
abstract: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” the skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa has to tunnel through a snow mass to get to a ski run in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” the skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa has to tunnel through a snow mass to get to a ski run in Alaska.

headline: Grooving to Egyptrixx
abstract: The new Egyptrixx album, “A/B Til Infinity,” is a lustrous and resonant thing.
lead_paragraph: The new Egyptrixx album, “A/B Til Infinity,” is a lustrous and resonant thing. Released on the Night Slugs label, home to some of the most challenging but danceable music of the last couple of years, it relies heavily on texture, scrape and atmosphere for its effect, and only sometimes slips into outright groove. Compared to its predecessor, 2011’s “Bible Eyes,” as well as several EPs, this album by Egyptrixx (the recording alias of David Psutka) shows him drilling down to one coherent idea about dance music: The thing that moves the body need not be rhythm, but rather a primal response to sound. With Sinden and Judge Wise. (11:30 p.m., Friday, the Glasslands, 289 Kent Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; theglasslands.com.)

headline: A Parade Wedding and a Dream Home
abstract: The New Year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, that champion of the fantasy lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: The New Year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, that champion of the fantasy lifestyle, which heralds 2014 from its traditional perch at the 125th Rose Parade. Starting at 11 a.m., Vin Scully, the Hall of Fame sports broadcaster and grand marshal, will lead nearly 50 floats, centered on the theme “Dreams Come True” and adorned with more botanical elements — black lichen, Spanish mosses, safflower blossoms, cordon puffs, coconut flakes and even chive and onion seed — than the average florist might go through in five years, down Colorado Avenue in Pasadena, Calif. The “Property Brothers,” Drew and Jonathan Scott and Nancy O’Dell will provide a play-by-play of the nuptials of Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots on the AIDS Healthcare Foundation’s wedding-cake float with the tagline “Love Is the Best Protection.” And eight former Women Airforce Service Pilots from World War II expected to ride atop a float titled “Our Eyes Are on the Stars.”

headline: Art Films at MoMA and Times Square
abstract: Before New Year’s revelers overtake Times Square, art lovers can have their own countdown to midnight.
lead_paragraph: Before New Year’s revelers overtake Times Square, art lovers can have their own countdown to midnight. At 11:57 each night through Monday, an abbreviated version of Isaac Julien’s film “Playtime” is being shown on electronic billboards and kiosks as part of the “Midnight Moment” art program presented by the Times Square Alliance and the Times Square Advertising Coalition. The full-length version of “Playtime” explores the international art market from the perspectives of five characters with varying levels of access and privilege. One is an auctioneer in London, another a worker in Dubai.

headline: Video: Pro Skier Hacks Into Challenging Run
abstract: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” professional skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa has to tunnel through a school bus-sized mass of snow to access a ski run in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Love Is Hunger: Watch Your Appetite
abstract: Francesca Gregorini discusses her new film, “The Truth About Emanuel.”
lead_paragraph: The creepy thriller “The Truth About Emanuel” deals with “loss and heartbreak and madness and mortality,” the writer and director Francesca Gregorini said recently. “Every artist is haunted by specific themes, and those, for better or for worse, seem to be mine.”

headline: Heartthrobs Rule the Korean Stage
abstract: “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamboat” with a celebrity K-pop presence: That’s the sort of musical that’s selling on stages in Seoul.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — His acting was all smiles and scowls, and his dancing fell short of Broadway caliber, but Yang Yoseop, at 23, was an old pro at exuding heartache. Which was all that really mattered.

headline: Finra Fines Barclays $3.75 Million Over Record Retention
abstract: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, the self-regulatory arm of the brokerage industry, cited Barclays over the improper retention of Bloomberg emails and instant messages, as well as other records.
lead_paragraph: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Thursday that it fined Barclays Capital $3.75 million over its failure to properly retain records.

headline: Acupuncture, Real or Not, Eases Side Effects of Cancer Drugs
abstract: Both acupuncture and sham acupuncture were effective in reducing menopausal symptoms in women being treated with aromatase inhibitors for breast cancer, a small study found.
lead_paragraph: Both acupuncture and sham acupuncture were effective in reducing menopausal symptoms in women being treated with aromatase inhibitors for breast cancer, a small randomized trial found. Joint and muscle pain, hot flashes and night sweats are common side effects of those estrogen-lowering drugs.

headline: On Point in Message, and Technique
abstract: Heather Kravas weaves themes of labor and repetition in “a quartet,” choreography that blends folk dance and ballet, at the Coil Festival.
lead_paragraph: Whether it rises to the surface or not, the notion of labor usually lurks somewhere in a Heather Kravas dance, in which repeated steps and patterns are knitted together with such exactitude that the results blend vulnerability with steely tenacity. It’s an idea that she extends to herself, especially now as she prepares to unveil “a quartet,” her latest, at the Kitchen in Chelsea beginning Jan. 8.

headline: Bring Your Film Here, Then Run
abstract: Foreign filmmakers learn to navigate the Oscar race, which often takes a lot of P.R. work and money to run a campaign for a nomination.
lead_paragraph: “We’re not a big country” the director Drasko Djurovic said from his home in Montenegro. “We’re like the Bronx.” So he was very grateful to be part of the Academy Awards. “It means great opportunities for future projects.”

headline: Elegant Provocateur in a Puritanical Era
abstract: A comprehensive retrospective of George Cukor’s 50-year career spotlights his classics and underrecognized movies.

headline: Zombies Amok Amid Fine Design
abstract: DVDs of “The Beast Within,” “Nightmare City” and “Crawlspace” arrive on Blu-ray in time for a home New Year’s fright fest.
lead_paragraph: Should auld acquaintance be filleted? That’s the message of a batch of splattery movies released on Blu-ray just in time for New Year’s Eve.

headline: Times Minute | Controversial War Shrine
abstract: Also on the Minute, a crackdown on jaywalking and a look back at Rana Plaza.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a crackdown on jaywalking and a look back at Rana Plaza.

headline: Mirth Amid Strauss Waltzes
abstract: Jeremy Sams’s production of “Die Fledermaus” is set in Vienna and embellished with Klimt-like touches and nods to Modernism.
lead_paragraph: One of the baritones was asked to work on his pitch: “Enter as a tenor!” A soprano was coached on her volume: “Make that the top of your crescendo!” And the ensembles were urged to work on their diction, and the rhythm of their back and forth: “Like table tennis!”

headline: Sebastian Faulks: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “A Possible Life” and “Jeeves and the Wedding Bells” says literary novels tend to make bad movies: “One form is all inward; the other is two-dimensional.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “A Possible Life” and “Jeeves and the Wedding Bells” says literary novels tend to make bad movies: “One form is all inward; the other is two-dimensional.”

headline: K-Pop Meets Broadway
abstract: Theater producers in Seoul have been increasingly hiring K-pop stars, as well as Korean soap opera actors and other celebrities, to perform in homegrown versions of American and European shows.
lead_paragraph: Theater producers in Seoul have been increasingly hiring K-pop stars, as well as Korean soap opera actors and other celebrities, to perform in homegrown versions of American and European shows.

headline: New Program to Support Operas by Women
abstract: Opera America is offering grants for women who write operas.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered whether female characters in opera would be less likely to go mad, struggle with horrible diseases (consumption, usually) or be murdered by their former lovers if the works were composed by women?

headline: Warrant Issued in Russia for the Owner of Hédiard
abstract: Sergei Pugachev was being sought in connection with a bank fraud case not directly related to the failure of the French confectionery and luxury food chain.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A court in Moscow has issued an arrest warrant for Sergei Pugachev, a Russian banker who bought the French confectionery and luxury food chain Hédiard six years ago with hopes of expanding its global reach only to run it into bankruptcy instead, the Kommersant newspaper reported on Thursday.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: bad laughter, cancer rates and nuts during pregnancy. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: bad laughter, cancer rates and nuts during pregnancy. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: In Blue-Collar Toledo, Ohio, a Windfall of Chinese Investments
abstract: Toledo is hardly the only United States city pursuing investors from China, but the Chinese have noticed its location, housing stock and space.
lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio — The realization was as surprising as it was momentous. Toledo, long known as Glass City, needed glass, and it could no longer be manufactured here quickly enough.

headline: Yanks and Dodgers Know Tanaka’s Agent Well
abstract: Major league teams bidding for the Japanese pitcher Masahiro Tanaka will have to negotiate with Casey Close, who also represents Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka, the 25-year-old pitching ace from Japan, is officially up for grabs to Major League Baseball teams. To get him, they will have to go through Casey Close, the prominent baseball agent at Excel Sports Management who also represents Derek Jeter and Mark Teixeira of the Yankees and pitchers Clayton Kershaw and Zack Greinke of the Dodgers.

headline: Museum of the City of New York’s Gelato Giveaway
abstract: Free gelato and hands-on activities at Museum of the City of New York and free concerts at Brooklyn Night Bazaar.
lead_paragraph: At no other time of year is the Miser’s mom repaid more kindly than over the Christmas holiday, while watching, with a level of glee only an act of cosmic justice could occasion, her eldest child attempt to manage the perfectly unmanageable hopes, desires and vestigial energies of his own little angels.

headline: A Night’s Meal at the Opera
abstract: Running the Grand Tier Restaurant in the Metropolitan Opera House requires a nimble stage management all its own.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was growing up, most girls I knew went to Lincoln Center for “The Nutcracker.” I went to the opera. Specifically, to Metropolitan Opera rehearsals with my father, who didn’t think twice about pulling me out of school. The first one, when I was in fifth grade, was “Madama Butterfly,” with Teresa Stratas. Let other children tarry with visions of the Sugar Plum Fairy. We cut straight to heartbreak and suicide. I loved it.

headline: Discoveries in the Past Year’s Auctions
abstract: Several auctions this year sold objects and documents that unexpectedly divulged intriguing, even secret, histories.
lead_paragraph: When some of the year’s most intriguing auction lots emerged on the market — lots that hardly anyone had known existed — museum staffs hurriedly persuaded patrons to finance purchases. Here are eight success stories about objects that are already going on view and yielding more secrets.

headline: ‘Degenerate Art’ Opens at Neue Galerie in the Spring
abstract: A Neue Galerie exhibition will include modern art collected by the Nazis, including paintings, works on paper, posters and photographs.
lead_paragraph: The Neue Galerie’s big spring show, “Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937,” has been nearly three years in the making, yet it seems particularly prescient after the discovery last month of what may well be the biggest trove of missing 20th-century European art — about 1,400 works suspected of being traded or looted during the Nazis’ reign, including paintings by Matisse, Chagall, Renoir, Toulouse-Lautrec, Picasso and a host of other masters. Some disappeared in the late 1930s, around the time the Nazis raided German museums and public collections, confiscating works they called degenerate because Hitler deemed them un-German or Jewish in nature.

headline: Google Penalizes Rap Genius for Gaming Search Rank
abstract: The site rapgenius.com, which offers annotated song lyrics, acknowledged that it had violated Google’s rules regarding optimizing search results.
lead_paragraph: Google has apparently punished a provocative music-lyrics website after learning it had unscrupulously tried to improve its search rankings.

headline: Philadelphia Monsignor’s Conviction Overturned in Cover-Up of Sexual Abuse
keywords: ['Priests', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The criminal conviction of Msgr. William J. Lynn was overturned by a Pennsylvania appeals court after the court rejected the argument that a child welfare law applied to employers.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania appeals court on Thursday overturned the criminal conviction of a Roman Catholic official who was accused of covering up sexual abuses by priests he supervised. The court rejected the legal basis for a prosecution that was viewed as a milestone in holding senior church officials accountable for keeping abuse reports secret in past decades and transferring predatory priests to unwary new parishes.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Is a Hit With TV Pirates, Too
abstract: HBO’s “Game of Thrones” tops a list of the most-pirated TV shows in 2013.
lead_paragraph: More than a few fans of “Game of Thrones” are so eager for the murder, villainy, depravity and wedding banquets gone horribly wrong depicted on that series that they don’t mind engaging in a little piracy to see the show. The hit HBO fantasy series enjoyed the dubious distinction of placing first on a list of the year’s most pirated television shows, compiled by TorrentFreak.com.

headline: A Film Festival’s Greatest Quick Hits
abstract: This collection offers eight films, including prizewinners and other noteworthy entries, from the most recent edition of the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah.
lead_paragraph: A diverse sampler, “2013 Sundance Film Festival Short Films” bundles together prizewinners and other notables from the most recent edition of the festival in Park City, Utah. As with many collections of shorts, there’s a slight danger of whiplash (to borrow the title of one selection) when each filmmaker introduces a look, sets a mood, sketches a story. Over the course of the eight-film selection, you might see a foulmouthed teacher berating a nervous drummer, photographs of working-class villagers by the sea in 1980s northern England, a dead man rising and pieces of furniture roaming the countryside in Ireland.

headline: Victory, and Setback, for Indian Opposition Leader
abstract: A court declined to prosecute Narendra Modi over his role in an ethnic riot in 2002, but the government ordered a formal inquiry into allegations against his top lieutenant.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The fiery head of India’s leading opposition party, who remains under pressure for his handling of an ethnic riot 11 years ago, won a victory on Thursday in one of the many disputes dogging him as he seeks to become India’s next prime minister, but faced a setback in another.

headline: A Wider Family Circle
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'New Year', 'Parties (Social)', 'Gifts', 'Dating and Courtship']
abstract: Addressing a difficult family reunion, a potential romantic interest, being ignored and an empty gift card.
lead_paragraph: We have been estranged from our son for a couple of years (thanks mostly to his difficult and dominant longtime girlfriend). Still, we followed your advice and wrote him a loving letter for Hanukkah, which he returned in kind. We’ve spoken on the phone a few times since then and even set a date for New Year’s brunch. Now he’s told us that he wants to bring the girlfriend to our reunion. Is there a nice way to let him know that we want to keep it just family for now?

headline: ‘I Have Been Totally Abandoned and Forgotten,’ Captive Says
abstract: Warren Weinstein was abducted from the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore in August 2011. For the second time, he has appealed directly to the White House.
lead_paragraph: An American kidnapped in Pakistan more than two years ago has sent an impassioned video message to President Obama, imploring the administration to negotiate with his captors for his release and saying he felt “abandoned and forgotten.”

headline: In Red Hook, a Home a Bit Away From It All
abstract: Jaime Roark and Ben Krone found a house to fix up from scratch.
lead_paragraph: About 10 years ago, after he finished his master’s degree in architecture at Columbia University, Ben Krone rented a three-bedroom loft in a big brick factory building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Living in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn
abstract: A stable, relatively affordable enclave in a borough that has grown almost too popular for its own good.
lead_paragraph: A stable, relatively affordable enclave in a borough that has grown almost too popular for its own good.

headline: Dyker Heights, Brooklyn: A Neighborhood for All Seasons
abstract: A stable, relatively affordable enclave in a borough that has grown almost too popular for its own good.
lead_paragraph: Dyker Heights, a middle-class, largely Italian-American neighborhood in southwestern Brooklyn, bears signs throughout the year of a place that people deeply care for.

headline: In ‘Natasha, Pierre,’ House Managers Are Part of the Action
abstract: Karyn Meek and Royce Love Russell, the stage and house managers, respectively, of “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812,” do much more than traditional ushers.
lead_paragraph: They may be friendly, or they may be brusque, but the ushers who point the way to your theater seat have only so much to do with your experience once the curtain goes up. In the new world of immersive theater, where lines between the audience and the performers are blurred, it’s a little more complicated. “Here Lies Love” at the Public Theater featured a squadron of helpers in neon pink jumpsuits, moving the standing audience around a dance floor as the show’s set whirled and reconfigured.

headline: Claire Chase Invites Young Musicians to Create New Paths
abstract: “Our calling,” Claire Chase says, “is to create positions for ourselves and others, to improvise and blow the ceiling off of anything resembling a limitation.”
lead_paragraph: Of all the empowering statements the flutist Claire Chase made in her convocation address to the graduating students of Northwestern University’s Bienen School of Music in June, one must have really surprised them: “I’d love for every single one of you to put me out of business. Then I will know that I have done my job.”

headline: Jenji Kohan, Creator of ‘Orange Is the New Black’
abstract: Netflix viewing is a change for audiences and creators, says Jenji Kohan, show runner of “Orange Is the New Black.”
lead_paragraph: When Jenji Kohan set out to find a network home for “Orange Is the New Black” two years ago, empowering a revolution in the way we watch television was not on her agenda.

headline: The Meanings of the Selfie
abstract: The actor-writer-director James Franco writes about selfies and why Instagram posters and viewers alike are so obsessed with them.
lead_paragraph: Selfies are something new to me, but as I have become increasingly addicted to Instagram, I have been accused of posting too many of them. I was called out on the “Today” show, and have even been called the selfie king.

headline: Mustaches in Vogue on Film Screens
abstract: From Tom Hanks to Ron Burgundy, er, Will Ferrell, mustaches have come back in fashion for many actors. Phil Olsen shares his thoughts on the look.
lead_paragraph: It might be going too far to proclaim 2013 the Year of the Mustache, but viewers have been privy to a glorious bounty of mustachioed upper lips at the movies this year. Phil Olsen, the captain of Beard Team USA, knows a thing or two about hirsute looks. He and his colleagues will battle for global facial hair supremacy at the World Beard and Mustache Championships in Portland, Ore., in September. He agreed to share his thoughts on a selection of actors with striking ’staches.

headline: Michael B. Jordan on His Role in ‘Fruitvale Station’
abstract: “Fruitvale Station,” about the killing of a young African-American on an Oakland, Calif., subway platform, has lifted the actor Michael B. Jordan a few rungs on the ladder of stardom.
lead_paragraph: The “B.” in Michael B. Jordan stands for “Bakari,” which in Swahili means “of noble promise.” For Mr. Jordan, the 26-year-old star of “Fruitvale Station,” 2013 has been the year in which potential — “I’ve been walking in it since I was born” he said of the pressure embodied in his middle name — fully blossomed into reality.

headline: Miley Cyrus on Her Jump to Sexy Twerker
abstract: Miley Cyrus, pop’s enfant terrible of 2013, answers critics, and says, “I’m telling women be whoever you want to be.”
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Miley Cyrus wagged her tongue and set tongues wagging. Thanks to a handful of steamy videos, some outrageous wardrobe choices and an erotic comedic performance at the MTV Video Music Awards, Ms. Cyrus took the warp-speed path from directionless ex-child star (as the Disney Channel’s Hannah Montana) to the most directional of pop stars, sliding easily into the role of pop’s enfant terrible. Her album “Bangerz” (RCA) — for which she’ll begin touring in February — was notable for its risk-taking attitude in a year when her competition played it frustratingly smooth.

headline: Portrait of an Aunt With Dark Secrets
abstract: Nicholas Shakespeare tries to separate fact from fiction in a new book about his aunt Priscilla.
lead_paragraph: The mythical status of Nicholas Shakespeare’s aunt Priscilla, the subject of this biographical memoir, took shape in his family on her return to London after the liberation of Paris. A glamorous survivor of four years as a British enemy alien in France during World War II, married to a French viscount, astonishingly and adulterously dating the British movie star Robert Donat. The family’s image couldn’t have been how she saw herself, as the once-adored daughter of a father she barely glimpsed after she was swept off to Paris by a mother she described (seemingly accurately) as “a selfish, vain, stupid woman,” next as an aspiring ballet dancer crippled by illness, then a shy 20-year-old whose parents wouldn’t support her, and — on her way to have a French abortion — a pickup by the viscount.

headline: A Cinderella Is Back to Waiting for a Happy Ending
abstract: At 0-11, Cornell, the darling of the 2010 N.C.A.A. tournament, is the lone Division I men’s basketball team without a victory this season, but its coach sees brighter things ahead.
lead_paragraph: In Cornell’s last men’s basketball game, at Stony Brook, Coach Bill Courtney often threw his arms up in frustration after turnovers and frequently flashed an exhausted smile when his team committed imprudent fouls.

headline: Lorde’s ‘Royals’ Is Class-Conscious
abstract: Ella Yelich-O’Connor, better known as Lorde, delivered her class-conscious critique to listeners around the world this year.
lead_paragraph: A flourishing teen-pop industry thinks it knows what teenagers care about: crushes, breakups, clothes, parties, perhaps an occasional glimmer of rebellion or idealism. It dispenses songs that are calculated to suit that market. But in 2013, a songwriter who is an actual teenager emerged from the far side of the planet with something smarter and deeper: a class-conscious critique of pop-culture materialism that’s so irresistible it became a No. 1 pop single.

headline: Damian Woetzel at the Vail International Dance Festival
abstract: Damian Woetzel, a onetime principal with New York City Ballet, has found a mission as director of the Vail International Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: When Damian Woetzel retired in 2008 as a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, popular opinion had him aiming at a ballet company directorship. But he has taken a more surprising direction, becoming an all-around arts advocate. He is involved in Musicorps, which helps war veterans; he’s on the President’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities; and he directs the Aspen Institute Arts Program.

headline: Sheikha al-Mayassa Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani of Qatar Museums
abstract: A new power player in the Middle Eastern art world is Sheikha al-Mayassa Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, a 30-year-old chairwoman of the Qatar Museums Authority.
lead_paragraph: In October, when Sheikha al-Mayassa Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, the 30-year-old chairwoman of the Qatar Museums Authority, unveiled 14 monumental new bronze sculptures by the British artist Damien Hirst in front of a women’s and children’s health center on the outskirts of Doha, her intention was neither to shock nor offend residents of this conservative Middle Eastern city.

headline: ‘Key & Peele,’ With Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele
abstract: The sketch comedians Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele use their mixed-race backgrounds on their Comedy Central series “Key & Peele.”
lead_paragraph: There are two complementary forms of radical humor taking place on “Key & Peele,” the sketch show that just finished its third season on Comedy Central. On the one hand is the race humor, savvy in tweaking fraught white encounters with blackness and sometimes equally fraught black encounters with blackness. On the other hand are sketches that are completely race neutral in content, which are given frisson merely by the race of the comedians: Both Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele are the children of black fathers and white mothers.

headline: Wheelies: The Fresh Air Volvos Edition
abstract: Volvo’s pollen filtration technology may appeal to pollution-conscious Chinese customers; a faux pas by Japan’s prime minister may affect auto sales.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Is This a Video I See in Front of Me?
abstract: WordPlay Shakespeare and other programs allow readers to watch or listen to sections of his works as they view the text.
lead_paragraph: Pity the English teacher of today, faced with a roomful of adolescents busy updating their Facebook status, communicating on Snapchat or gossiping via text message about the latest perfidy committed by a frenemy. Trying to instill in students a passionate interest in Shakespeare (or even a passing one) has never been a teacher’s easiest task. With all those digital distractions, the challenge of awakening teenagers’ interest in his plays has surely become harder.

headline: Big Spanish Labor Union Facing an Investigation on Misuse of Funding
abstract: The regional government of Andalusia contends $2.46 million in public money was spent illegally to pay for events and gifts to officials.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s shrinking labor unions have struggled during the economic crisis to put a brake on the government’s austerity measures and help reduce record unemployment.

headline: 2013: A Look Back, and Beyond
abstract: Reporters and editors for The New York Times are recalling the people, teams and moments that made 2013 memorable, and in some cases looking ahead to next year.
lead_paragraph: Reporters and editors for The New York Times are recalling the people, teams and moments that made 2013 memorable, and in some cases looking ahead to next year.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Writers and Drinking
abstract: This week, Olivia Laing talks about “The Trip to Echo Spring”; and John Williams discusses Morrissey’s “Autobiography.”
lead_paragraph: This week, Olivia Laing talks about “The Trip to Echo Spring”; and John Williams discusses Morrissey’s “Autobiography.”

headline: With Health Law Cemented, G.O.P. Debates Next Move
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With more than two million Americans poised to be covered under the Affordable Care Act, Republicans opposed to the law are considering several ideas for how to proceed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the first enrollment deadline now passed, Republicans who have made the repeal of President Obama’s health care law their central aim are confronting a new reality: More than two million Americans are expected to be getting their health insurance through the Affordable Care Act come Jan. 1.

headline: Amazon Reveals a New Hint About Prime Membership Rolls
abstract: The company has never said how many Prime members it has, leaving analysts guessing about the popularity of the service that is crucial for increasing retail sales and video streaming.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The world’s biggest online retailer has mastered the art of talking a lot about its holiday sales, while saying very little.

headline: Epiphanies at ‘Home’
abstract: From the Off Broadway musical “Fun Home” to the star-crossed “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” Times writers offer a few last-minute theater picks.
lead_paragraph: Watching prepubescent girls undergoing stirrings of sexual awakening is not generally regarded as a comfortable or suitable cultural experience. (Yes, there’s always Balthus, but then again ....) Still, you’d have no reason to feel guilty about enjoying the downright wholesome spectacle of the 8-year-old girl who recounts in song her realization that she just might be attracted to member of her own sex in “Fun Home,” the wonderful musical that ends its run at the Public Theater on Jan. 12 (publictheater.org).

headline: No Aid Seen in Syrian Town Despite a Deal to Lift Barriers
abstract: Government officials and rebels blame one another as no aid is yet delivered to the civilians in Moadhamiya, just outside the city limits of Damascus.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The rebel-held Syrian town of Moadhamiya hoisted the government’s flag from its tallest building on Thursday as part of a tentative truce deal, a symbolic victory for the government, which has blockaded the town for nearly a year, preventing food and medical supplies from entering.

headline: Learning to Measure Time in Love and Loss
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Marriages', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Missed opportunities are not the events that define us.
lead_paragraph: For about 10 years, I worked full time in prisons as a teacher, logging more than 40 hours a week behind those fences, including a long winter at one facility that had been a cereal factory and stood near the highway in downtown Indianapolis. It was a rock of a building with finger-thick grilles on the windows.

headline: The Creative Alchemy Behind Potent Soundtracks
abstract: Marvin Hamlisch’s career as a composer for films and Broadway is the subject of an engaging “American Masters” documentary on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Hamlisch died more than a year ago, but he can still teach a fine master class.

headline: Bringing Parisian Flair to Police Procedural
abstract: “Spiral,” a subtitled French crime series on Netflix, and HBO’s “Getting On” offer fresh variations on the usual TV offerings.
lead_paragraph: Put the blame on Danes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Thailand, Peru, Central Africa Republic and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Thailand, Peru, Central Africa Republic and China.

headline: Where Weather’s Always Fine for a Run
abstract: When the temperatures outside are discouraging, runners can try New York’s indoor tracks. Here are three of the best.
lead_paragraph: IF the words “wintry mix” are enough to make your inner runner want to head to the nearest treadmill, or even forgo a workout altogether, there’s another option: Visit an indoor track. New York City has a strong indoor-running scene, with an array of gyms, universities and Y.M.C.A.s offering tracks insulated from the elements.

headline: Injuries, More Injuries, Stunning Upsets and Other Wimbledon Weirdness
abstract: Seven players withdrew or retired on Day 3 at Wimbledon, and by the end of the day, 12 seeded players, including seven former No. 1s, had lost.
lead_paragraph: The tennis year was full of riveting story lines: the dominance of Serena Williams; the triumphant comeback of Rafael Nadal; the long-awaited Wimbledon title for Andy Murray and Britain; a record-setting year for the Bryan brothers; the steep decline of Roger Federer.

headline: LightSquared Proposes New Financing as Way to Emerge From Bankruptcy
abstract: Lawyers for the bankrupt wireless company LightSquared filed documents in a New York bankruptcy court, outlining a plan to bring in at least $1.25 billion in new equity and $2.75 billion in loans.
lead_paragraph: The wireless communications company LightSquared may have a path out of bankruptcy that lets its biggest shareholder, the billionaire hedge fund manager Philip Falcone, retain some of the control he has sought.

headline: The Queen’s Reign
abstract: Focus Dance offers the Doug Elkins work “Scott, Queen of Marys” at the Joyce Theater, and the Rockettes offer a rebirth of all-American glamour.
lead_paragraph: The Focus Dance season at the Joyce Theater brings just two performances of “Scott, Queen of Marys” (1994) by Doug Elkins: Jan. 7 and 12 (joyce.org). When I first saw this in December 2012, I at once arranged to see it a second time that week, and now I’m impatient for this chance to renew the acquaintance.

headline: The Lady Barbara
abstract: Film Forum’s survey of Barbara Stanwyck’s movies concludes on New Year’s Eve. On Friday and Saturday, there’s her classic noir “Double Indemnity” (1944).
lead_paragraph: One of the main qualities we look for in a diva is a variety that somehow stays the same; we want from our great artists both adventure and safety. But Barbara Stanwyck pushed her range further than most. She was sometimes a femme fatale and sometimes a screwball comedian; she was a noble missionary’s wife in “The Bitter Tea of General Yen” (1933) and a scheming con artist in “The Lady Eve” (1941).

headline: Women Ruling Falstaff’s Roost
abstract: More than any other opera this year, “Falstaff” deserves a second viewing to savor the details.
lead_paragraph: Two memorable new productions book-ended the year at the Metropolitan Opera: François Girard’s painfully human “Parsifal,” set in a post-apocalyptic no-man’s land, and Robert Carsen’s zippy “Falstaff,” set in a 1950s England of Technicolor opulence. For a director approaching “Parsifal,” the challenge is to come up with ideas to populate the dramaturgical moonscape that are Wagner’s interminable monologues in this five-hour-plus opera. Verdi’s comedy “Falstaff,” by contrast, is teeming with action, and the task of the director — no less difficult — is one of traffic control.

headline: Officer Kills Armed Suspect in the Bronx
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Officials said the suspect was struggling with an officer over a loaded gun when a second officer fired.
lead_paragraph: A police officer shot and killed a suspect in an armed robbery in the Bronx early Thursday as the suspect struggled over his loaded gun with another officer, the police said.

headline: Subterranean Acts of Sudden Intimacy
abstract: The immersive theater show “Queen of the Night” is opening New Year’s Eve at the Paramount Hotel’s Diamond Horseshoe supper club, which is back in business for the first time since 1951.
lead_paragraph: IN its heyday, Billy Rose’s Diamond Horseshoe was quite the thing — “the most zestful, gorgeous and lovable pleasure palace in town,” a critic for The New York Times wrote shortly after it opened in December 1938. Buried deep in the basement of what is now the Paramount Hotel on West 46th Street in Manhattan, the theater transported audiences back to New York in the Gay Nineties, the era of Diamond Jim Brady and Lillian Russell, in a revue stacked with old vaudeville troupers and glamorous showgirls.

headline: Memories, Stitched Together, for Gallery Walls
abstract: The Folk Art Museum show “alt_quilts: Sabrina Gschwandtner, Luke Haynes, Stephen Sollins” shows just how personal quilt making can be.
lead_paragraph: After a year of shows that combined folk and self-taught artists (a.k.a. “outsiders”) with M.F.A.-groomed “insiders,” we’re finally starting to recognize quilts as powerfully contemporary artworks. Last summer’s excellent Americana-theme group show “Roving Signs,” for instance, organized by the artist Terry Winters for the Matthew Marks gallery, featured the dazzling abstract quilts of Rosie Lee Tompkins alongside works by Donald Judd, Rachel Harrison and Richard Aldrich.

headline: A Chilling Crime in an Everyday Setting
keywords: ['Football', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The accusation that Patriots tight end Aaron Hernandez had committed murder seemed out of step with the quiet normalcy of his Massachusetts neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was how normal Aaron Hernandez’s neighborhood appeared. Perhaps that’s what made the accusations so chilling.

headline: Reactions to World War II Shrine Visit
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visited a contentious shrine and honored Japan’s war dead, triggering protests from China and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visited a contentious shrine and honored Japan’s war dead, triggering protests from China and South Korea.

headline: Unusual Play by Unfamiliar Yankees
abstract: In April, Robinson Cano, Jayson Nix, Kevin Youkilis and Lyle Overbay caught the visiting Orioles in a rare 4-6-5-6-5-3-4 triple play, a memorable moment in an otherwise disappointing season.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 Yankees may be best remembered for their inability to remain healthy in a season that, despite the efforts of a lineup of down-to-their-last-hurrah veterans and castoffs from around the league, ended short of the playoffs.

headline: Pageant of a Bucolic Ukraine
abstract: Korchma Taras Bulba opened its first New York restaurant in SoHo, featuring Ukrainian food and servers in traditional dress.
lead_paragraph: Korchma Taras Bulba opened its first New York restaurant in SoHo, featuring Ukrainian food and servers in traditional dress.

headline: A Day in SoHo, a Night in Ukraine
abstract: Part restaurant, part folk performance, Korchma Taras Bulba keeps the dumplings and vodka shots coming.
lead_paragraph: It starts and ends with vodka.

headline: That’s Vintage Verdi, That ’61 ‘Otello’
abstract: As the bicentennial celebration of Verdi’s birthday draws to an end, critics of The New York Times note their favorite recordings of his work.
lead_paragraph: SOME days are left in 2013, so it is still officially the bicentennial of Verdi’s birth, which means it is not too late for the classical music critics of The New York Times to share their choices of favorite Verdi recordings. This August we came up with our favorite recordings of Wagner, who also had a big bicentennial year. As with Wagner, Verdi has been as central to the history of recordings as he is to the history of music.

headline: Representational Work in Years When Abstract Was Hot
abstract: “See It Loud: Seven Post-War American Painters,” running through Jan. 26 at the National Academy Museum, features works from the collection of a former trustee, Henry Justin.
lead_paragraph: However often it is bent, the rule still holds: People who govern public art museums must set aside self-interest in carrying out their institutional duties. Maintaining higher standards is especially urgent when a museum runs into trouble, as the National Academy did five years ago,  when it sold two Hudson River School paintings to cover budgetary shortfalls and briefly considered selling its Fifth Avenue building to resolve its debts.

headline: All That Glitters (and a Lot That Shines)
abstract: “Jewels by JAR” is devoted to the work of Joel Arthur Rosenthal, who creates pricey jewels for a handpicked clientele from his shop in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who visits museums has spent time looking at costly luxury goods and status symbols cherished by the upper echelons and ruling classes of bygone eras. The list of objects elevated to unprecedented heights of artistry includes Japanese lacquer boxes, Fabergé eggs, French porcelain, Roentgen furniture, bejeweled objects from the treasuries of this cathedral or that court. Almost without exception, they dazzle the eye with astounding craftsmanship, superb design and carefully orchestrated material extravagance.

headline: In the Holiday Movie Crush, a Few Twists
abstract: Specialty theaters like the Picture House in Pelham, Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville and the Alamo Drafthouse in Yonkers offer alternatives to the usual multiplex experience.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth of July it’s fireworks. Thanksgiving Day it’s turkey. Christmas week, it’s movies, and lots of them. Schools release their students, studios release their awards contenders and the box office totals swell.

headline: Wintry Wanderings Among Chelsea’s Ghosts
abstract: Many luminaries have called the London neighborhood home, and winter is “an excellent time for dead-celebrity stalking.”
lead_paragraph: I’ve lived in some historic places over the years — Paris, Greenwich Village, Washington — but it wasn’t until I spent a winter in Chelsea a year ago that I felt as if I were inside a diorama. The ur-Chelsea, I mean: London, not the quarter of Manhattan that provided Joni Mitchell with inspiration for a song and, in the process, Bill and Hillary Clinton with a name for their newborn daughter. For historical voyeurism, London’s Chelsea is hard to beat, especially if you incline to artist-writer types, or as my late friend Christopher Hitchens would put it, “people of that kidney.”

lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the dominant ideas and themes in pop in 2013.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the next budget deadline just weeks away, top lawmakers said this week that they had made significant progress negotiating a huge government-wide spending bill that gives the once mighty congressional Appropriations Committees an opportunity to reassert control over the flow of federal dollars.

headline: Islamic World Through Women’s Eyes
abstract: A show at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, of work by female photographers from the Muslim world, challenges stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Middle Eastern women, supposedly powerless and oppressed behind walls and veils, are in fact a force in both society and the arts. They played a major role in the Arab Spring and continue to do so in the flourishing regional art scene — specifically in photography — which is alive and very well indeed. Some Middle Eastern photographers have taken their cameras to the barricades, physical ones and those less obvious, like the barriers erected by stereotypes, which they remain determined to defy. The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, takes note in “She Who Tells a Story: Women Photographers From Iran and the Arab World,” an ambitious and revealing exhibition of work by 12 women, some internationally known.

headline: Intoxicating Prose
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: In “The Trip to Echo Spring,” Olivia Laing chronicles the alcoholism of six writers: John Cheever, Tennessee Williams, John Berryman, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver.
lead_paragraph: “Modern life,” Hemingway once wrote, “is often a mechanical oppression and liquor is the only mechanical relief.” It’s a pertinent observation if we remember that it was written in an age before other drugs had become widely available, but it’s also one of the premises of Olivia Laing’s charming and gusto-driven look at the alcoholic insanity of six famous writers, namely John Cheever, Tennessee Williams, John Berryman, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. Rather than simply weld their stories together into a kind of collective biography, Laing weaves portraits of each man into an overland journey she made between New York and Port Angeles, Wash., last abode of Raymond Carver. The idea is to bind together cities and landscapes in which these men were immersed.

headline: The City at the Center of the World
abstract: Russell Shorto offers a history of Amsterdam and the culture it created.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch in the 17th century, Russell Shorto informs us at a characteristic moment in “Amsterdam: A History of the World’s Most Liberal City,” were on their way to becoming “the greatest shipping nation the world had ever seen.” Amsterdam’s canal ring was “the greatest urban feat of the age.” In fact, Shorto says, Amsterdam more or less gave us the American Revolution, the French Revolution, the Enlightenment and the stock exchange (though Antwerp’s stock exchange building is 80 years older). The United East India Company, put together in Amsterdam, was “unique in world history,” Shorto writes. It “remade the world.” It “pioneered globalization and invented what might be the first modern bureaucracy.” It inaugurated “the beginning of consumerism, which, for better or worse, is surely a component of liberalism.”

headline: Homeowner’s ‘Cannons’ Warn Demolition Teams: No Closer
abstract: Determined to protect his home from being razed, a man in Henan Province has stationed six “cannons” outside it. They apparently cannot be fired, but they are drawing attention.

headline: An Interview With Liz Eswein, Instagram User-Turned-Entrepreneur
abstract: Just a couple of years after she first opened an Instagram account, Liz Eswein has built a successful business on helping brands use the service.
lead_paragraph: We often read about how the founders of start-ups become rich and famous, but sometimes, users of new web services also find a way to benefit financially. Take Liz Eswein. Just a couple of years ago, she signed up to Instagram while a senior at New York University. Then she managed to turn that account into an Instagram-based business called The Mobile Media Lab, which has generated more than $1 million in revenue by helping brands use the service. The following is an edited interview with Ms. Eswein.

headline: Music for Final Hours, Set to Primal Beats
abstract: Critics and writers for The New York Times recommend New Year’s Eve pop music events in the city.
lead_paragraph: It’s over. It’s a wrap. Nothing more to see here. The damage is done. Finis. These are the lies we tell ourselves on New Year’s Eve, a holiday that ostensibly celebrates renewal but really places an arbitrary cap on a year’s worth of love and hurt and strife and joy and seals it, freeing up space to try again, once the ball drops. Going out on New Year’s Eve, then — that’s really for the people who want that jar sealed tight. They want to rage, to get lost in shamanistic fever, to laugh until the body doesn’t know how else to move. Here, writers for The New York Times weigh in on events that, for some, may fill a need for a sense of finality but that are also a reminder that even after the worst, life goes on. JON CARAMANICA

headline: Life on the Edge
abstract: We are on the cusp of the year, where the past and future intersect.
lead_paragraph: IN environmental parlance, the ecotone is the zone where two habitats merge, that threshold where water meets the shore, where the forest comes to meadow, or where woodland ends at a cultivated lawn. It is the edge habitat where everything — soil content, vegetation, moisture, humidity, light, pollination — changes. It’s also where species from both sides converge, rendering it a place of complex interaction and diversity.

And so on a brisk day in February, feeling run down, Ms. Jang found herself in a storefront clinic, a needle in her arm and a bag of solution she knows as “ringer” sliding into her veins.

But Jay Ellis, founder of the private equity firm Sporting Ranch Capital Management, sees something sparkling in the distance. He slams on the brakes and jumps out of his rented sport utility vehicle to get a closer look at one of the dozens of natural springs spilling out from small aqueducts. “You could fill up your water bottle and drink it,” he says excitedly. “It’s that pure.”

headline: Ukraine: Third Suspect Detained in Beating of Activist
abstract: Ukrainian authorities on Thursday increased the severity of potential charges in the case after initially deeming it a matter of “hooliganism.”
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian authorities on Thursday said they had detained a third man in connection with the brutal beating of an antigovernment activist and had increased the severity of potential charges in the case after initially deeming it a matter of “hooliganism.” The authorities also said that they were questioning three members of Parliament, though their connection to the case was unclear. The activist, Tetyana Chornovol, 34, was severely beaten Wednesday by men who forced her car off the road. Partly as a result of her description of the attack, the authorities said, the suspects now face possible charges of inflicting serious bodily harm. Ms. Chornovol, who is also a journalist, remained hospitalized on Thursday as hundreds of people marched on the Ministry of Interior Affairs and demanded the resignation of the minister, Vitaly Zakharchenko.

lead_paragraph: On Thursday, one year after coming to power, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visited Yasukuni, the controversial Shinto shrine that honors Japan’s war dead, including war criminals from World War II. China and South Korea swiftly criticized the move, as did the United States. Mr. Abe’s visit will worsen Japan’s already tense relations with China and South Korea, which see the shrine as a symbol of imperial Japan’s wars of aggression and colonialism. headline: His Green Card Returned, Doors Reopen
abstract: With plans to attend a prestigious school in New York, José del Carmen Arias’s life ground to a halt when his green card was confiscated after an extended stay in the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: On July 22, 2011, José Arias and José del Carmen Arias, then 19, were just another father and son in a long security line at the San Juan Airport in Puerto Rico. Both had green cards showing they were lawful residents of the United States. They had made this journey — from the Dominican Republic, where both were born, back to Puerto Rico, where they lived — many times before.

(IFC) THE ASSASSINATION OF JESSE JAMES BY THE COWARD ROBERT FORD (2007) Andrew Dominik directed this contemplative portrait of the final days of the outlaw Jesse James (Brad Pitt, above) and his gang (Sam Rockwell, Paul Schneider, Jeremy Renner and others). One member of the posse is Robert Ford (Casey Affleck), who is more obsessed fan than loyal sidekick. And when Jesse James, the man, does not live up to the myth, Ford decides to grab a piece of fame for himself. “Dressed in near-all black, the question mark known as Jesse James stands away from the camera, knee-deep in a golden, grassy field stirred by the wind or perhaps just an off-screen mechanical fan,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The cinematography may speak to Mr. Dominik’s yearning for meaning and importance more than it does of his outlaw, but the visuals often dazzle and enthrall.” Roger Deakins received an Oscar nomination for best cinematography for his work on the film, and Mr. Affleck was nominated for best supporting actor.

David Gutowski, the man behind the site, aggregates year-end books coverage. With a full two weeks left in the year, his list of lists had 834 entries.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BETWEEN MAN AND BEAST: An Unlikely Explorer and the African Adventure That Took the Victorian World by Storm,  by Monte Reel. (Anchor, $15.95.) In 1859, Paul Du Chaillu emerged from a four-year hunting expedition in Gabon with a major zoological discovery: 20 preserved skins of a massive ape, which soon took its familiar name — gorilla. Reel’s robust intellectual history recounts Du Chaillu’s exploits and places his “objects of wonder” at the center of the nascent debate over Charles Darwin’s theories about the origin and nature of mankind.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN MIRROR: The Life and Art of Norman Rockwell,  by Deborah Solomon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Solomon pays honest respect to Rockwell for his dedication through periods of self-doubt, depression and marital tumult.

headline: Bullet Diplomacy
abstract: Michael Burleigh surveys many of the international wars and anticolonial insurgencies during two decades of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: In “Small Wars, Faraway Places,” Michael Burleigh recounts the violent end of the British and French empires in Africa and Asia, and their partial replacement by the United States in its often ill-informed and costly efforts to combat Communism during the early stages of the Cold War. Burleigh surveys many of the major international wars and anticolonial insurgencies between 1945 and 1965, but opts to focus most on those involving America, Britain and France, and how they related to the rivalry with the Soviet Union. The result is a well-researched and readable account of two tumultuous decades. Burleigh judges most of these wars, both small and large, to have been futile and destructive. But while he clearly has no interest in defending or rehabilitating such conflicts, he nonetheless offers a fair, thoughtful assessment of the motives and interests behind them. He also takes care to understand and explain the grievances of the insurgents.

headline: Man Against Nature
abstract: A biography of Jack London, whose fictional characters lived in a determined universe.
lead_paragraph: “The superficial reader will get the love story & the adventure,” Jack London wrote, in 1903, of the story that would become “The Sea-Wolf,” “while the deeper reader will get all of this, plus the bigger thing lying underneath.” These are the typically blunt words of a writer who seemed to think of his work in terms of purchase value. Here, he might have been describing his own life: much adventure, a sort of love story, a weird bang of a finish. In a new biography by the London scholar Earle Labor, the “bigger thing” has a harder time coming out: Perhaps it doesn’t exist.

headline: Stealth Maneuvers
abstract: Frederick Busch’s plain-spoken stories culminate in often unsettling realizations.
lead_paragraph: Imagine the writer as a wager of war. Some stun with shock-and-awe prose, surprise plot twists, barrages of literary ordnance. Others deploy steady blasts of sentiment, turning heartstrings into so many tripwires. But some conduct a subtler campaign, built on stealth maneuvers: escalating schemes, deft and imperceptible, that quietly, thrillingly, devastate. ­Frederick Busch, the author of more than two dozen books, who died in 2006 at the age of 64, was a master of this approach.

headline: Close Quarters
abstract: Sam Thompson’s first novel puts urban life under a microscope.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to call “Communion Town” a novel about a city. But neither “novel” nor “city” quite captures the eerie multi­dimensionality of Sam Thompson’s dazzling debut; everything about “Communion Town” — from its genre to its subject to its shifting perspectives — proves to be more complicated than it seems. At the end of the book, the city remains as hazy to readers as shadows on the walls of a cave. What “Communion Town” renders with stunning and often heartbreaking lucidity is the complexity of consciousness itself.

headline: Guests of the Ayatollah
abstract: An Iranian-American recounts his yearlong sojourn in Tehran.
lead_paragraph: To write about one’s country while living in another is to invite questions about loyalty. Why are you writing this? And for whom? The questions can take an ominous tone: What is your agenda? The journalist Hooman Majd faced such suspicions on one of his trips to Tehran, when an employee from the Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance told him bluntly: “Just because you have an Iranian passport doesn’t mean you can come here and write whatever you want when you leave.”

headline: Little Angels
abstract: The Yale psychologist Paul Bloom mines child-development research for insights into morality.
lead_paragraph: Is morality innate? In his new book, “Just Babies,” the psychologist Paul Bloom draws from his research at the Yale Infant Cognition Center to argue that “certain moral foundations are not acquired through learning. . . . They are instead the products of biological evolution.” Infants may be notoriously difficult to study (rats and pigeons “can at least run mazes or peck at levers”), but according to Bloom, they are, in fact, “moral creatures.”

headline: Storm Clouds in the Aura of a Sunny Teenage Pop Star

lead_paragraph: The key moment in “Justin Bieber’s Believe,” the new hagiographical film, comes in the second half, in a segment that touches ever so lightly upon Mr. Bieber’s tumultuous public image over the last year. The scene is London, last March: A small cluster of paparazzi is egging Mr. Bieber on, and he takes the bait, jumping at the photographers and being held back by a bodyguard. At least half of the conversation (on both sides) is bleeped.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Authors of some of the Book Review’s Best Books of 2013 share their favorite reading experience from the year just ended.
lead_paragraph: Best of the Best: The Book Review has had its say; a few weeks ago, we named our 10 Best Books of 2013. But in the interests of inclusiveness — and, O.K., advance planning before the holidays — I wondered what our 10 best authors would pick as their favorites. So I asked them. The rules were simple: Tell us the best book you read this year (whether it was published in 2013 or not) and, briefly, describe it. Not everybody responded — I wasn’t the only one beleaguered by sugarplums — but enough did to devote the column this week, and next, to their replies: the best books as chosen by the authors of the best books, a sort of chain letter of terrific reading ideas. Here they are.

abstract: Topics from 2013 get another look, including the increasing popularity of no-contract cellphone plans.
lead_paragraph: MY final column of the year gives me a chance to revisit some topics from 2013 to see what has changed or what, as astute readers have pointed out, I didn’t include in the first go-round.

headline: On the Asymmetry of Booms and Slumps (Wonkish)
abstract: Booms are nice, slumps are bad. Why?
lead_paragraph: Something I’m thinking about: Recently Antonio Fatas listed four ingredients that he considered missing in macroeconomic models, with the first element being the asymmetry of the business cycle. Basically, the standard models say that output fluctuates around a normal level, with the ups and downs equal in size, and that all policy can do is reduce the variance. Fatas believes, however, that the business cycle is better seen as occasional drops below potential output, then returns to trend — a view that makes good policy much more important. I agree. But why?

abstract: According to studies released this year, piracy of video content continued to rise during 2013.
lead_paragraph: There are some lists where you don’t want to be crowned as the winner: most likely not to succeed, for example, or most boring person of the year. And if you own a company that makes and sells TV shows, having one of your creations at the top of the Most Pirated Show on Television list probably isn’t something you’d stick on your fridge.

headline: Taking Stock of 2 Thefts With Little in Common Except Their Status: Unsolved
abstract: The items — a Norman Rockwell painting and a life preserver taken from a dive bar — seem to have nothing in common, except that they’re both missing.
lead_paragraph: In a perfect world, or at least a perfect newspaper story, the two objects, each of extreme value in its own way, would not only turn up, but would be discovered in the same place — a breathtaking trove. In this scenario, a master thief has stashed them away in his underground lair, where he gazes upon them from time to time, chuckling over a Cognac.

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, when Times Square is mobbed, Dr. Maria Evans, a 53-year-old surgical and clinical pathologist, will be having a party in Kirksville, Mo.

headline: Linda Ronstadt’s Borderland
abstract: Taking a road trip with the singer through southern Arizona and northern Mexico, a region where her roots run deep.
lead_paragraph: We are driving outside Naco, Ariz., near the Mexico border, on a two-lane blacktop under a half-moon and stars. The distant mountains are lost in shadow, and there’s not much to look at beyond the headlight beams and the rolling highway stripes.

lead_paragraph: Four days after their release from a Russian prison, two members of the punk band Pussy Riot gave their first news conference to emphasize that they were starting a human rights organization, while sticking by the message that put them in jail: ending the presidency of Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Dodging a Holiday in a Remote Mexican Town
abstract: It may not be easy to reach the seaside village of Xcalak, but when seasonal traditions loom, that could be a good thing.
lead_paragraph: The night before Thanksgiving, while most of my acquaintances were setting tables or stuffing turkeys, I was in a lonesome town in Mexico, watching a salamander eat mosquitoes on a greasy kitchen wall. It was a hungry thing and went about devouring its prey with whip-quick lashes of an energetic tongue. Though I had chosen to avoid the feast day in the north, I didn’t mind the little lizard’s gluttony. Its meal, after all, was untroubled by the usual distractions: by football on TV or, moreover, the familiar family dramas. Despite — or perhaps because of — its enforced veneer of bliss, the month between the Macy’s parade and the Times Square ball drop can often inspire an unseasonable longing to escape.

headline: Syrian Security Forces Kill Dozens of Rebels in Ambush
abstract: The Syrian security forces struck near the town of Maaloula, north of Damascus, Syrian rebels and government television said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces ambushed and killed dozens of insurgents on Friday near the ancient Christian town of Maaloula, north of Damascus, during fighting close to the Lebanese border, Syrian rebels and government television said. Syrian state television said that government forces killed more than 60 fighters from the Nusra Front, an insurgent group with links to Al Qaeda. A Syrian rebel commander in the area, Abou al-Majd, said the attack killed more than 20 fighters, including Syrian members of Nusra and other local rebels. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, an organization based in Britain that tracks the conflict through a network of contacts in Syria, reported that dozens of fighters had been killed, and that 20 had been wounded. A government offensive has been taking place in the mountainous Qalamoun region for several weeks, driving a new wave of refugees into Lebanon.

headline: Big Ticket | A Park Avenue Gem for $18 Million
abstract: A 10-room full-floor apartment in a Candela-designed building, with five terraces and views galore, was listed for the first time since 1943.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor apartment at the Rosario Candela-designed 778 Park Avenue at East 73rd Street, held by the estate of the New York City philanthropist Celeste Bartos, sold for $18 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. Listed for the first time since 1943, the 10-room full-floor unit, No. FL17, had a $22.5 million asking price and has $18,658.32 in monthly carrying costs.

headline: Maserati Recalls Cars; Mercedes-Benz Investigation Is Upgraded
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Maserati will recall 63 vehicles for electrical problems, and an N.H.T.S.A. investigation of more than 250,000 Mercedes-Benz cars has been upgraded.
lead_paragraph: Maserati will recall 63 of its 2014 Quattroporte GTS V8 models because of a possible loss of electrical power and a potential fire risk, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: In Sign of Strength, Audi Steps Up Investments
abstract: Audi, which like its German rivals has suffered less from the economic malaise in Europe than other carmakers, said it would spend more than $30 billion through 2018.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Audi, the luxury car unit of Volkswagen, said on Friday that it would spend more than it ever has on expansion and new models over the next four years, a demonstration of how Germany’s high-end carmakers have retained their financial strength during a crisis that has devastated their European rivals.

headline: Video: The Next-Generation Kia Soul Keeps Its Soul
abstract: Although it is improved in almost every way, the new Soul retains the mojo that made it a strong seller to begin with.
lead_paragraph: When Kia introduced the first-generation Soul for the 2010 model year, many dismissed it as a blatant rip-off of the Scion xB. Perhaps, but Soul went on to outsell the xB six to one. Who knew hamsters had that kind of disposable income (or could reach the pedals)?

headline: Vote on Monte dei Paschi’s Future Is Postponed
abstract: A decision on the timing of a €3 billion share issue at the Italian bank, which is also the world’s oldest, was delayed after too few shareholders turned up to vote.
lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — The latest chapter in the saga of Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, ended inconclusively Friday after a decision on a rescue plan was postponed amid a quarrel between top management and the bank’s largest shareholder.

headline: The Stars Inside the Building
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums']

lead_paragraph: The real estate industry in New York City continues to produce pricey new condominiums, seemingly at the rate of tennis balls spit out of a ball launcher. This market revival has pushed the role of the boldface architect back into the spotlight, although that position may have to be shared this time around with interior designers.

headline: Mission Schools Opened World to Africans, but Left an Ambiguous Legacy
abstract: The potentially subversive nature of Christianity’s teachings found expression in the education of a generation of rebels against apartheid.
lead_paragraph: Of the hundreds of pages in Nelson Mandela’s autobiography, “Long Walk to Freedom,” barely a dozen recount his college education at the University of Fort Hare, established by white Christian missionaries. He spent less than two of his 95 years there. Most obituaries made only a brief mention of that period.Mandela left Fort Hare partway through his studies during a conflict with its leader, a Scottish evangelist named Alexander Kerr, about a student boycott of college elections. “At that moment, I saw Dr. Kerr less as a benefactor than as a not-altogether-benign dictator,” Mandela wrote in his memoirs. As for himself, a 22-year-old at that point in late 1940, “I was in an unpleasant state of limbo.”

headline: Adding Citrus to Salads and Desserts
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, cooks with oranges, grapefruit and more.
lead_paragraph: I always stuff an orange or a tangerine into the toe of my son’s Christmas stocking. He is more interested in the chocolate in his stocking and I usually end up eating his orange, but I’ll never forego this European tradition that dates from a time when citrus was a rare treat. We in the United States take our oranges and grapefruit for granted year round, but citrus really does have a season — winter — and it is welcome at this time of year, when we need all the vitamin C we can get.

headline: Target’s Nightmare Goes On: Encrypted PIN Data Stolen
abstract: On Friday, Target confirmed that cybercriminals had managed to steal encrypted PIN data for its customers, in what is officially the second largest breach of a retailer in history.
lead_paragraph: After hackers stole credit and debit card records for 40 million Target store customers, the retailer said customers’ personal identification numbers, or PINs, had not been breached.

headline: Where Celebrity Assistants Go When They’re Losing Their Minds
abstract: “It’s tough to even own plants because you’re not home enough to water them, let alone be in a relationship.”
lead_paragraph: In this past weekend’s Lives column, Jessica Berger Gross, who worked as Bella Abzug’s personal assistant in the late ’90s, wrote about finding emotional support in a confidential gathering held by the Association of Celebrity Personal Assistants. Intrigued, we got in touch with one of the association’s founders, Rita Tateel, to find out more about the group.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: The Ronald McDonald House

lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, I asked readers to share stories of charities that had touched and inspired their families and sparked an urge to give in their children. headline: At Long Island Restaurants, Fondue Is Melted Comfort
abstract: Restaurants serve cheese and chocolate fondue with flavors ranging from classic to exotic.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, several groups of diners who had come in from the cold could be seen huddling around bubbling pots of cheese fondue at the Village Cheese Shop in Mattituck. “Nostalgic and interactive and warming” is how the owner of the 13-year-old-shop, Rosemary Dougherty Batcheller, 54, described the appeal of fondue. “You linger over it, and it has a festive feeling.”

headline: Children Need To Take Risks, and Parents Need to Let Them
abstract: The arguments for and against letting a child light the menorah—or peel potatoes, or, someday, take the train into the city on a Friday night. What is “ready,” anyway?
lead_paragraph: I’m haunted by a 3-year-old French girl in a buttercup-yellow dress. She’s a vague remnant from an article I read sometime in the last two to three years about the supreme competence of French children. While her mother chatted with a reporter in the living room, the girl very ably made cupcakes in the kitchen. In the years since I read the article, she periodically appears in my life as a rebuke against too much caution.

headline: Change Would Be Criminal

lead_paragraph: It used to be that when the Los Angeles-based novelist Jonathan Kellerman came to the city that never sleeps, he never slept either. “I was here all the time for book tours, for business with my publisher,” said Mr. Kellerman, 64, who is married to a fellow best-selling crime writer, Faye Kellerman. “I stayed at the best hotels, but they were always noisy and I never got a night’s rest.”

headline: Customizing Trips With a Computer Assist

lead_paragraph: Guidebooks and crowdsourced travel websites compete with advice on where to go. But the new site Trekkel attempts to automate a trip designer’s job by asking users to rate their interests and itemizing a custom list of recommendations in return.

headline: Through the Winter on a Locally Sourced Menu
abstract: Seagrass Grill is trying to use only fruits and vegetables, dairy products, meats and poultry that are locally produced and, whenever possible, organic.
lead_paragraph: Although chefs at farm-to-table restaurants in Connecticut build their menus around locally sourced ingredients, few match the commitment of Kim Dziubinski, the owner of Seagrass Grill in the Indian Neck neighborhood of Branford. She is making her way through its first winter — it opened in April — with the goal of using only fruits, vegetables, dairy products, meats and poultry that are locally produced and, whenever possible, organic.
