abstract: A new eight-unit condominium in West Chelsea designed with reinforced walls and ceiling lights.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of the High Line, the wildly popular elevated park, are quick to point out that it has catalyzed the redevelopment of West Chelsea. What may get lost in the enthusiasm is the fact that art galleries, too, have provided a major spark, going back to the 1990s, when they first began appearing amid factories in this longtime industrial area.

headline: Critics’ Picks: Recovery Is Paying Off
abstract: Two writers for the Automobiles section each pick their 12 favorite vehicles for 2013. The Mazda 3 tops both of their lists.
lead_paragraph: It was the year when Fisker fizzled and Coda collapsed, along with the dreams of several other would-be automakers. Tesla provided endless drama as its chief executive, Elon Musk, swatted at naysayers, state dealer associations and federal regulators, even as the Model S became a trophy car for the affluent and tech-savvy.

headline: Tune In, and Turn On the Reading Light
abstract: Mark Lewisohn discusses the first installment of his planned three-volume biography of The Beatles.
lead_paragraph: Mark Lewisohn never intended to become a Beatles biographer. His interest was mainly in pure research, and his first books were compilations of facts: an annotated listing of all the Beatles’ concerts (“The Beatles Live,” 1986); a descriptive catalog of the music, released and unreleased, in EMI archives (“The Beatles Recording Sessions: The Official Abbey Road Studio Sessions Notes, 1962-1970,” 1988); and a record of the group’s radio and television appearances (“The Complete Beatles Chronicle,” 1992). Around the time his recording sessions book was published, he described the market for Beatles biographies as oversaturated.

headline: Ale’s Not Just for Drinking
abstract: Gastro pubs popping up across Westchester have brought hundreds of craft beers to the attention of diners, and some chefs, too.
lead_paragraph: Gastro pubs have been popping up across Westchester for several years, bringing hundreds of craft beers to diners’ attention, from light lagers to imperial stouts. Along with interesting food, these gastro pubs will offer 10, sometimes 20 different drafts at a time and dozens of bottled choices, including those from Captain Lawrence, the eight-year-old Elmsford brewery that makes about 15 different brews, and Yonkers Brewing Co., founded in 2010. Peekskill Brewery, an ambitious restaurant in that Hudson River town, even makes its own beer.

headline: Distributor Apologizes for Movie Posters Ignoring Chiwetel Ejiofor
abstract: The distribution company marketing “12 Years a Slave” in Italy apologized for posters that focused on two white supporting actors rather than Chiwetel Ejiofor, the film’s star.
lead_paragraph: BIM Distribuzione, the film distribution company that is marketing “12 Years a Slave” in Italy, has formally apologized for distributing posters and publicity materials that played down Chiwetel Ejiofor, the black actor who is the film’s protagonist, while prominently featuring two white supporting actors: Michael Fassbender, who plays a sadistic slave owner, and Brad Pitt, who has a small role as a laborer.

abstract: The continued hard feelings over the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York suggest that the dispute could have a long-term impact on a relationship both sides say is crucial.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s diplomatic corps, still seething over the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York, continued its tit-for-tat campaign against American diplomats this week, revoking privileges, beginning tax investigations and issuing new consular identity cards that say the card holder can be arrested for serious offenses.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A court in Moscow on Friday withdrew an arrest warrant for the Russian banker Sergei Pugachev, the owner of the French luxury food chain Hédiard, a day after the warrant’s issuance had been prominently reported in the Russian business newspaper Kommersant.

headline: A Refusal Stands Strong, 32 Years Later
abstract: Jennifer Holliday performs “And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going” and other songs at her new show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: It has been 32 years since Jennifer Holliday unleashed on the world her version of “And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going,” in the original Broadway production of “Dreamgirls,” and pop-gospel belting hasn’t been the same since. Like the sound of thunder rolling off a mountain, its echoes cascading for miles, Ms. Holliday’s voice resounded with a power that combined the range of Sarah Vaughan with the fervor of Aretha Franklin. And at Thursday’s sensational opening-night show of her debut at 54 Below, Ms. Holliday infused that howl of refusal with the same defiant, fearsome intensity she displayed onstage three decades earlier.

headline: Aiming to Reinvent Itself, Panasonic Moves Beyond the Living Room
abstract: As it backs away from consumer electronics, Panasonic is focusing on two less visible but more profitable areas — homes and cars.
lead_paragraph: FUJISAWA, Japan — Panasonic used to make televisions, refrigerators and computer monitors in this suburb of Tokyo. Now, six years after closing its factories in Fujisawa, the company is building homes on the site, which is sandwiched between Mount Fuji and the Pacific.

headline: A Year of Teasing at Shapes to Come (and Sometimes Just Teasing)
abstract: The international auto shows of 2013 showcased many futuristic design studies and fanciful concept cars. Here are the highlights.
lead_paragraph: As in most years, the international auto salons of 2013 showcased scores of futuristic design studies and fanciful concept cars among their attractions. Some of the vehicles were merely exercises in styling fantasy; others hinted at exciting, mold-breaking production cars to come.

headline: Plug In, Turn On, Pass Gas Station
abstract: Cars with plugs are finding more buyers, with sales doubling since 2012, but they were still a tiny fraction of the 15 million vehicles sold in 2013.
lead_paragraph: When the final figures for 2013 are tabulated, sales of battery-electric and plug-in vehicles in the United States are expected to nearly double 2012’s totals, according to the Electric Drive Transportation Association, a trade group based in Washington. Even so, that is fewer than 100,000 vehicles, in a year when the industry is on track to comfortably top 15 million sales.

headline: Of Hovercraft, Heroes and Hens
abstract: Automotive odds and ends, mostly odd, from 2013 included a hovercraft with the appropriate futurist appeal and a chicken that confused a Rolls-Royce for a henhouse.
lead_paragraph: We writers enjoy bemoaning that there are no more surprises in the automotive world, but the last 12 months was full of them, from an exhaust note that caused constant double-takes to a Rolls with unexpected avian appeal. And then, of course, there was the hovercraft.

headline: The Independent Journal Esopus, Still Going Strong After a Decade of Publishing
abstract: These might be difficult times for print magazines, but the beloved Esopus, which just published its tenth-anniversary issue with work by Matthew Weiner, keeps on keeping on.
lead_paragraph: It takes chutzpah to start a print publication these days, and a loose grip on reality to imagine that it could last a decade. But the biannual journal Esopus defied the odds last month when it published its 20th issue, “Special Collections,” which features work by Matthew Weiner, the creator of “Mad Men.” Tod Lippy, the magazine’s affable founder and editor, is a one-man masthead, conceiving and executing every issue with assistance only from interns who get paid in lifetime subscriptions.

headline: Spiritual and Prolific, in an Era of Upheaval
abstract: “Francesco Vanni: Art in Late Renaissance Siena” at Yale University Art Gallery, offers a look at European art during an era of revival and reformation of the Catholic church in the 1500s.
lead_paragraph: You can generally depend on Italian Renaissance art for tasteful, traditional Christmas imagery, and “Francesco Vanni: Art in Late Renaissance Siena” at Yale University Art Gallery delivers plenty of Madonnas, angels and adorable infants. But it also offers a view of European art at a moment of upheaval and of an artist working in the centers of religious power and responding to these changes.

headline: What the Tipsy Peasant Knew
abstract: In France, onion soup is considered a balm for hangovers, or simple comfort for the winter weary.
lead_paragraph: For those who imbibe with abandon on New Year’s Eve and need soothing relief the day after, soup may be the answer. Some swear by a big bowlful of menudo: spicy Mexican tripe soup topped with chopped raw onion, chiles and a squeeze of lime. There’s Korean hae jang gook, a heady concoction of ox blood, meaty bones, bean sprouts and dried cabbage. The list of possibilities is long. Every nation seems to have a surefire hangover cure to recommend.

He was Little Thunder, a Lakota leader and a contemporary of Crazy Horse, whose life spanned several decades central to the history of the tribe — from the battles it fought across the Great Plains to its resettlement on reservations.

headline: Medicare to Cover More Mental Health Costs
abstract: Effective Jan. 1, Medicare will cover the costs of mental health care much as it does other medical expenses.
lead_paragraph: For decades, older adults with depression, anxiety and other psychological conditions have received unequal treatment under Medicare. The program paid a smaller share of the bill for therapy from psychiatrists, psychologists or clinical social workers than it did for medical services. And Medicare imposed strict lifetime limits on stays in psychiatric hospitals, although no such limits applied to medical care received in inpatient facilities.

On Sundays he tries to dial it back, so he can unwind with his wife, Fernanda Capobianco, 32, owner of the bakery Vegan Divas; prepare and share good food with friends in the couple’s Turtle Bay apartment; and take his mind off business for a day.

headline: First Attempts Fail to Free Ship Stranded by Heavy Ice
abstract: Icebreakers sent to free a stranded Russian research ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, off Antarctica were stopped by heavy ice within sight of the ship, officials said early Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Icebreakers sent to free a stranded Russian research ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, off Antarctica were stopped by heavy ice within sight of the ship, officials said early Saturday. A Chinese icebreaker in the area, the Xue Long, or Snow Dragon, was asked to divert toward the Shokalskiy, which is carrying members of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition and became stuck in the ice on Tuesday about 1,700 miles south of Tasmania. A spokeswoman for the Australian Maritime Safety Authority said the Xue Long was about seven miles from the Shokalskiy when the ice became too thick to cut through. A French icebreaker also could not clear a path to the ship, said an expedition spokesman. The ships will await the arrival of an Australian icebreaker, which has a greater icebreaking capacity, he said.

headline: The Faces Behind the Counter
abstract: A glimpse of fast-food workers, men and women, young and old, some of whom have shed their anonymity and joined a year-old effort to achieve an increased wage of $15 an hour.
lead_paragraph: When we eat at a McDonald’s or a Burger King, we rarely pay attention to the people behind the counter. Our eyes are often focused upward on the brightly lighted menus, or perhaps downward on our smartphones or watches. But according to employment statistics, more than 55,000 people work in fast-food restaurants in New York City, and the number is rapidly increasing. Many of them earn the minimum wage: $7.25 an hour, increasing on Jan. 1 to $8. Forty percent are 25 or older. More than a quarter are parents raising children.

headline: The Freedmen of Wisconsin
abstract: How hundreds of emancipated slaves ended up living in the Badger State.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1862, a 31-year-old slave named Samuel Mathews and his family freed themselves by escaping from their plantation in Franklin County, Ala. With the army of Union Gen. William Rosecrans nearby, local Confederates had been talking of impressing Mathews into service as a cook. Unwilling to serve the rebel army, Samuel, his 25-year-old wife, Sarah, their 8-year-old son, Richard, and their 7-year-old daughter, Ellen, snuck away to a Union Army camp in nearby Tuscumbia, in the northwest corner of the state. But it was only the first step in their journey to freedom, which would last eight months and finish 700 miles north in the unlikely locale of rural Dodge County, Wis.

lead_paragraph: This is the season of lists: roundups and recaps, forecasts and resolutions.

headline: Finessing Typewriters for Nearly 40 Years, and Now Turning Over the Keys
abstract: Bino Gan, who started working in his brother’s typewriter repair shop after immigrating from the Philippines in 1976, is closing the shop he founded in 1987.
lead_paragraph: Bino Gan has never seen any of Woody Allen’s movies, but in his own way he has helped in the writing of them. Mr. Gan has made sure that the famous Olympia typewriter Mr. Allen uses to write his screenplays is always in good pecking order.

headline: In Miracle Season, Auburn Breaks a Machine
abstract: A bit of overachieving, some wacky plays and a few huge wins put the Tigers on course to play for a national title.
lead_paragraph: The Auburn football program has a thing for slogans. “All In” was the rallying cry a couple of years ago. “Together” showed up on shirts this season, a “Season of Miracles” in which “Destiny” was big, alongside the perennial catchphrase “Family” — the kind of stuff you hear on corporate retreats or in Hallmark specials.

keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Bankruptcies', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Police', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Desert Hot Springs is sliding into bankruptcy for familiar reasons: unrealistic revenue estimates and too-generous pension promises to city workers.
lead_paragraph: DESERT HOT SPRINGS, Calif. — Emerging from Los Angeles’s vast eastern sprawl, the freeway glides over a narrow pass and slips gently into the scrubby, palm-flecked Coachella Valley.

headline: Despair at Guantánamo
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Hunger Strikes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The delivery of credible justice for those at the prison camp remains far from complete.
lead_paragraph: In April, when a hunger strike by detainees at the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was in its third month, Pentagon officials agreed with defense lawyers that the underlying cause was a growing despair among prisoners who have been in detention for a decade with no hope of getting out. The protest, which at its height involved 106 of the 166 prisoners there this summer, served to put the Guantánamo issue back on the radar in Washington.

headline: Singapore’s Angry Migrant Workers
abstract: The government must ensure higher pay and an end to the abuse.
lead_paragraph: Frustration among Singapore’s unappreciated and underpaid migrant workers has been building in recent years as their numbers have grown faster than the country can accommodate them. Tensions boiled over earlier this month, after a 33-year-old Indian migrant worker was killed by a bus in the Little India neighborhood. A crowd of fellow workers from South Asia gathered at the scene. Their anger quickly escalated, with some 400 people pelting stones, attacking emergency responders and setting fire to vehicles. It was the worst riot to hit Singapore, one of the world’s most orderly countries, since 1969.

headline: This Week, Mass Surveillance Wins
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Editorials']
abstract: Congressional action is urgently needed after a federal court upholds the N.S.A. phone dragnet.
lead_paragraph: Has the National Security Agency’s mass collection of Americans’ phone records actually helped to prevent terrorist attacks?

headline: Summer Camp That Makes a Difference
abstract: The Neediest Cases Fund brings rewards to a painfully shy boy and relief to his mother.
lead_paragraph: Yancy Rivera’s son Brian, 11, is autistic and painfully shy. Summers used to be the worst time, with Brian out of school and spending his days watching TV. So Ms. Rivera, a single mother who works in a Lower East Side pharmacy to support him and his older brother, began searching three years ago for a summer day camp.

headline: Paul Blair, Center Fielder for Champions, Dies at 69
abstract: Perhaps the finest outfielder of his era, Mr. Blair was known for his speed and grace, and for his ability to read a hitter’s swing and make a quick break on a fly ball.
lead_paragraph: Paul Blair, the fleet and elegant ball hawk who roamed center field for four World Series champions, the Baltimore Orioles twice and the Yankees twice, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 69.

headline: Rocket’s Day at Line Costs Grizzly Who Cries Foul
abstract: Memphis’s Zach Randolph was fined $25,000 for criticizing the referees who sent Houston’s James Harden to the foul line 25 times Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of a long N.B.A. season, it is not uncommon to see a player, or more often a coach, punished by the N.B.A. for publicly criticizing the refereeing in a game.

headline: Snooker Star Who Walked Away Races to Title
abstract: Ronnie O’Sullivan, perhaps the finest snooker player in history, quit the game in 2012 but changed his mind and won his fifth world title.
lead_paragraph: Imagine Rafael Nadal walking away from tennis for a year and then returning to win Wimbledon. Or imagine Tiger Woods winning the Masters and then threatening to quit golf for good. That is akin to what happened in 2013 with the Englishman Ronnie O’Sullivan, perhaps the finest snooker player in history.

headline: 2,500 Pigs Join Debate Over Farms vs. Scenery
abstract: The installation of a 2,500-pig farm in a major tourist area has raised questions about the environmental impact of such operations.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT JUDEA, Ark. — Anita Hudson’s moment of realization came early this year when she saw cement trucks whizzing past her home in this blip of an Ozark town. For Sam Dye, it was when an employee at the school where he once was principal pointed out bulldozers clearing a wooded area in the distance.

lead_paragraph: The Hartford Whalers of the N.H.L. departed in 1997, packing their bags, pads and sticks and moving to North Carolina, where the franchise was reborn as the Carolina Hurricanes.

headline: Reassured or Not, Knicks Still Look Overburdened
abstract: A day after James L. Dolan’s impromptu meeting with his embattled team, the Knicks fell to the Toronto Raptors as fans booed vociferously and fled to the exits early.
lead_paragraph: A day after James L. Dolan’s impromptu meeting with his embattled team, not much changed for the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Nets Get Off the Mat, but Heavyweights Loom on the Schedule
abstract: After showing glimpses of promising play in a victory against Milwaukee, the Nets begin a three-game trip Saturday against Indiana, San Antonio and Oklahoma City.
lead_paragraph: In a week when their tumultuous season may have reached its lowest point — a week marred by back-to-back 17-point losses, a season-ending injury to the All-Star center Brook Lopez and reports of locker-room turmoil — the Nets finished a three-game home stand by showing a glimpse of the play that many had envisioned when they talked of a title contender budding in Brooklyn.

headline: In War of Attrition, a Giants Rookie Remains Unscathed
abstract: The rookie right tackle Justin Pugh is poised to become the first Giants opening-round draft choice to start every game as a rookie since Lawrence Taylor became a fixture in 1981.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Pugh, the Giants’ rookie right tackle, refers to the N.F.L. as the “Not for Long” league. After the wrenching changes he has observed in the team’s offensive line and elsewhere, no one can blame him for developing such cynicism at an early age.

headline: Cruz Wants Tighter Connection to Manning
abstract: Giants receiver Victor Cruz said quarterback Eli Manning and the receiving corps have to build a better rapport during the off-season.
lead_paragraph: Victor Cruz said Friday that there was an obvious disconnect between Eli Manning and the Giants’ wide receivers this season, which may have contributed to Manning’s career high in interceptions.

headline: Fletcher Lasted Where Most Don’t
abstract: On Sunday, London Fletcher, a Washington linebacker, will play in his 256th straight game, the third-longest streak in N.F.L. history for a player who was not a kicker.
lead_paragraph: In the 1998 N.F.L. draft, more than 30 linebackers were selected. But the only linebacker to enter the league that season who is still playing today is London Fletcher, who was not drafted and provides one of the more remarkable stories in league history.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 27
abstract: Subjects include: Santa’s bag of presents in Herald Square, a Christmas pageant at a church in Manhattan and a foggy view of the Hudson River from Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include: Santa’s bag of presents in Herald Square, a Christmas pageant at a church in Manhattan and a foggy view of the Hudson River from Harlem.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) WARM BODIES (2013) “The zombie romance ‘Warm Bodies’ is cute and amusing enough to catch on cable one day, where its star-crossed, blood-drenched lovers will eventually present sweet relief from the apocalyptic freakout that is the AMC series ‘The Walking Dead,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this twist on the zombie genre, written and directed by Jonathan Levine and based on the novel by Isaac Marion. Nicholas Hoult plays a zombie; Teresa Palmer, above with Mr. Hoult, is Julie, the living girl he strangely does not want to eat; and John Malkovich plays Julie’s father, who threatens to keep the star-crossed lovers apart.

headline: Fire on Indian Express Train Kills Dozens
abstract: More than two dozen passengers were killed and seven others were badly injured when an express train traveling through the center of India caught fire early Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — More than two dozen passengers, many of them headed home for the holidays, were killed early Saturday when an express train traveling through the center of India caught fire.

headline: Delhi’s New Leader Vows to Halt Corruption
abstract: Arvind Kejriwal, who swept into office on an anticorruption campaign, pledged Saturday to arrest anyone in his government who demanded a bribe.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Standing before a crowd estimated in the tens of thousands, Delhi’s unlikely new leader, swept into office on an anticorruption campaign, was sworn in Saturday, and he vowed to arrest anyone in his government, from police officer to bureaucrat, who demanded a bribe.

abstract: No one immediately took responsibility, but the Taliban, which accuses the United States of using a drive to eradicate polio as a cover for spying, has threatened health workers who immunize children.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A health worker supervising a polio vaccination campaign was fatally shot and two others were wounded on Saturday when gunmen opened fire at a hospital in northwestern Pakistan, officials said.

headline: The Merchant of Just Be Happy
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: The life coach Martha Beck has made a lot of money from a simple theme: If it feels right, go for it. She wants both women and men to conquer the “soul-sucking” forces around them.
lead_paragraph: On a cool mid-September afternoon at the California horse ranch of the life coach Martha Beck, two blindfolded, crouching men came to an impasse. The men had been told to think of themselves as animals and to use only their sense of hearing to try to locate and tag each other — all in an effort to awaken the senses and instincts presumably deadened by desk jobs and smartphones.

headline: A Second Wind From an Injured Knee
abstract: An executive turned ski instructor has joined the ranks of baby-boomer entrepreneurs — by starting a company that makes biomechanically engineered tights for knee support.
lead_paragraph: When Kim Gustafson moved to Vail Valley in Colorado more than a decade ago, he was 54 and had recently retired as an executive in the office-equipment business. But he wasn’t ready to stop working. “I’m not the type of person who wanted to play checkers,” he says.

headline: Reading Your Palm for Security’s Sake
abstract: The use of biometric scans for consumer identification is growing, but some experts are concerned about the data being hacked or misused.
lead_paragraph: They aren’t taking any chances at Barclays Bank in Britain. Stating an account number and other bona fides isn’t enough to get to your money at the bank’s wealth and investment management service. As an additional safeguard, a program analyzes customers’ voices when they call in, to make sure they match a voice print on file.

abstract: Shareholders derailed a plan by management to raise urgently needed new cash, leaving the bank’s future in limbo.
lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Shareholders in Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, derailed a plan by management to raise urgently needed new cash, leaving the bank’s future in limbo and illustrating the conflict in crisis-ridden Italy between change and tradition.

headline: Alive, and Living in the Moment
abstract: Jeff Bauman lost his legs in the Boston Marathon bombings, and his easygoing manner has helped him through much of what he has encountered.
lead_paragraph: If you have heard Jeff Bauman’s name, you have probably seen the photograph, of him clutching what was left of his left leg, being wheeled off by a man in a cowboy hat near the finish line of the Boston Marathon. Because of the photograph, Bauman became a face of the bombings that day in April.

headline: Signs of a Russian Thaw (Toward Business)
abstract: In a country where entrepreneurs are scorned (or worse), an influential voice is speaking up for them — carefully.
lead_paragraph: It was just after 9 on a mid-May morning in 2011 when Ruslan Telkov got into his car and headed toward one of his upholstery company’s warehouses near Moscow. His parents had warned him not to start his own business, that only frustration and heartache awaited, if not worse. But it was not the 1990s anymore, he told them; the days of bandit capitalism in Russia were over. “I decided it’s what I wanted, and that was that,” he said.

headline: When Giants’ Season Ends, Effort to Avoid a Similar One Begins
abstract: The responsibility for the team’s first losing season since 2004 can be traced to expensive and risky gambles on injury-prone and aging players, exposing an absence of depth.
lead_paragraph: It was late on a mid-October night when Eli Manning’s voice cracked, a trembling quiver that said what everyone around him already knew: The 2013 Giants season, after six weeks, was irretrievably broken and ruined.

headline: Big Decisions for Jets, and Not Just on the Coach
abstract: Surrounding Geno Smith or a starting quarterback to be determined with more offensive talent, particularly at receiver, is imperative to the team’s success in 2014.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The sentiment expressed most often by Rex Ryan over the last week — aside from his pledging that, no, he has not thought about his uncertain future — is that the Jets are an ascending team. It is his steadfast belief that they have an enviable foundation, especially on defense, and a young core that will expand through free agency and the draft.

lead_paragraph: A train traveling between Nanded and Bangalore caught fire at 3:30 a.m. on Saturday. An electrical short-circuit was suspected as the cause, according to local media reports.

lead_paragraph: TAKETOMI, Japan — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s conservative government has begun to pursue a more openly nationalist agenda on an issue that critics fear will push the country farther from its postwar pacifism: adding a more patriotic tone to Japan’s school textbooks.

headline: Members of Jewish Student Group Test Permissible Discussion on Israel
abstract: Swarthmore’s Hillel rebelled this month, saying it would not abide by its parent group’s guidelines prohibiting collaboration with speakers or groups deemed unsupportive of Israel.
lead_paragraph: At Harvard, the Jewish student group Hillel was barred from co-sponsoring a discussion with a Palestinian student group. At Binghamton University, a Hillel student leader was forced to resign his position after showing a film about Palestinians and inviting the filmmaker’s brother to speak. And on many other campuses, Hillel chapters have been instructed to reject collaboration with left-leaning Jewish groups.

headline: Warriors Duo Leads a Flood of 3-Pointers
abstract: Klay Thompson and Stephen Curry, who make up the starting backcourt for the Golden State Warriors, are shooting 3-pointers more often than any other teammates have before.
lead_paragraph: Klay Thompson and Stephen Curry, who make up the starting backcourt for the Golden State Warriors, are shooting 3-pointers more often than any other teammates have before. They are 1-2 in the N.B.A. in 3-pointers and 3-point attempts. And in a league that has gone crazy for the 3-point shot, it could be argued that they are a rare case of players who should be shooting from long range even more.

lead_paragraph: The grocery shop in Newark was crowded on Monday, as customers picked up last-minute supplies for Christmas.

headline: A Choice, and a Second Chance
abstract: Gold-medal swimmer Missy Franklin resisted the siren call of professional sports in part because of what happened to Dagny Knutson, who turned pro after shining at the 2008 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Upon completing an interview with the American swimming sensation Missy Franklin on the University of California-Berkeley campus in October, a television reporter from Brazil, in a show of appreciation, gave a T-shirt to Franklin. She accepted it graciously, and then surreptitiously handed it to a coach who was standing nearby. The coach handed the T-shirt back to the television reporter with apologies, explaining that N.C.A.A. rules prohibit Franklin from accepting gifts.

lead_paragraph: The political talk shows will air their final editions of the year on Sunday, mostly looking back at a couple of issues that dominated the news in 2013 and won’t likely be forgotten in the new year.

abstract: Charles Rowan, an amateur cage fighter, faked his death but was later sentenced to prison in an armed robbery. The reporter told his tale in the long-form article “Tomato Can Blues.”
lead_paragraph: In order to keep himself alive, Charles Rowan had to die.

headline: West Virginia Democrats Face an Uneasy Time
abstract: Long a backbone of the Democratic Party, West Virginia has an accelerating rightward tilt that could affect next year’s Senate race.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Although Democrats have owned West Virginia’s two Senate seats since the Eisenhower administration, Republicans are eyeing this state as one of their best bets as they seek to win a Senate majority next year.

headline: At City Ballet and Elsewhere, In Jokes Take the Stage
abstract: Some shows, including New York City Ballet’s “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” incorporate secret homages to their creators, sometimes disguised in the costumes or the set.
lead_paragraph: Even the most devoted ballet fans, who catch “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” every year at the David H. Koch Theater, tend not to realize that Balanchine still makes a cameo appearance in each performance of the dance, which he created in 1954.

headline: When Reality Doesn’t Fit the Narrative
abstract: In his junior football season at South Carolina, Jadeveon Clowney did not meet the expectations set up for him by hyperbolic news coverage.
lead_paragraph: Legends — by definition romanticized myths and unverified stories — are impossible to live up to. Jadeveon Clowney found that out this season.

headline: A Celebration of Running and Diversity
abstract: A West Side Runners Club celebration after the New York City Marathon included a table that held Ethiopian injera bread, Mexican tamales and Ecuadorean ceviche.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday night after the New York City Marathon in November, members of the West Side Runners Club celebrated their year of racing at the Upper West Side co-op of the group’s president, Bill Staab.

headline: A Civil Servant in Mexico Tests U.S. on Asylum
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Drug Cartels', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Mexican officials have become frustrated by a local official who has provided residents with letters describing their area’s drug violence to help them seek asylum in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LA RUANA, Mexico — Jittery families cram into his tiny office here, daily. Hundreds more have appeared at the San Diego border 1,500 miles away, clutching an official-looking letter bearing his name, gambling that its description of the violence in this blistering stretch of central Mexico will help them gain asylum in the United States.

headline: No Cheer for the Jobless
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Federal unemployment benefits expire while Congress enjoys a holiday.
lead_paragraph: The House Republicans who refused to renew expiring federal jobless benefits before leaving Washington for an extended Christmas break have shown no inclination to revisit the issue when they return to work in January. This is unconscionable. In each of the previous seven major recessions, dating back to 1958, Congress has never let federal benefits expire when the need has been as great as it is today. And for good reason. Prematurely ending benefits inflicts needless harm on families — the average benefit is about $270 a week — as well as avoidable damage on the economy by denting essential spending.

headline: 12 Years of Mayor Bloomberg
abstract: Despite policy mistakes, he will leave a lasting and largely beneficial imprint on New York City.
lead_paragraph: When he walked into the mayor’s office 12 years ago, businessman and billionaire Michael Bloomberg took charge of a damaged city. The World Trade Center was a windblown construction site, barely cleared after the attacks on Sept. 11. Tourists were afraid to come to the city; residents were afraid to stay. The budget was a disaster, $3 billion to $5 billion in the red. In a modest speech at an intentionally modest inauguration, Mr. Bloomberg nevertheless pledged to rebuild and renew New York and to keep it “the capital of the free world.”

headline: Words for the Dumpster
abstract: The most annoying locutions of the year.
lead_paragraph: WITH the last tick of 2013, let’s throw out the most annoying, overused and abused words of the year. A few of these terms, “twerking” or “stay classy,” die a natural death when someone like John McCain starts using them — the aural equivalent of a comb-over. Others need a push.

headline: When Demons Are Real
abstract: In Africa, encounters with a God different from that of United States evangelicals.
lead_paragraph: SOME months ago, on a warm Friday evening in Accra, Ghana, I found myself in an all-night prayer session with a charismatic evangelical church. All-night prayer has become wildly popular in the city, somewhat to the distress of those who object to the late-night noise, which rivals that of an American frat party.

headline: Confessions of a Columnist
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Here is a look at my three biggest mistakes of 2013.
lead_paragraph: IN ancient Sanskrit, the word “pundit” meant “wise man” or “religious sage.” In modern English, it means “often wrong, rarely accountable.” There are ways that those of us who scribble about politics can avoid living down to that reputation — by keeping our predictions vague (it worked for Nostradamus), by sticking to sure things (I told you Herman Cain wouldn’t be elected president), or by deploying weasel words like “it’s possible that ...” at every opportunity. But time, chance and fallibility eventually make false prophets of us all.

headline: When the Mentally Ill Own Guns
abstract: People who brandish guns, threaten others and even admit to mental illness are able to get around the police.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers who refuse to support effective gun safety measures often prefer to talk about better screening of the mentally ill to identify deranged would-be perpetrators before they can carry out mass shootings. This is, of course, a political dodge. Even in the handful of states where law enforcement agencies are trying to confiscate the guns of unstable individuals, state and federal laws too often enable the mentally ill to reclaim their guns as a right under the Second Amendment.

headline: Bitcoin Is Evil
abstract: There’s an agenda there, and it’s a bad one.
lead_paragraph: It’s always important, and always hard, to distinguish positive economics — how things work — from normative economics — how things should be. Indeed, on many of the macro issues I’ve written about it has been obvious that large numbers of economists can’t bring themselves to make that distinction; they dislike activist government on political grounds, and this leads them to make really bad arguments about why fiscal stimulus can’t work and monetary stimulus will be disastrous. I don’t, by the way, think that this effect is symmetric: although people like Robert Lucas were quick to accuse people like Christy Romer of fabricating macro arguments to support a big-government agenda, this didn’t actually happen.

headline: Game Theory: The Year of the Blockbuster
abstract: Many noted indie video games were released in 2013, but major studios grabbed the headlines.
lead_paragraph: When I look back at a year of playing video games in 2013, many of my favorite moments come from the putatively soulless games made by hundreds of people on behalf of multinational corporations. Among them are Ellie’s discovery of the giraffes in Utah in The Last of Us, along with the joy of getting to play as Ellie in the sequence called “Winter,” and the bleakness of the game’s final seconds, which sit alongside the end of the movie “Blue Jasmine” as the most unforgiving closing scenes in all of entertainment this year. Also memorable is Trevor’s May-December romance with Patricia Madrazo in Grand Theft Auto V, revealing the tender side of a psychopath, capped by the long, bittersweet drive back to Martin Madrazo’s house while listening to Chicago’s “If You Leave Me Now.” And in BioShock Infinite what stuck with me was everything from the game’s audacious first hour or so, the racist Boxer Rebellion and Battle of Wounded Knee exhibitions from the Hall of Heroes, and listening to Elizabeth sing “Will the Circle Be Unbroken.”

headline: Calder Lawsuit Dismissed
abstract: A $20 million fraud lawsuit filed by the heirs of the sculptor Alexander Calder against the estate of his art dealer, Klaus G. Perls, has been dismissed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A $20 million fraud lawsuit filed by the heirs of the sculptor Alexander Calder against the estate of his art dealer, Klaus G. Perls, has been dismissed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The suit claimed that Perls and his family held on to hundreds of Calder’s works, cheated the artist’s estate out of tens of millions of dollars over the course of three decades and sold fake Calder works. According to the decision by Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich, made public last week, the various claims are “an incoherent stew of irrelevance and innuendo” and the evidence failed to show that any fraud had been committed. “All these allegations are so patently inadequate that the court can only conclude that they were brought solely for the purpose of harassment or embarrassment,” Judge Kornreich said. The lawsuit was filed in 2010, two years after Mr. Perls died. His wife, Dolly, and employees of his gallery have also died. Calder died in 1976, leaving Judge Kornreich to conclude, “Plaintiffs are attempting to litigate issues that necessarily stretch back decades without any personal knowledge or contemporaneous records, where nearly all of the people who had personal knowledge of the facts of the case are dead.” Perls represented Calder for more than 20 years, and they were considered friends who frequently dined and traveled together and visited each other’s families. The Calder Foundation, which is devoted to collecting, cataloging and archiving Calder works, could not be reached for comment on Sunday.

headline: In the Name of Winning, the Cubs Kept Losing
abstract: The Chicago Cubs were willing to lose this season in hopes of building a team of young stars for the future.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a half-century ago, entering another dismal year in another dismal decade, the Chicago Cubs named Leo Durocher as their manager. He appraised the talent on his 1966 roster and said, “This is not an eighth-place ball club.” That observation was more or less correct. The Cubs went on to finish 10th in the 10-team National League.

abstract: The Giants ended a disappointing season on a positive note with a 20-6 home victory over the Washington Redskins, but Eli Manning was injured and played only the first half.
lead_paragraph: The Giants ended a disappointing season on a positive note with a 20-6 home victory over the Washington Redskins, but Eli Manning was injured and played only the first half.

headline: With A-Fib Rhythms, Higher Odds of Stroke
abstract: About three million Americans have atrial fibrillation, a heart rhythm abnormality that significantly increases the risk of stroke.
lead_paragraph: When a lean, healthy, physically active person has a stroke, seemingly out of the blue, the cause may well be a heart rhythm abnormality called atrial fibrillation.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (Sundance) THREE KINGS (1999) George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg and Ice Cube, from left above, are American soldiers who discover a map to an Iraqi bunker filled with gold at the end of the gulf war in this film directed by David O. Russell. But their plan for a simple heist becomes more complicated when they choose to help a group of Iraqi rebels escape to Iran. “The Pandora’s box of camera tricks that is opened here must surely have been intended to capture the speed and disorientation of wartime experience, and the jittery atmosphere in which soldiers’ snap judgments are made,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. But “it takes a sure hand to know when to eliminate the superfluous and let a story unfold on its own terms,” she added. “When Mr. Russell begins to do that in the latter half of ‘Three Kings,’ his film begins homing in on the political and moral conundrums that were always at the heart of this material.”

abstract: The Warriors, making their first extended trip east this season, have the speed and size to give the Heat trouble.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A

headline: At the End, the Telltale Runners’ Bags
abstract: There were hundreds of unclaimed bags hours after the explosions at the Boston Marathon, and each bag belonged to a runner, and each runner had a story.
lead_paragraph: It had been only a few hours since the bombs had gone off at the Boston Marathon and I was among those in a stupor. As a runner and a reporter, I had long relished the boringness of the sport. Throw on a pair of sneakers, get to the finish line. Simple.

headline: An Underdog’s Tale, Half Written
abstract: A mesmerizing shooting display gave a final glimmer of hope to the last underdog in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: The upstarts of the N.C.A.A. tournament hailed from Dunk City (Florida Gulf Coast) and unspooled Southwest Philly Floaters (LaSalle) and redefined nicknames, those mighty Shockers of Wichita State becoming known less for wheat than for, ahem, shock. All lingered as long as they could, but by April 8, night of the national championship game, the underdogs had packed up and returned to campus.

headline: German Juggernaut, Led by Spaniard
abstract: Bayern Munich won five titles, including the Club World Cup, but it still has more international aspirations.
lead_paragraph: The best in German engineering (in terms of soccer) had a trophy in its hands and a new Spanish driver. What could Bayern Munich and Coach Pep Guardiola possibly do for an encore?

headline: Bomb Attacks in Russia Echo Threats by Chechen Insurgent
abstract: Two terrorist attacks in Volgograd have sowed widespread fear across the country, and the attention of Russian security services has turned to the insurgent leader, Doku Umarov.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Twin terrorist attacks in the city of Volgograd within 24 hours injected new urgency on Monday into Russia’s long, ruthless effort to contain a diffuse Islamic insurgency on its southern border, one nominally led by a veteran, battle-scarred Chechen often called Russia’s Osama bin Laden.

headline: Young, Injured and in Limbo
abstract: From Derrick Rose to Matt Harvey, promising athletes were felled by a laundry list of ailments and, perhaps, overly optimistic expectations.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be Derrick Rose’s year.

headline: Egypt Detains Journalists It Says Aired ‘False News’
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The arrests of people working for the Al Jazeera English news channel appeared aimed at deterring journalists from reporting on the Muslim Brotherhood’s continuing protests.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian authorities detained a team of journalists working for the Al Jazeera English news channel on Sunday, including an Australian correspondent and the channel’s Canadian-Egyptian bureau chief, accusing them of broadcasting illegally and meeting with members of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that the Egyptian government classified a terrorist organization last week.

headline: At City Ballet, Footwear Is Almost as Important as Feet
abstract: Slamming her shoes against a wall before going onstage in “The Nutcracker” is just one of many alterations the Sugar Plum Fairy makes to her ballet shoes to dance en pointe.
lead_paragraph: As the sets were silently put in place for a recent performance of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” the evening’s Sugar Plum Fairy, the petite and graceful Tiler Peck, was behind the stage making a few last-minute adjustments to her toe shoes.

keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: All humanity — from the peasant farmer to the society lady to the secret policeman — comes through the dentist’s clinic.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Novelists work hard to acquire human experience. They search for characters who might inspire them. They go to unusual places to collect the necessary material for their novels.

headline: Doctors Say Racing’s Schumacher Is ‘Fighting for His Life’
abstract: The seven-time Formula One champion Michael Schumacher underwent brain surgery after a skiing accident on Sunday in the French Alps.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Michael Schumacher, the most successful driver in the history of Formula One motor racing, with seven world drivers’ championships, is “fighting for his life” with brain injuries sustained on Sunday when he hit his head on a rock in a skiing accident in the French Alps, his doctors said on Monday.

abstract: What you need to know for Monday: crime mostly falls, cold weather ahead, and the first daughter likes heavy metal.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:11 a.m.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter’s Stock Soars, Reflecting Exuberance in Silicon Valley
abstract: Tech stocks may not quite have returned to the anything-goes dot-com era, but Twitter shares’ rapid rise is a sign of giddiness in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Max Ganik has no doubts that Twitter’s stock — up 145 percent since it first began trading on Nov. 7 — is firmly in bubble territory, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: China Orders Officials to Stop Smoking in Public
abstract: Smoking is one of China’s most serious public health problems, and critics ask if the latest move to curb tobacco use will be any more effective than previous efforts.
lead_paragraph: China is stepping up efforts to ban smoking in public places by ordering Communist Party officials to “lead by example” and refrain from smoking in government offices, schools, hospitals, sports and cultural venues and on public transport. Party officials have also been ordered to ask others not to smoke in public.

headline: The Year That Will Be
abstract: A precap of news sure to happen in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Late December is traditionally a time to recap the year’s news, but do we really have the stomach for it in 2013? Let’s look ahead, with a precap of news sure to happen in 2014.

headline: Behind the Cover: Henry Leutwyler on Photographing the Things They Lived With
abstract: An astronaut’s glove. Lou Reed’s glasses. And other objects left behind.
lead_paragraph: Henry Leutwyler shot the cover for the 2013 issue of The Lives They Lived. The issue, subtitled “And the Things They Loved,” also includes Leutwyler’s photographs of objects that belonged to several people who died during the past year.

headline: This Year in Small Business: Highlights From 2013
abstract: Management lessons from Disney U. A restaurant eliminates tipping. How to reduce shipping costs.
lead_paragraph: In July, I wrote a half-time report that compiled links to some of the best stories for small-business owners that I had read so far this year. Here’s an update through the end of December.

headline: Chinese Women ‘Name and Shame’ Companies They Say Discriminate
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Discrimination', 'Gender', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: By lodging formal complaints with local government alleging gender-based discrimination in how many Chinese companies hire, a group of women is drawing attention to a well-known problem largely hidden from public debate.
lead_paragraph: Eight young Chinese women, most of them university students facing a tight job market, have “named and shamed” dozens of Chinese companies they say are illegally specifying that only men can apply for certain positions. They have mailed their complaints to government human resource departments in the cities of Beijing, Guangzhou and Nanjing, and in Yunnan and Henan Provinces.

abstract: No one claimed responsibility for the shooting on Monday but anti-German sentiment has been festering over a harsh austerity plan linked to Greece’s bailout.
lead_paragraph: Assailants raked the German ambassador’s residence in Athens with gunfire early on Monday in an attack that caused no injuries, Greek police officials said.

headline: China Says Local-Level Debt Soars, Stirring Fear
abstract: A report from the National Audit Office says debt rose 12.7% in six months, which is likely to further raise concerns about China’s borrowing.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The total debt of local governments in China has soared to nearly $3 trillion as the country’s addiction to credit-fueled growth has deepened in recent years, according to the findings of a long-awaited report released on Monday by the central auditing agency.

headline: Once an Agitator, Now in Charge of Delhi’s Government
abstract: Though Arvind Kejriwal, and his Aam Aadmi Party were dismissed as political novices, they made a series of astute moves to upend the state assembly.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Saturday morning, Arvind Kejriwal, the leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, took the subway from his house in Ghaziabad, a suburb bordering Delhi, to Barakhamba Road in central Delhi. This was an unusual way to travel for someone about to be inaugurated as the city’s chief minister. But Mr. Kejriwal, the harbinger of a new paradigm in Indian politics, has done much to suggest a flair for the unusual.

lead_paragraph: If you’re anything like the Bagger, you’ve spent the last week in a blissful state of awards-season blackout. Oscar who? Academy what? To return to our rightful place of handicapping the waltz with the little bald man, we thought we’d start off slow, with a little recap.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Laws used to have boring names, like the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Now they bear titles that seem focus-group-tested, like the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

abstract: The Browns’ Rob Chudzinski, the Redskins’ Mike Shanahan, the Vikings’ Leslie Frazier, the Lions’ Jim Schwartz and the Bucs’ Greg Schiano lost their coaching jobs Monday after poor years.
lead_paragraph: Black Monday lived up to its billing this year as five N.F.L. coaches and one general manager were fired in a dramatic, if unsurprising, mass catharsis that left owners across the league ready to reset the clock and shop for replacements.

headline: Seeking a Buyer for a Home Full of Creatures From the Time of Noah
abstract: The Brooklyn building that houses Torah Animal World, a collection of taxidermied animals that represent creatures depicted in the Old Testament, is for sale.
lead_paragraph: The first thing prospective buyers should know about the two-story rowhouse for sale in Borough Park, Brooklyn, is that its glassy-eyed menagerie of taxidermied tenants, from the family of lions to the fluffy-feathered emu, will be removed before the closing.

headline: A Distributor’s Online Pressure and an Actor’s Personal Pressure
abstract: A distributor reacting to an online outcry withdrew Italian posters minimizing Chiwetel Ejiofor’s role in “12 Years a Slave.” Meanwhile Michael B. Jordan says he felt the weight of his own expectations in taking on the lead role in “Fruitvale Station.”
lead_paragraph: Context matters, as Chiwetel Ejiofor can confirm. The star of “12 Years a Slave” was minimized on posters for the Italian version of the drama, which instead prominently featured Brad Pitt and Michael Fassbender. Mr. Pitt is a producer and has a small but pivotal part in the film; Mr. Fassbender, playing a brutal slaveholder, has drawn some acclaim. But neither are the lead, nor have they received the kind of attention that Mr. Ejiofor has for his searing performance. After an outcry online that the advertising was racist, the company that produced the posters withdrew them and apologized.

headline: Bain to Buy Control of Bob’s Discount Furniture
abstract: Bob’s Discount Furniture joins other retail investments by Bain like Michaels Stores and Burlington Stores. Bob Kaufman, pitchman extraordinaire, plans to remain the face of the company.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Bain Capital announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in Bob’s Discount Furniture, the chain of stores known for its low-tech commercials featuring its founder, Bob Kaufman.The company’s management team will continue to own a “significant stake” in the business, according to a news release announcing the deal on Monday.

headline: I Had My DNA Picture Taken, With Varying Results
abstract: A healthy 28-year-old with concerns about diseases in her family had three different companies check her genetic code. The discrepancies in their results were striking.
lead_paragraph: I like to plan ahead; that much I knew about myself before I plunged into exploring my genetic code. I’m a healthy 28-year-old woman, but some nasty diseases run in my family: coronary heart disease, rheumatoid arthritis, Alzheimer’s and breast cancer.

headline: Israel by Foot (and Bike and Sea)
abstract: From January to March 2014, Israel will host five races throughout the country–three marathons, a half-marathon and an Ironman.
lead_paragraph: From January to March 2014, Israel will host five races throughout the country – – three marathons, a half-marathon and an Ironman triathlon.

headline: Cracker Barrel Responds to Activist Investor
abstract: The board of the restaurant chain says it plans to continue business as it is despite a push by Sardar Biglari to put Cracker Barrel on the block.
lead_paragraph: Cracker Barrel won’t be sold to the “entrepreneurial mind” of Sardar Biglari anytime soon.

headline: Second Official to Leave After Health Site Trouble
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Michelle Snyder, who had been named at congressional oversight hearings as the person behind the troubled HealthCare.gov website, is retiring.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The No. 2 official at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, who supervised the troubled rollout of President Obama’s health care law, is retiring, administration officials said Monday.

headline: The Lincolns and the Booths
abstract: For years before John Wilkes Booth assassinated Abraham Lincoln, their families intersected in eerily coincidental ways.
lead_paragraph: Over a year before firing the shot that killed Abraham Lincoln, the assassin John Wilkes Booth began to stalk his victim by worming his way into Lincoln’s social circles. But even as the young actor pressed in, Lincoln’s friends and acquaintances began to cross his path through a series of bizarre, random personal encounters. Fate, it seemed, was stalking the stalker.

headline: Video: Matthew McConaughey on ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’
abstract: At a luncheon for “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Matthew McConaughey discusses his performance in the film.
lead_paragraph: Matthew McConaughey has had a busy awards season. Although his leading role in the drama “Dallas Buyer’s Club” is garnering most of the Oscar attention, the small part he has in Martin Scorsese’s “Wolf of Wall Street” also has critics talking (and humming). As a stock trader who teaches a few tricks of the trade to his new employee Jordan Belfort, Mr. McConaughey delivers his dialogue with a sharp tongue and a greedy spirit. In this video, from a recent luncheon for the film, he spoke about that scene and, in particular, the chest-thumping song that he hums in it.

headline: Game Theory: The Last of Us, Revisited
abstract: A designer for the studio Naughty Dog offers a perspective on women as video game characters and as part of the industry.
lead_paragraph: Chris Suellentrop reviewed The Last of Us, a post-apocalyptic video game drama from the studio Naughty Dog, for The New York Times in June. After that, a member of the team that made the game wrote a rebuttal letter. Below is a condensed and edited version of that essay. A little working knowledge of the game — including familiarity with characters like Ellie, David and Joel — is helpful for following along.

headline: Second Deadly Blast Hits Russia
abstract: Scenes from Volgograd, where an explosion on a trolley bus killed at least 15 people on Monday. The attack came a day after a suicide bombing at the city’s main railroad station.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Volgograd, where an explosion on a trolley bus killed at least 15 people on Monday. The attack came a day after a suicide bombing at the city’s main railroad station.

headline: Springsteen Album Leaked Through Amazon Download
abstract: Bruce Springsteen’s new album, “High Hopes,” is due for release on Jan. 14, but was temporarily made available for download on Saturday by Amazon.com.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen’s new album, “High Hopes,” made a brief appearance in MP3 form in the music download section of Amazon.com on Saturday, just over two weeks before its scheduled release date. Although the album could not be purchased and downloaded as a whole, all 12 of its songs could be purchased individually, Billboard reported. Except in the case of the title track, which has been available since Nov. 25, the loophole was closed quickly, but the album appeared on several file-sharing sites within hours.

headline: 3-Bean Good Luck Salad With Cumin Vinaigrette
abstract: A colorful version of a good luck black-eyed peas salad.
lead_paragraph: This is a colorful variation of the black-eyed peas salad I always serve at my New Year’s Day open house. You can cook the black beans and red beans together or separately. The black-eyed peas cook more quickly so should be cooked separately.

headline: Australia Plans Evacuation of Passengers Stranded in Ice
keywords: ['Aurora Australis', 'Ice', 'Rescues', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Passengers and some crew members aboard a research ship that has been stuck in thick Antarctic ice for nearly a week will be evacuated by helicopter.
lead_paragraph: Maritime safety officials began preparations on Tuesday for a helicopter rescue of scientists and others aboard a chartered research ship that has been stuck in Antarctic ice for a week.

headline: Farro and Swiss Chard Salad With Grapefruit Vinaigrette
abstract: A hearty salad with great texture and a citrus finish.
lead_paragraph: A farmer at my market recently was selling huge, sturdy bunches of Swiss chard, the kind I used to cook with in France, with wide ribs and heavy leaves. One bunch weighed almost 2 pounds; the leaves alone, off the stems, weighed in at about 13 ounces. I used the greens for more than one dish, including this substantial salad, to which I also added diced sautéed chard ribs.

headline: Lentil and Carrot Salad With Middle Eastern Spices
abstract: A combination of Mediterranean lentil salads that works well for buffets.
lead_paragraph: I combined two of my favorite Mediterranean salads to stretch the cup of lentils I had in my pantry. Take care not to overcook the lentils; they should be slightly al dente. They go quickly from al dente to mushy, so make sure to check after 25 minutes.

headline: Israeli Couscous and Spicy Herb Paste Frittata
abstract: A frittata is the perfect home for some leftover couscous.
lead_paragraph: In Italy leftover pasta is often recycled into a frittata. I decided to do the same with some Israeli couscous that I had tossed with a spicy Yemeni herb and chili paste called zhoug that I found in Yotam Ottolenghi’s book “Jerusalem.” I liked the couscous with the chili paste better in this pretty frittata than I did on its own. You won’t use up all of the zhoug in the frittata but you will be glad to have the relish on hand to use as a condiment. Note that I do not cook my Israeli couscous in boiling water; I find that it becomes too mushy that way.

headline: Andrew Luck’s Monster Problem
abstract: Can you help Indianapolis Colts quarterback Andrew Luck solve this monster problem?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Andrew Luck, the record-setting quarterback of the Indianapolis Colts. Mr. Luck was the N.F.L.’s number one draft pick in 2012 and led a remarkable turnaround of his team during his first year, taking it from 2-14 in 2011 to 11-5 in 2012. This year the Colts continue to thrive under Luck’s leadership, finishing the regular season atop their division with an 11-5 record.

headline: Volvo Recalls 31,000 Cars for Oil Pressure Sensor Problem
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: When a mechanic forgot to put oil in a Volvo S60, the oil pressure warning light never came on, alerting Volvo to a problem with the sensors.
lead_paragraph: Volvo will recall nearly 31,000 S60 sedans with 5-cylinder engines from the 2011 and 2012 model years because of a problem with the oil pressure warning sensors. The automaker discovered the defect after a mechanic performing routine maintenance on one of the cars forgot to put oil in the engine before the owner drove it off.

headline: Regulators Have New Cases of Frauds and Abuses to Tackle
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Insider Trading', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The new year will likely bring novel crackdowns of financial crimes, particularly with insider trading cases, crowdfunding frauds and settlements involving interest-rate manipulation, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Goodbye 2013 frauds; welcome 2014 abuses.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Formula One Champion Michael Schumacher Hospitalized After Skiing Accident
abstract: Schumacher is in a coma after hitting his head skiing; IndyCar announces that it is suing the company that promoted a 2013 series event in São Paulo, Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Michael Schumacher, the seven-time Formula One world champion who retired for the second time in 2012, underwent emergency surgery for brain trauma Sunday after a skiing accident in the French Alps. His manager, Sabine Kehm, said that he was skiing with his son on backcountry terrain near the Méribel ski resort when he fell and hit his head on a rock.

headline: Powerlessness and Pretense
abstract: Since the early days of the Soviet Union, state officials have cared more about reporting good results than achieving them.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Within two hours of a deadly bombing Sunday at the main railroad station in Volgograd, officials announced that they had identified the female suicide bomber. A name, a photo and a biography spread from news agency to news agency; law enforcement supplied journalists with details, including the tidbit that she had been married to two different Chechen rebel fighters, both now dead.

headline: On the Porch in ‘Osage County’
abstract: The preparation for filming “August: Osage County” included a powerful book of back stories for each character.
lead_paragraph: The Weinstein Company gambled that opening its dark family dramedy “August: Osage County” two days after Christmas, instead of on Christmas (when everyone has enough dark family dramedy to contend with), would pay off at the box office. In five theaters, its take ranked with this season’s other dysfunctional family stories, like “Nebraska,” but may not have had the surge the studio was hoping for.

headline: De Blasio Recognizes Obstacles Standing in Way of Schools Plan
abstract: While announcing his choice of Carmen Fariña as the next chancellor of New York City schools, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio acknowledged that his agenda could face hurdles.
lead_paragraph: As he announced his choice of Carmen Fariña as the next chancellor of New York City schools, Bill de Blasio suggested on Monday that he would depart drastically from the policies of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. He pledged to reduce the emphasis on standardized testing in classrooms, and he said he would end, at least for now, the practice of closing low-performing schools.

headline: No Meeting With Leader of Japan, Chinese Say
abstract: China’s Foreign Ministry said Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s visit to the Yasukuni Shrine was tantamount to honoring “fascists” and “the Nazis of Asia.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s Foreign Ministry said Monday that Chinese leaders, angered over a visit last week by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to a contentious war shrine in Tokyo, would not meet with Mr. Abe.

headline: Celebrity Cancer Diagnosis Spurs Smokers to Try to Quit
abstract: Researchers have found that a diagnosis of cancer in a high-profile person sharply increases efforts to quit smoking.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that a diagnosis of cancer in a high-profile person sharply increases efforts to quit smoking.

headline: Painting Bought at Antique Shop for  £400 Is Found to Be a Van Dyck
abstract: A British priest on the show “Antiques Roadshow” learned that a painting he’d bought for about $575 was worth about $660,000.
lead_paragraph: Father Jamie McLeod, a priest who runs a religious retreat in rural Derbyshire, England, became curious about the value of a painting he had bought at an antique shop in Cheshire about a dozen years ago, and brought it to the experts on the British version of the television program “Antiques Roadshow.”

headline: New York Stays Ahead of Florida in Population
abstract: New census figures cut the margin to fewer than 100,000 people, but California and Texas continued to be the most populous states.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — New York’s hold on its status as the country’s third most populous state is down to fewer than 100,000 people, according to figures released on Monday by the Census Bureau. And the trend is not in the state’s favor, as Florida, which is No. 4, gained residents at three times the pace of the Empire State over a year’s span.

Food from the fields of Ge Songqing and her neighbors ends up in their kitchens or in the local market, and from there goes to other provinces. abstract: Six institutions were chosen to explore how to set safety standards for commercial and private drones, train and certify their ground-based pilots, ensure that the aircraft will operate safely and avoid collisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Aviation Administration will authorize test sites for drone aircraft in upstate New York, New Jersey and at least eight other states, the agency said on Monday, preparing for a time when unmanned aircraft of various shapes and sizes cruise over the landscape.

headline: A Quiet Summer in Cooperstown
abstract: Voters for the Baseball Hall of Fame in January emphatically rejected the candidacies of players from the steroids era like Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens and Sammy Sosa.
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable that the steroids era would intrude on the business of the Baseball Hall of Fame. Mark McGwire had been rejected six times by the Baseball Writers’ Association of America when Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens and Sammy Sosa missed out for the first time last January. In his seventh rejection, McGwire received 16.9 percent of the vote, less than half of Bonds’s 36.2 percent and far short of the 75 percent required for election.

headline: Bankers Beaten Back A Bit
abstract: So you can be too cynical.
lead_paragraph: Mike Konczal has some surprising news: Financial reform is getting somewhere. We entered 2013 amid universal cynicism; the bankers had bought Washington again, and any reforms would be purely cosmetic. We leave it with significant progress. You can still argue that reform falls far short of what should have happened, and won’t do much to prevent future crises. But relative to expectations, this is a happy story.

headline: Obamacare Not A Total Disaster, Continued
abstract: Two million here, four million there, and soon you’re talking about real effects.
lead_paragraph: Perceptions about health reform are in an interesting place. Just about everyone on the right is still living in October, the annus horribilis of Obamacare (yes, I know it was just a month, and I don’t care), and is waiting to move in for the kill after the whole thing collapses. Meanwhile, a funny thing has been happening: enrollments surged this month, to such an extent that the original expectation of 7 million people signed up via the exchanges by the end of March no longer looks crazy.

headline: The Starting Lineup: As Othello, a 6-Foot-3 Running Back, No. 27, Eddie George
abstract: Eddie George, who retired from the NFL in 2005, is playing the title role in the Nashville Shakespeare Festival’s production of “Othello.”
lead_paragraph: When Eddie George retired from football in 2005, after nine years as an N.F.L. running back, he was 32 years old and had racked up some enviable statistics: 130 consecutive regular-season game starts, 10,441 rushing yards and 68 touchdowns, along with the Heisman Trophy he won at Ohio State University in 1995. Since then, he has started a string of businesses, including fitness programs and a landscape architecture company, opened a sports-themed restaurant and been a motivational speaker.

abstract: This year’s financial news had some important themes, but it is up to the individual investor to decide whether to act on them.

This year, there were a lot of catchy headlines in the financial news, and most of them represented little more than noise. There were, however, a few important themes in 2013 that may affect your financial plan as we head into 2014.

headline: Spared Winter Freeze, Florida’s Mangroves Are Marching North

That finding is the latest indication that global warming, though still in its early stages, is already leading to ecological changes so large they can be seen from space.

A comparison of animals from West African populations with some from Central Africa suggests that the groups are distinct species that diverged about seven million years ago. The results, published in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, may have implications for conservation efforts.

headline: Cocktail Culture | A Bubbly Twist on the Negroni
abstract: This version of the classic Italian drink substitutes dry sparkling wine for gin, which makes for a lighter libation that’s easier to drink and is perfect for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: When a bartender at Bar Basso in Milan mistakenly grabbed a bottle of spumante instead of gin while making a Negroni (comprised of the holy trinity of the cocktail world: Campari, Italian vermouth and gin), he inadvertently created a simple, endlessly drinkable twist on a classic: the Negroni Sbagliato (“sbagliato” is Italian for “mistaken”). By substituting effervescent wine for the piney, citrusy sweetness of gin, he’d somehow stripped the Negroni down to its essence. Sbagliatos retain that pleasing chalkiness and minerality of Campari and the herby qualities of vermouth, but these flavors stretch out across the bubbles and somehow lead one to drink more slowly, savoring the medley. Unlike Negronis, which are all booze but taste like adult candy, Sbagliatos are less likely to put one’s party-appropriate sobriety at risk. But if they do wind up going down a little too quickly, rest easy — the Sbagliato is significantly lower in alcohol by volume than its brawnier big brother, a key consideration in the holiday marathon drinking season.

headline: China: Police Kill 8 Assailants in a Clash in Xinjiang

lead_paragraph: Security officers on Monday killed eight attackers and detained one person as the police repelled an assault on a police station in the western region of Xinjiang, government officials said. A report on Tianshan News, the official news website of Xinjiang, said nine people armed with knives had attacked a police station in Shache County, near Kashgar. The attackers also threw explosive devices and set police cars on fire, the report said. It provided no further details. Violence between civilians and security forces has become increasingly common in Xinjiang, where officials say they are trying to deal with rebels or terrorists who live in towns heavily populated by ethnic Uighurs. But Uighurs in the area and some scholars in Beijing and abroad say the Chinese government exaggerates the terrorist threat and is instead mostly deploying security forces to maintain tight control over people who feel oppressed by the ethnic Han authorities.

headline: Thinking Outside the (Big) Box

lead_paragraph: When my wife and I first visited the supersize Ikea in Red Hook, Brooklyn, in 2008, we didn’t take time to stop for the lingonberry jam or meatballs. Soon after we walked in, we just wanted to leave. We realized that the place was a crowded, labyrinthine mess lacking the adequate amount of staff to help us chose between the Ekby Hensvik and the Ekby Bjarnum. We left angry and exhausted, and we swore — for the sake of our marriage — never to return. Ikea, I thought, was just like Walmart or countless other big-box retailers that seemed to have embraced a Faustian bargain with their customers. The chains would sell absurdly inexpensive stuff — like a Lovbacken coffee table for $60 — but as a consequence, customers would have to put up with huge stores manned by small, often unhappy and unhelpful staffs.

headline: The Top 10 Top 10 Lists of 2013
abstract: It’s that joyous time of year again where we take a look at the people who are reinvigorating the Top-10 form.
lead_paragraph: It’s that joyous time of year again: end-of-year list season! Two years ago I sang the praises of listmaking in the magazine, discussing the fun of “creating, in 10 increments, the person you want to be.” As 2013 comes to a close, it’s a wonderful chance to look back on a year of listmaking. Which critics are working at the peak of the Top 10 form? Who is reinvigorating the tropes of the best list, finding new ways to tell old stories? Let’s take a look at the Top 10 Top 10 Lists of 2013.

headline: An Auspicious New Year’s Day Buffet
abstract: This year, as I always do on New Year’s Day, I will host an open house and serve my beloved black-eyed peas salad, along with other Recipes for Health designed to stand up when left out on a buffet for several hours.
lead_paragraph: This year, as I always do on New Year’s Day, I will host an open house and serve my beloved black-eyed peas salad. But I had also found half-bags of various grains and beans in my pantry and wanted to use them up, so I decided to work them into a few other dishes for my buffet, mostly salads that will hold for a few hours. Most of these staples are foods that are considered symbolic of good luck and expanding fortunes in the New Year by different cultures. For example Italians eat lentils at the New Year because they resemble coins and expand when cooked. I will double my money by combining lentils with coinlike carrot slices in a delicious Middle Eastern salad. I use lots of greens and herbs in my salads as well; green leaves also symbolize money and growth.

headline: Does Philanthropic Peer Pressure or Morality Matter More?
abstract: Why do we continue to live relatively decadently when the money we spend on organic dishwasher detergent could save lives? My daughter says we’re selfish. My son says we do enough.
lead_paragraph: Do you know the philosopher Peter Singer’s thought exercise about charitable giving? It’s this: Imagine you’re on your way to work, but you see a child who has fallen into a pond and appears to be drowning. The idea of ruining your shoes or suit — or even, say, your brand-new Christmas iPhone — would not keep you from rescuing that child. You would, in fact, do it again the next day. So, why don’t we? What is keeping us from giving more to ill and malnourished children around the world, whose lives could be saved by the cost of a pair of shoes?

The glittering ball mounted under the arch of black satin is fun and festive for ringing in 2014, a tiny ode to the Times Square ball drop. headline: Mixed Results for WNET Membership Drive
abstract: The public television station’s 18-month campaign to add new members surpassed its target, but in the end the new donors ended up replacing lapsed memberships.
lead_paragraph: WNET, the New York City public television station, this week ended its 18-month campaign to encourage new donors and the mixed results are in. The drive added 52,800 new members, above the target of 50,000. The catch, however, is that the total ended up right back where it started, at about 180,000 members over all, since the new donors replaced those who let their membership lapse.

headline: The Grand Old Primate Party?
abstract: Only 43 percent of Republicans accept Darwin’s findings.
lead_paragraph: A Pew survey released yesterday on the public’s view of evolution shows Republicans growing more skeptical of Darwin’s findings, with only 43 percent now endorsing the theory — a drop of 11 points since 2009. Most Democrats are steady believers, with 67 percent in favor, a rise of three points. What all this means for social issue politicking in the new year remains to be seen. But the net effect is a remarkable 24-point evolution credibility gap between the two parties, more than double the 10-point gap of four years earlier.

headline: Out of the Shower, Onto the Runway

abstract: Locker-room footwear becomes street-worthy; Electric Nest is an eclectic new boutique in Williamsburg; Pret-à-Surf teams up with Thakoon Panichgul on bikinis and crop tops turn up in the winter, too.
lead_paragraph: Yes, 2013 was the year that Adidas shower slides became an acceptable form of fashion footwear. The onetime locker-room essential was taken up by cool kids on the street, was adopted by the singer Grimes, and even invaded Fashion Week, on Alexander Wang’s niece, who proved a most stylish street-style star when she wore a Nike version to her uncle’s show. Designers quickly took note, offering a slew of interpretations for 2014. These rubber Chloés from the resort collection, now on pre-order at a whopping $840, are said to be selling out fast. For styling, take a cue from the Joseph spring show (above), where slides were shown with sporty-sleek trousers, relaxed blazers and anoraks.

headline: The Law That Saved the Bald Eagle
abstract: The Endangered Species Act turns 40.
lead_paragraph: In this season of birthdays and holidays, on Saturday the environmental community rightly celebrated the 40th anniversary of the passage of one of the most ambitious of the Nixon era’s landmark environmental statutes: the Endangered Species Act. The act is at once the noblest of those statutes — aimed, in President Nixon’s words, at protecting “an irreplaceable part of our natural heritage — threatened wildlife”; and also the most controversial, detested by loggers, developers and other interests for elevating the needs of nature over the needs of commerce. Approved by huge margins in both chambers (the vote on the House was an astounding 355-4), the act would stand zero chance of passage in today’s poisoned political climate.
